HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The End of Pretending

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
In one bloody moment the hypocritical facade of President Clinton's empty policy on Bosnia crumbled. The mortar shell that killed 68 people as they shopped in Sarajevo's market Saturday brought an end to the pretense that America had a meaningful policy.
Mr. Clinton inherited a Bosnian horror from European appeasers and President Bush. After a weak show of wanting to act he essentially withdrew from the problem, hoping Americans would forget it. 
 From the lowest echelon of the State Department to near the highest, no one believed in the non-policy. How far the rot of official cynicism had gone was shown in a report given at the National War College last month by Richard Johnson, a department officer who formerly headed its Yugoslav desk. He titled the paper "The Pin-Stripe Approach to Genocide."
"Senior policy-makers have failed to level with the American people on the nature of the moral and security" challenges we face in the Balkans, Mr. Johnson said. He said officials had deliberately played down evidence that Serbian "ethnic cleansing" of Muslims in Bosnia amounted in law to genocide.
At a lunch last year, Mr. Johnson wrote, Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff said that he saw the moral issue in Bosnia but that a failed U.S. intervention "would destroy the American Presidency." Timothy Wirth, the department's counselor, said he agreed that the moral stakes were high but there were "even higher moral stakes at play: 'The survival of the fragile liberal coalition represented by this Presidency.' "
In short, officials knew what was right but did not have the courage to do it. Or more precisely, President Clinton did not. He gave the orders.
The political calculation in Washington, as in London and Paris, was that the Bosnian victims of aggression would eventually accept the division of their country, with most of it going to the Serbs and Croats. But the victims refused to go along. The mostly Muslim army of Bosnia fought on against the odds, and grew stronger.
France asked the Clinton Administration to join in pressing the Bosnian Government to give up and sign its dismemberment warrant. That was one thing the Administration would not do.
The Administration air-dropped food to the besieged Bosnian enclaves, but it did nothing to stop the aggression and genocide. The President's men said the situation was too complicated to intervene. In fact, it has become simpler. The necessary steps are plain.
1. The growing strength of the Bosnian Army means that no ground troops are needed from outside. What is needed is what President Clinton proposed and then abandoned: NATO air strikes against the aggressors and an end to the arms embargo on Bosnia.
2. The slaughter in the Sarajevo market underlines what should be the first air targets: the Serbian gun positions in the hills around Sarajevo and other Bosnian enclaves.
3. Planes should also be used to interdict the main-force Serbian and Croatian Army units now moving into Bosnia. That means taking out the Drina River bridges that link Serbia and Bosnia, and attacking the Croatian entry routes.
4. The United States has repeatedly warned President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia to keep his hands off Bosnia. It is time now to make Croatia pay a price, economic and political, for ignoring that warning.
The United Nations is seemingly prevented from acting effectively by its own bureaucracy and Russia's veto in the Security Council. Others must move.
NATO has the force. Lawyers have shown persuasively that the U.N. arms embargo is legally nonexistent. All that is required is leadership. That can come from only one man: President Clinton. If he leads, Europe will follow -- and so, I am convinced, will the American people.
On CNN last week Mr. Clinton's national security assistant, Anthony Lake, boasted that "Serb violence around Sarajevo has declined" since the NATO summit last month made another empty bombing threat.
Tell that to the parents of the six little girls killed by Serbian shells as they played in Sarajevo on Jan. 22. Or to the families of the 10 people killed by Serbian shells Feb. 4, or of the 68 on Feb. 5. They want action, not pretense. So should we.

HEADLINE: Accord Is Reported on Japanese Tax-Cut Package

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 8

 BODY:
The Government reportedly ended a week of turmoil this morning by agreeing on a $135 billion plan of temporary tax cuts and public works spending to revive the recession-bound economy and to satisfy one of the Clinton Administration's key demands in trade talks.
The battle over the economic plan has left the coalition Government badly divided, and today's deal, which has not yet been annnounced officially, is filled with compromises that might reduce its effectiveness. For instance, what had been proposed as a permanent reduction in income taxes will now be a one-year, $55 billion reduction because of a continuing dispute over how the Government will make up for the loss in revenues. 
 But the plan, which also includes large increases in public works spending and low-cost loans for businesses, will still be the largest economic stimulus plan Japan has ever initiated. It is intended to jolt the country out of its worst recession since World War II and, by quickening economic growth, pull in more imports and reduce Japan's yawning trade surplus.
The awkward agreement comes just two days before Prime Minister Hosokawa is scheduled to depart for Washington, where he will hold a critical summit meeting with President Clinton. The principal purpose of the trip is to review progress in a series of trade talks Japan and the United States agreed upon last summer.
In addition to demanding that Japan open a number of markets to more foreign-made goods, the Clinton Administration has also insisted that Japan take measures to reinvigorate the economy. With the talks in several of the sectors failing to make much headway, it had been hoped that the economic stimulus package would be the one clear area of concord between the two leaders.
The problem has been the question of how to pay for the tax cuts. Mr. Hosokawa had sided earlier with the conservatives in his Government, and in the Finance Ministry, by arguing that the Government would have to increase the national sales tax after a delay of three years. Their aim was to avoid long-running budget deficits.
Mr. Hosokawa had proposed increasing the sales tax, which has been highly unpopular since it was introduced five years ago, to 7 percent from 3 percent. That would have actually raised more revenues than the income tax reduction would have cost the Government.
The Socialists, the largest party in the coalition, had threatened to withdraw from the Cabinet and possibly bring down the Government if Mr. Hosokawa stuck by this proposal. The Socialists argued that the tax increase would fall most heavily on lower income workers.
Mr. Hosokawa was forced into the humiliating position of withdrawing his initial proposal a day after he presented it last week, but he still insisted the sales tax increase was needed.
That led to a political crisis that lasted throughout the weekend that jeopardized his meeting with President Clinton. If the trip goes badly, political analysts have said, it would take an enormous toll on Mr. Hosokawa's already shaky governing coalition.

HEADLINE: Hearing Opens Into Accusations of Fraud in Pennsylvania Election

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7

 BODY:
A Federal judge began a hearing today on accusations of voter fraud in a State Senate race, a case the national Republican Party has called an "egregious voter fraud targeted at minority voters."
Judge Clarence C. Newcomer of Federal District Court decided to hear the case, brought by the Pennsylvania Republican Party, after state election officials and state courts rejected the Republicans' claims. 
 The dispute involves a special election last November to fill a state Senate seat in north Philadelphia made vacant by a Democratic senator's death. It was a crucial election because the party winning the seat could also gain control of the State Senate. Before the death it had 25 Democrats and 25 Republicans, and the deciding vote was held by the Lieutenant Governor, a Democrat.
The Republican candidate, Bruce S. Marks, a 36-year-old Philadelphia lawyer and former aide to United States Senator Arlen Specter, won 564 more votes at voting booths than his Democratic opponent. But the Democrat, William G. Stinson, a 49-year-old former assistant deputy mayor of Philadelphia, won the election by 461 votes after he obtained 80 percent of the 1,757 absentee ballots cast.
 
Quick Action by Democrats
 Before the polls closed, Mr. Marks had protested, contending that there had been widespread forgery and other abuse of absentee ballots in many parts of the district, which spans white, black and Hispanic neighborhoods.
Mr. Marks maintained that as many as 800 absentee ballots had been illegally cast for Mr. Stinson. He said they included ballots forged on behalf of Hispanic residents who had been misled, or people living permanently in Puerto Rico or serving time in prison. In one instance, the Republicans said, a dead person was listed as casting a ballot.
The Philadelphia Inquirer has identified about 330 absentee ballots that appear to have violated state election law.
But on Nov. 19, without considering the merits of the case, the Board of Elections here dismissed Mr. Marks's objections, citing procedural and jurisdictional flaws. Just minutes after the board, which has a Democratic majority, unanimously declared Mr. Stinson the winner, Senate Democratic leaders in Harrisburg administered the oath of office to him.
The Democrats' swift action complicated legal efforts by Republicans to challenge the election, and a half-dozen state courts, including the State Supreme Court, have dismissed Mr. Marks's case without considering its merits.
Mr. Marks maintained that he did not get a fair hearing because most judges and election commissioners in Pennsylvania were elected Democrats.
After finding no relief in state courts, he turned to the Federal courts.
Judge Newcomer, who was appointed by President Richard M. Nixon, took the unusual step of hearing the case even though state appeals were pending. The hearing is expected to last a week to two weeks.
In court today, Paul Rosen, a lawyer for the State Republican Committee, read a script that Democratic campaign workers used when telephoning Spanish-speaking voters. One question on the script, translated into English, says: "Do you know that you can elect your candidate without having to go to your voting place?" Campaign workers also delivered absentee applications and ballots, and the Democratic campaign paid the volunteer workers $1 for each completed form, according to testimony given today.
The Democrats have acknowledged that they put a major emphasis on collecting absentee ballots in the race. Even though they outnumber Republicans in the district, Democrats have had a harder time getting out the vote, particularly in predominantly black and Hispanic neighborhoods.
 
Telling of Legal Worries
 A Democratic campaign worker, William J. Jones, testified today that Democratic workers tried to make voting more convenient by encouraging people to use absentee ballots illegally. By state law, voters may vote by absentee ballots only if they are physically unable to go to the polls or are planning to be out of the county on Election Day.
Mr. Jones, an unemployed bank loan officer who worked as a volunteer for the Stinson campaign for about 10 weeks last summer, testified that he oversaw the processing of absentee ballot applications and ballots. He said that he had complained directly to Mr. Stinson last summer that campaign workers were violating the law by collecting absentee ballots from ineligible voters.
"If people didn't have a reason to vote absentee, they were told, 'Just say you'll be out of the county, and we'll mark the application "out of county," ' " Mr. Jones testified.
He also testified that he told Mr. Stinson on more than one occasion that a lot of ballots he handled "seemed phony." Mr. Jones said he quit the campaign because he was worried about breaking the law and denied that it was because he was not being paid, as lawyers for the Stinson campaign suggested today.
Mr. Stinson did not appear in court today. He has denied knowing of any illegal activities that may have been done on his behalf.
Ernest D. Preate Jr., a Republican who is the Attorney General of Pennsylvania, and the United States Justice Department began independent investigations into accusations of voter fraud last November. But both are focusing on accusations of criminal activities and not whether the election should be overturned.
In court today, Lillian Cruz, a 33-year-old resident of the district, testified that a Stinson campaign worker, Ramon Pratt, "told me this was a new law, a new way to vote." She added, "To tell you the truth, I don't even know who I voted for because he pointed out to me where I should make the X."
Mr. Pratt was identified by several witnesses as the man who went door-to-door soliciting absentee ballots last summer. Mr. Pratt took the stand, but said that on the advice of his lawyer, he would not answer any questions.

HEADLINE: Prospects Dim for U.S.-Japan Accord

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Just days before Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa is to meet President Clinton in Washington, prospects for meaningful new trade agreements seem to have grown dimmer.
But in one potentially hopeful sign, Mr. Hosokawa's cabinet reportedly agreed this morning on a plan to stimulate Japan's sputtering economy by increasing public works spending and reducing some taxes. That is something the United States has been pressing for. 
 The deadlock is in the talks over opening Japan's markets for automobiles, insurance and other sectors. The question is whether the agreements will include numerical goals for increasing access to Japan's market. At a news conference here on Friday, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said that Tsutomu Hata, Japan's Foreign Minister, had "neither accepted nor rejected" the American view about numerical goals.
 
 
Avoiding an Argument
 The Japanese, however, told Mr. Kantor last week that Japan would not accept targets and that it was time for Washington to modify its approach. If Mr. Hata did not speak up, they said, it was only to avoid an argument.
Leaving Tokyo on Friday after three days of high-level talks, Mr. Kantor warned that if no agreements were reached before the meeting, Washington might resort to "other options," an allusion to sanctions.
Still, both nations have a strong incentive to avoid injuring their relationship if the meeting does not go smoothly. In the past, seemingly hopeless negotiations have been rescued in a series of last-minute all- night sessions that produce a fuzzily worded document that both sides declare a victory. In this case as well, there seems to be some room for such a compromise.
There has also been some movement on more detailed issues, so that if the key question regarding targets is resolved, the rest of the negotiations can be concluded. Japan on Friday announced a new plan to change Government buying of equipment like computers. And the two nations have agreed to cooperate in areas like advanced transportation systems and AIDS research and prevention.
Mr. Kantor came here as President Clinton's special emissary to urge Japan's top politicians to take an interest in the trade negotiations and not leave everything to bureaucrats, who have less room to be flexible. At his news conference on Friday, Mr. Kantor said "a new structure has been set up at the political level" to conduct the negotiations, with Mr. Hata taking charge for Japan.
 
Reasons to Stand Firm
 On the issue of numerical targets, the United States has reasons to stand firm. History has shown that Japan has caved in under American pressure rather than face sanctions or hurt relations with its main ally and trading partner. This time Japan faces an additional threat: If there is no agreement, the yen is likely to rise again, choking the nation's automobile and electronics exports.
Moreover, while Japan now professes an ideological abhorrence to "managed trade," it has agreed on previous occasions, like the semiconductor negotiations, to goals, though not guarantees.
Japan says it will not do so again because the United States misinterprets such goals as commitments and punishes Japan when they are not met. This explanation suggests that Japan's objection is more to punishment than to goals themselves. It might agree to goals if there were some assurances that Washington would not resort to sanctions.
For its part, Japan also believes the United States will yield. Japanese officials say that many officials in the Clinton Administration, although they cannot speak out publicly, do not believe in targets. The President, they point out, said in a speech here in July that the United States is not seeking "so-called trade by the numbers." They also think Washington can be persuaded to trust Prime Minister Hosokawa, who has pledged to deregulate the economy.
One senior Japanese official said his Government was not worried that failure to agree to numerical goals would rupture bilateral relations. "The U.S-Japan relationship is not that fragile that it would collapse over that single problem," he said.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: THE MILITARY;
Proposal Cuts Back on Some Weapons to Spend More on Personnel

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
President Clinton's military budget for the 1995 fiscal year puts Pentagon spending in a holding pattern, canceling some weapons to finance better training and higher pay for military personnel.
Military spending would rise $2.8 billion in the coming fiscal year under the Clinton plan. Taking inflation into account, that represents a decline of slightly less than 1 percent from the budget for the current fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30. The Administration plans a 5.9 percent cut for the 1996 fiscal year. 
 The $263.7 billion proposal submitted today has something for almost everyone to dislike. Some members of Congress want to cut more weapons programs to pay for social needs. Others fear the advent of a military unable to fight two major wars at once, a benchmark for Pentagon planners. A third faction sees the Pentagon's budget not only as the bulwark of military preparedness but also as a jobs supplier, from soldiering to shipbuilding to software manufacturing.
That is one reason that a huge peace dividend anticipated by many at the end of the cold war has not materialized. Instead, small reductions in spending have been achieved incrementally by cutting troop strength and dropping plans for a few major weapons.
The overall budget for buying new weapons is cut by $1.4 billion in the new proposal, compared with an $8.1 billion reduction in the procurement budget in the current fiscal year from the previous one. In the context of Pentagon spending, a cut of $1.4 billion represents little more than 0.5 percent of overall annual military spending.
Gone from the budget, for example, is money to build more F-16 fighter planes, long a mainstay of the American arsenal. The Administration would also cancel two fighter aircraft still on the drawing board: the Navy's A/F-X and the Air Force's multirole fighter.
Still in the works are multibillion-dollar proposals to build a new "stealth" fighter for the Air Force, a new attack helicopter for the Army, a new attack submarine and a new carrier for the Navy and the new Milstar satellite system for global communications in wartime. All have been attacked by Congressional critics as vestiges of the cold war.
 
A $22-a-Month Raise
 The proposed military budget for the coming fiscal year rose in large part because Congress ordered a 1.6 percent pay increase for every member of the shrinking military. For example, an Army sergeant with six years of experience, who now makes $1,401 a month, would get a raise of $22 a month under the Pentagon plan.
The number of active-duty troops would fall by 85,500, to 1.52 million, in the coming fiscal year. The Administration would also spend $2.8 billion to close bases as required by Congress and $5.7 billion to clean up environmental damage at military installations.
 
To Have or Have Not
 The budget battle in Congress will be waged between those who believe that the Pentagon can withstand a leaner budget, as does Representative Ronald V. Dellums, the California Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Committee, and those who believe that the Pentagon may already have sacrificed enough, as does Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee.
A spokesman for Senator Nunn said he would withhold comment today on the President's budget. In the past year, Mr. Nunn has defended the Pentagon against spending cuts.
Mr. Dellums said that the main questions to be answered in the budget debate are: "Do we need the forces to fight and win two wars simultaneously on two fronts? Is that more a political statement than a military reality?"
"There can still be a peace dividend," Mr. Dellums said. "The question is whether we have the political will to do it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
John Sculley quit as chairman of Spectrum Information Technologies, suing the president of the Long Island company for fraud. Mr. Sculley contended that he was deceived by the company's management about accounting practices and an S.E.C. investigation. The move comes three and a half months after Mr. Sculley left his job as chairman of Apple Computer. [Page A1.] 
 Encyclopedia Britannica will offer electronic distribution of its materials to universities and public libraries via the Internet. [D1.]
T<2> Medical will merge with three smaller companies, creating the nation's second-largest home health-care concern. [D4.]
The ouster of the head of Volkswagen's Audi unit has brought a spate of finger pointing at Volkswagen's chairman. [D4.]
The New York Post will invest millions in press equipment to produce a full-color paper, its new publisher said. [B3.]
The Canadian media company Maclean Hunter removed one obstacle to a takeover bid by Rogers Communications. [D4.]
For the car that has everything, Sony and Etak introduced a computerized navigation system complete with maps. [D5.]
Prudential Insurance executives pressured auditors to inflate the estimated values of real estate held in the company's institutional funds, a report supporting a lawsuit asserts. [D5.]
A typo in an ad for a CD player at the Bon Marche chain caused a near-stampede at some of the retailer's stores. [D5.]
The teamsters' union settled with United Parcel Service, after a one-day strike disrupted some of the company's service. [A16.]
 
Markets
Wall Street forged ahead in a frenzy of buying, with apprehensions easing, at least for now, that last week's Fed decision to nudge up short-term interest rates would end the three-year bull market. The Dow industrial average rose 34.90 points, erasing part of Friday's 96.24-point plunge. [D1.] In Europe, share prices dropped sharply in response to Friday's selloff on Wall Street. [D8.]
Treasury prices fell slightly, aided by a slide in commodity prices and good investor demand at the Treasury auctions. But traders remained jittery after Friday's increase in rates. [D18.]
Standard & Poor's raised its ratings outlook for New York State's general-obligation bonds. [B2.]
Precious metal prices were pounded by profit taking as investment funds bailed out of the market. [D16.]
The dollar ended mixed after surging on Friday. [D16.]
 
The Economy
President Clinton sent Congress a $1.52 trillion budget, with spending cuts and modest new initiatives. [B8.]
 
International
Berlin is experiencing a building boom, as the sound of jackhammers and buzz saws pulsate along the main streets. [D1.]
Japan's ruling coalition announced a tax-cut agreement. [A8.] Prospects for new trade agreements seem dim, just days before Prime Minister Hosokawa is to meet President Clinton. [D2.]

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: ANTI-DRUG EFFORT;
President Plans to Raise Drug Treatment Budget

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Following through on a campaign promise, President Clinton today proposed a sharp increase in spending for drug treatment and programs to prevent drug abuse.
Despite the spending increases for prevention and treatment, most of the $13.2 billion for anti-drug programs would go toward law enforcement. 
 Mr. Clinton budgeted $5.4 billion for drug prevention and treatment, up about 20 percent from the $4.5 billion approved by Congress last year. That increase would give prevention and treatment 41 percent of the budget.
Mr. Clinton also proposed increasing the spending for law enforcement to $7.8 billion, accounting for 59 percent of the budget.
Over all, the anti-drug budget would rise by 9 percent from the $12.1 billion approved by Congress for the current fiscal year.
 
'A Significant Move'
 In addition to the proposal for the anti-drug budget made public today, the Administration is asking for nearly $1 billion for drug treatment and education programs as part of an anti-crime package that would spend $22.3 billion over five years.
"This is a significant move toward putting resources where the need is greatest," said Dr. Herbert D. Kleber, who resigned as President George Bush's deputy directory of the National Drug Policy Office after his requests for such increases went unheeded. As the deputy director he was the chief aide for health and education.
Lee P. Brown, Mr. Clinton's principal aide on drug policy, said the increase in spending for treatment and prevention programs represented a "fundamental change in the way the nation responds to the drug problem."
But Mr. Brown emphasized that for the Clinton Administration, like the Bush and Reagan Administrations, law enforcement remained an important part of the country's drug strategy.
 
'A Good Strategic Move'
 "We're providing not only a significant increase in drug treatment capacity," Mr. Brown said in an afternoon briefing, "but also solid support for law-enforcement activity."
While Mr. Clinton proposed a 3 percent increase in spending for enforcement, his budget calls for reducing by about $100 million the $1.2 billion spent last year in trying to stop smugglers at the borders and on the seas and increasing by about the same amount, to a total of $400 million the amount spent on trying to counter drugs in the countries in Latin America and Asia that produce them.
"I think this is a good strategic move," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who heads the Judiciary Committee. "The major thrust toward more emphasis on treatment and prevention is what we've been arguing we should be doing for the past four years."
The budget for the 1994 fiscal year, which Mr. Clinton proposed last March, varied little from the approach taken by his Republican predecessors; spending was to increase to $13 billion from $12.2 billion in the last budget submitted by President Bush for the 1993 fiscal year, but Congress approved only $12.1 billion.
 
Optimism Among Democrats
 This year, the Administration and some Democratic members of Congress are more optimistic.
"I think this year, with greater emphasis on crime and drugs, there is an understanding that while punishment is warranted, treatment has been terribly underfunded," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Crime and Criminal Justice. "And I think Congress will stick with these numbers."
Last October, Mr. Clinton said he intended to make drug prevention and treatment programs a hallmark of his Administration, with emphasis on heavy drug users who consume most of the illegal drugs and are responsible for much of drug-related crime.
But the President was criticized at the time for not spelling out how he would divide his budget to convert his goals into reality.
Today, Mr. Brown said Mr. Clinton's drug strategy promised "dramatic change, and that is reflected in the budget."
 
Limits to Expansion
 Some experts had been skeptical of Mr. Clinton's drug plan last fall, partly because he had followed President Bush so closely in drafting his first anti-drug budget. Moreover, Mr. Bush, like Mr. Clinton, often spoke of the importance of drug treatment but continued to spend much more for law enforcement.
Experts in drug treatment estimate that four million to six million Americans are heavy drug users. There are now programs to treat 1.4 million of them, but Mr. Clinton's drug budget would provide treatment for 74,000 more men and women. In addition, the crime bill would enable an additional 66,000 to enter treatment.
Peter Reuter, a drug expert who teaches public affairs and criminology at the University of Maryland, said the Administration might be expanding in these areas "as much as they responsibly can in one year."
"You can't double these programs overnight," Mr. Reuter said. "You can't pump that much money out efficiently in one year."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, discussing President Clinton's proposed 1995 budget in a briefing yesterday in Washington. Mr. Panetta said the deficit could continue to shrink only if the fastest-growing areas of the budget, like health care, were brought under control through further cuts or changes. At right was Robert E. Rubin, chairman of the National Economic Council. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: THE NEW YORK REGION

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Under the budget President Clinton proposed today, the New York region would suffer deep cuts in programs, including grants that help poor people pay their home heating bills and operating subsidies for mass transit, while winning new money for Head Start, job training, AIDS care, services for the homeless and the redevelopment of Pennsylvania Station.
"It is a bad-news, good-news budget for New York," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn. "What we gain on education and training and mass-transit capital funds, we lose in housing and mass-transit operating subsidies." 
 Richard Munson, director of the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition, a research organization financed by members of Congress in 18 states from Maine to Minnesota, said the budget appeared likely to hurt the New York region disproportionately in some important ways.
"It hurts," Mr. Munson said, "largely because some of those programs that the Administration has targeted for the largest cuts are programs that New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have especially depended on, like low-income home energy assistance, while the ones where they get increases are ones where they'll mostly just get their proportional share."
 
Steep Cuts for Housing
 Some of the loudest howls in the region came on the proposal to cut the low-income home energy assistance program about in half, to $92 million, from $182 million, according to an estimate by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's office here. New construction of public housing would also be sharply cut, along with rental assistance for the elderly, block housing grants to the states and other public housing programs.
The budget would trim mass-transit operating subsidies in New York State by about one-quarter, to $90 million, a cut that could translate into a 5-cent increase in the subway fare if the fare alone was used to make up the difference.
Senator Frank J. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, said the cuts in the mass-transit operating subsidies "just don't make sense" and would have to be adjusted.
But at the same time, the budget would increase assistance for building projects for mass transit in the states by roughly $100 million, to $416 million, and would bring substantial increases in money for Head Start, public elementary schools in low-income districts, job training, care for AIDS patients and programs for the homeless. Community development block grants, a perennial target for cuts in the Reagan years, would be maintained at current levels.
The overall pattern of give and take left the region's state and city officials struggling to sum up the net effects and their political response to the President's proposal in the face of tight spending controls and few new programs. Those same officials often squealed through a decade of cuts in urban aid by Republican administrations in Washington.
 
Comparison to Nixon
 "It's something of a Nixon-in-China phenomenon, where a Democratic President has had some success in capping spending, and that causes some problems for the states," said Steve Hoffman, deputy director of Mr. Cuomo's office here. "The bad news is there's some pain; the good news is that they're serious about deficit reduction."
The New York office estimates that the state would receive $100 million under the President's proposal for community policing, but the precise amounts and distribution formulas for this are yet to be worked out in the crime bills in Congress, making the money somewhat less certain.
The Administration included money for a project long dear to New York's senior Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan: the transformation of the General Post Office opposite Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan into a new passenger rail terminal and retail complex. The project is intended to recapture some of the glamour of the station demolished in 1965. The President asked for authorization for $100 million for the redevelopment plan, with the first $10 million to come in supplemental money in the current year's budget.
But money for Amtrak's Northeast Corridor improvement project, which slices through the three-state New York metropolitan region, would be cut by $25 million, to $200 million.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
In Perry's First 100 Hours, What Could Possibly Go Wrong?

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
In his first 100 hours as Defense Secretary, William J. Perry weaved his way through a field of national security land mines, escaping slightly frazzled but unbloodied.
Sworn in late last Thursday to replace Les Aspin, Mr. Perry joined senior Administration officials at the White House the next day to tighten economic sanctions on Haiti's military government. Then, he hopped an Air Force jet for Munich to keep a long-scheduled date at a private conference on European security issues. 
 Some lawmakers and even Administration officials have raised doubts whether Mr. Perry, who made his name as a technocrat, not a diplomat, can handle foreign policy matters. But in Munich he sounded like a statesman -- though a bland one -- in urging European support for Russia's economic and political reforms, and in beckoning nations outside of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to join the Partnership for Peace program that seeks to bring nonmembers into closer relations with the alliance.
By Sunday, with the carnage from Saturday's attack on a Sarajevo marketplace dominating the news, Mr. Perry was finding his voice. Though he made some tentative statements initially, on Sunday he deplored the attack and urged a common approach to ending the strife. "He was precise and to the point," said Volker Ruhe, Germany's Defense Minister.
On the flight home Sunday, Mr. Perry only half-jokingly told reporters, "I don't know if I can stand another 72 hours like this." But the day was far from over. A few minutes later, one of the engines on his four-engine plane conked out, forcing the plane to land at Mildenhall air base, 70 miles north of London.
Mr. Perry took the detour in stride. He mingled with the troops at the officers' club until a second plane, full of lawmakers who also attended the conference, swung by to pick up the stranded Secretary and his entourage.
 
Secretary's New Clothes
 From the Dressed-for-Success Department: Mr. Perry told reporters traveling with him last weekend that one of his first Secretarial acts was to buy a new suit (off the rack at Nordstrom) for his formal swearing-in ceremony later this month.
Mr. Perry, of course, was referring to those critics who said Mr. Aspin didn't help his shambling image any by wearing rumpled, light tan, ill-fitting suits to work.
When asked what color he picked, Mr. Perry said beaming: "Dark blue, you bet. I learned my lesson well."
 
Back at the Pentagon
 When he returned to the Pentagon today, Mr. Perry had a new office. Over the weekend, workers had removed Mr. Aspin's belongings and moved in Mr. Perry's from his former office, just down the corridor on the outer ring of the third floor, which is synonomous with power in the building.
Officials have taken down photographs of Mr. Aspin, but new photos of Mr. Perry are still to come. For the next month or so, Mr. Aspin will have use of a small office in nearby Rosslyn, Va., a courtesy afforded to departing defense secretaries.
Mr. Perry immediately plunged into what is likely to be a major political issue on Capitol Hill this year: defending the Pentagon's budget for 1995. Many liberal Democrats are pressing Mr. Clinton to cut military spending deeper while many Republicans and conservative Democrats fear the Administration may already have cut too much, too fast.
In his first defense of the budget before Congress, Mr. Perry will testify before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday.
 
A Numbers Game
 Mr. Perry, frequently identified as a former engineering professor with a Ph.D. in mathematics, has a reputation for bookishness he is eager to shed.
But he did not advance his own cause last weekend when someone interrupted the talk about peacekeeping, Ukrainian nuclear weapons and the Bosnia crisis to ask if he believed Fermat's last theorem had really been proven.
Suddenly, Mr. Perry's eyes lit up. Fermat's last theorem -- it says that xn + yn = zn is true when n equals the integer 2 and no other -- is one of the most enduring and difficult problems in mathematics. Fermat, a 17th-century French mathematician, wrote in the margin of one of his notebooks that he had proved it but that there was no room in the margin to write it out. Then he died, and mathematicians have been struggling with it ever since. A Princeton mathematics professor announced last year that he had discovered a proof.
Mr. Perry confided that off and on during a year of graduate school at Stanford he had tried to solve the 350-year-old problem -- unsuccessfully.
But that doesn't make him a scholarly type, he maintained. "Someone wrote that I was bookish," said Mr. Perry, who quoted the poets T. S. Eliot and W. H. Auden in his speech to the conference on European security. "I haven't had a chance to read a book in six months."

HEADLINE: Illness Is Forcing Chancellor Of SUNY to Resign From Post

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
D. Bruce Johnstone, the Chancellor of the State University of New York, announced yesterday that he is stepping down, effective March 1, because he has cancer.
Trustees to the largest state university system in the country scheduled a special meeting in New York for today, reportedly to discuss a temporary replacement for Dr. Johnstone. But they are not expected to make a decision until their Feb. 24 meeting, at which time they will also outline the process for finding a permanent replacement for Dr. Johnstone. 
 His pancreatic cancer was diagnosed in September and he underwent extensive surgery. Dr. Johnstone, 53, returned to work in January, but said he made the decision to step down last week after consulting with his doctors and family.
"I've been seeing my physician in the last couple of weeks, and he has reaffirmed that the cancer has reoccurred," Dr. Johnstone said from his office in Albany. "I know that I can't continue being Chancellor for long. I wanted to give the trustees a chance to begin an immediate search for my successor."
 
Returning to Buffalo
 "I will also begin chemo- or radiation therapy soon, which will have some effect potentially on my level of energy," he said. "It's been a tough week."
During his return to work, Dr. Johnstone attended Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State message and was present at the Jan. 27 trustees meeting.
Dr. Johnstone was president of the State University College at Buffalo for seven years before he was appointed to the Chancellor's post in 1988.
After he leaves office, Dr. Johnstone plans to return to Buffalo, which he considers home, for treatment at the Roswell Park Cancer Institute, where his wife, Gail, works as director of planning.
The SUNY system has 400,000 students and 64 campuses, including 30 community colleges, and an annual budget of $4.5 billion. Dr. Johnstone headed the sprawling system during the state's financial crisis. The university's budget was cut $200 million in a four-year period ending last year, and during Dr. Johnstone's tenure, tuition for full-time students increased to $2,650 from $1,350.
 
Holding Enrollment Steady
 But through it all, Dr. Johnstone was credited with trying to preserve the university's quality and its accessibility to all students who sought a public education. Enrollment remained steady even as the number of high school graduates in the state declined. Last year, the Legislature gave SUNY its first budget increase in three years.
Governor Cuomo said Dr. Johnstone has improved SUNY's financial standing and academic reputation by making inroads in expanding areas like technology.
"His management skills have made SUNY more efficient and accountable," the Governor said in a statement.
Dr. Johnstone, who is widely published and lectures often on higher education matters, said he was sorry to be leaving the educational scene at this time.
"I'll miss the chance to be a party to these kinds of major issues -- the challenges to higher education, the accessibility, quality and affordability to students, parents and taxpayers," he said. "It's always tough to leave an agenda unfinished."

HEADLINE: 44 Million Words Strong, Britannica to Join Internet

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Encyclopedia Britannica, the publisher of the nation's oldest and most prestigious reference work, said today that it would begin offering electronic distribution of its materials to universities and some public libraries via the Internet, the world's largest computer network.
The development is one of the clearest indications that traditional publishers realize the limitations of offering only hard-bound volumes -- and are concluding that the opportunities of on-line publishing outweigh the risks. 
 "Companies in the electronic publishing market are beginning to see they want the largest possible market," said Christopher Locke, general manager of Mecklermedia, a Westport, Conn., publishing and exhibition company. "They don't want to be trapped in markets that are Balkanized or private."
Several encyclopedias are already available on line, but the Encyclopedia Britannica is now the largest, with worldwide revenues of $550 million a year.
It also represents a significant move toward instant information and a milestone in miniaturization for the 32-volume reference work, which contains 44 million words and 23,000 illustrations and adorns the bookshelves of millions of libraries and homes.
"This is a blessing for every school kid," Paul Saffo, a researcher at the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif., said. "We've all been there before, the night before we have a paper due in class."
The 225-year-old Encyclopedia Britannica, which is the oldest continuously published encyclopedia in the English language, will be made available initially to university faculty and students in the fall, using a variety of information-retrieval technologies that have been developed experimentally by Internet researchers and that are being quickly commercialized.
Encyclopedia Britannica executives said they were also planning to make their reference data base available to a larger commercial audience, but academic distribution would be a first step to insure that the electronic version of the encyclopedia was well tested.
"The whole development process has been an astonishing one for me," said Robert McHenry, editor in chief of the Britannica. "I've scrambled pretty hard just to keep up with the technical language."
The electronic version of the Encyclopedia Britannica, to be called Britannica Online, is now being tested by students and faculty at the University of California at San Diego. The on-line version includes "hypertext" links that cannot be matched by the traditional text version.
This technology makes it possible for each article in the encyclopedia to refer to other related works and illustrations. It also links the four components of the encyclopedia: the macropedia, which is the extended version; the micropedia, which is the condensed version; the index, and a broad outline of world knowledge called the propedia.
To organize more than 300 million characters of text and 2,000 illustrations, the Encyclopedia Britannica is using information retrieval software developed by WAIS Inc., a Menlo Park, Calif., software developer.
To search the electronic version, students use networked personal computers and work stations running a program known as Mosaic, developed at the National Center for Supercomputer Applications at the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana. The software displays documents and illustrations and highlights words and phrases that have links to other documents. By clicking on a highlighted block of text or illustration, it is possible to retrieve a related document automatically from the Encyclopedia Britannica database.
 
Pricing Plans Studied
 Encyclopedia Britannica executives said they would probably price the encyclopedia to universities on a subscription basis, depending on the number of students on campus. However, they said they were still considering a variety of pricing methods for general commercial distribution.
One possible plan may be to charge on a reference-by-reference basis. That is made possible by the WAIS and Mosaic software. Currently, on-line encyclopedias are provided as standard service by on-line publishers like Compuserve, America Online and Prodigy.
Encyclopedia Britannica executives said they had decided to become electronic publishers rather than align with an existing on-line service because of the economics.
"The main reason we're doing it ourselves is that you just can't make any money licensing your content," Joseph J. Esposito, president of Encyclopedia Britannica North America, said. "If you do believe that content is king, it's rather unfortunate that so many of the content providers have put themselves in a position where they're held hostage to the on-line services."
The Encyclopedia Britannica had an earlier experiment with on-line information delivery via the Mead Data Corporation but the agreement ended in 1985 when the two companies could not agree on development costs.
"We're creating a new market for content providers," said Larry Smarr, director of the National Center for Supercomputer Applications, which developed the Mosaic browser software. "Here is a whole world of people who are using cyberspace as their information stream. They are all potential customers for commercial information providers."

HEADLINE: European Stocks Plunge In Response to Fed Move

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
After enjoying a long run-up over the last year, share prices in Europe dropped sharply today in response to the Federal Reserve's decision last week to nudge up interest rates in the United States.
After declining sharply early in the day, stock markets in London, Frankfurt and Paris stabilized later in what analysts said was relatively light trading. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares plunged more than 93 points during the morning but recovered to close down 56.30 at 3,419.10. 
 In Frankfurt, the DAX-30 index lost 58.85 points to close at 2,079.40. In Paris, the CAC-40 index closed at 2,287.06, down 42.11 points.
 
Down From Record Highs
 Although important economies including Germany's and France's are still struggling to shake off the recession, the European markets have enjoyed a steady bull run, with the London and Paris exchanges hitting new highs last week and Frankfurt having hit one last month.
Much of the buying has been based on the assumption that interest rates in Germany and in other important European economies would continue to decline for much if not all of 1994. Lower rates make equities relatively more attractive than interest-sensitive investments like bonds or savings accounts, and the expectation of continued rate reductions has sent a huge flow of money into stock markets in search of better returns.
There has also been heavy buying of European stocks by investors from the United States, where stock market valuations are high by historical standards and interest rates are quite low.
 The rise in rates in the United States led to speculation in the European markets that the anticipated cuts in European rates would come more slowly than expected and that the flood of investment from the United States would be slowed or even reversed.
But many economists and analysts said that the market's fears today were overblown and that the fundamental outlook for the European economies -- and for the markets -- was little changed from last week. The European markets, they said, will probably stabilize within a day or two, just as Wall Street stabilized today after the 96-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday.
"It's a knee-jerk reaction," said Ros Lifton, an economist at Nomura Research in London, referring to the selling by European investors.
Peter Sullivan, a European equity strategist at Merrill Lynch in London, said that European interest rates should continue falling for some months at least, despite the modest rise in short-term rates in the United States. There is some danger, he said, that the dollar's rise against the German mark during the last two days would increase inflationary pressures in Germany. But he said that the effect should be negligible, and that the German central bank's basic strategy of measured rate reductions was very unlikely to change.
"We don't think this represents a top for the European markets," Mr. Sullivan said. "We believe they will go back above Friday's levels. This was the most expected surprise in years, and it doesn't change our view that interest rates are coming down and that we'll see strong cyclical recovery and strong earnings recovery."

HEADLINE: In This Fiscal Crisis, New York Must Rescue Itself

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
"If we stay where we are," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declared last week as he presented his first budget plan for New York City, "we're headed for a disaster." To turn the city's economy around, the Mayor argued, nothing short of an immediate halt to the rising tax burden and a fundamental reorganization of public spending would do.
But will it work? Experts disagree sharply over whether cutting the budget, slashing the city's work force and reducing several local taxes -- all central elements of the Mayor's proposal -- will give the city's economy a much-needed shot in the arm. For all the disputes, however, they share at least one point: Mr. Giuliani has little choice but to try. 
 The fundamental reason, analysts say, is that New York City can no longer count on the stock market booms and office-building extravaganzas that bailed it out of earlier fiscal traumas. Because of a huge oversupply of empty office space and the fact that cuts in corporate employment have become an end in themselves, the city is not likely to be lifted as high as it once was by a national economic recovery. Nor can New York expect much help from the state or Federal governments.
 
No Third Recovery?
 "Can New York hope to grow its way out of its current troubles?" asked Charles R. Morris, an economic analyst who wrote "The Cost of Good Intentions," a detailed examination of the roots of New York's fiscal crisis of the 1970's. His answer: "Regrettably, no."
"The city has long been able to finance its largess from a vibrant Manhattan office-tower economy and its financial-services base," he added. "That is what fueled New York's last two recoveries, but I'm afraid it won't be much help this time."
While Wall Street has made money hand over fist in the last two or three years, that prosperity has made little difference to New York's lagging economy. Because of increased automation, the financial-services industry no longer requires as many people or as much office space in New York for the legions of people processing its transactions.
Given those circumstances, the city's critical need is to create or attract new businesses. So Mr. Giuliani is making the risky calculation that cuts in public jobs -- for all the pain to city employees and for all the political backlash -- are the only way over the long run to help ease the tax burden enough to lure private jobs back to New York.
New York has long provided tax abatements and other specific favors for large, prominent companies that threatened to leave. But with those corporate giants in decline, the challenge now facing Mr. Giuliani, analysts say, is to lessen the burden for small- and medium-sized businesses.
He must accomplish this without seriously degrading the level of public services that all employers and employees count on to make life tolerable in New York. That will not be easy. Dirtier streets, more crowded classrooms, worse traffic, more hectic commutes, all could do as much to drive companies out of the city as the taxes that now burden them.
 
Politics of Budget Cuts
 "The basic principle that the city's budget problems are having adverse economic consequences is absolutely sound," said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, which oversees the city's public spending. "What is unresolved is whether the politics of budget cutting" will do more harm than good, he said.
Mr. Giuliani's financial plan, in fact, includes a slowdown in capital spending for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and a severe cut in the administrative staff of the Board of Education. But whether the Board of Education cuts will affect classroom instruction is a matter of some debate.
Current research suggests that high state and local taxes play a significant role in harming almost every aspect of economic performance, from inducing companies to leave for greener pastures to discouraging new business startups and hindering the creation of jobs. Until the last few years, the common academic wisdom was that local taxes didn't matter much.
The penalty for being a high-tax area appears to be rising, because telecommunications and other innovations make it easier for businesses to pick up stakes and operate elsewhere. That is particularly worrisome for New York City, where the overall state and local tax burden is about 40 percent above the national average.
"Companies have become much more footloose," said Timothy J. Bartik, senior economist at the W.E. Upjohn Institute for Employment Research in Kalamazoo, Mich.
The overwhelming advantages of Manhattan as a financial and cultural center once outweighed the adverse effects of its high tax rates -- and the city banked on that. Now, even though New York is starting to develop an expanded role as a nexus for global business, many companies are no longer willing to pay as much of a premium simply for the privilege of doing business in New York.
 
'Out of Line'
 "It's O.K. to be above the national average in taxes, but New York got a little too much out of line," said Howard Chernick, a public finance expert at Hunter College.
But while Dr. Chernick agrees with Giuliani supporters that New York needs to curb some of the extra social benefits that only New York City provides, he says the city will nevertheless pay a price.
"At most, there will be some modest increase in the economic base," he said. "But it will be at the cost of a meaner life for the poor."
Even under the best of circumstances, said Frank J. Mauro, executive director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a labor-supported research group in Albany, New York City cannot solve its fiscal problems alone.
Two-fifths of the state's residents live in the city, yet three-fifths of those in poverty reside here. New York City educates 37 percent of the state's public-school students, but receives only 34 percent of state aid, Mr. Mauro says. The city is receiving $242 million less in state support, he said, than it was five years ago.
Mr. Giuliani is counting on an extra $355 million in state aid in the next fiscal year and another $333 million in Federal support. But the Mayor will be lucky if he gets anywhere close to that amount.
 
Immigrants as the Future
 That's just one more reason, analysts say, why the city can no longer count on its past saviors but must look to new sources of local strength.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
With traders still jittery after the Federal Reserve's sudden increase in short-term interest Friday, prices of Treasury securities slipped lower yesterday.
But prices did manage to bounce off their lows of the day, aided in part by a slide in commodity prices and, traders said, good investor demand in yesterday's three- and six-month Treasury bill auctions. The February gold contract on the Commodity Exchange fell $7.70, to $378.90 an ounce, while the March contract for light crude on the New York Mercantile Exchange fell 38 cents, to $15.25 a barrel. 
 Gerald A Guild, senior manager of the fixed-income department at Advest Inc., said yesterday's market action was a continuation of the Friday selloff. "There is still alot of uncertainty in the minds of many investors," he said, adding that traders are also worried about how well the market will react to the Treasury's quarterly auction this week of 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. Even when the market is calm this big auction can upset the apple cart.
But Mr. Guild believes that over the long term the bond market will benefit from the rise in short-term rates that the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, announced last week. "The bond market will survive," he said, "and if Alan Greenspan is right about nipping inflation it should be favorable for long-term interest rates."
 
Traders and Investors Worried
 But even if the Fed move is taken as a positive, traders and investors are still worried about another interest rate rise by the Fed and when it will come. Many analysts expect the Fed to make one or two additional short-term interest rate increases this year, which may be a factor that will keep the bond market from rebounding too much.
In trading late in the day, the price of the 30-year bond was down 13/32 of a point, to yield 6.39 percent, up from 6.36 percent on Friday. A five-year intermediate note was down 9/32 , to yield 5.35 percent, up from 5.30 percent at the end of last week.
At The Treasury bill auction, the discount rate of a new three-month bill rose to 3.24 percent, from 2.99 percent last week, while the rate for a six-month maturity was 3.40 percent, up from 3.16 percent. While the increase in the rates were steep, they just mirror the quarter of a percentage point rise in short-term interest rates that the Fed engineered Friday.
Traders said the shorter-maturity bill market was often regarded as a haven in periods of uncertainty when the markets were buffeted by unfavorable economic news. Longer maturities are much riskier because there is a greater drop in the price if interest rates rise. This rush to shorter maturities, traders said, is one reason that the rates at the Treasury bill auction did not move higher.
Today the Treasury will begin its $40 billion quarterly auction with the sale of $17 billion in new three-year notes. The three-day Government sale also includes the sale of $12 billion in 10-year notes tomorrow and $11 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday. Mr. Guild says the 3-year securities usually do well at the auction, with some trouble on the 10-year sales. This auction will feature the first 30-year bond auction in six months and therefore should attract good demand, some traders said.
The following are the results of yesterday's three- and six-month bill auctions:

HEADLINE: Borrowing Rises 11.2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Consumer borrowing rose in December as holiday shopping helped to spur a surge in credit expansion at the end of 1993.
Borrowing climbed at an annual rate of 11.2 percent in December, after a revised increase of 10.7 percent in November, the Federal Reserve said today. The November increase was originally estimated at 10.6 percent. 
 The latest rise, the seventh in a row, brought outstanding debt to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $789.8 billion.
The buying binge in stores and auto showrooms was spurred by low interest rates that encouraged consumers to finance purchases of cars and items for the home like furniture and appliances.
It was the third straight double-digit increase in borrowing, coinciding with a 5.9 percent growth rate in the economy for the fourth quarter of 1993 -- the biggest expansion in six years.
Consumer spending represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Many economists expect spending to level off in the early months of 1994.
By category, auto loans increased in December at a 6.4 percent annual rate, to $278.3 billion, after rising 13 percent in November.
Revolving credit, which includes credit cards, rose at a 10.4 percent rate in December, to $281.7 billion, on the heels of a 9.3 percent jump in November.
Other kinds of consumer loans rose 17.9 percent, to $229.8 billion, after increasing 9.4 percent in November.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metal Prices Hit By Waves of Profit Taking

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metal prices were pounded by profit taking yesterday as investment funds fled the market in a continuing reaction to Friday's increase in short-term interest rates.
Gold for April delivery, the most actively traded futures contract, fell $7.60, to $380.70 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. And March silver lost 18.7 cents, to $5.24 an ounce. 
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, April platinum dropped $6.10, to $391.40 a ounce.
 
Reaction to Stock Market
 About half of the drop in gold prices occurred at the opening, as the metals market caught up with Friday's plunge in the stock market, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 96.24 points.
The precious metals absorbed a second round of selling late in yesterday's session. Paradoxically, analysts said the stock market's recovery yesterday -- the Dow rose 34.90 points -- was a key factor.
Lower stocks typically push gold down initially. But if stocks continue falling, investors usually turn to gold for its safety, pushing the metal's price higher, Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst with Prudential Securities Inc., said. "This has not occurred and may not occur if the stock market continues to firm," she said.
The Federal Reserve's action on Friday to raise a key short-term interest rate for the first time in five years initially reduced demand for gold as an inflation hedge because higher rates act as a brake on economic growth. But the size of the increase -- to 3.25 percent from 3 percent in the interest that banks charge each other for overnight loans -- was considered marginal.
The bottom line, according to Jon Nadler, a vice president at Bank of America, is that little has changed.
"There is really no change in the big picture, namely a stronger economy," he said, adding that economic growth "is supportive for precious metals in general."
Mr. Nadler said gold historically has made seasonal lows in midwinter and early summer. A recovery, beginning in March, is likely, he said.
"I don't think the forecasters overall have tempered their bullish outlook. The mid-$400's are talked about more and more often," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Mixed Showing Amid Caution After Rally

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday after surging on Friday after the Federal Reserve surprised the markets by pushing up short-term interest rates.
Foreign exchange dealers said the currency markets were still recovering from Friday's bruising session in which the Federal Reserve's decision to raise short-term interest rates caused the dollar to soar 3 pfennigs to trade at a intraday high of 1.7640 German marks, its highest in two and a half years. 
 Higher interest rates in the United States make dollar-based assets relatively more attractive than foreign investments.
 "Obviously some people made money on Friday, but a lot got hurt," said Tom Moore, senior director at the American Express Bank.
"There wasn't anything to grab onto and the market was moving so quickly," he said of Friday's trading.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.7590 German marks, unchanged from Friday's close.
Dealers said they were wary of taking the dollar much higher on fears that the Bundesbank of Germany would sell dollars to keep the dollar from rising too quickly against the mark.
 The dollar firmed slightly after the Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, speaking in his role as president of the Group of 10 central bank chiefs, said the group was not very concerned about the situation of currency markets after the Fed's move.
 But Mr. Moore said dealers were not soothed by these assurances, noting that "too many people got hit Friday by taking the signals wrong."
The timing of the Federal Reserve's action on Friday caught many traders off guard, since the Commerce Department early in the day had reported modest jobs growth for January. The sign of sluggish growth was expected to forestall higher interest rates.
The dollar eased further against the Japanese yen yesterday ahead of this week's talks between President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa. Preparatory talks on trade issues have shown no real signs of progress.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 108.56 yen, down from 109.30 yen on Friday. Many traders fear the United States will seek to depreciate the dollar to encourage sales of American goods to Japan if other ways to narrow the trade gap fail.
The British pound rose in New York yesterday to $1.4830 from $1.4765 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Record Japan Trade Surplus

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Japan's current account surplus ballooned 12 percent in 1993, to a record $131.35 billion, the Finance Ministry announced today.
The current account is a broad measure of a nation's international financial flow, which includes merchandise trade, services and tourism. The surplus grew from $117.55 billion in 1992. Japan's huge trade surplus continues to be a source of tension between Japan and its trading partners, particularly the United States. 
 In dollar terms, imports and exports rose in 1993 as Japan's economy faltered into recession. Imports grew 5.7 percent, to $209.85 billion, as exports swelled 6.2 percent, to $351.28 billion.
When expressed in yen, however, the current account surplus fell 2 percent, to 14.602 trillion yen, the ministry said. In 1992, it jumped 53 percent, to 14.902 trillion yen.

HEADLINE: 4% Rise Sought in Science Budget

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7

 BODY:
Continuing earlier priority given to research and technology, the budget proposed today by the Clinton Administration calls for more spending for research on computers and communications, environmental sciences, manufacturing sciences and diseases like AIDS and breast cancer.
The budget proposal generally spares science the deep spending cuts affecting other parts of Government and increases financing for technology that could have a future economic impact on the nation, officials said. 
 The Administration asked for more than $71 billion in the fiscal year 1995, which will begin Oct. 1, for all Federal research and development, an increase of about 4 percent, or $2.5 billion more than the current year. Of that amount, spending on civilian research and development would increase by about $1 billion, to $32 billion.
Dr. John Gibbons, the President's science adviser, said Mr. Clinton was trying to continue his commitments to science and technology as an investment in the country's future, but had to reserve support for some programs that the Administration would have wanted. "The increases we make have to come at the cost of other things," Dr. Gibbons said at a briefing.
 
Funds for Medical Research
 The White House proposed increases in spending for medical research, including a 4.7 percent rise in money for the National Institutes of Health. Under the proposal, the institutes would get $11.5 billion, about $500 million more than this year, that would include a 6 percent increase in spending on AIDS research and 28 percent more for breast cancer studies.
The National Science Foundation, which supports more than half of the nonmedical basic research at colleges and universities, would receive a 6 percent budget increase to $3.2 billion under the proposal, including an 8.3 percent rise in direct research spending. Funds for research into global climate changes would rise 46 percent to $207 million, while funds for high-performance computing and communications research would rise by 23 percent to $329 million, officials said.
Computing and communications research, much of it connected with the so-called information superhighway advocated by Vice President Al Gore, would also get added support through increases for several other agencies. The Defense Department's budget in that area would rise by $56 million, to $397 million. Increases are also proposed for computer research projects in the budgets of the Energy Department, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Environmental Protection Agency and other agencies. Governmentwide, the computer-communications initiative would get a proposed $1.2 billion, an increase of 23 percent over this year.
The Administration said it would ask for $14.3 billion for the space program in 1995, a cut of more than $200 million from this year, but would continue support at current or higher levels for the international space station and aeronautical research that would help keep American industry competitive with overseas rivals. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said it would spend slightly less than the $2.1 billion cap it had agreed to maintain on space station work, including money to promote Russian participation in the program.
Although the space agency said it would reduce spending by cutting costs on the space shuttle program by more than $50 million and with other economies, the agency said it would increase spending on environmental research from space and even proposed to start a new program.

LENGTH: 627 words

HEADLINE: Small Budget Steps, Right Direction

 BODY:
What's the difference in budgetary emphasis between President Bill Clinton and President George Bush? Try $14 billion. That's the amount the Clinton Administration has found in a very tight budget to pay for its investment initiatives.
It is tempting to dismiss the redirection of $14 billion in a $1.5 trillion budget as tinkering. But the Administration deserves more credit than the raw numbers suggest. 
 Last year's budget law, which Mr. Clinton rammed through Congress, was needed to bring the Federal deficit down to responsible levels. But it imposed tight constraints on spending. It virtually froze discretionary programs -- everything from defense to border patrols. By 1998 civilian discretionary spending will fall to the lowest levels, relative to the size of the economy, since 1962.
There was little choice but to hammer the discretionary programs because the chief factor driving budget deficits -- the rapid increases in entitlements programs like Medicare and Medicaid -- can't be reined in without reforming the entire health care system. Under the 1993 budget law, Federal spending is expected to rise over the next four years by about $250 billion. But of that total, discretionary spending explains a minuscule $20 billion; entitlements, primarily Medicaid and Medicare, account for $230 billion.
The near freeze on discretionary spending forced the Administration to propose one dollar of cuts in existing programs -- thereby inviting instant opposition in Congress -- for every dollar it wanted to spend on its investments. So it is no surprise this budget proposes nothing bold.
Carving out even small sums for education, training, science and technology was hard. The Administration proposes eliminating more than 100 programs -- saving $3.2 billion -- and cutting an additional $20 billion or so out of several hundred other programs. Some of the cuts -- for oilseed export subsidies and tree planting -- are perennial suggestions, perennially defeated by Congress. Other proposed cuts take on sacred cows, including social programs the Administration concludes are not effective.
Mr. Clinton proposes cutting subsidies that help poor families heat their homes, on the reasonable grounds that he wants Congress to target aid on the truly needy. He proposes cutting money for public housing because there is unused money for this purpose sitting idle. And he proposes cutting money for grants under the Job Training Partnership Act for low-income youth because they do not work well. He also proposes cutting agriculture, space and energy programs.
The cuts are needed to meet the budget caps and to allow $14 billion for his new investment initiatives. He proposes modest increases in science and technology ($1.5 billion), infrastructure construction ($1 billion), and education and training ($3.3 billion).
The last figure allows Mr. Clinton to begin a long-promised school-to-work program that combines classroom instruction with on-the-job training for high school students who are not college bound. Mr. Clinton also plans to improve training and job-locating assistance for dislocated workers.
Other increases are for housing vouchers for the poor, assistance for the homeless, AIDS treatment, environmental protection, nutrition programs for poor mothers and community policing.
Mr. Clinton's budget makes small steps in the right direction. Though they are not enough to make a big impact this year or next, that is not the proper test. If Mr. Clinton succeeds in tilting Federal spending toward investment and away from consumption, this year's small steps could be repeated year after year. Before long, the Federal budget would then target aid to the needy and raise the productivity of everyone.

HEADLINE: Sarajevo: The Right Response

 BODY:
The mortar shell that turned Sarajevo's main market into a killing field Saturday afternoon heightens pressure on NATO leaders, President Clinton included, to find a way to hasten the end of the 22-month-old Bosnia war. But it would be perverse indeed if this latest Serbian atrocity became the occasion for Mr. Clinton to abandon his long and principled resistance to French and British pressure to impose an unjust and unenforceable settlement on the Bosnian Government.
European governments have been playing a cynical game. Until Serbian gunners pushed matters too far last weekend, the Europeans were perfectly willing to use the shelling of Sarajevo and other cities to pressure the Bosnian Government to accept a bad partition plan that denied them vital territory and transit routes. 
 If they now agree to endorse NATO air strikes against the siege guns, they fully expect Washington, in return, to join in their diplomatic gang-up, at the very moment the Bosnian Government has begun to gain military strength, even reversing some of its earlier losses.
Mr. Clinton must tell the Europeans no deal. Instead, he should call on them to lift the one-sided United Nations arms embargo so that the Bosnians can properly defend themselves. In that context, and in that context alone, NATO air strikes, with European as well as American planes participating, could speed a decent end to the conflict.
What has held up air strikes until now is a joint United Nations-European Union strategy based not on stopping aggression but on forcing a negotiated peace. While diplomacy is generally preferable to warfare, the flaw in this strategy has been the false moral equality it has applied to the Serbian and Croatian aggressors and their Muslim victims.
An arms embargo theoretically applied to all sides has until recently disarmed only the landlocked Bosnian defenders, not the Serbian and Croatian attackers who manage to produce or smuggle in all the guns they need. Pressure on the Serbs has consisted of economic sanctions that have grown increasingly porous; the Croats have received little more than words of warning. Meanwhile the Bosnians have been pressured to accept a truncated share of territory by the siege guns shelling Sarajevo and other government-controlled cities.
In the name of this "evenhanded" strategy, European and U.N. officials left that artillery unmolested, despite Security Council resolutions proclaiming those cities protected safe havens and NATO resolutions threatening air strikes unless the Serbs lifted the sieges.
The callous amorality of this "evenhandedness" rightly repelled the Clinton Administration, which, though it had no clear strategy of its own, refused to endorse the efforts of its allies to let the Serbian siege artillery batter the Bosnians into accepting an unjust peace. Not only principle is at stake. Given the bitterness of this conflict, a peace imposed at the bargaining table is guaranteed to be resisted in the forests, mountains and cities of Bosnia. Any international force deployed to enforce or even monitor such a sullen peace is likely to become a target for all sides.
Now the carnage inflicted by the Serbian artillery may be more than any democratically accountable government can abide. But as the Europeans soften their opposition to punitive air strikes, the Clinton Administration must stand firm on the principle of not imposing an unjust peace.
