HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Little Respect for Former Capitol Star

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Not so long ago, the submission of the President's budget to Congress was one of the big news events of the year. Big surprises were the rule: sometimes vast new programs or sometimes radical changes in the way the Government does business.
The details of the Great Society were revealed in a Lyndon B. Johnson budget. Richard M. Nixon once proposed in a budget to combine all the Cabinet departments into four giant agencies. Ronald Reagan explained in his first budget how he would slash taxes, build up the military and balance the budget with one hand tied behind his back. 
 In those days, budget documents were distributed to reporters and Congressional staffs on a Friday with the understanding that they would not be written about or discussed publicly until the next Monday. No one complained. It gave reporters and editors the weekend to digest complicated material and lawmakers time to think about how they wanted to respond.
How times have changed!
When President Clinton presented his budget on Monday, "it was about as exciting a time as Ground Hog Day," said Stanley E. Collender, director of Federal budget policy at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm.
"I do a lot of work with people in the bond market," Mr. Collender said today. "Those guys just didn't want to hear about the budget yesterday. They said, 'O.K., thanks, but we're paying attention to other things now.' "
One reason Presidents' budgets are less compelling nowadays is that Congress no longer accepts them uncritically.
In part, that is a consequence of so many years of divided Government, with Republicans in the White House and Democrats controlling Congress. But it is even more the result of Congressional budget procedures set up 20 years ago.
Before the mid-1970's, Congress had no mechanism for considering the budget systematically. But then the budget committees and the Congressional Budget Office were established. Gradually, Congress began to assert the power of the purse granted it by the Constitution. For the last decade at least, the big budget news has come off Capitol Hill, not out of the White House.
A second reason why budgets create less of a splash is that they were treated so cynically during the Bush Administration. They have always been primarily political documents. But recognizing that his proposals stood no chance in Congress, the impresario of Bush budgets, Richard G. Darman, turned them into polemics with rhetorical flourishes and ludicrous forecasts.
Four years ago, for example, Mr. Darman wrote a didactic introduction about "the ultimate cookie monster" and "hidden Pac-Men." That budget estimated that the deficit in the 1991 fiscal year would be $64.7 billion. It was slightly optimistic. The deficit turned out to be $269.5 billion.
This year, the Democrats in Congress will probably pass Mr. Clinton's budget more or less intact. And the President seems to have presented an honest accounting of what programs will cost and what the deficit will be.
But in terms of stirring up interest in his budget, Mr. Clinton ran head-long into the third reason why budgets deserve so much less attention than they used to: There is precious little money to fool around with.
So Mr. Clinton tinkered, adding a little money here for education and training, a little there for drug treatment. But in the first full-scale budget by a Democratic President in 13 years, he proposed nothing bold, nothing likely to make the history books.
The biggest initiatives he plans for this year, overhauling the health and welfare systems, were hardly mentioned in the budget. In the case of health, that was because even if the Clinton plan is enacted this year, little of it will be in effect in the 1995 fiscal year. As for welfare, the Administration argues, to the disbelief of most students of the subject, that millions of Americans can be moved off welfare and into jobs without costing the Government any extra money.
One of the President's pride and joys, the national service program, which is supposed to allow all students to work off their college loans by serving their communities, was budgeted for only $850 million. That is enough for only 33,000 students, approximately the enrollment at New York University alone.
"We can't do what we'd ultimately like to do," conceded Gene Sperling, a Clinton economic adviser. "We're constrained by the deficit."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond Yield at 6-Month High

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year bond jumped to 6.44 percent yesterday, its highest level in six months, as dealers pushed rates up at the beginning of the Treasury's $40 billion quarterly borrowing.
Yields in the government securities market often rise during the Treasury's debt auctions because traders are hoping to make the new securities cheaper so they are attractive to investors and thus sell quickly. 
 But because yields have moved higher since the Federal Reserve raised short-term rates on Friday, traders are not able to say whether the yield on the 30-year bond will decline after the auction on Thursday, or whether the Fed move will keep long-term yields up.
"You're going to find that investors want a little more of a premium before buying Treasuries in a market where there is still a lot of uncertainty about the Fed's next move," said Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist at CS First Boston.
 
Further Rate Rise Seen
 Market participants expecting a further rise in short-term interest rates over the next few months said they saw a signal of such a move in comments from John P. LaWare, a Federal Reserve Board governor. He told reporters that the quarter of a percentage point jump to 3.25 percent in the rate charged on overnight loans between banks might not be sufficient to cool the economy and prevent inflation from reviving.
Another factor lifting interest rates is concern about the approach of new inflation data. It was concern about inflation that prompted the Fed's interest rate move. On Friday the Labor Department releases the January producer price data. The bond market is concerned that a strong inflation number could lead eventually to a second increase in short-term interest rates by the Fed, which would be likely to push long-term interest rates higher, at least immediately.
"If the number shows a significant rise in inflation, it could cause yields to rise," Mr. Alexy added. "So in essence what the Fed did last week by raising interest rates was put the market on an inflation watch."
The rise in yields yesterday came as bond prices, which move in the opposite direction, fell yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, as the Treasury sold more than $17 billion in new three-year notes, the first leg of the three-part quarterly borrowing. In late trading the price of the 30-year bond was off 12/32 , to 9713/32 , or down about $7.50 per $1,000 invested. The yield was up from 6.39 percent on Monday.
Analysts see the three-day auction as an important test of investor sentiment. While many traders expect a relatively successful Treasury auction, some suspect it will come at a cost.
 
3-Year Yield Rises
 At yesterday's auction of three-year notes the average yield was 4.83 percent, the highest auction level since the 5.17 percent in November 1992. The average at auction was 39 basis points higher than the last three-year note auction on Nov. 9, 1993. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Today the Treasury will sell $12 billion of 10-year notes followed tomorrow by the auction of $11 billion more of the current 6.25 percent 30-year bond due August 2023. The Treasury is issuing more of the current 30-year bond, which is called reopening the issue, in an effort to alleviate a shortage of the bond.
Many analysts have suggested that the current bond is trading at a distortedly high price and low yield because the Treasury cut its scheduled annual sales of long bonds in August by about 40 percent in an attempt to reduce borrowing costs. In addition to reducing the number of 30-year bonds sold, the Treasury also shifted to just two long bond auctions a year instead of four. The borrowing done in the past with 30-year bonds has been shifted to shorter-term, lower-interest Treasury notes and bills.
In when-issued trading for the two remaining maturities of the three-part government sale, the 10-year note being auctioned today was offered at a price to yield 5.95 percent, up from 5.90 percent on Monday, while the 30-year bond going on sale Thursday was offered at a price to yield 6.45 percent, up from 6.39 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
British Rate Cut Strengthens Traders' Demand for Dollars

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar advanced yesterday to its highest level against the German mark in more than two and a half years, as a reduction in British interest rates bolstered it against most European currencies.
The dollar hit a high for the day of 1.7686 marks after the Bank of England set a minimum lending rate at 5.25 percent, implying a quarter-point cut in base lending rates. The dollar finished at 1.7644 marks in New York trading, up from 1.7590 on Monday. 
 The British rate cut spurred selling of British pounds for dollars and other currencies. Traders were particularly eager to buy dollars in light of the Federal Reserve's move last Friday to lift interest rates one-quarter point, touching off an immediate surge in the United States currency.
"It was a follow-through from Friday's rally," Rob Pasqua, vice president at Banque Francaise, said of the dollar's advance.
The British pound fell in New York to $1.4670, from $1.4830 late Monday.
 
Dollar at 108.90 Yen in New York
 In other trading, the dollar posted a small gain against the Japanese yen after moving in a narrow range. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 108.90 yen, up from 108.56 yen on Monday.
The currency market had an unexpectedly muted reaction to the Japanese Government's announcement of a fiscal stimulus package, which included a major tax cut.
Traders had been anxiously awaiting the package, which some said could help pare the huge Japan trade surplus with the United States by spurring demand for American exports.
But now, traders said, the market has turned its attention to Friday's meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan, where they will discuss trade.
"The stimulus package is an issue that's done and over with," Belal Khan, senior customer dealer at Bank of Tokyo, said. "Now, people are focusing on trade."
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Monday, included: 1.4803 Swiss francs, up from 1.4682; 5.9820 French francs, up from 5.9645; $1.3428 (Canadian), down from $1.3441 (Canadian), and 1,698 Italian lire, up from 1,696.

HEADLINE: Productivity Up by 4.2% In the Last Quarter of '93

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Led by manufacturing industries, the productivity of American workers rose 4.2 percent in the fourth quarter last year, the Labor Department said today.
That was up from 4 percent in the third quarter and the strongest since a 4.2 percent rate 12 months earlier in the last quarter of 1992. Productivity increased 1.6 percent for the year, the Labor Department said. 
 Productivity is a measure of how efficiently businesses produce goods and is formally defined as output per number of hours worked. In the fourth quarter last year many industries, but especially automobiles, speeded up production schedules and added work shifts.
Manufacturing industries' productivity advanced at a 7.8 percent annualized rate in the fourth quarter, more than double the 3.1 percent rate in the third quarter.
 
Annualized Calculation
 The burst of manufacturing activity helped propel total goods and services output, measured by the gross domestic product, at a 5.9 percent annual rate in the quarter.
Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers, said that meant American manufacturing companies were outproducing competitors in Japan and most of Western Europe. "Productivity growth rates have been extremely high in the goods-producing industries that make up the bulk of international trade," he said. "These figures provide evidence that the United States will achieve high productivity in traded-goods sectors during the 1990's."
Separately, the Commerce Department reported lower wholesale sales in December, and as a consequence, an increase in the supplies of unsold goods.
 
Drop in Sales
 Sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $161.03 billion after a revised four-tenths of 1 percent rise in November that had previously been reported as a much stronger 1 percent increase. Sales in October had also risen four-tenths of 1 percent.
Wholesale inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in December to a seasonally adjusted $217 billion after a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in November, the Commerce Department said. Inventories had fallen in October by one-tenth of 1 percent.
Some goods were still selling briskly in December, notably lumber, which was up 7.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $7.49 billion, as starts of new homes kept rising. Furniture sales were also up strongly from November.
Among categories of goods where sales fell were clothing, down 7.1 percent in December to $6.15 billion, and motor vehicles, off three-tenths of 1 percent, to $14.5 billion.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
NEC, Faltering, to Get New President

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Tadahiro Sekimoto, who presided over the NEC Corporation as it grew into one of the world's most successful electronics companies, and then as it fell into trouble, announced today that he would step down in June.
The new president will be Hisashi Kaneko, the executive vice president in charge of international operations. Dr. Kaneko headed NEC's American operations until last August and is viewed as a protege of Dr. Sekimoto's. 
 The change in leadership comes as NEC is struggling to regain profitability after suffering a consolidated net loss of 45.2 billion yen, or nearly $420 million, in its last fiscal year.
During Dr. Sekimoto's 14-year tenure as president, NEC moved swiftly to capture more than half the personal computer market in Japan. The company also became the world's largest semiconductor manufacturer until it was passed by the Intel Corporation. Total sales exceed $30 billion.
Still, that record has been somewhat marred by the troubles of the last two years and Dr. Sekimoto, 67, has been criticized for not moving fast enough to deal with NEC's problems.
 
'Fresh Perspective' Needed
 "Personally, I think he stayed a bit too long," said Steven Myers, electronics analyst with Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo. "The company does need a fresh perspective."
NEC's personal computer business, once the company's main source of profits, has been buffeted by a price war sparked by the entrance into the Japanese market of American companies like Compaq and Dell Computer.
Dr. Sekimoto initially dismissed the American computers, saying they were as ill suited to the Japanese culture as American cars with the steering wheel on the wrong side. But while Compaq and Dell remain small players in the market here, all Japanese vendors have since adopted the same operating system as the American companies, posing a threat to the dominance of the NEC standard.
Meanwhile, NEC's mainframe computer business is suffering from the shift to smaller computers and from Japan's recession. NEC's consumer electronics business, never a strong point, has lost money for years. And while NEC's motto has long been "computers and communications," the company has not become a leader in multimedia or other areas in which computers and communications are merging.
Still, some cost-cutting has occurred and the company is projecting a slight profit for the fiscal year that ends in March, giving Dr. Sekimoto a chance to retire on a positive note. He will become chairman.
 
New Course Uncertain
 How or whether Dr. Kaneko, the next president, will change things is unclear. During a news conference today, he sat quietly by Dr. Sekimoto's side and declined to discuss his ideas, saying he had been informed about his promotion only yesterday.
Dr. Sekimoto said he had chosen Dr. Kaneko because his experience in research and in the United States matched two of the main themes for NEC in the future -- globalization and multimedia.
Dr. Kaneko, 60, earned a master's degree in electrical engineering from the University of California at Berkeley in 1962 and worked at Bell Laboratories from 1968 to 1970.
From 1989 to 1993 he was based in Melville, L.I., as president of NEC U.S.A., the parent company of NEC's American operations, and as president of NEC America, the telecommunications subsidiary. During his tenure, the telecommunications business had some difficult times and Dr. Kaneko consolidated some operations in Texas and Oregon.
Dr. Kaneko's career path closely mirrors that of Dr. Sekimoto. Both earned doctorates in engineering from the University of Tokyo and worked their way up through NEC's telecommunications business. Both were managers in the central research lab and served as general managers of the transmission division.

HEADLINE: Stocks Up in Europe After British Rate Cut

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Britain shaved its base lending rate by a quarter of a point today to its lowest level in 22 years, giving a boost of confidence to investors and signaling that rates in Europe would continue to move down even as they tick up in the United States.
Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke said he was reducing the base rate to 5.25 percent from 5.5 percent because Britain's modest economic recovery had so far created no significant inflationary pressures. Inflation in December was 1.9 percent, and the Government and the Bank of England have set a goal of keeping it below 4 percent.
 
Rebound in Stocks
 "Inflation has been lower than expected," Mr. Clarke said. "Looking ahead, inflationary pressures appear subdued." 
 The move helped send share prices up on the London Stock Exchange, one day after the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares fell 56.3 points on worries about rising interest rates in the United States. The index closed up 21.1 points today at 3,440.2.
Other European markets also rebounded from their tumbles on Monday. In Frankfurt, the DAX-30 index rose 27.81 to close at 2,107.21. In Paris, the CAC-40 index closed at 2,299.85, up 12.79 points.
Britain had been widely expected to cut interest rates before April, when a package of tax increases will take effect, potentially taking some of the steam out of the recovery.
Today's move suggested that Britain saw no reason to reassess its interest-rate policy in light of the Federal Reserve's decision on Friday to raise short-term rates in the United States by a quarter of a point, to 3.25 percent. The United States economy is growing strongly and is at risk of generating inflation. But Britain is still very early in its recovery, and most of the rest of Europe is still emerging from recession.
Germany is expected to continue its policy of rate reductions in an attempt to stimulate its struggling economy. The Bundesbank may be concerned about the potential inflationary pressures from the weakening of the German mark against the dollar, economists said, but those concerns are almost certain to be outweighed by other economic problems. The Bonn Government reported today that unemployment in western Germany rose from 8.1 percent in December to 8.8 percent in January, its highest level since 1985.
"Given the U.S. move on Friday, today's reduction does highlight the differing positions of the U.S. and the U.K. and to an even greater extent the Continental European countries in terms of the economic cycle," said Matthew Merritt, a global strategist at NatWest Markets in London. "You're going to see their interest rates moving in different directions in 1994."

HEADLINE: Stiglitz, Idea Man Among the Economic Advisers

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
When Joseph Stiglitz was invited to join the President's Council of Economic Advisers, many wondered whether the ivory-tower theorist from Stanford University could possibly navigate the currents of real world policy-making. The council's role, played mostly behind the scenes, is to inject as much economic rationality into Administration proposals as politics allow.
Mr. Stiglitz, 51, had written hundreds of papers on the economics of information, public finance and economic development, won the prestigious John Bates Clark medal in 1979 and was widely expected to collect a Nobel someday. He was also the quintessential absent-minded professor, who has dashed into class and lectured on the wrong subject, and often turned up with his tie or shirt collar seriously askew.
 
Repairing Markets
 In fact, as the council's chairwoman, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, must have recognized when she chose Professor Stiglitz, he and Washington circa 1993 were made for each other. He has spent his professional life focused on the idea that markets are imperfect and need to be repaired. "What ends up in the Government's portfolio are the things where the market is having problems," Mr. Stiglitz said, "Government can make a major difference for the good if you structure policies appropriately." 
That sentiment is in keeping with everything that the Administration has done, or is thinking about, whether it is overhauling the nation's health care, ushering in the electronic information age or reducing the country's emissions of greenhouse gases. And while economists -- including the ones who work for the White House -- rarely have the last word on policy, many of those who have worked with him say that Mr. Stiglitz is having an impact by suggesting creative solutions to complicated problems.
"What he brings to the table is a fountain of ideas," said Alan Blinder, the third member of the economic council.
Take a recent contribution to the nuts and bolts of the Administration's environmental policy, the new plan to reform the Superfund. The Government's program to get companies to clean up polluted industrial sites has practically become synonymous with government waste and inefficiency. It was Mr. Stiglitz's idea to replace part of the current system of liability -- which encourages costly legal suits more than cleanups -- with a system of arbitration and a set of economic incentives to encourage companies to stay out of court.
Mr. Stiglitz sold his contribution to the lawyers on the interagency task force that crafted the Administration proposal partly by the cogency of his arguments and partly by his ability to suggest compromises and alternatives when the discussion seemed to be heading for a stalemate.
"He always brings a new idea and perpetual good humor," said Alicia Munnell, Assistant Treasury Secretary for economic policy. "He always has another notion of how this deal could be worked."
Mr. Stiglitz is also helping shape the Administration's thinking on ways to help politically powerful but economically weak states like California and New York without playing havoc with the budget agreement.
Although Mr. Stiglitz sometimes compares himself to the greatest economists of all time, from Adam Smith to Paul Samuelson, many in Washington are disarmed by his tendency not to take himself too seriously -- he played an elaborate practical joke on the council staff soon after arriving and showed up at the C.E.A. Christmas party dressed as Santa -- his ability to listen and his genuine enthusiasm for other people's ideas.
 
No Sign of Arrogance
 "Joe brings a lot of intellectual power to problems," Ms. Tyson said, "but how you bring it matters as much as what you bring, and Joe doesn't bring even the slightest trace of arrogance."
Of course, Presidents rarely do what their economists tell them. Michael Boskin, President Bush's chief economist, recalls that he had to threaten to quit to get an interview with his boss at the height of the recession. President Reagan wanted to disband the Council of Economic Advisers. President Clinton uses the council, among other things, to help with Chelsea's homework.
But it is completely characteristic of Professor Stiglitz, a born can-do optimist, not to dwell on the half-empty cup of his influence. Twinkly eyed, smiling and comfortably rotund, he is simply having too much fun munching his way through "the smorgasbord of interesting problems" that wind up on the council's agenda. "I have the greatest job in Washington," he said. The biggest surprise, he added, is the fact that Washington isn't populated by a bunch of back-stabbers.
"When a decision is informed, when we've had an intelligent discussion," he said, "I don't feel bad when people don't go along with our recommendations."
Endless meetings don't exhaust him. Instead, he says, he's invigorated. And he still has energy to spare for playing with his two young children, Siobhan and Michael, and his dog, Woofie; making feasts for friends, and taking an occasional expedition to California, though his frequent and far-flung travels ("Joe is the person you'd be most likely to meet at the head of the Amazon," a friend said ) have temporarily been put on hold.
 
The Perks of Office
 "He was tickled when Clinton walked over to us and said, 'Hi, Joe,' " said Jane Hannaway, his wife, who added that her husband relished the chance to eat at the White House mess and take out-of-town guests to the President's box at Kennedy Center. "But he couldn't exist on that," she continued. "For most people in Washington, a good problem is something Congress will pass. To Joe, it's one that's interesting,"
The work Professor Stiglitz has done in the past gives important clues to advice he'll give in the future.
His analysis of insurance markets concludes that such markets frequently break down because it is impossible for insurance companies to know as much as individuals do about their true health status. His solution? Universal coverage.
His theories about credit markets suggests that high rates may not ease credit crunches because they attract poor credit risks. And his analysis of labor markets suggests that discrimination can be self-reinforcing, not self-correcting as conventional economic models imply.
 
Shifting the Paradigm
 "What I've tried to do for first time is to shift the paradigm," Mr. Stiglitz said. "The key to economics is problems of information -- who knows what -- and these problems of information are core to our understanding of all our institutions."
George Ackerloff, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, said: "The old-style economics is the standard story of perfect competition. The new style of economics makes you focus very heavily on imperfections in markets and their consequences."
Some other economists question whether market breakdowns in theory are pervasive enough in reality to warrant an entirely new economic paradigm. "Markets get the wrong answer. That's a logical pass that can't be ruled out," said Robert Lucas an economist at the University of Chicago "But he never turned the corner into quantitative research. It doesn't give you a prescriptive apparatus either."
Others worry that Mr. Stiglitzis is too ready to believe that government intervention will work as benignly as intended.
 
Overcoming Naivete
 John Taylor, a close friend at Stanford and a member of the economics council under President Bush, added that he, for one, was confident that a spell in Washington would remedy any such naivete. Professor Stiglitz's recently published introductory economics text -- some call it a potential rival for the Samuelson classic -- contains hundreds of pages on market failures, but just a couple on government foul-ups. "There will be more stories about government failures in the second edition," he said.
Perhaps. What's certain is that the sojourn in Washington is not likely to tarnish his reputation as an absent-minded professor.
Twenty minutes into a recent meeting of the Administration's economic team, for example, the budget director, Leon Panetta, who had been staring at Professor Stiglitz, jumped up, exclaimed, "I can't stand it any more!" and walked over behind the economist, grabbed the latter's tie and put it in its rightful place. Professor Stiglitz -- and not, his colleagues say, for the first time -- had tied the tie on top of his collar instead of underneath it.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph Stiglitz, who is on the Council of Economic Advisers, is known for suggesting creative solutions to complicated problems. Many in Washington are disarmed by his tendency not to take himself too seriously. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Franklin Resources' shares gain favor as a mutual fund play.

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne

 BODY:
THERE are more ways than one to invest in mutual funds. One is to buy the stocks of publicly traded mutual fund companies. Several analysts are looking favorably at Franklin Resources of San Mateo, Calif., the world's largest publicly traded asset manager.
"It's a buy," said James Hanbury, an analyst for Wertheim Schroder. "It's a well-run, well-positioned company." 
 But Franklin is a buy only for those willing to bet on the overall market, because the stock is vulnerable in a sharp downturn. During the market plunge on Friday, Franklin's stock dropped $3, or 6 percent, although the shares regained $1.125 on Monday and $1.625 yesterday to close at $48.625.
Charles F. Gunther, an analyst at Van Kasper & Company, said he was more cautious on Franklin than some of his fellow analysts. He said he thought that Franklin's stock was "reasonably fully priced," but that it was a good long-term buy.
"Franklin's discipline is marvelous, and they have surprisingly strong earnings," Mr. Gunther said. "The quality of their investments is first rate. And the long-term potential is fabulous. It's a classic example of buying a good stock and sticking with it. I'd start buying if it came down a bit."
Franklin benefited from its purchase in October 1992 of Templeton funds, a 78-fund global firm headed by the legendary investor John Templeton. The price of $913 million was the highest paid for a mutual fund company; the Mellon bank is planning to top that with a $1.85 billion deal for Dreyfus.
The Templeton acquisition has helped Franklin's earnings, and the arrangement was not so bad for Mr. Templeton either, who does his stock-picking from the Bahamas: He and his sons owned 70 percent of the Templeton fund's voting shares.
 The acquisition has allowed Franklin to ride the boom in international investing, while providing it diversification from its mainstay fixed-income funds. In retrospect, analysts say, the Templeton merger looks cheap. Franklin's assets have grown by 14 percent annually since the merger, and analysts say that Franklin could hardly have found an alternative investment with such strong growth.
During 1993, money poured into international mutual funds at an ever-increasing rate that peaked at more than $7.2 billion in new cash inflows in December alone. This has made foreign stock funds the fastest growth area of this fast-growing industry. The Templeton acquisition has pushed up Franklin's assets to $114 billion, from $75 billion before the merger. And mutual fund company economics are simple: The more money under management, the more earned through fees.
Mr. Hanbury estimated that the company, which earned $2.10 a share last year, would earn $2.85 a share in 1994 and $3.30 a share in 1995. The company is trading at 21 times earnings, and at those estimates, the stock could reach $60 to $65 a share in the next year or so, Mr. Hanbury said.
One possible cloud for Franklin is that it is sold only through brokers at a time when more of its competitors are beginning to use alternative distributors, like banks. There are worries that the investment houses that sell Franklin funds, like Merrill Lynch and Dean Witter, may push their own funds over those of Franklin. And there is concern that bond funds could come under pressure from low-cost rivals like Vanguard, whose funds are sold with rock-bottom expenses.
Such concerns have not fazed some analysts. "Franklin has simple and elegant product ideas," said John Keefe, president of Keefe Worldwide Information Services, a consulting firm. "They offer basic products that people need. And the Templeton name is a Cadillac."
Steve Eisman of Oppenheimer & Company recommends the stock because of the name recognition. "There's a lot of mutual fund companies," he said, "but few with a brand-name presence."

HEADLINE: Job Losses At a High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Despite statistics saying that the United States economy is recovering, job cutbacks announced last month by companies reached their highest level in at least five years, a survey released yesterday showed.
Companies announced 108,946 job reductions in January, more than four times the number announced in December, the survey by Challenger, Gray & Christmas, an outplacement consulting firm, said. 
 James E. Challenger, president of the Chicago-based company, said the figure was the highest since monthly records of layoff announcements were first compiled in 1989.
The biggest job reductions came from the communications industry, with four companies saying they planned to eliminate 44,314 jobs. The GTE Corporation announced the most cuts: 17,000 jobs spread over three years.
Companies based in Connecticut, New York and Pennsylvania accounted for more than 60 percent of the jobs to be lost, the firm said. But the positions eliminated were not all in those states.
"Although consumer confidence is reportedly at record levels," Mr. Challenger said, "America's work force continues to be subjected to a steady stream of cutback announcements by employers every day."
He added that the true number of workers laid off was probably larger than the numbers his firm compiled, since some companies do not announce job reductions.

HEADLINE: Searching the Soul Of French Cuisine

BYLINE: By PIERRE FRANEY

 BODY:
LAST summer, I returned to my native France with a single-minded journalistic mission. There has been much discussion recently suggesting that French cuisine is in the doldrums, bereft of new ideas. On this nostalgic journey I set out to determine: where is French cuisine today? And, equally important, where is it heading? After three months, 10,000 miles and 60 restaurants, the answers were palpable, though not simple.
In short, French cooking, from Nice to Normandy, is going through another of its periodic revolutions, only this time it is more subtle. And it is a somewhat contradictory movement, with leading chefs taking one step forward and one step backward at the same time. I'll try to explain. First, a little background. 
 As a chef who earned his culinary stripes in the 1930's under the wings of Escoffier's lieutenants, I have always had the gastronomic creed "flavor first, everything else second." In the 1970's, with the rise of nouvelle cuisine, everything changed. Histrionics were put on the front burner as chefs competed for visual appeal with all manner of culinary sleight-of-hand. Flavor was almost accidental, at least in the hands of less skilled practitioners.
This approach never made sense to me, and fortunately nouvelle cuisine ran its course and was tossed aside.
In the 1980's, many of France's top chefs, including Paul Bocuse, Roger Verge, the Troigros brothers and Michel Guerard, to name a few, aimed their culinary rudders back toward the shores of traditional cuisine -- but with a contemporary outlook. Less butter, less cream, more olive oil, more vegetables, more steaming and broiling -- all gained currency in the name of lightness and health.
Then came the international recession of the late 1980's. In a funny way, this difficult period had a beneficial effect on cooking, in both Europe and the United States. In order to save money, chefs started experimenting with cheaper cuts of meat and underused species of fish. They re-examined regional home cooking, for example, the onion soup burgundy-style and crayfish fricassee that I knew growing up near Chablis.
About the same time, France expanded its vocational schooling system, which gives youngsters the chance to attend two years of cooking school, which includes apprenticeships in the kitchens of various restaurants and stints in the dining room.
This opportunity, as much as anything else, accounts for the astounding number of young people flooding into the restaurant business these days.
I encountered them everywhere in my journey, in all regions of France. Some were rising fast in the ranks of larger urban kitchens, others had already opened their own places in the countryside.
In the enchanting village of Biot, on the Cote d'Azur near Antibes, I was dazzled by the food and hospitality of Christian and Brigitte Metral, who own the restaurant L'Auberge du Jarrier. The establishment is at the end of a little passage in the heart of this Provencal village, which is known for its distinctive pottery (Jarrier refers to ceramic pots in the local dialect). Mr. Metral, who is in his early 30's, exemplifies the new style of updated traditional cooking, with sunny, generous Provencal fare that is attractive but never fussy-looking (Mrs. Metral tends to the dining room). My favorite dish there was his fillet of fish with potato scales, garnished with an a la minute sauce of tomatoes, garlic, lemon and nicoise olives.
In Chablis, which is about a half-hour's drive from my village, St. Vinnemer, I cooked with Michel Vignaud, who, with his wife, Sylvie, owns the Hostellerie des Clos, a renovated ancient hospital in the heart of Chablis village. His cooking blends much of the traditional food I recall from my youth in Burgundy, but with a distinctive modern accent.
His contemporary interpretations include a wonderful fricassee of crayfish served with blanched fresh peas and fava beans. I was particularly interested in this dish because, as a boy, I went to a nearby river and caught fresh crayfish. We would make a bundle of thorned twigs from a prunelle bush and hide chicken necks in them as bait; the crayfish would enter the twig bundle but could not get out. We'd boil them right there, with a bit of thyme, bay leaf and salt, let them cool to lukewarm and eat them with mayonnaise. Since then I have had a special fondness for crayfish.
Mr. Vignaud made a court bouillon with crayfish heads (there is really no substitute) and reduced the liquid way down rather than thickening it with cream. The finished dish, explosive with flavors and colors, is souplike in consistency -- but what a soup!
I have known Michel Chabran for more than a dozen years and have watched him progress into one of the most respected chefs of the Rhone valley. His luxuriant auberge and restaurant in Pont-de-l'Isere, north of Valence, is in the sun-drenched center of France's productive fruit region.
Mr. Chabran is a vibrant, athletic man -- aside from cooking, his passions are tennis and race-car driving -- and his cooking reflects this vitality. Because Mr. Chabran is in an area between Lyons and Provence, he finds himself cooking with the butter and cream of the former and the olive oil and garlic of the latter -- and often mixing them together. I find that melange appealing, from both health and flavor perspectives.
One of the recipes I brought back from Mr. Chabran is his extraordinary mashed potatoes blended with olive oil, cream and milk. The consistency is very loose, not at all like American-style mashed potatoes. The flavor is sublime. Another dish is a simple but delicious roasted monkfish (he sometimes uses sandre, a freshwater fish not generally available in the United States) roasted on the bone with a pan sauce of olive oil, carrots, onions, garlic, white wine and fish broth. It is meant to be served with the mashed potatoes.
Most of the monkfish in shops in the United States is sold as fillets; Mr. Chabran much prefers to cook it on the bone, which he feels adds flavor. If you would like to prepare it this way, it may require a special request at the store.
My travels also took me to Normandy, the lush, emerald-green land known for its butter, cream, cheese, cider, Calvados and much more. I wanted to visit a young chef whose reputation had spread far beyond this sea-swept region. In the town of Rouen I met Gilles Tournadre, who trained in Paris before returning and eventually opening Restaurant Gill. Mr. Tournadre, who is ably aided by his wife, Sylvie, is known for a lighter, herb-infused style of Norman cooking. Extensive use of fresh herbs is not something I had associated with Norman cooking, but it can be magnificent, as evidenced by his updated classic of duck with turnips.
In classical French cooking, a cut-up duck is browned and a dark sauce is made. Turnips are browned in butter and added to the braised duck at the last minute. Mr. Tournadre's version, to my taste, has almost an Indonesian flair, using magret (the breast of a fattened duck) that is blanched and then roasted with cloves, coriander, cumin, honey, vinegar and cider. It is an exciting, complex flavor sensation. Magret of duck is available in many markets and by mail order from D'Artagnan, 399-419 St. Paul Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., 07306; (800) 327-8246.
Many miles to the south, along the coast near La Rochelle, in the southwest of France, I visited some amazing mussel farms. The mussels there are cultivated on poles for 12 miles or so along the coast, about a half-mile out to sea. In little more than a year, the small (compared to those in the United States), plump, yellow-fleshed mussels are harvested -- and they are grit-free because they never touch the sand.
One of the best mussel dishes I tried was in the old port section of La Rochelle in a restaurant named after its chef, Richard Coutanceau. It was a version of mouclade, which in classic French cuisine means steamed mussels with shallots, white wine and cream, always based on a roux. Mr. Coutanceau follows the traditional recipe but adds curry and fresh thyme to the sauce, which is a lovely match to the sweet mussels.
They say all roads lead to Paris, and so did my long journey across France. Rather than visit the famed three-star establishments, I sought out new talent, restaurateurs who represented the trend I had discovered in the countryside. There were many: Andre Genin at Chez Pauline near the old Opera, Jacques Paul of the rustic and raucous A la Tour de Monthlhery in Les Halles, Gabriel Biscay of Laperouse, and Michel Rostang, who has a two-star luxury restaurant near the Arc de Triomphe, as well as two earthy bistros.
One that particularly impressed me was the wildly popular new Bistro La Regalade, in the Montparnasse neighborhood. The chef, Yves Candelaborde, serves up a robust menu of dishes from the southwest of France, replete with all of my favorite foods: tripe, andouillettes, chunky country terrines and pates, cured Bayonne hams, game and more.
One of the most heartening developments I noticed during my extraordinary journey was the number of bright, amiable young couples who are opening restaurants. Cooking, ultimately, is a family enterprise, and the scores of delightful young people I met along the road gave me reason for optimism that French cuisine, and France itself, is on a rebound.

Curried Mussels
(Adapted from Richard Coutanceau)
Total time: 40 minutes

 1 cup heavy cream
 1 tablespoon mild curry powder
 1 tablespoon freshly squeezed lemon juice
 3 tablespoons butter
 1/4 cup shallots sliced thin
 4 sprigs thyme
 1 bay leaf
 1 cup dry white wine
 9 cups mussels, cleaned (about 3 pounds)
 2 tablespoons flour
 Salt to taste.
1. Combine the cream, curry powder and lemon juice in a small bowl, and mix well. This step enables the curry flavor to develop.
2. Melt 1 tablespoon of the butter in a large pot over high heat, and add the shallots, thyme and bay leaf. Stir until wilted. Add the white wine and bring to a simmer. Add the mussels, cover and cook for 2 to 3 minutes, or just until the mussels open. Stir from time to time to assure even cooking. As soon as the mussels are opened, remove them from heat, and strain cooking liquid through a fine sieve into a bowl. Reserve 2 cups of the juice.
3. Remove the top shell from each mussel and discard it, leaving the mussel meat attached to its bottom shell. Arrange decoratively on a serving platter, and keep warm.
4. In a large saucepan, over medium heat, melt the remaining butter, and whisk in the flour, stirring until the mixture is smooth. Cook briefly; do not brown. Slowly add the 2 cups of reserved cooking juice, whisking constantly. Bring to a rolling boil. Add the cream-and-curry mixture, and combine well. Strain the sauce through a fine sieve. Add salt, and check for seasoning. Ladle the sauce over the mussels, and serve immediately.
Yield: 4 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 460 calories, 35 grams fat, 175 milligrams cholesterol, 480 milligrams sodium (before salting), 20 grams protein, 10 grams carbohydrate.
 
Roasted Monkfish
(Adapted from Michel Chabran)
Total time: 20 minutes

 2 pounds monkfish on the bone, head and skin removed
 Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
 1/2 cup olive oil
 1 carrot, cut in 1/4-inch cubes
 1 onion, coarsely chopped
 5 cloves garlic, unpeeled
 1 cup dry white wine
 1/2 cup fish broth (see recipe).
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees.
2. Season fish with salt and pepper.
3. Heat 2 tablespoons of the olive oil in a large nonstick skillet. Over high heat, cook one side of the fish until golden brown, about 1 minute. Turn, and brown the second side. Add carrot, onion, garlic, wine and fish broth, and simmer 2 to 3 minutes.
4. Transfer the contents of the skillet to an oven-proof baking dish, and cover tightly with aluminum foil. Roast for 5 minutes. Remove the fish to a serving platter and keep warm.
5. Meanwhile, in a saucepan, boil the cooking liquid and vegetables over high heat until reduced by half. Stir in the remaining olive oil to bind the sauce.
6. Spoon the sauce and vegetables over the fish, and serve with mashed potatoes.
Yield: 4 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 445 calories, 30 grams fat, 55 milligrams cholesterol, 80 milligrams sodium (before salting), 35 grams protein, 7 grams carbohydrate.
 
Fish Broth
Total time: 30 minutes

 3 pounds fresh fish bones, including the heads, gills removed
 6 cups water
 1 1/2 cups dry white wine
 1 cup sliced celery
 1 cup sliced onions
 1 cup sliced leeks, green portion only
 4 sprigs fresh parsley
 1 bay leaf
 1 teaspoon dried thyme
 6 whole peppercorns.
1. Chop the fish bones into thirds.
2. Combine all the ingredients in a kettle or saucepan. Bring the mixture to a boil, and simmer for 20 minutes. Strain and discard the solids. Leftover stock can be frozen.
Yield: 6 cups.
 
 Mashed Potatoes Flavored
With Olive Oil
(Adapted from Michel Chabran)
Total time: 45 minutes

 1 1/2 pounds Idaho or Washington potatoes, peeled and cut into 2-inch cubes
 2 cups milk or enough to cover
 Salt to taste
 1/2 cup heavy cream
 1/3 cup olive oil
 Freshly grated nutmeg to taste
 Freshly ground pepper to taste.
1. Place the potatoes and milk, salted to taste, in a large saucepan. Bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer, cover and cook 25 minutes.
2. Strain the potatoes and reserve the milk. Put the potatoes through a food mill or ricer, and transfer to a large saucepan.
3. Heat the cream and olive oil in a small saucepan, and add them to the potatoes, stirring well with a wooden spatula. To obtain a looser consistency, stir in some of the reserved hot milk. Season with grated nutmeg, salt and freshly ground pepper. Serve hot.
Yield: 4 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 420 calories, 30 grams fat, 50 milligrams cholesterol, 50 milligrams sodium (before salting), 5 grams protein, 30 grams carbohydrate.
 
Crayfish Fricassee
With Chablis
(Adapted from Michel Vignaud)
Total time: 90 minutes

For the court bouillon:
 
 1 cup coarsely chopped onions
 1 cup coarsely chopped carrots
 1/2 cup coarsely chopped celery
 1/4cup coarsely chopped shallots
 1 bouquet garni in cheesecloth consisting of 1 sprig thyme, 1 sprig parsley, 1 bay leaf
 12 black peppercorns
 1/4 cup vinegar
 Salt to taste
 4 pounds fresh crayfish (heads reserved for sauce).
 
For the sauce:
 
 Reserved crayfish heads
 2 tablespoons butter
 1/3 cup coarsely chopped carrots
 1/3 cup coarsely chopped leeks
 1/3 cup coarsely chopped celery, plus 2 ribs
 1/2 cup peeled, seeded and coarsely chopped tomato
 1 cup white Chablis wine.
 
Assembling the dish:
 
 4 tablespoons butter
 1 tablespoon finely chopped sweet red pepper
 1/4 cup diced carrots
 1/4 cup diced celery
 1/2 cup Chablis white wine
 4 tablespoons fresh peas, blanched
 4 tablespoons fava beans, blanched and skinned
 Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
 4 sprigs fresh tarragon for garnish.
1. Prepare the court bouillon. In a large pot, place the onions, carrots, celery, shallots, bouquet garni, peppercorns, vinegar, salt and 12 cups of water. Bring to a boil and simmer about 5 minutes.
2. Meanwhile, to prepare crayfish, take them, one-by-one, in the palm of your hand, belly up. With the thumb and forefinger of the other hand, remove the middle, fanlike appendage at the end of the tail, which is connected to the intestines. Pulling it out gently will remove the bitter, black intestine.
3. Add the crayfish to the simmering court bouillon. Cover, and bring the liquid back to a boil. Remove the crayfish from the bouillon immediately. Allow them to cool briefly so that they can be handled for shelling.
4. Reserve 4 whole crayfish with shells on for decoration. To shell the rest, gently separate the head section from the tail section. Reserve heads for the sauce. Remove the tail meat in one piece from its casing by squeezing the shell gently to loosen it and then gently pulling away each ring of the tail shell, one by one.
5. To make the sauce, crush reserved crayfish heads using a kitchen mallet.
6. In a large saucepan melt the butter, and add the carrots, leeks, chopped celery and tomato. Cook, stirring, over medium heat. Add the crayfish heads, and continue to cook about 5 minutes. Add the wine, 2 cups water and the 2 celery ribs. Simmer for 15 minutes. Strain through a fine sieve and reserve.
7. To assemble the dish, heat 1 tablespoon of the butter in a medium-size saucepan and add the sweet red pepper, carrots and celery. Cook, stirring, over medium heat, about 3 minutes. Add wine, and continue to cook until the liquid is reduced by half. Add the crayfish sauce, and cook until the liquid is reduced by half. Whisk in the remaining butter over medium heat, being careful not to let the sauce return to a boil.
8. Add peas and fava beans, and continue to cook only until ingredients are heated through. Check for seasoning, and sprinkle with salt and pepper.
9. Divide shelled crayfish evenly among 4 warmed soup plates. Pour sauce over them. Top each serving with a whole crayfish in the shell, and decorate with a sprig of tarragon.
Yield: 4 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 355 calories, 20 grams fat, 290 milligrams cholesterol, 390 milligrams sodium (before salting), 35 grams protein, 9 grams carbohydrate.
 
 Duck Breasts With Turnips
And Eastern Spices
(Adapted from Gilles Tournadre)
Total time: 40 minutes

 2 medium, round white turnips, about 1/3 pound each
 2 duck breasts, like magret, skin on, about 6 ounces each
 2 tablespoons coriander seeds
 2 whole cloves
 2 teaspoons cumin seeds
 Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
 4 tablespoons natural honey
 3 tablespoons white vinegar
 1 cup hard cider, or 1/2 cup dry white wine
 1 cup fresh chicken broth or good canned version
 2 sprigs flat leaf parsley.
1. Trim the ends of the turnips and peel them. Cut into 1/4-inch slices.
2. Place the duck breasts and the turnips in a large saucepan, and cover with boiling water. Cook, simmering, over low heat for one minute. Remove the duck breast, and cook the turnips two minutes longer. Remove the turnips, and place the duck breasts and the turnips into an ice-water bath to prevent them from cooking further. When cool, remove the duck and the turnips. Pat the duck dry with a paper towel. Using a sharp knife, remove the thick, excess fat, leaving a thin layer of fat underneath. Score the surface of the fat diagonally.
3. Grind the coriander, clove and cumin by placing them on a cutting board and crushing them with a heavy sauce pan. This can also be done in a spice mill, but be careful not yo grind them too finely -- you want a crunchy texture to the spice crust.
4. Meanwhile, season the duck breast with salt and pepper. Place in a skillet over medium-high heat, skin side down, until lightly browned, about 2 minutes. Add the turnips, turning them from time to time, and continue cooking another 2 minutes. Remove the duck and turnips from the skillet, and pour off the fat. Pat the skin of the duck with paper towels to absorb any excess fat.
5. In the same skillet, combine the honey and white vinegar. Bring to a boil, stirring constantly, until the mixture begins to caramelize lightly and evenly. Add the ground spices while stirring. Be careful not to burn. Remove the skillet from the heat. Return duck breasts to the skillet, fatty side down. Move them around in the pan to coat them with the spice mixture. Remove the duck, and keep warm.
6. Return the skillet to medium-high heat, and add the cider. Cook, scraping the side and bottom of the pan, until all the brown particles are dissolved. Add the chicken broth, and bring to a simmer. Add the duck breasts, fatty side up, and place the turnips around them. Simmer for about 3 to 4 minutes. Remove the duck and keep warm. The meat should be pink in the center.
7. Bring the sauce and the turnips to a boil and cook until reduced by more than half, until the sauce has thickened to a syrupy consistency.
8. Cut the breasts on a bias into thin slices. Arrange the slices of the breasts in a fan shape in the center of a warm serving plate. Garnish with turnip slices, and spoon the sauce around. Garnish with parsley.
Yield: 2 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 340 calories, 7 grams fat, 1 milligram cholesterol, 520 milligrams sodium (before salting), 25 grams protein, 45 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Yankees Are Shut Out As Olson Picks Braves

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
If Gregg Olson returns to form as a superb closer, if he overcomes a troubling right elbow injury and performs splendidly for the Atlanta Braves this season, the Yankees will remember the frigid day in February when he auditioned for them at Yankee Stadium. And they will wince.
The Yankees' chance to make Olson a possible cure for their bullpen woes vanished yesterday when the Braves proved more appealing and signed the right-hander to a one-year, incentive-laden contract that could be worth as much as $3.5 million. 
 The Yankees had made a two-year offer loaded with incentives, but Olson chose Atlanta over New York, Toronto and California because with the Braves he will be the primary closer on a pennant-contending team. That was important for Olson because he also set himself up to become a free agent after the 1994 season.
"At this stage of his career, he and I feel that changing to a new team in a different league is appropriate," said Jeff Moorad, Olson's agent. "In the end, we focused on the opportunity of joining the Braves over the economics of it."
Although Moorad would not divulge the specifics of New York's offer, he conceded it included a low base salary and several incentives, which is what Olson accepted from Atlanta on a one-year basis.
Olson, who earned $2.3 million while saving 29 games for Baltimore last season, will receive $500,000 for signing with the three-time National League Western Division champions, $1 million more if he makes the Braves and could earn another $2 million in bonuses based on appearances. Olson would receive $25,000 for each of his first 40 appearances and $50,000 each for appearances 41 to 60. If the 27-year-old Olson matches his average of 62 appearances over the last five years, he will make the $3.5 million.
Not only that, but if Olson pitches often enough to cash in all his incentives, the doubts about the strained elbow that bothered him for the final two months of 1993 also would be erased and he would be quite attractive as a free agent.
Olson, the only relief pitcher to have 20 or more saves in his first five major league seasons, could make the Yankees rue their decision.
"I won't dwell on not getting him," said Manager Buck Showalter. "I think everybody knows he's a good pitcher if he's healthy. But that's a big question. It's quite a risk for a team."
 
Farr's Hopes Rise
 By waiting three days after Olson tested his elbow for them last Friday before they made an offer, it is obvious the Yankees were somewhat reluctant to take the risk. Now, Olson's signing with Atlanta should reopen the clubhouse door in the Bronx for 37-year-old Steve Farr, who became a free agent when the Yankees did not offer him arbitration five days after the World Series and who would not be as expensive as Olson.
But Steve Fehr, one of Farr's representatives, said yesterday that the Yankees had not made any new contact regarding his client. General Manager Gene Michael did not return telephone messages for comment on Farr's possible re-signing, and said through a subordinate, "There's nothing going on."
Olson was the American League rookie of the year with Baltimore in 1989, when he had a 1.69 earned run average and 27 saves. A year later, he had 37 saves, and over all, he has a 2.26 e.r.a. with 160 saves in 191 opportunities.
No matter. After making a out of unsuccessfully pursuing starting pitchers this off season, the Yankees added a twist by failing to secure a relief pitcher.
The Yankees were moderately interested in Tim Belcher before he signed with Detroit on Monday, then lost out on Olson yesterday.
"Maybe George will see this and do something," Showlater said, referring to owner George Steinbrenner. "Or maybe he'll just say we should go with what we have."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 KEVIN MAAS , the first baseman-designated hitter for whom there does not seem to be a roster spot, lost his arbitration case yesterday and must settle for a salary of $425,000. Maas, who made $255,000 last year while batting .205 in 151 times up, with 9 home runs and 25 runs batted in, had been seeking $490,000. . . . Second baseman PAT KELLY is the only Yankee left in arbitration and his case will be heard next Monday.

HEADLINE: China's Bad Report Card

 BODY:
The State Department's annual review of human rights paints a grim picture of China's police state, documenting torture, forced confessions and long imprisonment for ideological "crimes." The White House must decide this spring on China's continued access to low American tariffs; the report is a reminder of how far Beijing still has to go to meet the conditions President Clinton set down in an executive order last May.
That order set only two firm conditions: that China ease restrictions on emigration and comply with its own promises to stop exporting goods made by enslaved prisoners. It also called on Beijing to demonstrate significant progress on releasing political prisoners, ending forced abortion and sterilization, easing religious persecution, allowing medical treatment for prisoners, protecting Tibet's cultural heritage and stopping the jamming of Voice of America broadcasts. 
 For the Administration, and for most human rights activists, renewal of trade privileges is the goal, but not if Beijing makes a mockery of reasonable U.S. conditions. The Administration's final decision will most likely hinge on three things: the fate of some 100 political prisoners about whom Washington has expressed special concern; negotiations for Red Cross inspections of Chinese prison camps, and China's follow-through on its agreement to allow U.S. inspection of sites where the production of slave labor exports has been alleged.
Beijing has made some promising human rights gestures in the early weeks of this year, so it is reasonable to hope that renewal will be possible, though probably some conditions will still need to be attached.
Some argue -- correctly -- that China's continued economic contact with the West has a positive influence on human rights, and that to end China's trade privileges would isolate further those Chinese who are struggling for democracy.
However, the U.S. now buys one-third of China's exports and provides Beijing with its only significant hard currency. To lose trade privileges would be a severe blow for Beijing; America has a lot more leverage over China than it ever exercised in the years of George Bush's Presidency.
The challenge for President Clinton is to balance America's humane values with legitimate U.S. business and strategic interests, including the need for Chinese cooperation in discouraging North Korea from developing nuclear weapons. The best way to achieve that balance is to keep human rights demands modest and achievable. Mr. Clinton's 1993 executive order did that. The rest is up to Beijing.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: More Is the Pity at the Pentagon

 BODY:
With all the talk about budget cuts, the Pentagon is actually scheduled to get more money next year. The Clinton Administration is seeking $264 billion in defense spending authority for 1995, up $2.8 billion from 1994.
Advocates of higher defense spending explain away the rise as reflecting a military pay increase voted by Congress. But the sadder truth is that the Administration refused to reduce Pentagon programs enough, despite the end of the cold war. By preparing to wage two regional wars simultaneously, the Administration is still setting force requirements too high. That will put upward pressure on the budget for many years to come. 
 President Clinton is admittedly in a bind. If he cuts defense too much, he will trigger a fight with Congressional hawks at a time when he needs their support on more urgent domestic issues. And if he further cuts the flow of funds to defense contractors, he could plunge California deeper into recession, jeopardizing his electoral chances in that pivotal state. But with civilian investment desperately short of money, Mr. Clinton needs to prune more out of the bloated defense budget.
The Administration says that spending on new weapons will go down $1.4 billion next year. But that reduction is less than it seems. Few new weapons systems were canceled outright -- the notable exceptions are the Navy's A/F-X aircraft, the Air Force's multirole fighter and a few of the many helicopter programs. Instead, procurements have been postponed or stretched out, which will only increase the price per weapon.
The new Secretary of Defense, William Perry, says flatly, "There are no cold war relics in the budget." But that is flat wrong. Another Seawolf attack submarine will be built, a cold war relic if there ever was one. The purpose of attack submarines once was to protect against Soviet ships and submarines so that American reinforcements could be shipped to Europe in the event of war. With the collapse of the Soviet Union, who is left to challenge U.S. naval supremacy?
The biggest cold war relic of all is the excessive size of American forces. The U.S. still has 19 divisions of ground troops -- 10 active-duty and 5 reserve in the Army, 3 active and 1 reserve in the Marines. It still has 35 air wings in the Air Force, Navy and Marines, 26 of them on active duty. And it still has 12 aircraft carriers -- one of them for training. These force levels differ little from those set by the Bush Administration in 1990 -- before the disintegration of the Soviet Union.
A new aircraft carrier, which will cost $4.5 billion to build and billions more to equip and man, is also a cold war relic of sorts. If the Navy were appropriately reduced to 9 or 10 carrier battle groups, it would be retiring old carriers instead of building new ones.
The Administration is planning to spend nearly as much on defense next year as the rest of the world combined. If it maintains all its current programs, it will face pressure to spend even more on them in the future. Unless Mr. Clinton finds the courage to trim defense, he will be forced to shortchange domestic investment for years to come.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Crown Heights Coalition Has Done Much to Heal Community

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Crown Hts. Tension Persists Despite Healing Effort" (news article, Jan. 27) does a disservice to efforts to heal Brooklyn's Crown Heights community. Minimizing the work of the Crown Heights Coalition adds fuel to those who seek to foment unrest. 
 In the wake of the summer 1991 unrest, the coalition of African-American, Caribbean-American and Hasidic community leaders was the first group to investigate the causes of violence. They recommended improvements in police-community relations, cultural understanding, youth services and economic opportunities.
The coalition lobbied City Hall for programs and services outlined in "Crown Heights: A Strategy for the Future," a comprehensive report. Coalition initiatives, which have resulted in measurable improvements in public safety, employment and recreation for Crown Heights, have been lauded by former Mayor David Dinkins and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani.
As a result of the coalition's work, the 71st Precinct received its full complement of community policing officers three years ahead of schedule. Crown Heights police officers receive additional cultural diversity and anti-bias training. "Safe corridors" have been established to protect high school students traveling to and from school. The Department of Employment has started a new Testing Assessment and Placement Center in the area. The St. John's Recreation Center has reopened with many new programs.
It is difficult to understand why anyone would want to dismiss these and other valuable programs that have been implemented at the coalition's strong urging. The coalition is working with the next generation -- our youth -- to eradicate and avoid precisely this type of cynical attitude.
The coalition remains a strong and forceful entity in Crown Heights. It meets regularly to deal with divisive issues in the community.
For example, the coalition, which early called for a Federal investigation of the Yankel Rosenbaum murder, continues to monitor the case. Bringing the murderers to justice is a priority for the entire community.
The coalition is also working to resolve a dispute raised over this year's West Indian-American Day Parade and the Jewish observance of the eve of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, which coincide on Labor Day. That the coalition has not yet told the press about these efforts does not mean that it is not addressing the problem.
 
HOWARD GOLDEN
 (Rabbi) SHEA HECHT
 EDISON O. JACKSON
 Brooklyn, Feb. 1, 1994
