HEADLINE: In Bomb Plot Trial: A Blizzard of Evidence

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
After more than four months of testimony, the Government rested its case yesterday against the four defendants in the World Trade Center trial. Given the 207 witnesses the prosecution called to the stand and the 1,003 exhibits presented to the jury, it is clear what the prosecutors have attempted to do: they have produced an avalanche of circumstantial evidence with which they have tried to bury the defendants.
But the Government's avalanche has seemed uneven, crushingly thick and heavy in many places, thin in others, and weighing differently on each defendant. 
 Over all, the prosecution has attempted to narrate the story of a bomb plot that started with the arrival in this country of a mysterious Iraqi named Ramzi Ahmed Yousef on Sept. 1, 1992. According to the prosecution, Mr. Yousef brought with him the plans to carry out what has since been called the single most devastating terror attack ever committed on American soil.
While officially a defendant in the case, Mr. Yousef left the country the very day of the trade center explosion and was not on trial. But, the prosecution's long and sometimes tedious parade of witnesses delivered seemingly damaging information about the four men who are.
It appeared to establish, despite defense lawyers' unwillingness to concede the point, that the explosion that ripped through the six underground floors of the World Trade Center, killing six people and injuring more than 1,000, was caused by a bomb. And it seemed to show that the explosive was carried into the trade center in a yellow Ryder van that was rented by the lead defendant in the case, Mohammad A. Salameh, who appears to have acted in close association with Mr. Yousef.
Witnesses have also given powerful testimony that Mr. Salameh rented a storage locker at 69 Mallory Avenue in Jersey City where two other defendants, one of them Mr. Yousef, had chemicals delivered in the months before the trade center blast that could have been used to make the explosive.
But, in attempting to create a plausible bombing plot, the Government's lawyers have run into difficulties. The biggest problem has been what they do not have: a witness who could place the defendants in the trade center at the time of the blast. Beyond that, some witnesses did not come through with unambiguous identifications.
Perhaps more important, prosecutors never found a way to establish a critical link in the case: Its witnesses were unable to say exactly what caused the explosion on Feb. 26, and thus witnesses could only infer that the chemicals found in Mr. Salameh's storage locker were the same as those used to make the trade center bomb.
Yesterday, as the defendants' lawyers cross-examined the Government's final witness, David R. Williams, an F.B.I. bomb expert, they wasted no time in making that point.
"You realize that there was an expert chemist who testified that he cannot determine the cause of the explosion?" Hassen Ibn Abdellah, the lawyer for Mahmud Abouhalima, asked Mr. Williams.
"Yes," Mr. Williams replied.
"So you're trying to draw an inference that because these items were found at 69 Mallory Avenue that they must have been the items that were used in the World Trade Center?"
"They could have been used," Mr. Williams said.
 
Overlapping Evidence
 The prosecution's carefully constructed case seems intended to overcome any weaknesses by producing a huge volume of overlapping evidence, so that even if any single point is subject to doubt, the avalanche will prevent any of the defendants from wriggling free. It seems that in the case against some defendants, the closing arguments that will be made by both prosecutors and defense lawyers in the next week or so may prove decisive. These, meanwhile, are the main elements in the prosecution's case against each of the four men on trial.
 
Mohammad A. Salameh
 Much of the Government's case has centered on the activities of this 26-year-old Palestinian immigrant, against whom prosecutors have managed to compile the heaviest layer of circumstantial evidence. Mr. Salameh was the first to be mentioned in the Government's case, as the renter of the yellow Ford Econoline van whose shattered remains were found in the trade center wreckage.
He also rented an apartment at 40 Pamrapo Avenue in Jersey City, where, according to several witnesses, chemicals that could have been used to make the bomb were mixed, leaving telltale blue stains on what had been white walls. Mr. Salameh also rented the locker at the Space Station Self Storage Company where similar chemicals were delivered. Two workers at the Space Station testified that they saw Mr. Salameh accept delivery of three hydrogen tanks of exactly the sort that were found, in fragments, after the explosion.
 
Bought Chemicals
 Mr. Salameh's fingerprints were found on a World Trade Center parking stub dated Feb. 24, two days before the explosion. He was often seen in the presence of Mr. Yousef, who has emerged in testimony as the apparent on-the-scene mastermind of the bombing plot. Mr. Yousef, the testimony has shown, helped to buy chemicals for the Space Station locker and was often seen there.
He was said to have have lived with Mr. Salameh at the apartment on Pamrapo Avenue. He was in an accident in a car that Mr. Salameh was driving and that had been rented by another defendant, Nidal A. Ayyad. Finally, Mr. Salameh was identified by one witness as having bought gas for the yellow Ryder van nine hours before the trade center explosion, and several hours after Mr. Salameh reported the same van stolen.
In cross-examination, Mr. Salameh's lawyer, Robert E. Precht, has tried to remove the sting from the evidence by suggesting that Mr. Salameh may have done the things he is alleged to have done because somebody else asked him to do them, suggesting that he may not have known the purpose. For example, Mr. Salameh says that he rented the Ryder van to help a friend move some furniture, but then reported it stolen the night before prosecutors say it appeared, loaded with a 1,200- to 1,600-pound bomb, in the World Trade Center's underground parking garage.
Was the van really stolen, or was Mr. Salameh's report faked to provide an alibi? Could he have rented the Space Station locker and taken delivery of chemicals without knowing what they were for? Does the presence of explosive chemicals in the locker mean that those same chemicals were used to make the bomb that blew up in the trade center, a bomb whose components could not be ascertained by investigators? Those are the questions for the jury.
 
Nidal A. Ayyad
 In many ways, this 27-year-old naturalized American citizen of Palestinian origin had the most to lose. He had married and had a child shortly before the explosion. He had earned a degree in chemistry from Rutgers University and embarked on a promising career at the Allied Signal Corporation in Morristown, N.J. He supported a younger brother and his mother, who lived with him at 60 Boyden Avenue in Woodbridge, N.J.
Mr. Ayyad's lawyer, Atiq Ahmed, stressed these facets of Mr. Ayyad's life in his cross-examination, arguing that his client was not a likely terrorist. But the prosecution has presented some apparently devastating testimony.
Several witnesses identified Mr. Ayyad as the man who bought, or tried to buy, chemicals of the sort later delivered to the Space Station. One chemical company owner said that he twice saw Mr. Ayyad pick up orders of lead nitrate, an ingredient in the making of lead azide, often used to initiate explosive charges. Two witnesses said that Mr. Ayyad tried to buy explosives even after the trade center bombing, suggesting that he had already embarked on another unspecified bomb plot.
Then there were telephone calls and letters taking credit for the bombing, which, testimony suggested, appeared to have come from Mr. Ayyad. One witness said he was sure that it was Mr. Ayyad's voice that was recorded in such a call made to The Daily News the day after the explosion. A DNA analysis of saliva found on an envelope mailed to The New York Times with a similar claim matched Mr. Ayyad's saliva, though it could have also matched the saliva of many other people.
Investigators found in Mr. Ayyad's computer at Allied Signal the text of still another message warning that more bombings would be committed "if our demands are not met."
 
Mahmud Abouhalima
 The Government probably ended up with more questions than it could have anticipated in its case against this Egyptian-born limousine driver. That is largely because Mr. Abouhalima, accused of helping to mix the explosives and transport the bomb, was supposed to have been identified in court by a gas station attendant who told investigators that he saw Mr. Abouhalima, Mr. Salameh and the fugitive defendant, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, together just hours before the explosion. The witness, Willie Hernandez Moosh, said that the three men came in a dark Lincoln Town Car and the Ryder rental van to get gasoline early on the morning of Feb. 26.
But Mr. Moosh provided the trial with its most bizarrely funny moment when, instead of picking out the red-haired Mr. Abouhalima as the man he had seen that night, he pointed to a red-haired juror. Then, asked whether he recognized another man, the man driving the van that night, whom he had indicated was Mr. Salameh, he picked out a second juror. Only later, when Mr. Moosh's testimony continued the next day, did he say that he had made a mistake, and pointed to both Mr. Abouhalima and Mr. Salameh as the men he saw that night. The question is whether his later identifications will be believed by jurors who saw him make clear mistakes only one day before.
Still, Mr. Abouhalima was identified by two other witnesses in other contexts. One said that he came to visit Mr. Salameh and Mr. Yousef in an apartment that they had rented at 34 Kensington Avenue in Jersey City. The driver of a tow truck also identified Mr. Abouhalima as the man who picked up Mr. Salameh's car at a garage after Mr. Salameh and Mr. Yousef were in a traffic accident.
Other witnesses, while they did not point to Mr. Abouhalima in court, said they saw "a big guy" with red hair carrying large buckets and other things from the Pamrapo Avenue apartment. Finally, investigators found sulfuric acid burns on a shoe discovered in a carton in the basement of Mr. Abouhalima's home. Sulfuric acid was one of the chemicals presumably used by the bomb makers.
Mr. Abouhalima's defense lawyers have touched on two points in their cross-examinations: one, that knowing Mr. Salameh and Mr. Yousef does not prove that Mr. Abouhalima participated in any plot together with them; second, sulfuric acid can end up on a shoe if you spill the liquid from a car battery, and Mr. Abouhalima made his living as a limousine driver. Finally, even though Mr. Moosh eventually, on his second day, did point out Mr. Abouhalima, would the jury be willing to send a man to life in prison based on a shaky identification?
 
Ahmad A. Ajaj
 The case against Mr. Ajaj, a Palestinian who has applied for political asylum, seems weakest, if only because he was in prison for the six months immediately before the bomb exploded, after he tried to enter the country on a return trip from Pakistan with an altered Swedish passport.
Yet the prosecution has kicked up a swirl of suspicion around Mr. Salameh. When he entered the country on Sept. 1, 1992, he was carrying four passports under four different names, along with several other fake identity cards. He had six volumes of military manuals that showed how to make a bomb using the same materials that were later found by investigators in the Space Station locker. On some pages in two of the manuals, Mr. Yousef's fingerprints were found. Mr. Ajaj also had two videotapes made by something called the International Islamic Resistance that showed how to make bombs.
But do these things show, as the prosecution claims, that Mr. Ajaj came to this country intending to participate in the trade center bombing? Mr. Ajaj's lawyer, Austin Campriello, is expected to try to show that Mr. Ajaj was an Islamic militant involved in the conflict in Afghanistan, but not in the trade center bomb plot. The jury would be asked to decide if that explanation is plausible.

An article yesterday about the prosecution's case in the World Trade Center bombing trial misidentified a defendant at one point. It was Ahmad A. Ajaj, not Mohammad A. Salameh, who was arrested when he entered the country on Sept. 1, 1992, carrying four passports under different names.

HEADLINE: Taste of Middle-Class Pay for Welfare Mothers

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 9

 BODY:
At 4:30 in the morning, when no one is up but the drug dealers, Charlene Franklin is pulling herself out of bed. In the darkness of her South Side housing project, she puts on her grimy brogans and yellow hard hat, kisses her six sleeping children goodbye and braves bullets and envy to earn a paycheck beyond a welfare mother's wildest dreams.
For $13.52 an hour, Mrs. Franklin paints, plumbs, plasters, scrapes, scrubs, sweeps, hangs doors and lays tile to make abandoned public housing units, stripped by vandals and gang members, habitable again. It is the first real job she has ever had.
 
Power of a Consumer
 She works with a team of other former welfare recipients in a pilot project, Step Up, which uses Federal housing rehabilitation money to train poor residents in construction jobs. 
 Now that she is making more money than just about anyone else in the neighborhood and has come to accept the inevitability of taxes and the high cost of breakfast cereal, she has come to the conclusion of just about every employee in America: "The more you make, the more you need," she said.
While Congress and the White House prepare to wrangle over ways to put welfare recipients to work, the Step Up program is quietly transforming the lives of a small group of housing residents in Chicago and elsewhere, who the program's officials have discovered will work for the same incentive other people do: money.
The program is in the very earliest stages, and it is not yet clear how easily it can be duplicated. Also, the program's primary goal of moving trainees into private jobs is limited by the market for construction workers in general.
But would-be workers appear desperate to get on someone's payroll. When the Chicago Housing Authority held a jobs call in the fall of 1992, 1,200 residents, many of them high school dropouts and welfare recipients who had never worked before, showed up for 300 training slots. To be hired, they had to pass a drug test, be able to read at sixth-grade level and show that they were on a public housing lease.
To make the program possible, the Department of Housing and Urban Development established a new job category to satisfy Federal restrictions on who can work on Federal job sites. It also had to persuade trade unions to cooperate with housing authorities, with inducements being an agreement to hire union members to train residents and the idea that unions could add to their numbers.
The Chicago Housing Authority made sure that the trainees did not lose their Medicaid benefits and that their rents did not go up. The participants receive no other public assistance while in the program.
The trainees went to work in late 1992, carrying out renovations that were part of the housing agency's regular program to repair vacant apartments. They have completed 1,551apartments in half a dozen housing projects in the last 16 months.
 
Lessons for Losers, Too
 In that time, some of the trainees have gotten their high school equivalency diplomas. Some women have started fixing themselves up, wearing makeup instead of rollers so they look like people who earn $13.52 an hour. Some of the men have teamed up with journeymen to work private jobs on weekends. Some now have credit cards, new curtains and dinette tables and a whole new set of problems: relatives wanting money and resentful neighbors who no longer speak to them.
But a third of the trainees never adjusted to the rigors of work and were dismissed, mostly for absenteeism. Some still call or show up begging in vain to get their jobs back. Even they, program officials insist, have learned a valuable lesson about life in the real world.
The program is being duplicated on a smaller scale in Baltimore, Phoenix and Huntington, W. Va.
To get residents to have middle-class dreams in the ambitious Chicago program, Vincent Lane, the chairman of the Chicago Housing Authority, decided to pay the trainees middle-class salaries. Mr. Lane said he needed to extend as big a carrot as possible to change the residents' way of thinking.
"Five dollars an hour is no incentive," Mr. Lane said. "They need to know what it tastes like to be able to put some money in the bank, to get beyond just surviving."
The work is hard and the conditions often dangerous. There have been times when Mrs. Franklin and her co-workers have had to stay at work late, not because their team was running behind, but because gang members were shooting outside the building.
 
A Natural for Public Housing
 Such incidents do not keep Mrs. Franklin from work. A grandmother at 31, she is her family's sole breadwinner and one of the few residents at the Robert Taylor Homes who gets a paycheck instead of food stamps. The unemployment rate there is 96 percent. Everyone in her family knows when pay day comes. "Soon as I get home, the hands are out," she said.
In many ways, Step Up is a natural job-training program for public housing, officials say. There are thousands of abandoned units around the country, millions of tenants with no skills or chance of getting them, and $3 billion in Federal rehabilitation money to pay whoever does the work.
One problem is the jobs are not permanent, because the housing authority wants to open slots for new trainees. The agency is trying to place the current trainees in formal union apprenticeships before taking on new participants. But there are no guarantees.
"If this is their only shot and they get 18 months of these wages and are back on public aid, it's a hard fall," said Doug Dobmeyer, executive director of the Public Welfare Coalition, an Illinois welfare advocacy group.
 
Vision of Better Things
 But even if the jobs do not prove permanent, Mr. Dobmeyer and others argue that with money, as with love, it is better to have had a taste than none at all. Kate Williams, executive director of Women for Economic Security, an advocacy group for women on welfare, said, "It will give all of them a vision of how things could be."
The goal, Mr. Lane said, is to entice the trainees into independence from the housing authority.
The money and dignity have indeed been seductive. Stephanie Stewart started paying her rent three months ahead of time and finally got a telephone. Melinda Powell got a car, a 1983 Oldsmobile. Jocelyn Denton bought a yellow floral sofa that no one in the family can sit on because it is for company. Mrs. Franklin bought a washing machine. And almost all of the trainees have fixed up their apartments, plastering walls and replacing sinks, now that they know how.
Mrs. Denton, the mother of five, has not missed a day at work and makes it her business to arrive half an hour early. There have been times when she has not felt like working, days when she had a bad cold or when it was 20-below-zero and her children said, "Mama, it's so cold out there, you're going to freeze."
She is giddy these days with the sense of mastery. "I can cut doors, I can hang dry wall, I can change a receptacle," Mrs. Denton said, suddenly smiling and catching herself. "Oh, I'm sorry -- you call it an outlet."
 
Envy Is No Bother
 Mrs. Franklin's neighbors do not speak to her anymore. Envy, that's all, she said. "It don't bother me," she said. "I'm doing this for me. They're not going to feed my kids if I can't."
It was not always this way. The residents came in as raw recruits unaccustomed to taking directions or accounting for their whereabouts.
"We're teaching them not just a skill but how to be an employee," said Bettye Vance, the program's director. "We had to let them know that employers are not interested in where you live and what your problems are. You don't bring that to work."
The jobs corrupted some already shaky relationships as the rituals of welfare check day -- men waiting outside the projects to get money from the women -- began to play out every other Friday when Step Up women get paid. One woman's estranged husband moved back in with her after she got the Step Up job. When she became pregnant, he left again. She then dropped out of the program.
Of the original 298 trainees, 50 have finished the program and have been hired by the Chicago Housing Authority at $19 an hour to remove lead from the projects or as clerks with pay comparable to Step Up's or truck drivers at about $18 an hour. Eighteen are in training for union carpentry apprenticeships, which requires four years.
But twice that many people have been let go, including 64 who were dismissed for poor attendance. Eight were dismissed because they showed up for work drunk or high on drugs. Nine were dismissed for misconduct, usually for fighting on the job, while one was let go for taking a co-worker on a joy ride in the middle of the day.
The program graduates show its possibilities. Melinda Powell, who was on welfare for 14 years before enrolling in Step Up, is a tax-paying, card-carrying member of the Laborers' Union Local No. 1, making $19 an hour removing lead from public housing projects and now worrying about things like retirement savings and bank fees.
"Step Up kind of put a light on things," Ms. Powell said. "It was time to get off public aid, raise my kids, maybe send them off to college and meet my destiny."
The trainees are neither symbols nor window-dressing, the supervisors say. Some apartments needing renovation had been stripped to the studs, walls torn out between units by gang members so they could get to the stairwells more quickly, and everything from toilet pipes to switch-plates stripped by vandals for scrap metal.
The women do most of the work and the journeymen mostly watch, field supervisors say. The teams of trainees can renovate a gutted apartment in two or three days, compared with seven days for government contractors.
The other morning, Debra Webster was plastering a hallway wall. Mrs. Franklin was painting a bedroom. Dora Edwards was learning how to replace a sink. Gwendolyn Stanley was crouched on the floor, installing an electrical outlet near the kitchen, as Gary Anderson, a journeyman electrician, watched.
The journeymen say the trainees are as good as the professionals now. "She can wire my house any time," Mr. Anderson said of Ms. Stanley.
But the women have their own problems to worry about. For four months, Mrs. Edwards learned about painting from the painter and carpentry from the carpenter, but was going home to an apartment where she and her five children had to bathe in the dark with the bathroom door cracked open for light. The wires behind the light fixture were burned out and the authority's maintenance people never managed to get around to it.
Finally, Mrs. Edwards was assigned to work with the journeyman electrician, who taught her about electrical outlets. She went home that day to try out what she learned. Now there is light.

HEADLINE: Japanese Chief, Due in the U.S., Faces 'Impasse'

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 9

 BODY:
From the first time they met seven months ago, a new American President and Japan's most prominent reformer, Bill Clinton and Morihiro Hosokawa agreed that their countries needed a radically new way to deal with each other.
Neither Washington nor Tokyo could afford to continue the bickering, stonewalling and threats of retaliation, they said, that have gradually poisoned the trade relations between the two countries for a decade. Aides of both men kept talking enthusiastically about their special bond, two young Southern governors, both with a mandate for reform and a common outlook on the world. This time, everyone said, things would be different.
 
Everything at 'an Impasse'
 But just a day before Prime Minister Hosokawa flies off for his first trip to Washington -- the White House, Capitol Hill and Georgetown University in 36 hours -- very few are talking that way anymore. After three weeks of lurching from one crisis to another that threatened to oust him from office, Mr. Hosokawa admitted to Japanese reporters today that the negotiations over carrying out a broad new "framework" for trade relations between the two countries had gotten nowhere. 
 "Everything has come to an impasse," he said. The two sides have yet to move beyond a fundamental disagreement on how to measure progress -- an issue that was papered over in July, left for later resolution.
Later has arrived. In a frenzy of last minute activity, Mr. Hosokawa sent a secret envoy, Akitane Kiuchi, a former ambassador to several countries, to see President Clinton late Tuesday to plead for more time. His presence was disclosed by American officials. The Prime Minister's intentions are good, Mr. Kiuchi said, but his coalition Government is in such chaos than he cannot yet deliver.
American officials say the special envoy had been politely told by both Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore that six months of negotiations had been plenty of time for the Japanese Government to get its house in order. Mr. Kiuchi, a close friend and adviser of the Prime Minister's, rushed back to Tokyo early today in time to brief Mr. Hosokowa before he departs for Washington and the summit meeting Friday with Mr. Clinton.
American officials said that when Mr. Kiuchi first met with Mr. Gore on Monday and appealed for more time, Mr. Gore looked at his watch and responded with an innocent smile: "Why? He has four days."
Last night, Mr. Kiuchi was brought into the Oval Office for a meeting with Mr. Clinton. He told the President that Mr. Hosokawa "agrees with you" on the need to deregulate Japanese markets, provide more consumer choice, stimulate the Japanese economy and generally open markets to more competition.
 
Achievements Cited
 Mr. Kiuchi pointed out that Mr. Hosokawa had already opened Japan's previously closed rice market, begun political reform, opened the construction market and last week moved to stimulate the economy with a tax cut.
The envoy insisted that the Prime Minister "can only take on so many battles at once," according to an American official. Therefore, he appealed to Mr. Clinton not to turn the summit into a confrontation, or bring excessive pressure on Mr. Hosokawa, who is already sinking in popularity at home.
American officials said Mr. Clinton's response was that "sometimes in a great relationship you achieve more by disagreeing" and facing up to your disagreements than by papering them over. The President also argued that the Japanese leader should be aligning himself with the Japanese public, and indirectly with the United States, in pressing for sweeping change.
Mr. Kiuchi was politely sent packing, reminded that for months now Mr. Clinton has sent envoys of his own to Tokyo to urge the political leadership to get involved in the talks and overrule the country's powerful, turf-protecting bureaucrats. "They still didn't get the message," an American official here said.
 
Each Wants Concessions
 Both the Prime Minister and Mr. Clinton appear to be counting on a last-minute concession from the other that can keep the talks from becoming what editorial cartoonists here were picturing today as an impending train wreck. Mr. Hosokawa has already survived two near misses in a month, and has proven that he is the master of the last-minute compromise, an art that is highly valued in Japanese brinkmanship. But there are doubts among his advisers that he can sidestep this one.
Tonight, Mr. Hosokawa sent another envoy, Tsutomu Hata, the Foreign Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, in hopes that on Thursday he can patch something together.
But by Friday in Washington, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa will face a choice: to word their way around the disagreements, or face a confrontation with his most important ally and second-biggest trading partner. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen has already said he would rather have no deal than a bad one. "We will not settle for anything cosmetic," he vowed during a visit here two weeks ago.
Already senior Japanese officials are urging the Administration to look at Mr. Hosokawa's intentions rather than his results so far. "He won't be able to say 'I have done this,' " a senior Japanese official said the other day. "Instead, he will have to say 'I tried.' "
 
Japan Cites Security Issues
 Fearful that the White House is focused exclusively on trade, Japanese officials are again warning of the need to give equal weight to security issues in Asia and the "global cooperation" programs between the two countries, in AIDS research, space and other scientific pursuits. A top official of the Japanese Foreign Ministry went so far the other day as to warn that a breach in the Japanese-American relationship would be the wrong signal to send North Korea, at a time of growing tension over nuclear inspections.
"It is important not to let the assessment of the framework agreement affect the other dimensions of the relationship," said Yukio Sato, who oversees the Government's relations with North America.
Efforts to change the subject have clearly frustrated the American Ambassador here, Walter F. Mondale. Mr. Mondale arrived in Tokyo brimming with ideas about how to get the two countries out of their rut of charge and countercharge, in which one trade barrier is eliminated and another magically pops to the surface. But after a few months of receiving promises from senior Japanese politicians that they would step in to overrule the bureaucrats, Mr. Mondale is still waiting.
"We get in there and they say there is no problem, their market is open," he said recently. "If that's the case, why are we negotiating?"
In word, if not yet in deed, Mr. Hosokawa has embraced an agenda once put forth by Japan's critics: He wants radical deregulation, a shift of power from producers to consumers, and a country that buys car parts and insurance and banking services on the basis of price and quality, rather than corporate or political relationships.
In practice, Mr. Hosokawa is greatly hamstrung. He has repeatedly backed down from his ambitious goals -- first on reforming the political system, then on a stimulus package to spur a recession-bound economy -- because of rebellions among the Socialists, the biggest party in his coalition. In the end he has been forced to ally himself with the Liberal Democrats or the bureaucrats, the forces he had vowed to defeat.
Mr. Hosokawa's first love, like Mr. Clinton's, seems to be domestic politics. Dealing with the country's $50 billion trade surplus is guaranteed to be a political nightmare at home, and he often seems detached from the details, leaving it to the trade negotiators.
The framework talks are the latest incarnation of an old idea: to find a comprehensive approach to bringing down the trade gap, mixing broad economic techniques -- mostly to encourage Japanese consumers to buy more imports -- with specific attention to key industries and markets. But the United States insisted from the start that they quantify the results, something that was missing from the last effort, the Bush Administration's awkwardly named "structural impediments initiative."
Japan rejected that idea, with an argument that makes perfect economic sense: One cannot set "targets" for America's share of the market without abandoning free-market principles. For days at the Tokyo summit meeting last summer there were heated arguments about how to set targets without managing trade. Mr. Miyazawa and Mr. Clinton retired to the sushi bar at the Hotel Okura.
 
'Objective Criteria' Undefined
 A few hours later, as Japanese bureaucrats still argued bitterly among themselves, the two countries announced a new system in which "objective criteria" would be used to measure progress in some key problem areas: autos and auto parts, which make up three-quarters of the trade deficit; insurance, intellectual property rights and government purchases of telecommunications equipment and medical technology. The agreement calls for a meeting every six months between the President and the Prime Minister, to insure that political pressure to make progress remains at a consistently high level.
The problem is that the "objective criteria" were never defined, and Japan and the United States have spent six months and untold millions of dollars arguing over what they mean.
Japan now says that agreement was a huge mistake it will never make again. Failure to meet even "informal" targets invite American threats of retaliation. The only acceptable indicators, the Japanese insist, are historical ones. How many right-hand drive cars did Detroit produce last year for Japanese roads? How many seminars did Japanese car makers hold for their American suppliers?
"That's how far the distrust has come," a senior Japanese official mused recently. "We're counting car bumpers."

HEADLINE: ISRAEL-P.L.O. DEAL SOLVES KEY ISSUES IN SELF-RULE PLAN

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Yasir Arafat and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel initialed an agreement tonight that removed many of the obstacles that have delayed putting into effect the accord to give the Palestinians limited self-rule. Mr. Peres said the agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, which crowned weeks of intensive negotiations between the two sides, covered the main issues between them.
The two sides have been trying for months to work out the details of an agreement reached last September that provides for Palestinian self-rule in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank town of Jericho. 
 Mr. Peres said the two sides reached agreement on the question of the administration of border posts between Gaza and Egypt and between Jericho and Jordan.
The Israeli Foreign Minister, who has been directly involved in the negotiations, said the two negotiating teams had also signed a three-page accord that not only dealt with passage in and out of Jericho, but also with the role of the Palestinian civil administration in Jericho. He also said they had settled what he termed "the distribution of security."
 
Issue of Jericho's Extent
 A major question has been the actual size of Jericho -- whether the zone of Palestinian self-rule would be limited to the city, or would include the area around the city. Mr. Peres said the final boundaries of Jericho would be decided when Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel meet again. However, he said the limits had been all but agreed upon tonight.
"All the problems we had before us we solved either completely in detail, or in principle," Mr. Peres said. "Some details were left over for later."
Mr. Arafat said the agreement that the two leaders initialed was an important step toward carrying out the agreement, but cautioned that there was still work to be done.
 
Approval by Higher Bodies
 "It's a very important step towards translating the declaration of principles into a reality on the ground," he said, referring to last year's agreement, which was signed in Washington on Sept. 13. "We have agreed with Mr. Peres to continue work here in Cairo and in Paris."
A senior Egyptian official involved in the talks said that Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, would take the proposal back to Tunis for approval by his Executive Committee and Mr. Peres would present it to Mr. Rabin and the Cabinet. The Egyptian official also said that a compromise had been worked out on the size of Jericho, but did not give details, saying only that it would be between 55 and 70 square kilometers (21 and 27 square miles).
It was clear, however, that there were still details to be ironed out before the agreement would be carried out. Originally, the Israelis were supposed to start their withdrawal from Gaza and Jericho by Dec. 13, as part of a timetable leading to eventual Palestinian self-rule in the area.
Israeli officials said they still had to work out details on security issues, the transfer of civil powers to the Palestinians and economic arrangements.
"We have agreed with Mr. Peres to continue with the work on other issues so that we can overcome all our problems," Mr. Arafat said.
 
'A New Era for Our People'
 "We are sure we can create now a new era for our people," he said. "We can say that Palestine and the name of Palestine have returned to the map of the Middle East."
The agreement, which came after some half dozen meetings in 48 hours between Mr. Arafat and Mr. Peres, was the first tangible sign that they have bridged wide gaps delaying the Israeli withdrawal. Mr. Peres was in constant contact with Mr. Rabin throughout the sessions, an Israeli official said.
"Occasionally it was not simple," Mr. Peres said, "because what we call security the Palestinians call dignity, and what we call dignity they call security."
Mr. Arafat and Mr. Peres initialed one three-page document on principles, to be called The Cairo Document, and a separate eight-page agreement on details. They also initialed maps and shook hands to scattered applause at the Al-Itahidiya Presidential Palace. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt was host for the brief ceremony and spoke with Mr. Rabin late last night.
Mr. Rabin told the Egyptian leader there was still a lot to be done, an official from the Prime Minister's office said.
 
A Final Meeting
 Mr. Arafat and Mr. Peres met for about one hour before the signing ceremony to overcome last-minute problems, Israeli officials said.
A Palestinian negotiator, Nabil Shaath, said agreement was reached on separate Israeli and Palestinian entry routes at the border with Egypt and Jordan. He said it was still unclear what authority the Palestinian Government would have over travelers to the self-rule area.
"It's all about sovereignty," Mr. Shaath said, referring to the self-rule area. "They are trying too remind us at every step that it is not an independent state, that it's only an interim stage."
The Israel-P.L.O. accord is the initial phase of a five-year interim period of limited Palestinian self-rule. A final settlement will be negotiated during the interim period.
 
Palestinian Police Unit
 A 15,000-member Palestinian police force will take over security duties inside the self-rule area.
The Israeli withdrawal from the area became bogged down when the two sides failed to agree on the boundaries of Palestinian self-rule in Jericho, control of border crossings from Gaza to Egypt and Jericho to Jordan, and how the Israeli Army would protect Jewish settlers.
The Israeli Prime Minister said on Tuesday that even if there was an agreement, more issues would have to be resolved in talks before the withdrawal could start.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Agrees to Avert Cuts For Arts With Donation Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
A week after proposing budget cuts for the arts in New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced an agreement yesterday in which the city would restore the cuts and provide even more money -- but only after the city's cultural institutions raised matching contributions from private sources.
The goals of the new plan, announced by the Mayor and leaders of some of the city's most prestigious arts institutions, are to increase overall financing for the arts, which Mr. Giuliani hopes will help the city's economy, and to encourage arts groups to raise more private money and become less dependent on city subsidies. 
 The Mayor also held up the proposal as a model of the kinds of public-private partnerships that he hopes to encourage throughout government as a way of reducing the city's financial obligations and huge budget shortfall. Under the plan Mr. Giuliani said the city would offer $5 million in the fiscal year that begins in July and ask the state to do the same, to match the $10 million in private contributions that the arts institutions pledged to raise. Also, he said, if the private money is raised, the administration will restore the nearly $4.2 million he proposed cutting from the $86.6 million the city would grant in the next fiscal year to arts groups, large and small.
It was not clear, however, whether Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Legislature would approve the state's $5 million share at a time when the state faces a projected gap of $3 billion in its own budget.
While the city provides financing for more than 400 cultural groups, including the 31 major institutions on city property, any group or artistic program would be eligible to apply for the matching grants for any new contributions.
No single group could receive more than $750,000 in the grants, and the larger institutions whose annual budgets exceed $1 million would have to show that the grants would be used to improve the public's access to the arts -- for example, by extending hours at a museum.
While the program, if successful, would increase the city's spending on the arts by $9.2 million above the $82.2 million proposed in Mr. Giuliani's preliminary budget last week, the Mayor made no guarantee that the increase would be repeated next year.
Appearing with the Mayor at City Hall were Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the co-chairman of the New-York Historical Society; Martin E. Segal, the chairman of the New York International Festival of the Arts, and leaders of other institutions. In addition to their pledge to raise $10 million, they said they would form a partnership to help the city's smaller museums, theaters and other arts groups raise money, perhaps by holding a benefit on their behalf.
The plan puts an extra burden on the smaller cultural organizations to raise money, since most have less established fund-raising mechanisms than the larger institutions, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art or the New-York Historical Society.
Curt Dempster, the director of the Ensemble Studio Theater in Manhattan, which received a grant of $8,116 from the city this fiscal year, expressed initial support for the plan as a welcome enticement to raise money. He added, however, that questions remained and that some smaller groups could be put at a disadvantage.
"It's a little bit like saying to somebody in the poverty cycle, 'Get out and get a job and we'll match it,' " said Mr. Dempster, whose organization presents a variety of new productions or experimental plays. "Some of these groups cannot just get out of poverty."
The plan grew out of negotiations over the last month between the city's cultural and arts establishment and one of the Mayor's deputies, John S. Dyson, who caused a furor after Mr. Giuliani's election when he suggested that the city might benefit more if it focused its cultural budget on the institutions that attracted tourists.
Mr. Giuliani, who has maintained that he never intended to cut money for smaller groups at the expense of the major institutions, said that the new plan offered a way to increase money for all the arts in cooperation with private foundations or individuals.
Emphasizing that the arts leaders would work with the Department of Cultural Affairs to teach smaller, less established groups how to raise money, the Mayor added that the city's arts groups could not simply rely on government grants.
"The way in which they are going to survive and grow and expand," he said, "is if they develop the expertise to do their own fund raising and develop a constituency in essence of their own."
Some questions still remained unanswered. It was not clear how exactly the matching grants would be distributed or whether the program would prevent only a handful of large institutions, raising $750,000 each, from absorbing all the matching grants.
As for the state's role, Charles F. Porcari, a spokesman for the Governor, said that Mr. Cuomo had not seen the proposal but that he "appreciated the interests in the arts" and would consider it as he negotiates his budget with the State Legislature by April. "We can consider this along with the $275 million in other requests from New York City," Mr. Porcari said.
In making their announcement, the Mayor and the arts leaders said the fund raising would begin once the city and state committed the matching grants of $5 million each.
The city's Cultural Affairs Department, whose new head is Schuyler G. Chapin, a former manager of the Metropolitan Opera and dean of Columbia University's School of the Arts, would oversee the program in conjunction with its private sponsors, headed by Mr. Ross and Mr. Segal. A meeting is planned next week to begin to organize the details of the plan.
Mr. Segal said the coalition would hold at least one fund-raiser to benefit the smaller institutions, with the money to be divided by the Cultural Affairs Department.
"We hope to encourage people who give to the larger insitutions to consider donations to the smaller ones as well," he said.
But some representatives of the city's smaller institutions questioned how much benefit their less established programs would receive.
Stanley Cogan, president of the Queens Historical Society, which receives a major part of its budget from the city, including $71,914 this fiscal year, said fund raising had become extremely competitive. He said he worried that smaller groups would be at a distinct disadvantage competing for the grants and could be left with less in the end.
"Sure, we'd try it," Mr. Cogan said, "but it's a very dubious way to go."
But Mr. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor, said the intent was not to hurt art groups, large or small. Noting that the arts were vital to the city's economy, he said the plan would entice groups "to reach a new plateau" of financing by tempting them to compete for the grants.
"They could get a lot more money," Mr. Dyson said of the smaller groups. "It depends on how hard they work. That's part of the excitement of it. They can go to donors, even at $10, and say we can match that from the city and state."

HEADLINE: Clinton Health Plan: Testimony Reveals the Government's Hand

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Though President Clinton dismissed its conclusions as "a policy wonk deal," the Congressional Budget Office has put its finger on something the Administration was loath to acknowledge: Mr. Clinton's health plan depends heavily on the power of the Government to compel behavior that would not otherwise occur in the private market.
Such an exercise of Federal power may be good or bad, but it should be recognized for what it is, said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the budget office, who has testified before two Congressional committees this week. 
 In some ways, his statement underscored the obvious: the reason for any new governmental program is to produce results that would not otherwise occur. But in public remarks, the President has gone to great lengths to minimize the Government's role and to insist that his plan represents merely an expansion of the existing system of private health insurance, a more rational version of the market, not a vast new Federal enterprise.
 
Flexing 'Sovereign Power'
 In testimony on Tuesday and again today, however, Mr. Reischauer said the Clinton plan "would establish a universal entitlement to health insurance that would be largely financed by mandatory payments resulting from an exercise of sovereign power."
Under this plan, he said: "Federal law, rather than the employer, would determine the benefits and premiums. The transaction would no longer be voluntary. The employer could not drop or change the terms of the health insurance benefit."
Under the Clinton plan, most Americans would get coverage through insurance purchasing pools known as health alliances. The alliances "would operate primarily as agents of the Federal Government," not as private entities, Mr. Reischauer said, adding that by the year 2004 the alliances would get 30 percent of their money from the Federal Government.
"The health alliances would be more like Federal agencies than like state or private entities," and their spending should be included in the accounts of the Federal Government, where they would be subject to "a full accounting and some sort of control," Mr. Reischauer said.
 
Product of Policy Wonks
 The President brushed aside the significance of these recommendations, just as he minimized the criticism of his health plan last week by the Business Roundtable, a group of executives from about 200 of the nation's largest corporations. Referring to Mr. Reischauer's concerns, Mr. Clinton said: "We'll fix that. That's not a problem. That's a Washington policy wonk deal."
But the Clinton plan was devised by a small army of policy wonks. And they had just such concerns in mind -- as something to avoid. One such White House expert said today, "The concern that the alliances would be viewed as governmental agencies, collecting taxes, heavily influenced the design of our plan."
Under the President's proposal, premium payments would flow from consumers and employers to alliances, then to doctors and hospitals, without going through the Federal Treasury.
A major reason for the complexity of Mr. Clinton's plan, with its premiums and subsidies, is that he was determined to avoid a payroll tax. Administration officials acknowledge that such a tax might have been simpler to administer, but they say it would have been politically unacceptable.
Mr. Reischauer said the premium payments should be treated as Government receipts. This conclusion reduces the political advantage that Mr. Clinton thought his plan had over the "single payer" bills sponsored by two Democrats in Congress, Representative Jim McDermott of Washington and Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, who explicitly propose new taxes to finance universal health care.
The Congressional Budget Office also said Mr. Clinton's health plan would increase the Federal budget deficit over the next decade, rather than reducing it as the President had predicted. And Mr. Reischauer said the premiums would have to be 15 percent higher than the White House estimated.
These were differences of degree -- Mr. Clinton had acknowledged an initial rise in the deficit -- and Mr. Reischauer called the disparities "small potatoes" in a world of trillion-dollar Federal budgets.
 
Some Findings Welcomed
 After consulting with the President today, Democratic Congressional leaders echoed the President's statement that the discrepancies were not very significant. Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said the budget office report was "not a problem." And House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington said that modest changes in Mr. Clinton's plans would remedy the problems identified by the Congressional Budget Office.
Supporters of the Clinton plan welcomed some of Mr. Reischauer's findings, particularly his conclusion that the plan would increase the range of health care choices "for the vast majority of Americans." In addition, Mr. Reischauer said the plan would slow the growth of health spending overall and probably reduce the total spent on health insurance by all businesses taken together.
But these predictions are based on Mr. Reischauer's assumption that the President's proposal to limit health insurance premiums would work as intended and would be completely effective.
Kathryn M. Langwell, director of health economics at the accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick, said she was surprised at this assumption. Ms. Langwell, who supervised health research at the Congressional Budget Office from 1989 to 1993, said, "In previous cost estimates of health reform plans, the budget office did not assume that expenditure caps would be 100 percent effective, and I doubt whether they will be."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert D. Reischauer, director of the budget office, testifying yesterday in Washington at a hearing of the Senate Finance Committee. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Quake Bill Spurs Long Deficit Debate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
The Senate had every intention today of approving $9.7 billion in new deficit spending for the Pentagon and victims of recent earthquakes and floods, but instead it found itself snared in a nasty debate over whether cutting the deficit might be wiser than raising it again.
The lawmakers argued for about seven hours. In the end, it was no contest: the cuts were shelved, in a lopsided 65-to-31 vote. 
 Picking the fight was Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat who has lately made deficit reduction his personal cause, not to mention a pain for President Clinton.
Last fall, Mr. Kerrey very nearly sank Mr. Clinton's first budget by threatening until the last hour to oppose it as too fainthearted on cuts in spending. Today, as the Senate took up the earthquake-relief bill that the House passed last week, Mr. Kerrey sprang again, proposing an amendment to enact 56 spending cuts totaling $94.2 billion through 1998.
 
Debt Prompts Fears
 And once again he chided Mr. Clinton, saying the President "got his priorities wrong" by proposing new social and public-works programs in his latest budget instead of further reducing the deficit, now pegged at $176 billion in the 1995 fiscal year, which starts on Oct. 1. Just the interest payments on the overall Federal debt of $4 trillion-plus, the Senator noted, are expected to total $212 billion next year.
"It's difficult to look at these numbers; difficult to look at this accumulation of debt every single year and say we're doing the right thing," Mr. Kerrey said, "because we're not."
Mr. Kerrey and his Republican co-sponsor, Hank Brown of Colorado, echoed what fiscal conservatives and some economists have argued for years: that a continued rise in the Federal debt would soak the national savings, lower living standards and strip the Government of any money to address the nation's ills.
But that argument withered before a chorus of objections from colleagues who accused the two Senators of trying to cut favorite programs or rob money needed for fighting crime and changing health care.
 
Tough Words From Byrd
 Most pitiless was Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Democrat who is chairman of the Appropriations Committee, which had voted to finance the programs that Mr. Kerrey sought to pare.
Mr. Byrd said that most of the proposed savings were illusory, and that much of the rest was irresponsible.
And he spoke about the political morality of passing big debts onto one's descendants as viewed by Thomas Jefferson, a President who opposed the notion but who borrowed $15 million to buy the Louisiana Territory anyway.
"He saddled the taxpayers of this country far beyond his Administration's ability to pay that debt," Mr. Byrd said of Jefferson. "If he had waited until he'd gotten the down payment, we'd never have gotten that territory. He did it -- Jefferson did it -- and I thank heaven that he did it."
Mr. Byrd then moved to table Mr. Kerrey's proposal and a second Republican one, by Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, that would have enacted a similar amount of cuts in Pentagon programs.
 
Cuts That Aren't Cuts
 Three of Mr. Kerrey's largest cuts, in truth, were not cuts at all, but increases in Medicare charges, mostly for better-off retirees. The Senate had already considered and rejected them last year as politically untenable.
Some others were hardy perennials in the attack on Federal excess. For example, Mr. Kerrey suggested that the Government stop awarding subsidies for college students to prison inmates. He asked the Senate to wipe out a Small Business Administration tree-planting program, shut down a Pentagon school for doctors that has long been criticized as hugely expensive and end subsidies to beekeepers.
He also asked Congress to cut its own pay by 5 percent, its budget by 7.5 percent and its fund for free mailings to constituents by 20 percent.
Lost amid all this was the earthquake bill, which now seems destined to be considered -- and, everyone agrees, passed -- on Thursday.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%);

HEADLINE: Colombia's Leader Defends Presence of G.I.'s

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 9

 BODY:
President Cesar Gaviria today accused Colombia's highest administrative court of being politically motivated in asking the Congress to investigate him for allowing the presence of 150 United States Army engineers in the country.
The court, called the Council of State, contended that Mr. Gaviria was violating Colombia's Constitution by permitting armed foreign troops to enter the country without prior congressional approval. The ruling added fuel to a three-month public outcry led by the press and politicians who charge that the presence of the United States troops in Juanchaco Bay in southwest Colombia is illegal and that American labor is being used at the expense of unemployed Colombians. 
 In charging at a news conference today that the ruling by the court was politcally motivate, Mr. Gaviria questioned its interpretation of the Constitution. "This means that to permit the entry of any military attache we would need to ask Congress for permission," he said.
Mr. Gaviria added that American cooperation in Colombia also included radar and other technology used in antidrug efforts. He said that the United States and Colombia had been involved in military cooperation projects since the signing of a military cooperation treaty in 1952 and that Colombia could not renege on international agreements.
 
A $3 Million Project
 "I am surprised that Colombians demand more international cooperation in the fight against drugs and then criticize such operations," Mr. Gaviria said.
The Army engineers in Juanchaco Bay plan to build a school and roads in a $3 million project described by American and Colombian officials as an army exercise. Although Juanchaco Bay is just 50 miles west of Cali, home to a notorious drug cartel, United States and Colombian officials have denied that the operation involves antinarcotics activities.
Under the headline "North American Search Bloc," the Bogota daily La Prensa in December compared the United States Army contingent to the 3,000-man heavily armed police and military force that spent 17 months hunting for Pablo Escobar, the Medellin drug cartel leader.
Other reports have referred to the American troops as "marine," a term that for many Colombians conjures up images of a Yankee invasion.
Politicians who face elections this year wasted little time in profiting from what was for them a well-timed renewal of nationalist ferver, incorporated the controversy into campaigns otherwise starving for debate. The American troops were depicted as invaders, marines and Drug Enforcement Administration agents.
In December, Gustavo Alvarez, Mayor of Tulua, a city near Juanchaco known the activity of drug traffickers, said of the Army engineers, "Since the U.S. is not capable of winning battles in its own cities, it has come to make war in Colombia."
 
2 Missionaries Kidnapped
 In recent weeks guerrilla groups have stepped up attacks against American targets in what has been interpreted as a protest against the United States presence in Colombia.
Three weeks ago, two American missionaries stationed near the town of Villavicencio in western Colombia were kidnapped by a guerrilla group known by its Spanish acronym FARC. Last week, the police in Medellin said they had uncovered a rebel plan to bomb American multinational companies there.
Suggestions have been made that much of the criticism is influenced by the Cali cartel, which feels threatened by the nearby presence of American troops.
Amado Gutierrez, the Council of State president, denied that the court's decision was influenced by drug trafficker. But a fuming Mr. Gaviria suggested the drug barons were influencing the present debate.
"The real threat to our national soverignty is if we let drug traffickers and criminals overrun the country," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
U.S. Seeks To Expand Airwaves

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration will propose a broad, 10-year plan on Thursday to force the Pentagon and other Federal agencies to cede control of a big block of the nation's airwaves and make them available for new commercial technologies.
If adopted, the plan could ultimately force a wide range of military activities, from some long-range air defense radar systems to ground-based communication links, to move to different radio-frequency bands. Civilian programs like atmospheric monitoring would also be affected. 
 Administration officials said today that many services vital to national security or public safety -- like space communications and the air-traffic control system -- would not be moved.
The purpose is to relocate many disparate services in order to clear swaths of frequencies for new commercial services that might include satellite radio broadcasting or whatever other money-making activities that private industry might dream up.
 
 
Auctions Are Planned
 The Government intends to auction licenses for most of these airwaves, which might generate billions of dollars in Federal revenue over the next decade, because wireless communications represent one of the fastest-growing segments of the telecommunications industry.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said today that the plan marked an important attempt to speed the introduction of new commercial technologies and fits into a broader effort by the Administration to shift resources from military activities to the civilian world.
"It certainly fits in with our notion that our national security is inextricably tied to our economic security," Mr. Brown said in an interview. "We clearly had some goals, to promote some sensible use of the spectrum, that keeps our goal of sustained economic growth paramount."
The Administration's plan, a response to legislation passed by Congress last year to reallocate the public airwaves, comes on top of a large band of frequencies that are already being allocated for "personal communication services," -- a new family of offerings that will be available via wireless telephones, computers and palm-sized personal communicators. Licenses for these personal communications services are to be auctioned beginning later this year.
In the plan described today, the Administration took care to accommodate the military, proposing that many of its services be allowed to continue for periods ranging from 3 to 15 years. In addition, the first parcels of airspace that would be turned over to the civilian use are those involving very high frequencies that are more difficult to use than the lower-frequency portions of the bandwidth that will eventually become available.
As a result, the proposal is virtually certain to kick off intense lobbying that will find business and military interests on opposite sides. The Commerce Department is giving all parties about 90 days to comment on the proposals, and officials said they hoped to put the final plan in place exactly one year from now.
The agencies that would be most affected by the plan are the Defense and Energy Departments and the Coast Guard. But in a lengthy report to be released on Thursday, the Commerce Department proposed to protect a number of major activities. In general, it recommended against any changes for frequencies used in navigation, astronomy and space communications. And in other areas, the Commerce Department proposed stringent technical requirements on new commercial services to prevent them from interfering with important Federal activities on adjacent frequencies.
The recommendations thus far are essentially the product of months of internal wrangling between Federal agencies, as each department tried to preserve its own claims on the airwaves. But now the plan will be scrutinized by the public, particularly business groups, and they are likely to push for even more concessions from Federal agencies.
 
Infighting Is Seen
 "What you're seeing now is the result of infighting in the Federal bureaucracy," said a Congressional aide who helped draft the legislation that prompted the new effort. "When private interests take a look at it, and the timetable that's been proposed, it will undoubtedly change."
That view was echoed by Clarence L. Irving Jr., Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information, who coordinated work on the plan. "We want to hear from people, both Government users, commercial users and the general public about how we can make the report better," Mr. Irving said.
 
Easing the Transition
 In programs that will be forced to change, the Commerce Department proposed a number of conditions to make the transition less painful.
Frequencies being shifted from long-range air defense radars, for example, would not be freed up for at least five years. Even after that, about 17 key military radar sites would be allowed to operate for another 10 years.
And commercial users who start using the bands would have to incorporate special equipment to keep them from interfering with radars that will continue to be permitted to use adjacent frequencies.
Likewise, the Commerce Department proposed that a radio band now used for tactical radio relay communications and aeronautical telemetry be reserved for the military for at least five years so the Pentagon could replace its current generation of equipment.

HEADLINE: Texaco Settles With Louisiana, Vowing More Investment

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Texaco said yesterday that it would settle a longstanding lawsuit with Louisiana by including an unusual promise to invest $152 million in the state's battered energy industry, a move expected to produce about 1,000 jobs.
"It's going to create some new jobs," Lauren C. Scott, an economist for Louisiana State University, said. "That's what they really need down here. It's a good deal for the state." 
 The dispute mainly concerned royalties Texaco, which is based in White Plains, paid to Louisiana from natural gas produced in fields leased from the state. The state filed the suit in 1988, seeking $387 million plus penalties and interest, charging that the company had underpaid on the royalties for years.
Alfred C. DeCrane, Jr., Texaco's chairman and chief executive, said the settlement, which also includes a payment to the state of $250 million in cash, cleared the way for the company to invest in the fields again and attempt to recover more oil and gas and drill new wells.
Mr. DeCrane said that Texaco had made the proposal for new investment knowing that Louisiana was under pressure to attract new money to develop its mature oil and gas fields.
Without a settlement, he said, it was unlikely that Texaco would have put more money into the fields, which have been producing for about 30 years. "We wanted something that was good for both of us," Mr. DeCrane said.
Richard Ieyoub, the Attorney General for Louisiana, which has lost more than 60,000 energy-related jobs in the last decade, said that the litigation had inhibited Texaco from investing more into many leased fields and from exploring undeveloped fields.
He said that the state had been prepared to take away the leases from Texaco, making it too risky for the oil company to invest.
"There's been acreage in our state that has been laying around for 50 years," Mr. Ieyoub said, referring to Louisiana's undeveloped tracts. "We felt that through the settlement there will now have to be aggressive development of these leases."
Mr. DeCrane said that "the prospects in the new fields are very good."
 
Attempt to Reverse Trend
 Texaco, as are most leading oil companies, has been cutting back on the development of domestic fields and shifting money for exploration overseas. Many areas of the United States have seen a decline in jobs and investment as a result and have been seeking ways to reverse the trend of overseas investment.
Mr. Scott said that much of the investment would benefit the state's Houma-Thibeaux region, which has lost about 27 percent of its jobs since the early 1980's.
As part of the settlement, Texaco also agreed to subcontract some work to companies in the state.
 Mr. Scott said that Texaco had also committed to using advanced technology in some drilling and recovery methods, which would help the state's energy industry remain competitive.

HEADLINE: IMPROVED TRAINING SOUGHT FOR PILOTS

BYLINE: By CARL H. LAVIN 

 BODY:
The Federal Aviation Administrator said yesterday that his agency wanted to increase safety training and standards for commuter airline pilots to the levels required of pilots for major airlines.
The Administrator, David R. Hinson, told the House aviation subcommittee that his agency was preparing rules requiring the single higher standard for all airline pilots. 
 "The commuter safety record has been improving," Mr. Hinson said, but he cited a December crash in Hibbing, Minn., which killed 18 people, and other fatal accidents as evidence that more needs to be done.
The number of hours flown by commuter planes grew to 2.4 million in 1993 from 1.3 million in 1978. In the same period, the accident rate dropped to .72 per 100,000 hours from 4.69 per 100,000 hours. But Government statistics show that commuter planes are still five times more likely to have an accident than larger airliners.
 
Every Six Months
 Under current rules, pilots who fly airliners with more than 30 seats must undergo rigorous training every six months. Typically, each pilot spends two or three days using computerized flight simulators to practice responding to a wide range of emergencies.
Pilots of smaller planes need to pass only a check ride every six months, an aviation official said. The proposed rule would require the same specified instruction periods as are now required for pilots of larger planes.
"It will make the most significant improvement in commuter airline safety that we can make by just changing regulations," Anthony J. Broderick, associate administrator of the F.A.A., said in a telephone interview.
After the agency studies projected costs, publishes the proposed rule, accepts comments, and adopts any modifications, the rule should go into effect in about 18 months, Mr. Broderick said.
 
Training in Teamwork
 New rules would also require all pilots, at commuter airlines as well as major airlines, to undergo training devoted to helping pilots work together in the cockpit, Mr. Broderick said. Many of the major airlines already emphasize teamwork in training, but the proposed rule would be the first to require this.
Several smaller airlines, including Atlantic Southeast and American Eagle, said they already trained all their pilots to the higher standards. And the president of the trade group of commuter airlines, Walter Coleman of the Regional Airline Association, who also testified before the Congressional panel, defended the safety of his group's airlines.
Many commuter airline officials said they did not oppose rules aimed at increasing pilot safety. "Should we continue our efforts to make them safer?" Mr. Coleman said. "The answer is yes."
Other airline officials said that the proposal would help make the flying public feel more comfortable flying in small planes. And they said the major cost would be in the purchase of the flight simulators, which can cost $10 million apiece.
 
Fare Increases Called Likely
 Still, Gary Risley, vice president of Mesa Airlines, which carried 4 million passengers last year, said he was surprised at yesterday's announcement. He also said any new costs would be passed on in fare increases.
"We knew the F.A.A. was considering it, but we are really taken aback," he said. "It will obviously raise the cost of training for pilots. This industry is so safety conscious, but you have to deal with the perception as much as the realities. And the perception is that it's unsafe. That's what is happening here.
"The length the F.A.A. has gone to is not necessary for safety. We are highly conscious as a company and as an industry. Besides the fact you are dealing with human lives, it is not good business to be unsafe. You do the best you can to maintain high safety standards and you do it as economically as you can. The cost will of course be translated to the passenger."
 
Crash in Minnesota
 Mr. Hinson and Mr. Broderick each referred to the crash Dec. 1 near Hibbing of a Northwest Airlink flight that killed everyone on board.
The Jetstream 31, a 19-seat plane, was operated by Express II Airlines under the Northwest name.
The plane did not have any mechanical problems and should have been able to pull out of a steep descent before crashing, Carl Vogt, chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, said, according to an Associated Press report.
The plane's captain was angry with the airline and sometimes flew the plane roughly to jostle passengers or bullied his co-pilots, according to a preliminary report released by the safety board last week that was based on interviews with others at the airline.
