HEADLINE: Giuliani Broadens Attack on Mismanagement and Waste

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Offering his Republican vision of leaner city government, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday delivered his first State of the City address, vowing a vigorous assault on bureaucracy, strong support of the police and a supply-side view of stimulating the city's economy.
In a speech in the City Council chamber of City Hall, Mr. Giuliani also made his most forceful attack yet on the bureaucracy of the city's educational system and pledged to appoint a fiscal monitor for education to audit the flow of money through the school system. 
 His remarks continued a volatile series of exchanges with Schools Chancellor Ramon Cortines over the budget and the extensive personnel cuts that the Mayor has proposed for the schools' administrative staff. Although the two have met at least twice in the last week to discuss the budget cuts, their public statements indicate a sharp disagreement over how far the cuts should go.
Another theme of Mr. Giuliani's speech was fighting crime. The Mayor said that next week he would set up the city's second "crime-free" zone around a school, this at a site in Queens that he did not identify. He also said he would put into effect new property forfeiture procedures aimed at drug dealers.
Many of the themes in the 58-minute address had been sounded previously. But yesterday's speech, before members of the predominantly Democratic City Council and a Democratic Public Advocate and Comptroller, was the strongest articulation of Mr. Giuliani's philosophy of government.
 
Still Seeking School Cuts
 At times, Mr. Giuliani's tone was apocalyptic. When discussing what he called the high level of crime, governmental waste and mismanagement, he said, "This state of the city has to end, because if it doesn't end, it will end our city as we have known it."
The speech covered a number of topics, from his need to reach out to Democratic legislators to his desire to protect programs aimed at the poor. But much of the Mayor's speech was devoted to the city schools, and he became particularly expressive and forceful when discussing that topic.
He repeated his call for eliminating 2,500 administrative positions from the Board of Education. "It is time for major surgery, to remove the blockage preventing our tax dollars from reaching our children," Mr. Giuliani said. Of the Board of Education's administrative staff, he said, "If it needs more cuts -- and it probably will -- we'll make them."
 
School Cuts at Issue
 Although the city school system depends on city funds, it is under the control of the Board of Education.
A reduction in the number of school administrators has been a point of contention between Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Cortines. At a news conference earlier in the day, Mr. Giuliani was asked if tension had risen between them. "I can't really tell," the Mayor told reporters. "He says one thing to you and something different to me."
Robert H. Terte, a spokesman for the Chancellor, said that Mr. Cortines had targeted 1,000 positions to be cut. "He has indicated that as he finds additional positions to be eliminated he will. But he has also indicated it would be irresponsible to commit to some hypothetical number without first evaluating the impact those reductions would have on what is, in effect, an $8 billion business."
Mr. Giuliani talked of the disillusionment of some New Yorkers in Queens and other parts of the city with the municipal government. He added that he had asked Edward N. Costikyan, a seasoned Democrat and lawyer who served on Mr. Giuliani's transition committee, to work with borough presidents "to devise ways to share power and bring it closer to the people."
 
Seeking Council Backing
 The Mayor's State of the City address -- postponed by one day because of Tuesday's snowfall -- came one week after he unveiled his budget plan for the next fiscal year, including his strategy for closing a $2.3 billion shortfall.
In yesterday's speech, he referred to many of those plans and sought once again to enlist the support of members of the City Council. Indeed, he took great pains to portray himself as deeply committed to bipartisan government. "We haven't given in to partisan politics," he said. "I've appointed more members of the so-called opposition party than any mayor in history."
He also asked Democratic legislators for cooperation on a number of fronts, most notably in seeking more state funds for New York City's Medicaid costs from the state Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Mr. Giuliani, who in his first days faced conflicts between the police and worshipers at a mosque in Harlem and over the police shooting of a black Brooklyn teen-ager, reiterated his strong support of the police in his speech. "My standard is support for the police unless the evidence demonstrated that the police acted illegally or improperly," Mr. Giuliani said. "I believe it's the way to create a civilized society and respect for the law."
But he said that if there is evidence of illegal or improper behavior, "we must act strongly," adding that police officers "must be held to the highest standards."
Mr. Giuliani's speech drew varied reactions. Alan G. Hevesi, the city's Comptroller, said he considered it "very thoughtful, sober, serious, a good speech."
Mark J. Green, the Public Advocate, said he agreed that the city needed to shrink government, but said, "I fundamentally disagree with his economic premise that all job losses in this city in the last five years have been due to the bloated bureaucracy."
Stanley Hill, president of District 37, the city's largest municipal union, criticized Mr. Giuliani, saying, "He didn't talk about the workers and didn't give any credit to the workers and the role they have played."
Also yesterday, the Mayor appointed a new Commissioner for the city's Department of Buildings. His first choice, Frank A. Luzi, resigned two days ago amid questions about state and Federal investigations into companies in which he was involved.
The new commissioner, Joel A. Miele Sr., a member of the Planning Commission who has headed an engineering firm in Queens, had been a contender for the position Mr. Luzi ultimately received.

HEADLINE: Administration to Delay Proposals to Aid Labor

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
After promising to come up by mid-year with proposals to deal with some of the nation's thorniest labor issues -- including whether to strengthen unions, and how to regulate workers' councils -- the Clinton Administration has decided to wait until November, probably after the Congressional election.
The postponement is a setback for labor leaders who had hoped that the Administration would move forcefully to reverse labor's weakening position at the bargaining table. Seeking early action on this front, the President appointed a blue-ribbon commission last May to make policy recommendations in one year. 
 The commission sought an extension, arguing that its recommendations would be too contentious unless it had more time to sell its ideas. And the Administration agreed to the postponement last weekend, even though it has been deferring action on labor issues until the report is filed.
 
Reich Cites Tension
 Justifying the delay, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview: "Worker-management relations today are very tense, given all the corporate downsizings, the increased litigation in the workplace, the technological changes and the enormous pressures on companies to cut costs."
The commission is headed by John T. Dunlop, a Harvard economist who was Secretary of Labor in the Ford Administration. Most of the nine other members are former labor secretaries or academicians.
Among the proposals the commission is considering are steps that would make forming a union easier or would force binding arbitration on management in labor disputes. To make such recommendations easier for corporate America to accept, the commission will issue only "findings of fact" in May.
 
Facts Before Solutions
 "The important thing is to draw a line between the process of finding facts and the process of what to do about them," Mr. Dunlop said. "I want people to be able to say these facts are right or wrong or they need to be amended, and then after the nation has confronted the facts, we can come up with solutions."
One finding of fact already decided upon, commission members say, concerns the fate of workers engaged in trying to organize a union. American companies over the last decade have discharged many more people for trying to organize unions than they did in the 1950's.
If this finding survives challenges from business, then the commission in November might propose policies to protect union organizing by making it easier and faster. One way to do this -- a method favored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. -- would be to allow a union to represent a company's workers, if a majority signed membership cards. Labor law currently requires that workers go through the much longer and more complicated process of voting in a special election to be represented by a union.
 
Workers Councils on Agenda
 The commission will also consider the status of the workers councils that have appeared at many companies. These councils increasingly give workers control over their daily routines, and management has endorsed them as an effective way to improve efficiency. But some workers and some unions have charged that the councils are really management controlled, in violation of existing labor law.
Surprisingly, organized labor, which has the most to gain from the commission's proposals, agreed to the six-month postponement of the commission's report. "If it issued policy recommendations along with its findings of fact in May, that would be very difficult for Congress to swallow," said John Zalusky, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s specialist in collective bargaining. "In the current atmosphere, we need a public debate before someone comes out with a policy."
The National Association of Manufacturers, whose members employ most of the nation's unionized, private-sector workers, also endorsed the postponement. "The commission is not likely to come up with any finding in fact that suggests that sweeping labor law reform will be necessary," said Jerry Jasinowski, the association's president. "These findings are likely to focus on egregious cases, not widespread problems."

HEADLINE: Yale Law Dean Is Nominated To 2d Circuit Appeals Court

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Reaching out to his alma mater for a renowned legal scholar, President Clinton today nominated Guido Calabresi, dean of the Yale Law School, to be a Federal judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, a showcase court that hears cases from New York, Connecticut and Vermont and produces some of the country's most important decisions.
Mr. Clinton's choice had been rumored for several months, and both of Connecticut's Democratic United States Senators, Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman, issued statements enthusiastically supporting it tonight. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Calabresi would replace Judge Thomas Meskill, who took senior status on the court, which is based in New York, last year. 
 Born in Milan in 1932, Mr. Calabresi fled Fascist Italy with his family at the age of 6 and came to New Haven. He was first in his undergraduate class at Yale, won a Rhodes scholarship, then was first in his class at Yale Law School and became the youngest full professor in its history at age 29. He has been dean of the school, often considered the most prestigious in the nation, since 1985.
 
'I'm Greatly Honored'
 While Mr. Clinton, a 1973 Yale law graduate, never took a class with Professor Calabresi, they have long been members of a mutual admiration society, along with the President's wife and classmate, Hillary. Dean Calabresi was an early backer of Mr. Clinton's 1992 presidential campaign.
"I'm greatly honored by this nomination," Dean Calabresi said in a statement issued in New Haven. "My family fled Fascism in Italy nearly 55 years ago. The United States of America took us in and gave us extraordinary opportunities. I am immensely grateful for that. If confirmed, I will do my best to maintain the laws that have made this country a haven and a beacon."
Senators Dodd and Lieberman had strongly backed another Yale-educated jurist, Jose Cabranes, chief of the Federal District Court in Connecticut, for the vacancy. Mr. Cabranes' appointment was also urged by Hispanic rights groups, but there is a strict state-by-state quota system on the 13-member court, so it seemed unlikely that two judges could be appointed from Connecticut at once.
Aides to both senators said tonight that their understanding from the White House was that Mr. Calabresi's nomination had not precluded Judge Cabranes's and that his possible nomination was still under review, perhaps as a candidate from New York, where he grew up in the Bronx.
Mr. Calabresi's 1970 book, "The Costs of Accidents: A Legal and Economic Analysis," was a seminal study in the modern law of torts. He is the author of three other books and scores of articles and is one of the most colorful, popular figures at Yale.
"He is one of the most thoughtful, innovative law professors of his generation," said Paul Brest, dean of the Stanford University Law School. He called the nomination "a brilliant appointment."

HEADLINE: Bar to Anti-Gay Laws Is Upheld

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SALEM, Ore., Feb. 9

 BODY:
A state judge has upheld an Oregon law that voids local measures barring homosexual rights ordinances.
"The issue of homosexual rights is such a substantive social issue that the Legislature may pre-empt" local governments, said the judge, Albin Nor blad of Marion County Circuit Court. 
 Five counties and 11 cities around the state have prohibited the protection of homosexuals from discrimination in hiring and elsewhere. In nearly every case, local courts have overturned the measures or officials have refused to enforce them because of the state law, which was passed last July.
In his decision, Judge Norblad cited a 1978 Oregon Supreme Court ruling that allows state lawmakers to take precedence in decisions on issues that have a "statewide substantive, social or economic or other regulatory objective."
 
Appeal Is Planned
 The judge's ruling stems from a lawsuit filed by the Oregon Citizens Alliance, a group that sponsored the local anti-homosexual initiatives. The alliance said the state law infringed upon the citizens' right under the Oregon Constitution to initiate laws.
Lon Mabon, the organization's chairman, said he would appeal Judge Nor blad's ruling to the state Court of Appeals.
The alliance's lawsuit is so far the only direct challenge to the state law, and the ruling on Tuesday takes precedence over any local court rulings, said Charles Hinkle, a lawyer who argued for the state law on behalf of the American Civil Liberties Union of Oregon.
"Nobody's rights should be put up for a popular vote," said Julie Davis, executive director of Support Our Communities, a group that supports the state law. "I think the judge's ruling is a reiteration of that point,"
Judge Norblad's ruling does not prevent continuing votes on local anti-homosexual measures, including ones in Marion County and Turner, a town of about 1,250 five miles south of Salem.

HEADLINE: Weicker Urges an End to Personal Property Tax

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 9

 BODY:
In his final State of the State message, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. proposed a plan today to phase out the widely disliked local tax on motor vehicles and business equipment, including computers, known as the personal property tax.
Connecticut is one of 25 states with such a tax, and Mr. Weicker's budget office said its elimination during the next 10 years would eventually save businesses and individuals more than $700 million a year. 
 The tax assessed on a private car can vary widely, depending on the value of a vehicle and its location. A car valued at $8,000, for example, is taxed $542 in Bridgeport, with its high tax rate, but only $108 in much wealthier Darien.
The General Assembly is sure to question the finances of Mr. Weicker's plan, which relies on projected state surpluses to reimburse towns and cities for their lost tax revenue. But revision of the property tax system has the support of both business groups and financially pressed cities, which have made it a priority in the legislative session that opened today.
In a state with a property-tax burden surpassed only by New Hampshire, New Jersey and Alaska, businesses complain that the tax is one more reason to leave Connecticut, while residents protest that the tax falls heaviest on those least able to afford it: homeowners in poor cities or on fixed incomes.
"The foremost issue should be reforming the property-tax system," the House Speaker, Thomas D. Ritter, a Democrat from Hartford, said as he opened the House of Representatives with a state of the state message of his own. "The system is antiquated, regressive and clearly inadequate for our times."
The personal property tax is a potent symbol of what many critics say is wrong with the entire property tax system, even though most of the revenue raised by towns and cities is through property taxes on houses, office buildings and other real estate.
For drivers, the tax on identical vehicles can swing wildly from town to town, based on the communities' relative wealth. For businesses, "It's a tax that employers in states like New York and Massachusetts don't pay at all," said Joseph F. Brennan, a vice president of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association.
Mr. Weicker, who won election in 1990 under the banner of "A Connecticut Party" but who is not seeking a second term, devoted much of his speech to defending his fiscal strategy during the state's recession, when he imposed a personal income tax to balance the state budget, while cutting business taxes to make Connecticut more competitive and aiding businesses with investments or loans to save or create jobs.
That strategy, he said, had succeeded in balancing the state's budget, and now allowed the General Assembly, in his final year as Governor, to begin cutting property taxes while also spending more to fight crime in the cities and to rescue the children endangered by violence and poverty.
"Mistakes were made in the 80's," he said. "We've paid the price -- all of us in Connecticut, a dollar price -- and recovery is under way. Now let's get on with life and make sure recovery works for everybody."
In many ways, the initiatives that Mr. Weicker stressed today were personal, returning to issues and convictions that have occupied him throughout his term, from the need to reduce the tax burden on businesses to the plight of children in Connecticut's poor cities.
Few of those proposals greatly affected the $9.09 billion budget itself, which was approved by the legislature last year under a new state law mandating two-year budgets. Working within a state law that caps the annual increase in spending, Mr. Weicker looked for ways to make an impact with a few million dollars here and there.
For $24.3 million in state spending, plus $16 million in bond funds, for example, the Governor's cabinet put together a youth initiative that would strengthen neighborhoods by keeping school buildings open before and after class, expand youth and family centers, improve health services for children, and create more job and college opportunities for children from poor families.
"I confess to you, I've never been so excited about anything as long as I've been Governor," Mr. Weicker said, in proposing a trust fund that would guarantee tuition and fees at a state college for any poor child who gained admission. The plan would take effect in five years, starting with children in seventh grade this year.
Strongly supporting a bill to toughen gun licensing and stiffen penalties for crimes involving guns, Mr. Weicker vowed to push for "a total constitutional ban on all concealed weapons" if the bill was weakened.
"There is no constitutional guarantee to kill in America," he said. "There is no constitutional guarantee to kill in Connecticut."
He also praised the Commission on Educational Excellence for Connecticut, a panel of business people, educators and others who recently submitted a plan for remaking public education in the state.
But as a third-party Governor in his last year, constrained by budget limits, Mr. Weicker could do little today to support his enthusiasms. His proposal to eliminate the personal property tax projects that goal nine years beyond his term of office. Despite his praise for the education commission, his budget included only a few of the panel's recommendations for $200 million in new spending.
Even the college trust fund would be started with only $7 million from the sale of bonds, and its growth would depend on private donations and the willingness of future legislatures to continue contributing.
Senate and House members were spare with their applause during his speech. In an election year with Republicans and Democrats preparing to do battle over every seat in the legislature, Mr. Weicker's speech was seen by some as his opportunity to put his term in perspective before others set to work.
"I thought it was a speech that lacked vision about where Connecticut should be in the 21st century," said the House minority leader, Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol. "It was an attempt to rewrite the history of the state."
The main issue facing Connecticut, he said, was creating jobs to replace those lost in the recession. "That is the primary job for this legislature."
Senator John B. Larson, a Democrat who is the Senate president pro tem and one of seven declared candidates for Governor, has criticized Mr. Weicker's economic development efforts, saying the state's policy of lending money to businesses had made it the Connecticut Money Store without creating more jobs.
"The guy's been in public office for 31 years," Mr. Larson said of the Governor's address. "He was making the case for the last four years. Tomorrow the reality sets in, and the reality is the 200,000 jobs that have been lost here over the last four years."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Slip After 10-Year Note Auction

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Interest rates ended a four-day advance and turned modestly lower on good investor demand at yesterday's 10-year note auction. The small rally helped to ease market concern temporarily about inflation and the possibility of another jump in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
The price of the 30-year bond was up 14/32 , to 9728/32 , as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.41 percent, from 6.44 percent on Tuesday. 
 One sign that the 10-year note auction went well, according to Robert T. Falconer, a senior vice president at Aubrey G. Langston & Company, was that new notes rose in price in the afternoon on good investor demand.
The average yield at auction for the 10-year note was 5.92 percent, in line with market expectations. In the when-issued market late in the afternoon, the yield had fallen to 5.88 percent The average yield at the auction was the highest average yield since the note sale last May, when the average was 5.96 percent. A year ago, the average yield was 6.33 percent.
 
Awaiting Producer Price Figures
 Mr. Falconer said inflation and its impact on interest rates still concern traders and investors because the Government auction is ahead of the release tomorrow of the January producer-price data, a measure of prices at the producer level that will give the latest look at inflationary pressures.
"The data on Friday could give us a good clue as to whether the Government's quarterly sale was an ultimate success," Mr. Falconer said. If the increase in producer prices is small than expected,dealers would be able to sell the large amounts of Government securities they bought at the auction this week more easily. But if the number is bad, dealers could find themselves holding more issues than they would like, perhaps even forced to cut the price to raise the yield to a level more attractive to buyers.
Mr. Falconer said that one problem for analysts is that for the last several years, inflation data for the first few months of a year turned out to be distorted and left the impression that prices were rising at a much faster pace then they really were.
"Besides, quarterly borrowings are always difficult for the market," he added. "You have an avalanche of supply and a delicate balance of demand. And now we have a bond auction twice a year that generates a tremendous mountain of supply which suddenly enters the market and traders have to bid on it."
The market's concern is that a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent or more in the core Producer Price Index could force the Fed into another tightening that would push short-term interest rates higher. Economists surveyed by Reuters expect a rise of four- tenths of 1 percent in the overall Producer Price Index for January and a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in the core rate, which excludes food and energy prices.
Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist at CS First Boston, doubted the Fed would act after the release of the producer-price figures, but did not rule out another quarter-point rise in short rates following the release of January's Consumer Price Index next week.
Bond traders got some reassurance yesterday that inflation was not yet a problem, as oil prices fell. The price of crude oil for March delivery slid 61 cents, to $14.60 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 
30-Year Auction Today
 Today the market will contend with the final part of the Government debt offering when the Treasury sells 30-year bonds. In when-issued trading, the bond was being offered at a price to yield 6.42 percent, down from 6.45 percent on Tuesday.
Treasury bill rates are mixed, with a three-month bill rate unchanged at 3.23 percent and a six-month bill down three basis points, to 3.37 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The following are the results of yesterday's 10-year Treasury note auction:

HEADLINE: The Piggy Bank in the Real World

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Kids and cash have always constituted one of the more liquid economies. Children, after all, can get and spend with the best of them.
"I have something, then I have nothing," said Rasheda Edness, a 17-year-old Bedford-Stuyvesant victim of the consumer culture. "Except when I've got something stupid. I had $20 the other day. Then I had a $20 hat." 
 Reform, economic or otherwise, isn't a concept adolescents are eager to embrace. But in central Brooklyn, at the nexus of neighborhoods that include Bedford-Stuyvesant, Crown Heights and Prospect Heights, there is a movement to develop fiscal responsibility. The Central Brooklyn Youth Credit Union, one of 11 such projects awarded grants by the National Federation of Community Development Credit Unions, is coming into being.
The youth credit unions, including ones in Harlem and Hempstead, L.I., received an average of $15,000 in start-up funds early in 1993. The general goals are to infuse low-income minority children with concepts of ownership and to equip them with skills for jobs in the financial services industry. The new credit unions are modeled after the D. E. Wells Youth Credit Union in Springfield, Mass., which was formed in 1988 and has 1,000 members and $30,000 in assets.
 
About Feeling in Charge
 "The formation of these youth credit unions is a real example of a national effort to empower youth," said Carol Zippert, a board member for the national federation. "It's a very real, very significant way of allowing kids to feel in charge -- of their lives and of their communities."
The great equation that children from Brooklyn to Demopolis, Ala., will be asked to compute, according to organizers, is this: Money equals power equals democracy.
"I thought you had to be old to know how to manage money," said Akasa-Ra, an 11-year-old from Bedford-Stuyvesant who plans to be a charter member of the Brooklyn operation. "I'd get it and go to the store and spend it. I wasn't prepared for how to keep it, how to control it. Money, I know now, is very political."
And all politics is local, an axiom the adult organizers of the project have made explicit to the children. The youth credit union in Brooklyn, coordinated by the Central Brooklyn Partnership, a coalition of neighborhood development organizations and churches, will draw its membership from the area's children. Recruited from schools and church groups, the children, ages 8 to 18, will run it. They will deposit in it. They will own it.
"It's about a lot more than business," said Angela Riley, an officer with the partnership and an adviser to the youth credit union. "It's about what leadership means. It's about what it means to build an institution."
 
Workshop on Money
 The construction began in earnest last month, when about two dozen Brooklyn bankers of the future marched through freezing temperatures on a Saturday to an orientation workshop at Restoration Plaza in Bedford-Stuyvesant. A workshop exercise -- Reap and Loss: The Way Money Goes -- was played out.
The way money goes in neighborhoods like theirs isn't much of a mystery to the children. A lot goes out. Not much stays. Bank branches have closed with regularity over the last decade. The lines outside check-cashing establishments, whose numbers are double those of bank branches in the neighborhoods, seem to grow longer by the day. Many store owners sell, but don't live, in the neighborhood. According to a study commissioned last year by the Central Brooklyn Credit Union, for every dollar deposited in local banks, less than one penny is returned to their community in loans or other reinvestments.
"I see Brooklyn, and I see things that need to be changed," said Jason O'Connor, a 13-year-old who would like to be chairman of the credit union. "What are banks? Banks to me are a gang of people who want money and make money. We want to be more than that for kids. We want a chance to have power."
That chance was made real in Springfield by the D. E. Wells Youth Credit Union. There is an 11-member board, the credit union offers savings accounts and loans, and accepts deposits as modest as 5 cents. Graduates of the youth credit union -- 75 percent of whom have gone on to college, according to its executive director -- can invest in the adult credit union. And there has not been a single incident of delinquency with any of the 100 loans approved by the youngsters.
 
Need to Trust Adults
 "The difficult sell to the kids when we promoted the idea of the credit union was to get them to trust adults," said Carol Aranjo, the executive director of the D.E. Wells credit union. "We told the children that the institution would be theirs alone to own and run, and what I hear most from them now is how surprised they are that we kept our word."
Leone Baum is busy trying to keep her word to the children of Hempstead, where she expects to have the credit union, with about 300 members, in place later this year.
"We have children as young as 3 with their passbooks," said Ms. Baum. "They like to see the numbers. They especially like to see the numbers going up."
None of the children, though, seem to get too dizzy. One young girl in Springfield every week empties her tiny purse on the counter of the teller window, stares at her mother sternly enough to gain a moment of privacy and then always pulls back a handful of the coins. A 7-year-old in Hempstead spoke soberly during an orientation of debt-to-income ratios and how loans might be made for the purpose of buying a present for a mother -- but not a girlfriend -- one relationship evidently considered more stable than the other.
"They are not great lenders," agreed Ms. Aranjo. "I'd say 80 percent of the time the loan officers talk the members out of the loans. And they are not beyond laughing you out of the room. It happened to one 10-year-old who wanted to borrow $500 for a stereo. It took him a while to recover from the experience."
 
Recruiting in Churches
 Ms. Riley and others involved in the Brooklyn venture have reached out to church groups and schools in search of potential members and officers. She also enlisted as an adviser Errol Louis, the treasurer of the Central Brooklyn Credit Union, which started last winter and has more than 600 members and assets of $1.5 million. It will, with a sense of irony as well as opportunism, move its offices to the Chemical Bank branch nearby on Fulton Street upon the branch's closing this spring. The youth credit union will have its offices, and perhaps its miniature teller windows, at the new site.
"Consumption is soaked into these kids," said Mr. Louis. "I made a presentation to a group of them, and we talked about finances. They were a bit bewildered, but when I mentioned credit cards, they all wanted to talk.
"But there are also people in this community with cash and roots and a pathological fear of debt. There are parents who have brought their children into the main credit union and brought them right to the windows to join."
Mr. Louis said the "future officers" for his business could come from the ranks of the youth credit union. The first small Brooklyn platoon sat in a circle at the recent orientation, introducing one another to their small dreams. There was an 11-year-old point guard with ideas about directing deposits as well as fast breaks, a 17-year-old trying to figure out how to save for a driver's education course, a 13-year-old who confessed her slightly embarrassing but stubbornly enduring love for shopping.
"If other kids out there don't care, they should," Jason O'Connor said of the world of personal and community finances and the link between the two. "And if they don't get it, they will some day."

HEADLINE: Despite Violence, Colombia Surges

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
Protected by high tariff walls as steep as its mountainous terrain, and inward-looking in its leadership, Colombia was once described by a former Colombian president as "the American Tibet."
But since 1990, like so much of Latin America, free-market policies and a lowering of trade barriers have produced solid growth, surging imports and swelling foreign investment. Today, business people predict that Colombia in the mid-1990's will increasingly look like the Southeast Asian "tigers" of Malaysia, Thailand and Singapore. 
 "We are very positive on Colombia; we think they are making major strides to open the economy and to become world players," said Michael Tracy, president of Drummond Ltd., an Alabama coal company that plans to invest $50 million this year to build a private port to develop a coal mine near Colombia's Caribbean coast.
The coal project is part of an explosion in foreign investment in Colombia outside of its rich oil reserves, which have long attracted foreigners. From 1990 through last year, investment more than doubled to $475 million. This year, foreign investment is expected to double to $1 billion.
In the oil sector, foreign companies plan to also double investment rates, spending $5.5 billion through the end of the decade to develop Cusiana, the largest field discovered in the Western Hemisphere since Prudhoe Bay in Alaska.
Still, the nation's well-publicized violence remains a significant drawback to investment. Although drug terrorism appears to have abated after the death in December of Pablo Escobar, guerrilla violence is expected to be part of the landscape for many more years. Colombia's largely rural-based guerrillas started fighting to topple the Government in the early 1960's.
"The violence is costing us several growth points," Rudolf Hommes, Colombia's Finance Minister, wrote in January in Carta Financiera, a business magazine. Without the killings and kidnappings by guerrillas and drug traffickers, foreign investment in Colombia would be 25 percent higher, he estimated.
Colombia's new economic policies, known as the apertura, or opening, is the work of Colombia's President, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo. A technocrat who is short on charisma, Mr. Gaviria has an understanding of business that comes from his training as an economist.
Until Mr. Gaviria turned their world upside down, Colombian manufacturers had produced for years in a genteel environment protected by tariffs averaging 40 percent. Then, in 1990 the President started to cut them to their current level -- 11 percent.
In an audible rush, imports swept in the newly opened door.
In 1992, imports of American goods jumped 68 percent, to $3.3 billion, making Colombia the fastest-growing market worldwide for United States goods. According to President Gaviria, this import surge created 45,000 new jobs in the United States.
Over all, Colombia's imports nearly doubled in three years, from $7 billion in 1991 to $13 billion in 1993. Last year, for example, car sales doubled nationwide. Fueling imports, Colombia's currency, the peso, strengthened by 14 percent against the dollar last year.
Now, as Colombia moves decisively from state companies and protectionism, American companies are seizing opportunities. So far this decade, 70 percent of all new United States foreign investment has gone to Latin America and the Caribbean, according to the World Bank.
 
Selling Telephone Concessions
 Last month, Colombia got the attention of major American telecommunications companies. Chipping away at a state telephone monopoly, the Government sold three cellular telephone concessions to private investors for $624 million. The two largest concessions, for the Bogota region and for the Caribbean coast, are to be planned and operated by two American minority shareholders, McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. and LCC Inc. Calculating that there is an enormous repressed demand for cellular service in this capital city of seven million people, the winning consortium, Celumovil S.A., paid $23 per inhabitant for the 10-year concession, believed to be a world record.
This month, three more concessions are expected to be sold for about $600 million. In this round, the BellSouth Corporation is expected to have a chance as a minority partner in a consortium offering alternative service to Bogota.
In the banking sector last month, the Government auctioned off the nation's second-largest bank to private investors for $500 million.
"The change in Colombia is almost miraculous," said an American banker who has lived and worked here for more than 30 years. "Only 15 years ago they were 'Colombianizing' the banks. Today, they are raffling off the second-largest bank in Colombia, one called Banco de Colombia."
Abandoning vestiges of foreign exchange controls adopted in the 1960's, Colombia adapted in late January a policy of a free-floating exchange rate.
Opening another sector to foreign investment, Colombia plans this year to call for international bids on 20 highway repair projects, worth an estimated $1.5 billion. Construction companies are to be repaid through tolls.
 
Investments by Americans
 In Colombia's three stock markets, foreign mutual funds, largely American, made initial forays last year, quadrupling their holdings to $236 million by the end of the year. Trading volumes on the three exchanges surged 69 percent in 1993, hitting $13.2 billion.
Last year, the country recorded 5 percent growth, slightly above a 20-year average of 4.4 percent. Inflation maintained a four-year decline, hitting 23 percent, half the level of neighboring Venezuela. Flush with $8 billion in reserves, Colombia is trimming its foreign debt. Last year, Colombia prepaid $450 million in public sector foreign debt, reducing the debt to its current level of $13.8 billion.
Strong reserves helped Colombia to weather a wave of imports.
In Latin America, Colombia is rivaled only by Chile in its determination to negotiate free trade pacts. After signing free trade pacts with virtually all the Andean nations in the early 1990's, Colombia now plans to sign pacts this year with the common markets of Central America and the Caribbean and to enter into a three-way pact with Mexico and Venezuela.
"Virtually all our products can enter duty free into a world market of 800 million people," said Juan Manuel Tafurt-Rojas, an official with Coinvertir, a new public-private enterprise devoted to promoting foreign investment in Colombia.
 
Free Trade With U.S.
 Indeed, although Colombia eagerly wants to join the United States in an expanded version of the North American Free Trade Agreement, Colombia already enjoys many of the benefits. Under trade promotion agreements signed during the height of the war against cocaine in the early 1990's, most Colombian products enter the United States and Europe duty free.
A free trade pact with Venezuela proved to be wildly successful. From $500 million in 1991, trade between the countries more than tripled, hitting $1.8 billion in 1993. Reflecting strengthening business ties, the number of weekly flights between Bogota and Caracas increased in the last four years from 4 to 26. Today, Venezuela ranks second to the United States as Colombia's largest trading partner and foreign investor.
Although Colombia's macroeconomic indicators look good, not all boats are rising. The number of people living below the poverty line has increased by about one million since 1990, to include about half of Colombia's population of 33 million people. In 15 years, the gap between average rural and urban incomes doubled.
"Blind people believe that armed uprisings of the poor don't match the happy times in which we live: times of cellular telephones, of newspapers with pink pages just like The Financial Times, of privatizations and of free-trade treaties," Antonio Caballero, one of Colombia's most acerbic left-wing columnists, wrote in a news weekly, Cambio 16 Colombia.
"Our countries are countries of two floors: a penthouse built on a slum," he continued. "Neoliberalism has a simultaneous double effect: filling the penthouse with electronic goodies, including burglar alarms, while making the slum below ever more uninhabitable for the great majorities that live there."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
U.S.-Japanese Talks Sputter, And Dollar Closes Lower

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar eased against the yen yesterday on fear that a long-awaited meeting tomorrow between the American and Japanese leaders could end without a trade agreement.
Reports from both sides of the negotiating table were pessimistic. 
 The dollar tumbled in Tokyo after Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said Japan's one-year tax cut would not sufficiently stimulate demand for imports. It took another blow when the Japanese Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, said the trade talks with the United States remained deadlocked.
The dollar's sharp fall aroused talk that the Japanese central bank was buying dollars for yen, or, at the very least, checking currency rates with dealers.
 
Suspicions of U.S. Mischief
 Many dealers believe that United States officials might turn to talking up the yen if other ways to trim Japan's trade surplus fail.
"The market was quite sensitive ahead of the U.S.-Japan summit, reacting to each piece of news related to the framework talks," a German bank dealer in Tokyo said.
The dollar trimmed its losses in New York during the afternoon when an American official repeated that the White House had no plans to try to drive the yen higher if the trade talks with Japan failed. The dollar was quoted at 108.30 yen, down from 108.90 yen on Tuesday, in late New York trading.
"The Administration's comments gave the dollar the boost it needed to get above 108 yen," said Michael McKeever, foreign exchange dealer at Fuji Bank in New York.
Gold prices rose yesterday. Gold for April delivery gained $1.60 to settle at $385.70 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
The dollar drifted against the mark in light profit taking. Persistent rumors that the German central bank was selling dollars for marks weighed on the American currency, dealers said, finishing at 1.7590 marks in New York trading, down from 1.7644 on Tuesday.
In Britain, political pressure on Prime Minister John Major's Conservative Party and the interest-rate cut there Tuesday pushed the pound down to $1.4605 in New York, from $1.4670 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Drop as Traders Signal the End of Winter

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Oil prices dropped sharply yesterday as the market sensed that the cold weather blanketing much of the country might not push up fuel demand for much longer.
Traders were also betting that prices may be heading to new five-year lows as oil supplies remain high. 
 Crude oil for March delivery fell a steep 61 cents to close at $14.60 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. That was above the five-year low of $13.75 reached in December, but well off the $20-a-barrel price at this time last year.
 
 
'Winter Has Come to an End'
 The price weakness affected March heating oil, which sank 1.17 cents to end at 49.40 cents a gallon. March unleaded gasoline was off 1.32 cents at 43.35 cents a gallon.
"The market is saying that the winter has come to an end," Peter Gignoux, head of the energy trading desk of Smith Barney Shearson in London, said.
Analysts said the lower price stemmed from Tuesday's report by the American Petroleum Institute on the nation's oil inventories.
The trade group said that in the latest week the nation's reserve of distillate -- the refined product from which heating oil is derived -- fell by a smaller-than-expected 4.21 million barrels. That compared with a bigger decline of 8.4 million barrels a week earlier.
Oil prices have been supported recently by rising demand for heating fuel in an extremely cold winter in the Northeast. As recently as last week, oil stood at 10-week high of $16.34.
But oil traders reckoned the cold weather was about to end, which could put prices on a collision course with December's lows. They cited talk of ample supplies of North Sea crude oil.
A survey found that Norway's oil output was close to setting a new record in January despite continued winter storms, reaching 2.48 million barrels a day from 2.43 million in December.
 
 
'Few Buyers'
 "There seems to be a lot of cargoes available and few buyers," Tom Bentz, energy analyst at Quantum Financial Services, said.
Meanwhile, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said yesterday that it would not decide on any production cuts before it meets on March 25, and even then a cut is not certain.
"Traders are looking past winter and to the end of March, and OPEC appears unwilling to reduce output," said Alan Struth, chief economist at Phillips Petroleum in Bartlesville, Okla. "You don't see the Saudis out there saying, 'We need to cut.' "

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Vietnam may be too poor to justify a big business incursion.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IT'S Coke vs. Pepsi and United Airlines vs. Northwest in the post-embargo battle to win the hearts and wallets of the Vietnamese. These and dozens of other American name brands are sure to be welcomed, both because Vietnam is aching to end its psychological isolation and because American businesses are positioned to sell what the country wants most.
But there is a real question of whether Vietnam can grow fast enough to justify an aggressive marketing effort. While David Dollar, an economist at the World Bank, is "cautiously optimistic" that Vietnam will soon break out of the pack of the world's poorest countries, the obstacles are formidable. 
 The most immediate problems are wretched physical infrastructure (trains, planes, telephones, power plants) along with an absence of free market institutions (banking, property rights, contract law). But Adam Fforde, an Australian consultant specializing in the Vietnamese economy, thinks the Government may lose control over budget and credit policies -- a weakness that dogs Russia and is casting a shadow over China's development.
And even if Vietnam has the discipline to complete the transition from socialism, it is far from clear that America will play a significant part in its immediate future. Irwin Robinson, head of the United States-Vietnam Chamber of Commerce in New York City, says that "the President's proclamation ending the embargo is a one-way street:" Unless the Administration also lifts the heavy tariffs on Vietnamese goods, they will be priced out of the American market.
The end of the embargo allows American companies to sell or invest virtually as they please in Vietnam. And that puts Americans in a better position than one might expect in light of the fact that they must play catch-up with established Japanese, Taiwan, French, German and Thai businesses.
For one thing, Mr. Dollar says, Vietnam's greatest needs are in things that America produces well and relatively cheaply: industrial machinery, telecommunications equipment, financial services. For another, Mr. Robinson says, the Vietnamese are eager to offset the regional influence of China and Japan with a strong American presence. Last but not least, the Vietnamese retain great (some would say exaggerated) respect for the technology of their former adversary.
The fly in the trade soup is that Vietnam does not have "most favored nation" status -- the automatic benefit of the generous tariff reductions negotiated by America and its trade partners since World War II. To be eligible, the President must certify that Vietnam permits open emigration, a delicate matter in view of the wish of many liberals to retain the option to deny the same trade status to China on human-rights grounds. But unless Washington bends, Vietnam will surely be tempted to buy from countries that permit easier access for Vietnamese goods.
In any event, Vietnam may not have much to sell to anyone, anytime soon. On the plus side, the country is blessed with an educated labor force, enough arable land and oil to be self-sufficient in food and energy at high levels of consumption and, miracle of miracles, state enterprises that make a profit.
What's more, it embarked on a successful regimen of economic "shock therapy" in 1989, wiping out price controls while clamping down on both budget deficits and bank credit. Inflation was contained, apparently without reducing national income, and exporters weathered the collapse of Soviet trade far better than their counterparts in more heavily industrialized Eastern Europe. "There is a lot of dynamism" in the economy, says John Whalley, a development economist at the University of Western Ontario. "I see a lot of parallels with South Korea in the 1950's," he added.
But it is easy to lose perspective. Income per person is still in the same league as the destitute nations of sub-Saharan Africa. And while the Vietnamese economy has performed magnificently in the last few years, the next few may prove tougher.
Mr. Fforde's primary concern is inflation driven by slippage in fiscal and banking discipline. The tax system, he notes, is primitive and ill equipped to deal with private enterprise. And the Government's revenue problems may soon be worsened by state-owned monopolies' waning power to charge enough prices to cover their bloated costs.
The Pacific Basin Research Institute, a Maryland research group, focuses on the strains on the expenditure side of the budget equation. Personal incomes are already twice as high in Ho Chi Minh City as in Hanoi, and four times as much as in the highlands. If this gap between the capitalist-minded south and the deeply impoverished, largely rural north should widen yet more, the Government may feel obliged to compensate the losers with inflationary loans or subsidies.
It is hard to find an analyst who is bearish on the long-term prospects for Vietnam's growth, or pessimistic about America's long-term chances of forging links of mutual economic interest. The operative question, though, is how long is long?

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Yankees Strengthen Rotation With Mulholland

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

 BODY:
After months of inactivity and frustration in their quest for another quality starting pitcher, the Yankees finally erased some of the lingering doubts about their rotation yesterday by acquiring Terry Mulholland from Philadelphia for reliever Bobby Munoz and two Class AA players.
Excluding the economics, it was a splendid deal for the Yankees because they made their rotation much more formidable by adding the left-handed Mulholland and because they did not sacrifice their prized Class AAA pitching prospects. 
 Although the Phillies had initially asked for Sterling Hitchcock, Mark Hutton or Bob Wickman with Munoz, the Yankees would not relinquish them and instead surrendered left-hander Ryan Karp and second baseman Kevin Jordan. Besides Mulholland, the Yankees also got a player to be specified later.
 
Packed With Potential
 Injecting Mulholland into a starting group that already includes left-handers Jimmy Key and Jim Abbott and right-hander Melido Perez gives the Yankees four pitchers with the potential to win at least 15 games each.
The deal also sets up a tussle for the fifth spot in the rotation between Scott Kamieniecki, Hutton, Hitchcock, Bob Ojeda and Sam Militello. And most important, the trade elevates the Yankees closer to Toronto in the American League East.
"The way I look at it, it improves us," said General Manager Gene Michael. "If you improved yourself, you closed the gap."
Now that the Yankees have obtained Mulholland, Michael might be wise to consider signing him to a multiyear contract. Mulholland, who turns 31 next month and earned $2.65 million last season, has an arbitration hearing scheduled for Feb. 18 in which he is seeking $4.05 million for 1994.
Now that the Yankees have assumed Philadelphia's counteroffer of $3.35 million, they must either sign Mulholland before then or argue against their newest player in arbitration.
"I'm assuming we can probably get a deal worked out," said Joe Bick, Mulholland's agent, who asked for a three-year deal with a no-trade clause from Philadelphia and was rebuffed because the Phillies want to trim their payroll. "I don't think Terry wants to be losing an arbitration case as he goes into a new situation and I don't think the Yankees want to lose one either."
Regarding a long-term contract, Bick was not as confident.
"If the Yankees are interested in talking about more than one year," Bick said, "we'll listen."
Michael, who obviously wants Mulholland for more than one year, was unsure about future negotiations.
"When you trade for Terry Mulholland, you don't know the condition of his thinking," Michael said. "You don't know if he's going to play one year or sign a three-year contract."
Even Mulholland said he does not know.
"Being as this is my first three hours with the Yankees, it's hard to say I'm looking toward finishing my playing career as a Yankee," he said yesterday.
Mulholland, who reached the majors with the San Francisco Giants in 1986 and has a 57-58 career record that includes a no-hitter against the Giants for Philadelphia in 1990, is a pitcher who relies on sliders, sinkers, precise control and changing speeds. He has maybe the best pickoff move in the majors and his acquisition is certain to pick up the Yankees in a division that has been improving all around them.
Mulholland gives the Yankees the chance to have four left-handed starters, which is a plus at Yankee Stadium and against the Blue Jays. Toronto was 22-25 against left-handed starters in 1993 and was beaten by Mulholland in Game 2 of the World Series last fall.
Mulholland, the starter for the National League in last year's All-Star Game, finished 12-9 with a 3.25 earned run average in helping the Phillies win the National League pennant.
 
News on the Road
 He learned about the trade yesterday from his brother in a call to his car telephone while he was preparing to leave for Clearwater, Fla., Philadelphia's spring-training site. After first thinking it was a prank, he called General Manager Lee Thomas of Philadelphia, who confirmed the news.
"There's a lot of relief," Mulholland said. "I know where I'll be driving my truck this week. I'll just have to drive a little further to Fort Lauderdale."
Thomas, who conceded that he would probably "take a lot of heat" for the trade, said he feared losing Mulholland to free agency after this season for a draft choice. Instead, the Phillies have obtained in Munoz a talented pitcher who started out impressively before slumping to a 3-3 record and a 5.32 e.r.a. last season, angering the Yankees along the way because of his excessive weight.
Jordan hit .283 with 16 homers and 87 runs batted in at Class AA, but his path to the majors with the Yankees was blocked by Pat Kelly. Karp was 16-3 with a 2.10 e.r.a. at Class AA and Class A, but he will be 24 years old in April and is considered a soft thrower.
 
INSIDE PITCH
 While the Yanks obtained a needed starter in TERRY MULHOLLAND , they might be losing out on some bullpen help because STEVE FARR is close to signing with another team. DICK MOSS , Farr's agent, said, "We'll be doing something in the next few days."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Inertia Worries Progressives

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Jan. 27 Political Memo on the cold shoulder liberals are getting from Clinton Democrats conveys the depth of progressive misgivings about President Clinton, but not the content. Few liberals quibble with the importance of overhauling national policy concerning health care, crime and welfare. The question is: Do the Clinton proposals come close to addressing the real problems?
The Congressional Budget Office has shown that the only way to provide health care to the 37 million uninsured Americans and save money is through a single-payer, Canadian-style system. The biggest source of inefficiency is the private insurance industry, which consumes $1 of every $4 in health care (in Canada, Government administration costs only $1 of every $10). 
 Mr. Clinton's political judgment -- that it is better to raise taxes (an unpopular act) than to sacrifice the insurance industry (which no one likes) -- is bizarre. His proposals will probably give us a system that costs much more, still leaves millions of Americans uncovered, or both.
On crime, serious analysts know that Mr. Clinton's three-strikes-and-you're-out proposal is posturing. Our problem is not a shortage of prisons. We already have more prisoners per capita than any other country in the world. Crime is out of control because of the proliferation of guns and the persistence of deep poverty, about both of which the President is doing little. His signature on the Brady bill was a tiny step forward, but his embrace of National Rifle Association officials, rather than of proposals for comprehensive licensing and banning of all guns, is not encouraging.
As for poverty, the Administration's response is to toss welfare recipients off the dole in two years. But if there are no jobs for these 1.5 million to 2 million people (mostly single mothers), this will be the cruelest social policy in modern American history. Unfortunately for welfare recipients and for the 12 million Americans unemployed, there is no serious public jobs program on the table.
Mr. Clinton has no money to provide jobs or further poverty relief because he refuses to challenge the twin pillars of his Republican predecessors -- that taxes on the wealthy should not be raised and that the bloated military budget should not be cut. With the cold war over, the Pentagon budget is outrageous. Mr. Clinton argues that the military budget of $277 billion cannot be cut, though the next 10 largest military budgets in the world (nearly all allies) total $250 billion. Russia, arguably the most formidable potential threat, spends less than $40 billion.
Progressives worry not if this President is moving far or fast enough, but if he is moving forward at all.
 
MICHAEL H. SHUMAN
Director, Inst. for Policy Studies
Washington, Feb. 1, 1994

HEADLINE: George Wallace Rues and Relishes the Past

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala.

 BODY:
His thoughts, he says, are more on the next world than this one, but as he lies beneath a brooding cloud of smoke from his Garcia y Vega cigars, George Corley Wallace is still hoping for redemption before death as well as after it.
"They all talking like me," he gasped, pushing out his words in short hoarse breaths. "Nixon. Reagan. Clinton. Welfare reform. Crime. Big government. Taxes on the middle class. They all saying now what I was saying then." 
 For those who remember him as the defiant voice of the segregated South in its death throes, there is little that appears familiar in the tired man in the wheelchair who spends most of his time with black aides and talks of his commitment to racial harmony.
 
Assassination Attempt
 But just over two decades after a gunman's bullets tore into his spine, ending his national political aspirations, Mr. Wallace lives on, a presence at once ghostly and eerily up to date, whose political legacy says as much about recent political history as it does about him.
And if his version of his own history is a predictably sanitized one, it is hard to dispute that Mr. Wallace's Presidential campaigns, in a particularly raw form, presaged much of the politics since.
He was the first politician of his generation to mobilize the blue-collar white voters who came to be known as Reagan Democrats, the first to tap into the angry disaffection with Washington that has come to dominate the nation's politics, and the first national figure to jab a cattle prod into issues like crime, race and welfare that still resonate in more polite forms a quarter-century later.
"It is difficult to conceive of what American politics of the 1960's, 70's and 80's would be like without George Wallace," said Dan Carter, a professor of history at Emory University who is writing a biography of Mr. Wallace. "I don't think there's a single issue that Nixon and Reagan talk of in terms of social issues that he doesn't get to first."
A new biography, "George Wallace: American Populist," (Addison-Wesley, 1994) by Stephan Lesher, comes to the same conclusion.
No fiction could surpass the morality play that has been the life of Mr. Wallace. First was the man who hissed into a cold January wind "Segregation now, segregation tomorrow, segregation forever." The year was 1963, and Mr. Wallace was delivering his first inaugural address as Governor of Alabama.
 
Presidential Campaigns
 Then came the razor-edged, right-wing populism of two Presidential campaigns in 1968 and 1972 when he lambasted "pointy-headed intellectuals," "loose-minded, high-livin' liberals" and "briefcase-totin' bureaucrats." Five bullets fired by Arthur H. Bremmer at a Laurel, Md., shopping center on May 15, 1972, ended it all, beginning a long, pained effort to make amends and find peace that continues still.
At the age of 74, Mr. Wallace is paralyzed from the waist down, in considerable pain and almost totally deaf. He suffers from Parkinson's disease and arthritis, and his taut features have long since given way to a jowly old age.
A year and a half ago, a blood infection almost killed him. But, after all the obituaries were prepared, he rallied and recovered. He now goes to his office at Troy State University in Montgomery two or three times a week and eats lunch most days at Morrison's Cafeteria or Martin's Cafeteria. Most weekends he is strapped down in his van and driven to his hometown of Clio, 63 miles southeast of Montgomery, stopping to eat at Wilson's Barbecue in Troy along the way.
A few months back, he attended the National Black Mayor's Conference in Tuskegee at the mayors' invitation.
 
'I Didn't Hate Anybody'
 But he rarely makes public appearances and communicates only by responding to written notes. Instead, he spends much of his time at home in an electrically adjustable hospital bed, lighting up his Garcia y Vega Gran Premios with a Wild Turkey lighter, watching CNN, either close-captioned or with the sound off, and brooding about his place in history.
"The New York Times, the Eastern establishment newspapers never did understand that segregation wasn't about hate," he said, his eyes watery but clear. "I didn't hate anybody. I don't hate the man who shot me. When I was young, I used to swim and play with blacks all the time. You find more hate in New York, Chicago, and Washington, D.C., than in all the Southern states put together."
It is a theme he has voiced for 30 years, and historians may forever debate how much of his defense of segregation reflected bigotry, how much was a cynical political gambit and how much reflected the rage that surged through the South at the specter of Northerners telling them how to run their society.
 
Stains of Racism
 Mr. Wallace maintains that he supported segregation not because of racism but because he believed -- incorrectly he now says -- it was best for whites and blacks. But just as it is indisputable that he inflamed ugly racial issues as few national politicians have, it is also true that he has spent the last two decades seeking redemption, appearing at black churches, forging political alliances with blacks and being elected to his fourth term as Governor in 1982 largely because of black support.
On some level he knows, as Mr. Lesher's book says, that "Like the imagined indelible bloodstain on Lady Macbeth's hands, the stains of racism on Wallace's reputation will never be washed away." Still, he argues his case.
One by one, he calls in his two black attendants, Eddie Holcey and Jimmy Dallas, and a black state trooper, Benjamin Hamilton, asking them if he hates blacks. They roll their eyes, partly at the question, partly at the tableau in which they are actors, and say no, no, he does not.
"Segregation was wrong," he said, as he has for much of his life since the shooting. "But I didn't bring segregation about. It was there when I got to the Governor's office. It's gone, and I'm glad it's gone. It's so much better to see people together the way they are now."
Even before his shooting, Mr. Wallace realized he had made a Faustian bargain with race. It added a visceral intensity that fueled his national candidacy, but it left him too far outside the political mainstream to be elected President. But aside from his stand on segregation and the air of raw menace that pervaded his national campaigns in 1968 and 1972, there is little in those races that is not strikingly contemporary.
"What are people going to worry about in the 70's?" he said in a 1970 interview with The New York Times in which he predicted a conservative backlash against liberal social policies and a national tax revolt. "Why, about the things in our program -- taxes, law and order, local control of government and other institutions."
Asked in a recent interview what his main issue would be today, he returned to a favorite theme and said, "Changing our asinine tax structure and stop taxing the middle class."
 
Views on Political Figures
 Asked about political figures, he is generally approving of Bill Clinton, less so of Ronald Reagan, whose economic policies he says are responsible for the high deficit. He prefers to keep his negative comments on Ross Perot private, saying on the record only, "He's O.K."
Not long ago, he made one of his few public appearances in recent years, appearing at a local mall with Mr. Lesher to autograph copies of the biographer's book.
He came bearing a prepared statement. On segregation, he was contrite: "I was wrong, and I'm sorry. I don't expect people to forget words and deeds that might have hurt them, but I ask that they try to remember actions designed to help them."
On race, he sounded like a New Democrat. "I'm frankly concerned that much of this country is turning away from trying to overcome our differences and is retreating to resegregation," he said. "If it was wrong when I was supporting it, it's no less wrong now."
He congratulated Mr. Clinton on his State of the Union Message, called on him to revive his economic stimulus program. "Even though I have always supported strong law-and-order measures and welfare reform, I have always believed that the ultimate answer was in better education and more realistic job opportunities."
The crowds came early and stayed until Mr. Wallace, after almost three hours of sitting upright and signing almost 700 books, slumped down in pain and was wheeled away.
There was Claude McClearen, known as Rooster, who used to give a defiant rooster crow at Mr. Wallace's campaign rallies, and is still fighting the Civil War. There was Sarah Norred, the Montgomery County Tax Collector, who, with the unerring ability to gloss over minor unpleasantries, sees Mr. Wallace as a political legend, and cannot imagine race's dimming his legacy. "He's a good man, and he stood up for Alabama," she said.
There was Alva Lambert, a Montgomery County Deputy District Attorney, who admires Mr. Wallace as a shot of 100 proof J. W. Dant Bourbon in an era of Chablis politics.
"He wasn't perfect," Mr. Lambert said, "but he was a genuine human being. Now they're all media-produced, mass-marketed, blow-dried and look like a guy selling Century 21 real estate."
 
'He's Changed'
 There was Donna Gunn, a black woman who brought her fourth-grade class to see the man who once stood in the door at the University of Alabama rather than integrate the campus. "I really and truly hated that man," she said, "but I see how he's changed, and it's changed my opinion of him."
Another black woman, Mattie Brinson, was shopping in the mall, only to look up in amazement and see the former Governor sitting in his wheelchair.
"I have to shake his hand," said Ms. Brinson, who is 76. "I can't afford no book, but I have to shake his hand."
Asked if she harbored any ill will toward Mr. Wallace, she waved her arm as if swatting the question away.
"We're all human," she said. "The Lord made us all. We're born in this world alike, and we'll all go to sleep alike, too."

HEADLINE: New York Hospitals Chief Calls Brooklyn Plan a Giant Failure

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Charging a decade of mismanagement and incompetence, the new chairman of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that his agency had "completely screwed up" the planned billion-dollar reconstruction of Kings County Hospital, the city's largest public medical center.
In 1984 the agency embarked on what was then a $550 million project to build a new 1.4 million-square-foot public hospital for the largely impoverished neighborhood in central Brooklyn. "Ten years later," said Luis A. Miranda Jr., chairman of the corporation's board, "after having spent $119 million to date, we have only an administrative building, a food service building, a couple of holes in the ground, a few parking lots and some pictures of past mayors with hard hats claiming they have fulfilled a promise." 
 In addition, he said, "what we do have is an angry community and very little to show for it."
He laid the blame for the failure on his agency and its staff, the hospital's management and the project construction manager. "The absence of a team effort produced little or no project accountability, significant delays and a more costly project," Mr. Miranda said. "Because we have handled the management of the project so poorly, now it becomes everyone's and nobody's fault."
Following the lead of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who last week imposed a moratorium on the construction plan, Mr. Miranda called yesterday for a review of the project. That will mean yet another delay in the tortuous effort to replace a 62-year-old public hospital that is a virtual museum of an early-20th-century medical center. Almost all of its 1,200 beds are in large open wards, and the building makes do with balky window air-conditioners, broken elevators, frequent "brownouts" and an emergency room that cannot begin to meet the health needs of central Brooklyn's low-income residents.
 
An Angry Reaction
 The announcement of the review yesterday infuriated community leaders in central Brooklyn, who have spent years demanding that the hospital be replaced. Elected leaders in the largely black area, already angry at Mayor Giuliani's moratorium, suggested that yesterday's action might be an attempt to scale down or even kill the project.
Mr. Miranda's sharp criticism of his own agency's work under the Dinkins and Koch administrations is supported by interviews over the past week with city and hospital officials, as well as community leaders, who described a decade of legal problems, bureaucratic infighting and political wrangling that has stymied the rebuilding efforts.
The starting date for construction, originally set for early 1992, has been postponed several times, most recently until last month. At the moment, no one involved with the project knows when construction will actually begin.
Several hosptals corporation officials said that the agency staggered under the weight of a project far larger than any it had ever completed and that the logistical difficulties of building a huge new hospital next to an existing one proved far more difficult than either the agency or the contractor ever expected.
Mr. Miranda, who was appointed by Mayor Giuliani, acknowledged in an interview yesterday that the project might have been too much for the hospitals corporation, saying it was possible that the new hospital might have to be built by another government agency and then turned over to the hospitals agency to run.
"If we don't know how to build a billion-dollar project, then we need to figure out and find out who can build it with us," he said. "Our commitment should be, let's build a hospital and let's not have any preconceived ideas that we have to do it this way or the way we have been doing it."
Mr. Miranda mentioned the possibility of future construction being handled by the State Facilities Development Corporation, which built Lincoln and Woodhull Hospitals for the city in the late 1970's. But Woodhull, in northern Brooklyn, opened a decade late and tens of millions of dollars over budget because of problems attributed to mismanagement.
The city agency's admission of mismanagement drew outraged protests from black political leaders in central Brooklyn, who suggested that Mr. Miranda made the admission to justify the moratorium and eventually end the reconstruction project.
"One of the best ways to kill a project is to stop it, let it lay dormant for a while, and then never start it again because it looks too expensive," said Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., who represents the area in the State Assembly and is the Brooklyn Democratic leader. "This statement sounds to me like nonsense, a subterfuge for what they really want to do, which is kill it."
Mr. Norman and several City Council members from the area accused Mr. Giuliani of trying to kill the new hospital because much of the largely black section of central Brooklyn voted for Mayor David N. Dinkins in the November mayoral election.
 
To Review the Project
 But Mr. Miranda insisted yesterday that a new hospital would be built, though he declined to say whether it would be as large or fully equipped as residents have requested. He said the new hospitals corporation board would correct the management problems and proceed with the project, but he added that the construction manager, Turner/Santa Fe Joint Venture, might have to be replaced "if they are not up to the job." He appointed a senior director of the hospitals agency to review the project and recommend ways to get it started, and he said that from now on, the hospital would be the first item on the agenda of every meeting of the capital ommittee of the corporation's board.
Mr. Miranda did not specify the precise nature of the troubles afflicting the project, singling out only his agency and the staff of Turner/Santa Fe, which he criticized for not producing an independent audit of its work that was promised to the board 16 months ago. If the company does not produce the audit, he said, he "will ask the board to dump them."
Officials at Turner/Santa Fe, a joint venture of the Turner Construction Company and the Santa Fe Construction Company, did not return telephone messages yesterday.
But interviews with other city officials, as well as hospital and community leaders, described a decade of bureaucratic bungling and clashing political goals that virtually guaranteed the project would be delayed and over budget.
Two city officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity said that to begin with, the design of the project proved far more difficult than expected. The existing hospital buildings, most of which were completed in 1932, sit on an L-shaped 44-acre site at Clarkson and New York Avenues in Flatbush. Hospitals corporation planners and outside designers spent several years trying to find the right location for the new buildings, trying to work around ancient utility lines and support buildings.
 
Disputes Within Staff
 The pre-construction stage, planned for two years, grew to five. As part of this phase, the contractors had to build new space for the hospital's administrative staff and the food service department so that their existing buildings could be demolished for more construction. Those buildings, completed in 1991, were not occupied until a year later because of disputes within the staff over who would move into them, officials said.
Just before the initial excavation for the main building was scheduled in the spring of 1992, a lengthy dispute broke out over awarding of a contract to an excavation company after a rejected company sued the city. As a result, excavation on the main building never began.
Problems involving the construction manager, Turner/Santa Fe, first came to light in March 1992 when Coopers & Lybrand, an independent auditing firm, wrote the hospitals corporation that the contractor was not properly discharging its responsibilities. But despite the audit report, which warned the agency that the project was in jeopardy, the agency's board approved Turner/Santa Fe's request for $16 million on top of the $19 million it bid to be construction manager for the project.
Mr. Miranda, the agency chairman, said yesterday that the joint venture had recently requested $24 million more for the project, a request he said he did not intend to grant.
Several city officials said one reason for the delay and cost overruns was the area's insistence that much of the construction work go to small, minority-owned companies. Because many such companies were not large enough to be principal contractors in areas like air-conditioning, plumbing or electrical work for the entire building, the project was subdivided into scores of smaller jobs.
But hospital officials and community leaders said the additional contractors had nothing to do with the delays.
Councilwoman Una Clarke, who represents the hospital district, said residents had insisted on minority participation from the beginning.
"This is the first time in central Brooklyn that minority contractors have been able to help create some employment," she said. "The cost to the city will eventually be much higher if they can't create some economic stability in this area."
