HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
G.M. Posts $2.47 Billion Profit for '93

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 10

 BODY:
With demand for cars and trucks growing as its own costs shrink, the General Motors Corporation today reported profits of $2.47 billion for 1993. The company's reviving North American operations posted their first profitable quarter since 1989.
For the three months that ended in December, G.M. said it earned $1.18 billion, or $1.28 a share of common stock. In the quarter a year earlier, G.M. had a $651.8 million net loss. For the quarter, sales totaled $37.27 billion, up from $35.55 billion in 1992. 
For the year, G.M.'s profit equaled $2.13 a share. In 1992, G.M. reported the largest loss in corporate American history: $23.5 billion, or $38.28 a share. That loss reflected a one-time charge of $20.72 billion for the future cost of retiree health benefits.
 
 
 
Investors Disappointed
 Worldwide in 1993, G.M.'s revenue grew 4.5 percent, to $138.22 billion.
G.M.'s announcement, which came before the markets opened, touched off an avalanche of sales of G.M. stock; analysts attributed the selling to profit taking and to investors' disappointment with the company's profits. In heavy trading, the stock closed at $62.50 a share, down $1.75.
In part, analysts said, G.M. -- like the Ford Motor Company, whose stock has slipped since its earnings report on Wednesday -- was a victim of the Chrysler Corporation's success. Three weeks ago, Chrysler reported record earnings for the fourth quarter, surpassing all expectations and inflating investor hopes for the other Big Three reports.
In addition, some investors were anxious about one-time effects on G.M.'s earnings. The quarterly results were depressed by a loss of $189.5 million taken by G.M. on the sale of its Allison Gas Turbine division. But analysts attributed investors' disappointment to a large tax credit that bolstered G.M.'s earnings in the fourth quarter. At the beginning of the year, G.M. overestimated its tax liability for 1993; its adjustment added more than $400 million, or 65 cents a share, to the quarterly bottom line.
 
 
 
'Fundamental Improvement'
 "It's kind of sad, because all people want to know is, 'What's this tax thing, again?"' Jack Kirnan, the auto industry analyst with Salomon Brothers, said. Because of that fixation, he said, investors ignored the real news in the earnings report. "You've still got massive, fundamental improvement," he said.
Phil Fricke, the automotive analyst for Prudential Securities, said, "What this fourth quarter and full year tell me is that the company's effort to build a competitive automotive operation in North America is working, big time."
 G.M.'s North American operations lost $17 billion from 1990 to 1993, leading to a board room putsch more than a year ago. Since taking over as president and chief executive in late 1992, John F. Smith Jr. has been working to cut the cost of materials in North America, reduce the variety of parts in G.M. vehicles and increase the productivity of G.M.'s 262,000 hourly workers.
 
 
 
Profit in North America
 G.M.'s changes are occurring as demand for cars and trucks is growing and a strong Japanese yen is driving up Japanese car prices. As a result, G.M. bettered Mr. Smith's goal for 1993 of breaking even in North America -- before interest, taxes and other charges. On that modest basis, G.M. reported that it made $362 million in North America for the year.
But G.M. was also profitable in North America in the fourth quarter on a net-income basis. Even with the tax adjustment factored out, the North American operations cleared a net profit of $75 million in the quarter.
For 1994, Mr. Smith has set a "no excuses" goal of breaking even in North America on a net-income basis.
Although its sales grew during 1993 in the expanding United States market, G.M.'s share of that market continued its slide. In 1993, it held 33.2 percent of the total car and light- truck market, down from 33.9 percent a year ago. Ten years ago, G.M. held more than 40 percent.
G.M.'s unfinanced pension liability -- the amount the company has failed to set aside to cover future retirees' pensions -- ballooned in 1993. From $14 billion in 1992, it grew to $22.3 billion, despite G.M. contributions of $4.4 billion. But the final tally was less than the $24 billion G.M. had predicted, a result the company attributed to good portfolio management.
G.M. is awaiting Federal approval of a plan to contribute to the fund 185 million shares of stock in a subsidiary, Electronic Data Systems. The company's stated goal is to finance the plan fully by the year 2000.
 
 
 
A Surprise on Health Costs
 One surprise in today's report was that G.M.'s health care costs, after regularly leaping upward in recent years, held steady at $5.6 billion in 1993. "It's the first time we've been flat in, like, the history of mankind," said G. Richard Wagoner, the executive vice president who is G.M.'s finance and purchasing chief.
In fact, costs climbed about 5 percent, compared with a 13.1 percent increase from 1991 to 1992, but because the number of covered employees and dependents shrank, the net result was the same dollar cost as in 1992. Mr. Wagoner attributed the low inflation rate to G.M.'s growing reliance on plans that encourage workers to pick less expensive health care.
G.M. was the last of the Big Three auto makers to report fourth-quarter earnings. On Wednesday, Ford said it earned $719 million in the quarter, and last month Chrysler reported quarterly earnings of $777 million.
G.M. also reported today that it lowered cash rebates for its vehicles as demand rose, to $880 a vehicle last year from an average of $960 a vehicle in the fourth quarter of 1992.
Mr. Wagoner also said G.M. workers increased their productivity by more than 10 percent in the year, measured in labor hours per vehicles. He declined to say how many hours G.M. takes to build a car.

HEADLINE: Claims Fall For Jobless

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for state jobless benefits fell last week by 47,000, to 366,000, almost erasing the large jump after the California earthquake, the Government said today.
 The sharp drop in first-time claims for the week that ended last Saturday was the largest in more than five months, the Labor Department said. 
 New claims had surged 50,000, to 413,000, the prior week, with about 20 percent of the increase attributed to Californians seeking state unemployment benefits, the department said.
 That jump helped push the closely watched average level of claims over the last four weeks to 377,250, its highest level in more than 15 months. The four-week average was up from 375,000 the prior week and compared with 378,750 in the Oct. 17, 1992, week.
 But analysts said the claims level now appears to be stabilizing after unusual disruptions -- freezing weather and natural disaster -- in January. They had forecast 371,000 new state claims in the week that ended last Saturday.
 In addition to the new state claims, 6,010 people made first-time claims for Federal emergency benefits, which help people who have exhausted their regular benefits, in the week ended Jan. 29, the latest period for which those data are available. That was down from 7,615 emergency claims the previous week. Unlike the state data, the Federal figures are not seasonally adjusted.
 The department said the drop in initial claims last week was the largest since a 56,000 decline in the July 31, 1993, week.

HEADLINE: Review/Design;
Stylish Persuaders For Modern Times

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
LIKE the recent "Frontline" documentary on diamonds, the new show at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum tackles the subject of consumer manipulation. The "Frontline" program recounted how the South African diamond cartel conspired with advertisers to maintain high prices by creating the illusion that diamonds were rare. "Packaging the New," which opened this week at the Cooper-Hewitt, traces the history of an esthetic cartel -- industrial design -- and the mythology devised by designers to enlarge the market for furnishings, appliances and other household goods.
Focusing on the work of six noted American designers, the show traces a 50-year period beginning in the mid-1920's, when industrial design became an organized profession, and culminating in the mid-1970's, when the oil crisis and environmental degradation prompted widespread disillusion with the industrial juggernaut. Donald Deskey, Russel Wright, Norman Bel Geddes, Raymond Loewy, Walter Dorwin Teague and Henry Dreyfuss: those were the cream of the industrial-design profession. They set a machine-age stamp on everything from cocktail shakers to detergent boxes, airplanes to prefabricated housing, fabrics to World's Fair previews of an utterly transformed world. 
 The message sent forth by these designers was the antithesis of "diamonds are forever." What they said, more or less, is that "design is for the moment." Yesterday's chair, table or refrigerator was obsolete. Happiness awaited purchasers of the very latest style. Together with advertising men like Earnest Elmo Calkins, the designers introduced what the show's curator, Gail S. Davidson, calls "style obsolescence." Unlike planned obsolescence, which insured that an appliance would fall apart in a few years, style obsolesence guaranteed that its esthetic appeal would disintegrate with the arrival of the next streamlined style. The goal of this enterprise, to judge from this show, was only incidentally esthetic. The main objective was to stimulate the American economy by enticing American consumers to buy things they didn't know they wanted.
Organized chronologically by decades, the show is prefaced by a recreated store window designed in 1929 by Henry Dreyfuss for Saks & Company. The display, featuring a smart Molyneux outfit accented by a folding Deskey screen, announces the show's view of industrial design as something theatrical, something not far removed from fashion (and perhaps indistinguishable from it), and, above all, as something created chiefly to seduce onlookers to buy.
Fortunately for the museumgoer, most of the 200 or so objects on view have not lost their allure, decades after its intended obsolescence. For fans of Art Deco, 40's streamlining and the 50's style alternately known as "populuxe" or "googie," the show offers a filling visual binge. Though one need not venture this far uptown to enjoy Deskey's sumptuous interiors at Radio City Music Hall, the show sets out the impressively wide range of Deskey's work, from a gorgeous ebony chest of drawers from the 1930's to the cobra-head streetlight Deskey designed for New York in 1958. Deskey's design for a communications pavilion at the 1939 World's Fair, far from looking obsolete, is actually prophetic. More than half a century before "Late Night With Conan O'Brien," Deskey envisioned modern man as a gigantic, transparent plastic talking head.
Constantin Boym has designed the show's installation with economy and humor, arranging objects into period theme tableaux, like "Cocktails" in the 1930's, "Supermarket" shopping in the 50's and a 60's "Recreation Room." One witty section converts the museum's conservatory into a stretch of landscaped "parkway" connecting the 40's to the 50's. Dominated by a large photograph of Deskey's streetlight fixture, houseplants nestle at the base of magazine ads enlarged to resemble billboards. The display ushers in the postwar exodus to suburbia and the promised land of consumer products after years of wartime scarcity. There, all is Cheer, Joy and Micrin mouthwash, each handsomely packaged by Deskey.
Though much of the show is a cavalcade of relatively familiar period icons, there are nice surprises along the way. The chaste modernity of Ilonka Karasz's silverplated tableware (circa 1928) transcends the merely moderne. Richard Arbib's Musaphonic radio (1958) and Visonette television (1947), and David Chapman's mixer and blender (circa 1960) have the spiky, swollen glamour of erotic fetishes. For Valentine's Day, you will definitely want to give or get one of Kodak's folding "Coquette" cameras, designed by Walter Dorwin Teague to resemble a lady's compact. A concluding tableau, which Dr. Davidson calls the Hall of Obsolescence, mounts a hysterical fashion show of toasters. It sums up the show's message that while consumer products underwent dramatic changes in appearance, their inner workings often remained unchanged.
Needless to say, the show's somewhat jaundiced view of industrial design does not entirely conform to the profession's view of itself. And while it is commendable that Cooper-Hewitt should take a more critical look at its subject matter, there is something fundamentally misguided about the show's reduction of industrial design to a matter of style. It has resulted in a treatment of its subject that, in its own sour way, is as insubstantial as the froth from a Bel Geddes cocktail shaker.
Is it true, for instance, that styling in the 20th century has taken such overbearing precedence to technological innovation? While toasters may not have advanced technically, many things did. My father, a mechanical engineer who worked with Dreyfuss on Honeywell's ubiquitous round thermostat control, helped develop a device that made homes more comfortable. Dreyfuss made the device more attractive. Similar advances in lighting, food preparation, transportation, communication and, yes, fashion could not have occurred without the support of the marketplace. Design was a good way to muster that support.
Moreover, the willingness of consumers to be manipulated is not boundless, as American car manufacturers discovered to their chagrin in the 1970's and 80's. In those years, manufacturers put just as much effort as ever into "packaging the new." But their efforts went nowhere until they came up with designs that were not only new but corresponded to the consumer's view of contemporary life. The minivan, for example, is ideally suited to a time of breakdown in the distinction between "town" and "country."
Surely, many of the objects displayed at Cooper-Hewitt were successful because they connected consumers to the industrial age. Does the show mean to suggest that the Industrial Revolution was more hype than history? Or that the mass public, which was partly created by that revolution, had no business getting a kick out of it?
The concept of progress is not exactly something cooked up by advertisers, either. It was an Enlightenment tenet that industry would advance the cause of freedom because it would shift the balance of power away from palace and church toward natural law. Modernism was not the first movement to seek a design vocabulary to express this social ideal. Neo-Classicism, Arts and Crafts and Art Nouveau also employed formal means to create something idealistic from the realities of industrial production.
While I myself enjoy the delirious form-making made possible by the industrial designer's tactic of "creative waste" (and I suspect Dr. Davidson does, too), Cooper-Hewitt is surely right to challenge it. But the show's equation between novelty and waste overlooks the fact that "packaging the old" is also a form of waste, and not a very creative one at that. And it's a form we see all around us now.
Today, for example, Deskey's streetlight is being systematically removed from New York City streets and replaced with facsimiles of old cast-iron lampposts. It is a typical expression of our current widespread yearning for the stability of tradition. Such reproductions may give people the illusion that they are showing respect for history, when in fact, as the architecture critic Alan Colquhoun has observed, they are simply indulging a taste for "pastness." Often, as in trashing the epoch that produced Deskey's lamps, they are indulging it at the expense of history. In assailing the new, "Packaging the New" may end up unintentionally fueling an appetite that is no less wasteful, and is arguably more deceptive, than the one it is trying to challenge.
In fact, it might well fuel the same syndrome it wants to challenge. As Mr. Colquhoun observed, "newness" and "oldness" are not so much opposites as complements. They're two poles in the same search for cultural identity, a quest that has been going on since the 18th century, when the public assumed from traditional authorities the task of self-definition. If we want to get off of this shuttle (and maybe we don't), discrediting the new isn't the way to go about it. What we need to think about is the way newness and oldness feed off each other in an endless cycle of taste.
"Packaging the New" remains at the Cooper-Hewitt National Museum of Design, 2 East 91st Street, Manhattan, through Aug. 14.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Revisiting Vietnam on Fantasy's Odd Battlefields

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

Warrior Dreams
Paramilitary Culture in Post-Vietnam America
By James William Gibson
357 pages. Hill & Wang. $23.
With the involvement (and withdrawal) of American forces in Vietnam, the old ideals of movie machismo underwent a violent sea change. The old gunslinger ballads gave way to bloodier and more morally ambiguous sagas (movies like"Shane" were replaced by movies like "The Wild Bunch"), and then in the mid-1970's, the genre of the western itself seemed ready to fade away and die. Meanwhile, however, a new brand of movie hero began to make his way to the screen: Clint Eastwood's Dirty Harry, a renegade cop willing to break all the rules; Charles Bronson's one-man vigilante team in "Death Wish" (and "Death Wish 2," "3" and "4") and, of course, Sylvester Stallone's pumped-up ex-Green Beret, John Rambo. 
 The immense popularity of such heroes, the scholar James William Gibson argues in his new book "Warrior Dreams," both represented and galvanized the emergence of a highly energized new paramilitary culture that offered its aficionados an escape from the social, political and economic confusions of post-Vietnam America.
"It is hardly surprising, then," writes Mr. Gibson, "that American men -- lacking confidence in the government and the economy, troubled by the changing relations between the sexes, uncertain of their identity or their future -- began to dream, to fantasize about the powers and features of another kind of man who could retake and reorder the world. And the hero of all these dreams was the paramilitary warrior. In the New War he fights the battles of Vietnam a thousand times, each time winning decisively. Terrorists and drug dealers are blasted into oblivion. Illegal aliens inside the United States and the hordes of nonwhites in the third world are returned by force to their proper place. Women are revealed as dangerous temptresses who have to be mastered, avoided, or terminated."
In the course of amplifying this thesis, Mr. Gibson, who teaches sociology and history at California State University in Long Beach, pelts the reader with lots of information. He notes the rise of the "techno-thriller" -- exemplified by Tom Clancy's noisy, clattering novels -- and an increase in warrior magazines like Soldier of Fortune. He documents the escalating sales of military weapons like the Uzi and the AK-47, and chronicles the growing popularity of combat schools and firing ranges.
Substantial portions of this volume are devoted to descriptions of a Soldier of Fortune convention, a course in shooting combat pistols and a war-game retreat, where men use paint-ball guns to play at killing one another.
As Mr. Gibson sees it, such warrior fantasies began to seep dangerously into real life during the 1970's and 80's, as "the line between doers and wannabe's often blurred." Paramilitary zealots placed ads in Soldier of Fortune to hire themselves out as mercenaries and hit men; the head of a neo-Nazi group, in search of recruits to his cause, bought the magazine's mailing list. In the 1980's, Mr. Gibson reports, right-wing extremist groups like the Order (which plotted the assassination of the radio announcer Alan Berg in Colorado), began a stepped-up campaign of racist violence.
The same decade, he adds, also witnessed the emergence of psychotic killers who saw themselves as warriors, including James Oliver Huberty, who in 1984 opened fire in a McDonald's restaurant in San Ysidro, Calif., killing 21 and wounding 19; and Patrick Purdy, who used an AK-47 in a Stockton, Calif., schoolyard in 1989 to gun down 5 Southeast Asian children and wound 29 others.
It is Mr. Gibson's contention that American warrior mythology had reverberations on a governmental level as well. Ronald Reagan's Star Wars rhetoric, the invasion of Grenada, covert support of the contras in Central America, Oliver North's theatrics, the invasion of Panama and the Persian Gulf war: all, Mr. Gibson suggests, can be viewed through the lens of America's "post-Vietnam warrior culture."
Although Mr. Gibson lays out his arguments in energetic, readable prose and displays a keen reportorial eye for events he has witnessed, his overall analysis often feels simplistic, derivative and lacking in historical perspective. He fails to situate the new paramilitary ethos of the warrior fully in relationship to America's violent history and its historical faith in the redemptive possibilities of violence. He makes only passing references to the groundbreaking work of the historian Richard Slotkin, but at the same time takes many of his central ideas from Mr. Slotkin's monumental three-volume work on the frontier myth ("Regeneration Through Violence," "The Fatal Environment" and "Gunfighter Nation"). In many cases, Mr. Gibson simply extrapolates Mr. Slotkin's observations to the contemporary American scene, sometimes adding small editorial asides of his own.
These asides tend to be highly subjective, and poorly grounded in factual analysis. Mr. Gibson offhandedly dismisses the gun-control debate, for instance, as "the worst kind of fetishism, in which focusing on a part of the dreadful reality of the decade -- combat weapons -- became a substitute for confronting what America had become."
What are Mr. Gibson's own recommendations for reducing the appeal of warrior mythologies and making America a kinder, gentler place? Well, he suggests that adventure sports (mountain climbing, scuba diving) might provide men with a healthy outlet for their warrior impulses, and that increased male participation in child-rearing might help men to become "more emotionally expressive and less psychologically distant."
Such casually tossed-off suggestions hardly seem like the answer to the culture of violence delineated in these pages, and they ultimately trivialize the very subject Mr. Gibson has labored so hard to explicate in "Warrior Dreams."

HEADLINE: Who Is Running Our Korea Policy?

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration insists it will never subcontract its foreign policy to any international institution. Yet it is doing just that in its nuclear diplomacy with North Korea. It is letting the International Atomic Energy Agency decide how to carry out a deal Washington reached with Pyongyang. By changing the terms of that deal, the I.A.E.A. could embroil the U.S. in a dangerous confrontation on the Korean Peninsula.
The I.A.E.A. is supposed to be negotiating detailed arrangements for inspections at all North Korea's declared nuclear sites. These inspections are designed to insure that nuclear safeguards are in place. More thorough regular inspections, which could impede the diversion of nuclear material to bomb-making, would not resume until the U.S. holds a new round of high-level talks with the North. Inspections of suspected nuclear waste sites to determine whether such diversion has already occurred have yet to be negotiated. 
 But the I.A.E.A., which does not like to see member states trifle with its procedures, is asking for more intrusive access to a reactor site than the North agreed to with Washington, according to Pyongyang. The U.S. now needs to try to break the deadlock between North Korea and the I.A.E.A. before the I.A.E.A. refers the matter to the United Nations Security Council, which has the power to impose economic sanctions on Pyongyang.
The danger is that the drumbeat of war may drown out diplomacy. The Administration is considering the dispatch of Patriot missiles and other military forces to shore up the South. And members of Congress have, perversely, called for putting nuclear arms back into South Korea. Ratcheting up the threats may appease the hawks at home, but it bolsters hard-liners in North Korea, who could use such threats to justify proceeding with the development of nuclear weapons.
Reinforcing the South makes sense if and when the U.S. decides to abandon diplomacy and press for economic sanctions. Such sanctions would likely end all hope of inspecting North Korea's nuclear sites and could lead to the resumption of confrontation in Korea. Given Pyongyang's unpredictability, reinforcements would then be prudent.
But it is premature to be taking such steps now. The U.S. should be doing what it can diplomatically to gain unimpeded access to North Korea's nuclear sites, step by grudging step. And it should not leave it up to the I.A.E.A. to overreach and thereby trigger a confrontation with North Korea.

HEADLINE: Players and Payers

SERIES: SECOND OPINIONS: HEALTH CARE -- An occasional series

BYLINE: By Michael Graetz and James Tobin; Michael Graetz, professor of law at Yale, was Assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury from 1990 to 1992. James Tobin, emeritus professor of economics at Yale, won the Nobel Prize in Economic Science in 1981.

 BODY:
The President and First Lady have achieved remarkable consensus on a truly revolutionary principle: all Americans must be entitled to adequate medical services without regard to ability to pay or risk of ill health. Now it's up to Congress to embody that principle in law, a historic opportunity comparable to the enactments of Social Security in 1935 and Medicare in 1965.
Unfortunately, excessive solicitude for existing institutions and interests, and the difficulties of reconciling them with the Clintons' fundamental principles, have made their proposal a bureaucratic and legalistic morass. 
 The issue is much more basic than what is now preoccupying Washington: whether the reforms would modestly raise the Federal deficit in the short term, as the Congressional Budget Office said this week, and whether federally mandated insurance premiums should be "on budget." The biggest flaw in the Administration proposal is the requirement that employers pay the premiums -- a mandate whose awkwardness and unfairness stand out starkly in a system dedicated to universal coverage.
Employer-based medical insurance is a historical accident -- one that no one would choose now if given a clean slate. During World War II, trade unions and employers circumvented Federal wage ceilings by offering medical fringe benefits. Their popularity and generosity boomed after the war, as Congress sheltered them without limit from income and Social Security taxes.
The fact that employers write the checks for medical care does not mean that they bear the full costs. They can generally shift some costs to workers in reduced take-home pay and some to customers in higher prices. The sure losers are taxpayers who have to make up the revenue lost to the tax shelter.
Much of the Administration's 1,342-page proposal is devoted to expedients intended to mitigate the difficulties and anomalies of employer mandates. It's a hopeless task. Some families have no employed members. Some have two or more. Many employees work part time. Some have more than one job. Americans frequently change jobs, employers, work locations, places -- even states -- of residence.
Responsibilities for paying a family's premiums would frequently be divided among several sources -- various employers, governments and the family itself -- in proportions varying month to month. Keeping track of these liabilities would surely involve extensive paperwork and administrative hassle, contrary to Mrs. Clinton's claim that an employer mandate eliminates the need to track individuals.
Nor would the new system be equitable. Equity demands that public subsidies, direct or via employers, be a larger share of premiums and of income the poorer the family. Equity also requires that families' subsidies be the same if their incomes are the same. But in the Clinton plan, subsidies depend more on the size of employers' payrolls than on families' ability to pay. The system is also full of bad incentives -- for example, not to hire workers with dependents.
It's individuals who get sick and need medical services. It's individuals and families whose ability to pay is the natural criterion of equity. It's individuals who must be guaranteed coverage. So it is it's individuals who must be required to have insurance. Let employers help pay the premiums if they wish, but count those payments as taxable income. Treat the self-employed exactly the same as employees.
Let people choose where they will buy insurance. One option should be a kind of Medicare for those under 65; call it perhaps Fedmed.
Fedmed would offer the basic universal medical insurance package at premiums that in total would cover the costs. Let private health plans offer the same package, provided they do not pick and choose members or charge higher premiums for risky cases. As in the Clinton plan, it would probably be necessary to collect money from plans that happen to have low-risk clienteles and distribute them to plans with high-risk members.
With these provisions, Fedmed would be protected against becoming the last-resort insurer of bad risks. As in Medicare itself (which would continue as at present), people could choose their own physicians and other providers. Like Medicare, Fedmed would have low administrative costs and would wield enough clout to limit payments to providers. Like Medicare, Fedmed would let people change employment status, residence or family situation without losing coverage. But it need not be a monopoly.
Federal subsidies to individuals would take the form of refundable tax credits, "vouchers" payable to Fedmed or other insurers. For low-income families the subsidies would cover the whole premium of the basic package; most other families would receive vouchers at least as valuable to them as the current tax exemption for employer-provided insurance.
A family of four in the 28 percent tax bracket with a $4,300 insurance package would receive vouchers of $1,204 -- 28 percent of the premium. No family would face an out-of-pocket cost of more than 8 or 10 percent of their income for the basic package.
This plan would not require new broad-based taxes or new burdens on employers. One source of financing would be redirecting the Clintons' proposed subsidies to employers and low-income people, estimated at $100 billion in 1999 (somewhat more by the Congressional Budget Office). Eliminating the tax shelter for employer-paid premiums would contribute $125 billion, and our plan would replace Medicaid acute care for those under 65 ($75 billion more).
Robert Reischauer of the C.B.O. destroyed a semantic attraction of employer mandates when he testified that federally required purchases of insurance should be included in the budget. Their popularity is waning among businesses and in Congress, where support appears to be growing for the plans of Representative Jim Cooper and Senator John Chafee; unfortunately, these plans do not assure universal coverage in this century.
Our proposal is not a radical reconstruction. It builds on the best of existing institutions. A victory for it would be a victory for the basic principles that the Clintons have so eloquently set forth.

HEADLINE: Art, Money and the Mayor

 BODY:
Even when New York City is at its bitterest and bleakest, there is one claim New Yorkers can go on making. We have more museums, more galleries, more dance groups and more concerts than any other city in the United States. Furthermore, art -- which naysayers love to describe as elitist -- is for this city a cash cow. As a Port Authority study attested last year, New York's extraordinary cultural concentration means jobs, lots of them, for New Yorkers, and tax revenues for the city and state.
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani appears to realize this, which is why he has made a grab for the very attractive offer dangled by leaders in the city's art world. We will pony up $10 million in private contributions, they said, if you will restore the $4.2 million you want to cut from the arts budget -- and add $5 million more. The deal is contingent on the state also contributing an additional $5 million. 
 Mr. Giuliani has accepted the challenge; the arts group is confident of raising its share; and the rest is up to the state, which so far has seen virtue only in the short-term gains of Draconian cuts. Three years ago the New York State Arts Council budget, much of which comes to the New York metropolitan area, was $54 million. Today it is a mere $25 million. Given the arts' proven ability to trigger economic returns, this form of penny-pinching is foolish.
There are questions to be answered about this plan. Will the city's smallest art institutions, for instance, get the squeeze? No, the plan's sponsors say. They will benefit because not only will they get their share of the restored $4.2 million, but they will get help from the Department of Cultural Affairs about fund-raising. They can also benefit from the advice given them by the larger institutions and by being placed, on occasion, under one umbrella. One massive effort on behalf of groups involved in preserving and disseminating Hispanic culture, say, could profit all of them.
Could the city's largest institutions, by gobbling up $750,000 apiece, which is the plan's cap on grants, leave too little of the pie for the others? Again the sponsors say no. The rules applying to them would be more stringent than those applying to the small groups. The big players have to prove that their grants would be used solely to improve the public's access. The smaller groups could use their grants to pay the rent or the oil bills, hire security -- to do all the little things, in other words, that keep them alive and valuable.
Mayor Giuliani is wise to take the arts group's dare. May Governor Cuomo show equal wisdom.

HEADLINE: Populist Challenge in California Race

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 10

 BODY:
Picking up where Ross Perot and Edmund G. Brown Jr. left off in the 1992 Presidential campaign, Tom Hayden is running for governor of California on what he calls a crusade against the influence of special interests in politics.
Mr. Hayden, whose political career started in the protests against the Vietnam War in the 1960's, said he was not in the race to win. But his announcement on Wednesday stunned politicians in this state capital and could significantly shift the dynamics of what is shaping up to be a hard-fought race in a big state. 
 Republicans here said Mr. Hayden's decision would help the Republican incumbent, Gov. Pete Wilson, by fragmenting Democratic voters in the primary on June 7, in which Mr. Hayden is taking on Kathleen Brown, the state Treasurer, and John Garamendi, the state insurance commissioner.
Mr. Hayden, a 54-year-old state senator from Santa Monica, said in an interview today that he was running because of a "tacit silence among Republicans and Democrats about campaign reform and lobbying reform." Mr. Hayden, wealthy since he won a large divorce settlement after splitting with the actress Jane Fonda in 1989, would not need to raise much money for a statewide campaign.
 
$94 Gift Limits
 Like Mr. Brown, a former governor of California and Ms. Brown's brother, Mr. Hayden said he would not run 30-second television commercials and would accept only small contributions -- no more than $94 a person ("94 for Reform" is his slogan).
Mr. Hayden has long challenged the establishment; before he married Ms. Fonda, he was a defendant in the Chicago Seven case arising from his protests at the Democratic convention in 1968.
In concentrating on political reform, Mr. Hayden already has plenty of ammunition: Ms. Brown, who announced her candidacy this week, has so far raised far more than $5 million; Mr. Garamendi has more than $1 million. The nominee of each party is expected to raise as much as $25 million.
"It's the ideal situation for Wilson," the House Speaker, Willie L. Brown, a Democrat, said today. He said Ms. Brown, as the front runner in the polls at this early stage, would be hurt because she would be forced to be more specific about her positions during the primary. "Whether it's a crime issue or a race issue," the Speaker said, "she's got to say it now." But others assert that Ms. Brown could benefit because the entry of the liberal Mr. Hayden in the race will make her appear more moderate.
Mr. Brown said in an interview that he was pleased to see Mr. Hayden in the race. "I'm glad he's putting the issue of political reform front and center." Mr. Brown declined to compare his Presidential quest to that of Mr. Hayden, saying he is curious about whether Mr. Hayden will tap his own money.
 
Noncommittal Brother
 Asked whether he would endorse his sister in the primary, Mr. Brown replied: "I'm staying out of the campaign. I'm certainly urging my sister to get out front on political reform."
Mr. Hayden in an interview on the Senate floor rejected any comparison to Mr. Perot or Mr. Brown. "I would ask voters to judge me on the merits and not let immediate stereotypes characterize me," he said. "I don't want to make comparisons. You may. My point is that I think that there's a message of reform that needs to be voiced, and the alternative is the suffocation of silence. If I can be a magnet that redirects debate to reform, my mission is satisfied."
Asked about how much money he planned to spend on a campaign or whether any of it would come from his personal fortune, Mr. Hayden said, "That's unknown."
He said he would rely on a grass-roots organization and a belief that "the free press still can reach as many people as television commercials." And he insisted that he did not see himself as a spoiler, saying, "I'm not trying to defeat them but to unleash a debate and a movement to which they respond."
In a speech on Wednesday, Mr. Hayden, who was elected to the State Assembly in 1982, said he decided to run on the night before the filing deadline on Wednesday because "the earthquake of Jan. 17 jolted me into a greater urgency."
 
Republican Questions
 Some Republicans questioned whether Mr. Hayden was a legitimate populist voice against big money in politics given his own fortune.
"It borders on hypocrisy -- running on taking no more than 94 bucks is all right if you've got plenty of your own money," said Kenneth L. Maddy, the state Senate Republican leader. "You can be holier than thou all you want. It's one thing to limit how much you receive, but the issue is how much you spend." But Mr. Maddy conceded that his colleague across the aisle would be "forcing the issue in a way that no one likes, even Wilson."
In his 1992 campaign for the State Senate, Mr. Hayden spent an estimated $750,000 in a three-way primary, a large amount for such a race.
Mr. Hayden said he would withdraw from the race if the other candidates speak out on his agenda, which includes public financing of campaigns and outlawing political action committees. But thus far, that is not happening. The Brown campaign issued a statement saying that Ms. Brown would continue to emphasize creating jobs, eliminating violence and reforming schools, "no matter who else joins the race." Mr. Garamendi was not much more forthcoming, saying, "I welcome a discussion of the issues raised by Tom Hayden."
Given voters' worries about the economy, the fallout from the earthquake and other matters, Herbert E. Alexander, a political science professor at the University of Southern California, questioned whether Mr. Hayden would succeed in making campaign reform an important issue. "He's trying to force this as an issue," Mr. Alexander said. "But I don't know that Brown or Garamendi will adopt it in a way that will make it a prime issue that would satisfy Hayden or his supporters."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 17, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the entry of Tom Hayden into the race for California governor misattributed a quotation about Kathleen Brown, who is also a Democratic candidate. It was Ms. Brown's brother, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. -- not Willie Brown, the state House Speaker -- who said of Mr. Hayden, "I'm glad he's putting the issue of political reform front and center." Former Governor Brown, who ran for the Democratic nomination for President in 1992, also said: "I'm staying out of the campaign. I'm certainly urging my sister to get out front on political reform."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Investors in California S. & L.'s May Face Their Own Aftershock

BYLINE: By Andrea Adelson 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
ANALYSTS are cautioning that investors in California savings and loan associations need to prepare for a strong aftershock of their own after the Northridge earthquake.
The problem for the S.& L.'s, however, is not damaged homes but a damaged economy. 
 "The real key question is what this will do to the economy in the area," said Thomas O'Donnell, an analyst for Prudential Securities.
The region's already depressed residential real estate market could decline further. Housing prices in the hard-hit San Fernando Valley are at 1988 levels and dropping in some areas at 1 percent a month. Business and home foreclosures are at record levels, a 21-fold increase in four years.
Those trends could be accelerated by a population exodus, new taxes to pay for quake damage and mangled freeways. "Investors should be watchful," he said.
If California's economy continues to lag behind the rest of the nation, lenders will write fewer new mortgages and generate less fee income here, and their earnings will lag behind competitors.
But analysts do not think the direct impact from the quake -- cracked and collapsing homes the S.& L.'s hold mortgages on -- will be that hard on the institutions' earnings. The quake destroyed 9,949 homes and damaged another 45,000 between Santa Monica and Simi Valley.
At worst, industry analysts estimate lenders might face between $1 billion and $2 billion in losses on nonperforming quake loans spread across 100 or more institutions. These preliminary estimates are likely to add just a blip to already jagged earnings records.
For instance, at Great Western Bank, which had $555 million in loan-loss provisions last year, quake losses, including damage to its Chatsworth headquarters, may be $50 million, cutting profit by 15 cents a share, to $1.65, according to one estimate.
While potential quake losses may be widely disbursed, Bruce W. Harting, an analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc., thinks California S.& L.'s will shrug off the quake's impact for another reason. In fact, after avoiding California S.& L.'s since 1989, he is recommending the Great Western Financial Corporation, the San Francisco Federal Corporation and the Golden West Financial Corporation.
It is no coincidence that two of his three recommendations are outside the quake zone. "L.A. is ground zero, literally and figuratively," he said.
Mr. Harting said his stock picks reflected the findings of Salomon's real estate economist, David Hensley, who formerly headed the Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles. Known for his bearish outlook, Mr. Hensley thinks price deflation has ended in California and that the state should see job growth in 1994 outside of Los Angeles. "He may be the first bull," Mr. Harting said.
Even so, the concern is that quake victims, without equity, ineligible for Government grants and too indebted to accept low-interest Small Business Administration loans, will mail in their keys.
Here, mortgage bankers, who make Federal Housing Administration loans, are likely to have quake exposure, according to Jonathan E. Gray, an S.& L. analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. Mortgage banks are required to restore damaged homes with F.H.A. loans, he said.
The nation's largest mortgage banker, the Countrywide Funding Corporation, so far must fix the homes of 55 F.H.A. customers out of 800 borrowers with damage, Thomas H. Boone, a managing director, said. He could not estimate costs.
Unusual flexibility is how H. F. Ahmanson & Company, parent of Home Savings, intends to avoid quake losses.
Rather than foreclose, Home Savings will make interest-free repair loans to borrowers. If such a home eventually sells for less than the original loan, the S.& L. will take a loss. Home Savings estimates that 200 of the 2,000 homes that are damaged fall into this category and has said it will increase its reserves to cover the potential losses.
It was a better bet than the alternative, Charles Rinehart, Home Saving's chairman, said. Adding foreclosure costs to repair costs would likely double the losses, he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Japan Chief Say Trade Talks Fail; U.S. Threatens Action

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
With Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa standing beside him, President Clinton declared trade talks with Japan a failure today, and Administration officials threatened to take aggressive steps to break Japanese barriers to American goods that have created political and economic problems for both countries.
After meeting at the White House with Mr. Hosokawa in what had been billed by both sides as a crucial session for the two leaders, Mr. Clinton offered a pessimistic assessment of the chances that the trade imbalance between the two countries, which neared $60 billion in Japan's favor last year, would be eased anytime soon. 
 "Today we could have disguised our differences with cosmetic agreements," Mr. Clinton said soberly. "But the issues between us are so important for our own nations and for the rest of the world that it is better to have reached no agreement than to have reached an empty agreement."
Although Administration officials characterized the meeting between Mr. Hosokawa and Mr. Clinton as tough, they pointedly declined to specify what steps the United States would be willing to take in an effort to force Japanese markets open. That, one of them said, should wait until the Japanese Prime Minister has left Saturday.
One official said, however, that Mr. Clinton was almost certain to reinstate a lapsed section of American trade law that provides for a strict timetable for Japan to open certain closed markets and includes mandatory sanctions if no deal is reached.
Mr. Clinton invited Mr. Hosokawa to return to the White House before leaving for what an official described as "a purely social" breakfast with no policy discussions scheduled.
 
Otherwise, Warms Ties
 Both leaders emphasized that aside from the trade question, relations between Japan and the United States remained warm and stable.
Although other summit meetings, including President Bush's 1992 trip to Tokyo, have ended in failure, it is very rare for the participants in such conferences to proclaim their lack of accomplishment so openly. Usually, the actual negotiations are conducted by aides well in advance.
The failure to reach a trade agreement will deprive the United States economy of the stimulus Mr. Clinton had hoped it would provide. Retaliatory measures by the United States, like sanctions, could lead to a trade war that would hurt both nations, which is one reason Washington has been so reluctant to resort to them.
But in narrowly political terms, both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa stand to reap sizable domestic political benefits -- the President from having insisted on real rather than paper concessions, the Prime Minister from having stood up to the United States.
What comes next is unclear. Mr. Hosokawa spoke of a "cooling-off period," and Mr. Clinton commented, "I have no idea what will happen from here on in."
"I think this is a very serious problem," the President said.
Mr. Clinton leavened his stern words with a hefty measure of reassurance for Mr. Hosokawa, praising him for his successes in achieving political reform as well as for his less successful attempts to spur the Japanese economy through a stimulus package.
An Administration official said it would be "indelicate" to describe retaliatory options so soon after the collapse of the talks, which ended at about 4 A.M. today when Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, and Foreign Minister Tsutomu Hata of Japan left the negotiating table.
At first, at least, the steps will probably be modest in scope, in the hope that they will prompt Japan to reconsider its bargaining position.
 
Hosokawa Seems Undisturbed
 Mr. Hosokawa, who leaned comfortably on the podium with one leg crossed on an ankle as Mr. Clinton uttered his threats, appeared largely undisturbed by the President's statement that Japan's best offer "simply did not meet the standards agreed to" at the last talks in Tokyo in July.
"In the past," Mr. Hosokawa said, "Japan and the U.S. sometimes have reached ambiguous agreements which can gloss over the problems of the time, only to find them become sources of later misunderstandings between our two countries from time to time."
He said the relationship between the United States and Japan had matured to a degree that allows them to disagree unequivocally in public. "I believe such is the relationship between grown-ups, as we two are," said the Prime Minister, a reformer who took office last year as the first Japanese leader in 38 years not from the Liberal Democratic Party.
Mr. Hosokawa said that in the end, the two sides had been unable to "clear the hurdle of numerical targets." American negotiators had insisted that Japan agree to procedures that would allow them to measure progress made in opening Japanese markets, particularly for automobiles and auto parts, insurance, telecommunications gear and medical equipment.
 
Japan Cites Free Trade
 Japan has resisted numerical targets as a violation of the principle of free trade and a potential threat to critical Japanese industries at a time when its economy is in the worst recession in decades.
"I understand that the numerical target is not popular, as you said, among the Japanese people, the Japanese Government," Mr. Clinton said in response to a question from a Japanese reporter. "America's trade deficit with Japan is not very popular among the American people or the American Government. It's hard to explain it, year in and year out, always getting bigger."
There was muted tension in public appearance of the two leaders in the White House East Room. Mr. Clinton made faces occasionally at a question. Mr. Hosokawa allowed long silences to build before he offered replies to others.
 
A Three-Hour Meeting
 Mr. Clinton met with Mr. Hosokawa for three hours today, but it had become increasingly clear this week that the trade talks would bear little fruit. Lacking evidence of progress on the trade front, Mr. Hosokawa emphasized instead unrelated agreements, including Japan's intention to spend $3 billion on population and AIDS programs.
Mr. Clinton was left to interpret Mr. Hosokawa's stand for an American audience.
"You know, the problem may be -- it may be one of words, it may be one of the feelings behind the words," Mr. Clinton said. "Japan has taken the position, with which we on the surface do not disagree, that Japan does not wish to commit to numerical targets that amount to managed trade. We understand that."
Mr. Hosokawa was much more firm, in his rejection of the Administration's approach to trade policy.
"At the end of the day we believe that will lead to managed trade," Mr. Hosokawa said. "My administration is promoting deregulation, and so it runs right in the face of our basic tenet. This is what I've told the President during our meeting today."

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
French Aide Visits Bosnia; Both Sides Yield Some Arms

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Both the Bosnian Serbs and the Muslim-led Government troops handed over a small number of heavy weapons to United Nations forces today, and France's Foreign Minister paid a hastily arranged visit to Sarajevo to press the Bosnian Government leaders toward a peace settlement.
A cease-fire that took effect here on Thursday, considered critical to the momentum for peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina, seemed generally to be holding as the French minister, Alain Juppe, arrived. Only a few outbursts of gunfire were reported during the day. 
 With a new understanding developing between France and the United States on the importance of a negotiated settlement, Mr. Juppe tried to sound out the Bosnians on a set of demands that Washington and Paris could support in the peace talks in Geneva, a Bosnian Government official said.
"There are some conditions for peace now," the official said. "I don't think we were ever so close."
 
Bosnians Told to Be 'Realistic'
 The Bosnian Government official said that Mr. Juppe had asked the Bosnians to "refine" their requests so that the French and Americans "would know what to push for in the talks."
"He emphasized that to be realistic we cannot expect Bosnia's borders to be like they were," the official said.
Visiting the city's main marketplace, closed since a single 120-millimeter mortar shell killed 68 people last Saturday, Mr. Juppe said, "What I have seen passing through this city reinforces my belief that everything should be done to lift the siege."
But two days after NATO demanded that the Serbs remove or hand over all heavy artillery and mortar within 12.4 miles of Sarajevo or face air strikes, the mood here is tense and uncertain.
 
Differences in Agreements
 Significant differences are already evident in the demands outlined by NATO and the cease-fire that the United Nations military commander here, Lieut. Gen. Michael Rose, is working out step by step on the ground. Few residents expect the NATO ultimatum or the cease-fire to end the siege, since both call for Sarajevo to remain surrounded by checkpoints, with food, medicine and other relief supplies arriving by airlift.
After a short, sharp burst of artillery and sustained heavy machine-gun fire late Thursday, along with a few intermittent bursts overnight, United Nations officials said this morning that the firing came from both sides.
"A comparatively small number of rounds have been fired since the start of the cease-fire -- as far as I can judge, as many out of the city as into the city," General Rose said. He had sharp words for what he described as "renegade" Bosnian units that he said were "attempting to sabotage the cease-fire" at the risk of "prolonging the suffering of their own people."
At their barracks in the suburb of Lukavica, on the far side of the airport, Bosnian Serb officers turned over 13 heavy weapons to United Nations forces today. They included four 120-millimeter mortars, one 122-millimeter cannon, two 105-millimeter cannons, four 76-millimeter cannons and two multiple-rocket launcher systems, the United Nations command said at a briefing tonight.
The much more lightly armed Bosnian Government forces turned in four 120-millimeter mortars and one 82-millimeter mortar to Ukrainian troops at the Marshal Tito barracks in the city, the United Nations said.
After sleeping in their armored personnel carriers, 240 French marines in the United Nations force expanded their bases today in six high-combat areas in and around the city where they have placed themselves between the two sides.

Yugoslav Criticizes NATO
 BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 11 (Special to The New York Times) -- In the first reaction by a high-ranking Yugoslav Government official to NATO's threat of air strikes against Bosnian Serbs, Foreign Minister Vladislav Jovanovic said today that the Western alliance had no business issuing ultimatums that could determine "war and peace in Bosnia."
"The United Nations is the only organization with the authority to resolve the Bosnian crisis," the official Tanyug news agency quoted Mr. Jovanovic as telling ambassadors from nonaligned countries. Mr. Jovanovic called the NATO ultimatum "destructive to the peace process."

International
President Clinton declared U.S.-Japanese trade talks a failure and threatened to take aggressive steps to break Japanese barriers to American goods that have created economic and political turmoil for both countries. [Page 1.] Now that President Clinton has broken off trade talks with Japan, the question is what actions will he take now, and will they be more effective than further negotiations. News Analysis. [4.]
Le Monde has fallen into disarray after the resignation of the prestigious French newspaper's managing editor. [39.]
 
 The Economy
The White House is pressing for legislation to force telephone and cable television companies to install software so that law enforcement agencies can eavesdrop on phone calls and computer transmissions. [1.]
Producer prices rose 0.2 percent in January, the Labor Department found, providing the first reading on inflation since the Federal Reserve's move last week to raise interest rates. [37.]
The never-ending freezing weather and the waves of rain, sleet and snow are hampering output, productivity and sales in businesses from construction to airlines to retail stores. Economists are saying that if this continues, the wealth lost as a result of the severe winter could exceed losses from the California earthquake. [37.]
 
 Companies
Rogers Communications unveiled a $2.25 billion offer to acquire Maclean Hunter, in a merger of two Canadian communications giants. [37.]

Donate to charity anytime, day or night. Michigan National Bank's 300 automated teller machines now allow users to donate to charity when they get cash or deposit a paycheck. [39.]

HEADLINE: Dow Slides a Fraction As Trading Ends Early

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Despite a Government report of low inflation, Wall Street posted mixed results in dispirited trading yesterday, as a powerful snowstorm numbed stock market activity.
Many traders remained at home, and others were eager to leave early so they would not be stranded in Manhattan. After some hesitation, officials closed the major stock exchanges 90 minutes early. 
 In the end, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.56 point, to 3,894.78. For the week, the Dow recovered only 23 points of the 96 points it lost on Feb. 4, after the Federal Reserve Board nudged up short-term interest rates.
Many traders and exchange employees clamored to go home as train service to New Jersey and Long Island was cut back because of the snow.
"It was actually fairly festive here; the New York spirit comes out," Edward A. Greene, managing director of institutional sales at Mabon Securities Inc., said. "But when the exchanges closed, it was Katie bar the door."
 
Plunge in Trading
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange dropped to 213.7 million shares, well below the 300 million-share levels of earlier in the week.
With trading so thin, Wall Street may have a further reaction on Monday to the Labor Department's Producer Price Index. But on the other hand, the stock market's tepid response might be the full response, despite yesterday's abbreviated trading, analysts said. The tiny drop in the Dow came despite a rise of 1.25 points in the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, to 470.18.
The Labor Department reported encouraging results for the Producer Price Index, a barometer of wholesale inflation. Food prices, especially for fruits and vegetables, dropped. And durable goods, like vehicles and furniture, posted modest rises; there were even price declines for home electronic equipment.
There was some cause for concern in the fine print. The index rose two-tenths of a percent, less than the expected four-tenths of a percent. But the core rate, stripped of energy and food prices, rose a worrisome four-tenths of a percent, higher than the consensus range of two-tenths to three-tenths of a percent.
"The P.P.I. contained something for everybody," said David D. Holt, vice president for market research at Wedbush Morgan Securities in Los Angeles. "If you're a bear, it confirmed that the economy is weak, and if you're a bull, it confirmed that inflation is low. So it's no surprise that the index had so little impact on the markets."
Some of the traders who managed to get to the New York Stock Exchange yesterday mocked the opening gavel with scattered Bronx cheers, as executives at the Big Board and the American Stock Exchange decided at first to maintain normal operating hours. Later, after an urgent appeal at noon by the Public Securities Association to close bond trading at 2 P.M., the exchanges and Nasdaq decided to close at 2:30 P.M.
The New York Mercantile Exchange, the Commodity Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange all closed operations in the early afternoon to allow traders and employees to make their tortuous way home.
 
Bond Yields Lower
 While trading in the bond market closed at 2 P.M., long-term interest rates eased. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond fell to 6.40 percent from 6.43 percent, below Tuesday's six-month closing high of 6.44 percent.
Among other market indicators, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.03 points, to 781.39, and the American Stock Exchange market value index declined 1.90, to 477.23. But the New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.27, to 261.31.
The most active stock was Telefonos de Mexico, which typically serves as a proxy for Mexican stocks because it makes up such a large share of Mexican trading volume. Its American depository receipts rose 87.5 cents, to $74.25, on volume of nearly 4.3 million shares.
After Telmex, Columbia/HCA Healthcare shares were the second most active, at 4.1 million shares. The stock fell $1.875, to $38.625, after Columbia completed a $7.6 billion merger with HCA-Hospital Corporation of America on Thursday to create the nation's largest hospital chain.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Japan Card?;
As Trade Deficit Talks Lead Nowhere Tokyo Awaits President's Next Move

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Strip away the overheated bluster around the United States-Japan summit meeting and it comes down to this: For eight months the Clinton Administration has insisted that it was different from its predecessors, that it was not going to take it anymore. Japan would finally have to open its markets.
The Japanese listened politely. They nodded their heads. And today they called what they think is President Clinton's bluff. The question now is: What does Mr. Clinton really have in his hand? 
 The President could impose a variety of sanctions to bust open the Japanese market to American exports. But almost all of them carry the risk of hurting American companies and consumers or damaging political ties with Tokyo, and Mr. Clinton was offering no hints today about how he intended to play his cards.
In public, the President was remarkably polite in his news conference with Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, considering that eight months of negotiations had produced nothing. Mr. Clinton, in fact, seemed so concerned about not embarrassing his Japanese guest that his message may have been lost: that Japan's $60 billion trade surplus with the United States has become intolerable and will not stand.
 
The Real Issue
 But Administration officials insist that the real issue is not whether Mr. Clinton was too polite, given the fact that the Japanese had basically rejected the entire negotiating effort to opening their markets. The real issue, they said, is whether Mr. Clinton, having now broken off the talks with the Japanese, has some effective unilateral measures that will accomplish the same goals that the talks were supposed to achieve.
If he does, it is Japan's bluff that will be called. If he does not, Mr. Clinton could be accused of falling into the same pattern on Japan policy that he has in Bosnia and Haiti -- speaking loudly and carrying a small stick.
"I am not worried about words," said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt. "Our words can be courteous and gentle, and they should be. But they need to be backed up with action. I think the President is prepared to do that. Obviously he has a lot of options."
The challenge, say Administration economic officials, is finding the sort of swords that can slice open Japan's markets, but which are not double-edged and cut into American interests as well. The economies of both countries are so intertwined that hitting Japan without hitting American interests is not so easy.
 
The First Weapon
 The first weapon that Administration officials say they intend to use is the one demonstrated today: that despite the President's politeness, he did in fact break off trade negotiations and left the Japanese to stew.
Some might argue that that is exactly what the Japanese would like, since they are the ones with the trade surplus. But others maintain that the Japanese cannot tolerate a protracted period of trade tension with the United States, particularly when security cooperation over North Korea's nuclear program is so essential.
"I think this is an ideal time to use psychological pressure," said a senior Administration official. "If we put this relationship through a sufficiently protracted period of friction, I think they will sue for peace. The message to Japan is that the United States-Japan relationship is now on hold. You can be sure that we are not going to be picking up the telephone. The next conversation is going to have to be initiated from Tokyo. And if it is not for a month, so be it."
Beyond a general cooling of relations, the Administration has a number of technical options. Officials say that Mr. Clinton intends to immediately reinstate a lapsed section of American trade law that provides a strict timetable for Japan to open certain markets and includes mandatory sanctions if no deal is reached.
The legislation, known as Super 301, was in effect from 1988 to 1990, and was drafted by Congressional Democrats as a way to force Republican trade negotiators to take a more confrontational approach.
The law requires a President to identify countries that discriminate against American goods, then start the clock for imposing sanctions. Mr. Clinton intends to sign an order reinstating Super 301 and possibly name Japan as a violator.
 
Sanctions Invite Retaliation
 The risk is that when such sanctions have been used in the past, American companies that depend on Japanese suppliers beg the Commerce Department to make exceptions.
Such sanctions also invite retaliation from Japan against American companies and could trigger a trade war between the world's two biggest economies that could unravel the progress achieved by the Administration in the GATT and North American free trade agreements.
A second tool the Administration is considering is to stop allowing the expansion of so-called foreign trade zones in the United States. These zones allow Japanese manufacturers to import parts from Japan and not pay duty on them until the final product is shipped to American customers.
For instance, the Nissan Motors factory in Smyrna, Tenn., imports many car parts from Japan which normally would be subject to a 2.5 percent tax upon arrival in the United States. But because the factory has been designated a foreign trade zone, Nissan does not pay the tax until the fully assembled car is shipped to an American dealer, allowing it to collect interest on the tariff money in the meantime, which amounts to at least $5 million a year. The catch in restricting free-trade zones is that it deprives Americans of jobs.
Another option is to have the Justice Department bring antitrust suits against Japanese concerns doing business in the United States that are also part of cartels in Japan that lock out American companies. The Administration has to be careful here though that it does not abuse antitrust laws, otherwise it could find itself tied up in the courts.

HEADLINE: To Vietnamese in America, the Homeland Beckons

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WESTMINSTER, Calif., Feb. 10

 BODY:
As the last groups of bewildered refugees from the Vietnam War arrive here with their identity tags and bundles of belongings, plane loads of their successful countrymen are heading back with dollars in their pockets to visit relatives or open businesses.
Nineteen years after the fall of Saigon, with the Vietnamese population in the United States approaching one million, the flood of refugees is drawing to a close. 
 The flow is, in a way, reversing itself: more Vietnamese are now returning from the United States for visits than are arriving here as refugees or immigrants.
This shift took on momentum last week when President Clinton lifted the two-decade-old American trade embargo against a former enemy. The Little Saigon enclave of 80,000 Vietnamese in this town 40 miles south of downtown Los Angeles is suddenly busy with plans and projects -- not all of them realistic -- for their return to the homeland as wealthy heroes.
 
In High Gear
 "A lot of Vietnamese-Americans have been going to Vietnam like crazy when they heard the rumor that the sanctions may be lifted," said Co Pham, president of the local Vietnamese Chamber of Commerce. A medical doctor, he himself has plans to open a hospital in Vietnam.
Vuong Tran, who owns a travel agency and works as a consultant for American companies seeking to do business in Vietnam, said: "This is the day we have been waiting for. We spent a lot of money doing research for this day." Mr. Tran, who has frequently visited his homeland over the years to lay the groundwork for new enterprises, is in high gear now, determined to be one of the first to profit.
T. T. Nhu, a columnist for the San Jose Mercury News, said her uncle, who owned a bank in Vietnam and, as a refugee, earned a doctorate at Cornell University, may return to reopen his bank. "It's like living and dying and going to heaven again," she said.
Surprising some Vietnamese here, the mood even seems to have affected the younger generation here with American educations and only dim childhood memories of Vietnam.
 
Big Plans, Tough Reality
 "Many young professionals have declared to their parents over the last few days that they will return to Vietnam in the next month or two," said Yen Do, editor of Nguoi Viet Daily News here, the largest Vietnamese-language newspaper in the United States. "They said it solemnly and officially within the family. They didn't ask the parents, 'Should I go back?' They just said it: 'I will go.' "
He said the talk is of enterprises like banks and small import-export companies and of using American skills in construction, education, real estate and medical care. "Everything seems possible now," he said.
But Mr. Tran warned that in reality many things were still not possible in Vietnam, with its primitive and slow-moving centrally controlled economy. "The end of the embargo will benefit first the giant companies including rich oil companies, banks, construction, communications, law firms," he said. "Small and medium businesses, and this includes the Vietnamese-Americans, will have more difficulty. This is still a socialist country and doing business there is very complicated. It will take a couple of more years."
Nevertheless, Mr. Tran said his travel business had boomed in recent years as visits to Vietnam became more common and less politically risky within the emigre community, which has been polarized over whether to have dealings with a Communist Vietnam.
One of his plans involves building a retirement community for elderly returnees in their native country. He said he had circulated a questionnaire here and found that about half the 2,000 respondents said they would be interested in buying a home in Vietnam.
When Hanoi first opened the door for returnees in the mid-1980's, Mr. Tran said, he escorted groups of 5 or 10 people on visits to their homeland and his business so angered militant Vietnamese anti-Communists here that his office was firebombed.
Now, the Vietnamese mission to the United Nations estimates that nearly 100,000 Vietnamese return to visit every year. By some estimates, as many as 20,000 people have returned for the lunar new year of Tet this month. At the moment, only a few Vietnamese return home to stay.
 
Dwindling Arrivals
 At the same time, Vietnamese refugee arrivals in the United States, which reached a peak of about 150,000 a year in the early 1980's, have dwindled to fewer than 60,000 in the fiscal year 1993, down from 82,000 in 1992.
And these arrivals will all but end within the next year or two, said Pamela Lewis, a spokeswoman for the Bureau of Refugee Programs in the State Department, as a pool of Vietnamese deemed to be political refugees under an immigration program dries up.
Almost all the refugees arriving in the United States now leave Vietnam not by boat but by airplane in the Orderly Departure Program, which was begun in the 1980's.
Most of them now belong to two specific groups: the Amerasian offspring of Americans in Vietnam, along with their family members, and former South Vietnamese officers and Government officials who have been held as political prisoners.
The last 3,500 people in the Amerasian program are expected to arrive in the United States by summer, Ms. Lewis said, bringing the total to nearly 80,000. As many as 100,000 former political prisoners and family members will have entered the country when that program ends some time within the next two years.
The exodus of boat people has all but ended; fewer than 100 people were recorded last year. Their numbers are dwarfed by the 58,000 who have returned to Vietnam from refugee camps since late 1989. Those returnees were denied asylum by third countries, as most of the new boat people will be, because they were judged to be fleeing for economic rather than political reasons.
Once the pool of Amerasians and political prisoners is exhausted, in one more sign of normalization, virtually all Vietnamese arrivals in the United States will come not as refugees but as immigrants. Their entry would be based on the same criteria and follow the same procedures as people from the Philippines or Ireland or Argentina or France.
And yet, in the face of this turning tide of history, it remains politically difficult here in Little Saigon to support the end of the embargo and to do business openly with the Communist Government in Hanoi.
The lifting of the embargo was greeted with angry demonstrations and threats against advocates of normalization. Local political leaders chose their words carefully so as not to offend former Vietnamese military men and political prisoners who are still fighting the long-ago war in their hearts.
 
'They Lost Their Country'
 "These are the hard-core types that we call the San Jose paratroopers," said Douglas Pike, who heads the Vietnam Archive at the University of California at Berkeley. "They lost their country and they are bitter about it, and I guess I'd be even more bitter about it."
So the celebration one recent evening was quiet at the Vien Dong restaurant, where a Vietnamese-American banker, a construction contractor, a doctor, a restaurateur, an import-export executive and a half-dozen others gathered on the eve of Tet to mark the lifting of the embargo.
It was as if they shared a guilty secret in the aftermath of a war that had seemed to bring only tragedy. They were going to go home, and they were going to make money.
"Happy New Year," they said, as they lifted water glasses of California champagne, and they took pictures of one other smiling.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With the end of the trade embargo on Vietnam, the flow of Vietnamese returning from the United States for visits to their homeland is becoming a flood. Vuong Tran, who owns a travel agency in Westminster, Calif., near Los Angeles, said, "This is the day we have been waiting for." (Marissa Roth for The New York Times)
