HEADLINE: Hospital Fights Parents' Wish to Keep Life Support for a 'Brain Dead' Child

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 11

 BODY:
A Sarasota hospital that has been caring for a brain-dead teen-ager since early last month is seeking permission from the courts to disconnect her life-support system, despite opposition from the girl's parents.
The parents, Frederick and Sharon Hamilton, say the action is premature and want doctors at Sarasota Memorial Hospital to release their 13-year-old daughter, Teresa, to their custody. 
 Teresa, a severe diabetic, was admitted to the hospital on Jan. 7 and fell into a coma soon afterward.
"We are aghast at the fact that they want to call it quits," Mr. Hamilton said today in a telephone interview. "She must come home, and we have to work with her."
Michael Covert, the president of the hospital, said tonight that he planned to ask the state attorney next week how to proceed with the case.
 
No Brain Activity
 Medical workers familiar with the case say doctors determined that Teresa was legally dead after three brain scans showed no brain activity and a blood scan indicated no blood flow to the brain. But Mrs. Hamilton has asked the hospital to do everything to keep her daughter alive. The girl is being kept breathing by a ventilator.
"The hospital is asking the court for direction because of the conflict concerning Teresa Hamilton," said Mike Vizvary, a hospital spokesman, adding that the parents' wishes were in conflict with the hospital's policy.
"The hospital believes court intervention is appropriate to resolve the concerns surrounding Teresa Hamilton," he said.
But John Williams, a lawyer for the Hamiltons, said he feared that the hospital would seek to have a guardian appointed in the case, who would then be responsible for medical decisions about the girl. "The first question is should the parents be deprived of their guardianship rights," he said.
Further complicating the case, the Hamiltons' medical insurance has run out. The intensive care unit where Teresa is being treated costs about $3,240 a day, bringing the Hamiltons' five-week hospital bill to more than $116,000.
Mr. Vizvary said the court action had nothing to do with the family's lack of insurance. But hospital officials acknowledged that care of the girl had created stress and an emotional drain among medical workers who were handling the case.
 
An Atypical Case
 Until now, most cases in which a court has been asked to make a determination of life or death have dealt with family members who wanted to stop efforts by a hospital or state to keep a relative on life support. This case is attracting attention among specialists in medical ethics because it does not fit that pattern.
"If the child is still alive, this is an important case," said George Annas, director of the law, medicine and ethics program at Boston University of Medical and Public Health. "It's almost always the other way around. Hospitals never go to court trying to stop treatment on a child against the wishes of the parent."
In Florida, a person is considered dead "when there is irreversible cessation of the functioning of the entire brain," even though respiratory and circulatory functions are being maintained with the aid of machines. In such cases, there is no requirement for the hospital to ask permission of next of kin or a court to disconnect life support.
"The hospital has an obligation to take her off the ventilator," Mr. Annas said. "Now they are treating a corpse." By doing so, he said, "you really do confuse the parents, because you lead the parents to believe that the child is still alive."
That is what appears to have happened in Teresa Hamilton's case. "They have claimed that she is brain dead, which is the clinical way of saying she's a goner," said Mr. Hamilton, an unemployed oil engineer originally from Scotland. "But they've pursued with her care."
 
1990 Supreme Court Ruling
 In 1990, the Supreme Court ruled that treatment could be withheld if there was clear and compelling evidence of the patient's wishes. The decision came in the case of Nancy Cruzan, a young woman from Missouri who spent eight years in a coma while her parents fought to have her disconnected from life support, contending she had told them that was her desire.
Ms. Cruzan died in December 1990, six months after the Supreme Court ruling and 12 days after her parents won the right to remove the feeding tube that was keeping her alive.
But Teresa Hamilton had no known wishes for such a circumstance, and as a minor, the decisions for her medical care are made by her parents.

Ruling in Virginia
 RICHMOND, Feb. 11 (AP) - A hospital must treat a severely brain-damaged baby even though doctors believe the infant should be allowed to die, a Federal appeals court ruled on Thursday.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit ruled, 2 to 1, that Fairfax Hospital must honor the mother's wishes that her infant be given mechanical breathing assistance when she suffers respiratory distress. The hospital is near the town of Fairfax in northeastern Virginia.
The court cited a Federal law that requires hospitals to treat emergency medical conditions. The law was passed to protect indigent patients from being denied treatment.
"We recognize the dilemma facing physicians who are requested to provide treatment they consider morally and ethically inappropriate, but we cannot ignore the plain language of the statute," said the ruling written by Judge William W. Wilkins Jr. He was joined by Judge Karen J. Williams.
"Baby K," as the child is known, was born at the hospital in October 1992 with most of her brain missing. The baby breathes, sucks, swallows and coughs but cannot think, see, hear or feel, the hospital said.

HEADLINE: New Focus on Drugs;
President's Strategy Reflects Concern About Crime and Changing Priorities

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
For months, a handful of Administration officials had been urging President Clinton to place his personal stamp on the drug issue with a splashy White House ceremony. But there always seemed to be something else more pressing.
On Wednesday, Mr. Clinton leaped into the drug issue with both feet. With Vice President Al Gore and half a dozen Cabinet members in tow, he trooped out to a Maryland prison that boasts a model drug treatment program to announce a 1995 national drug strategy that will cost more than $13 billion. 
 Why the big change from a President who had scarcely mentioned drugs since taking office? Many experts on drugs and the ways of Washington say the answer is in the polls.
 
Public Demands Action
 In recent weeks, crime and violence have risen to prominence on the roster of national concerns. They now rival the economy, which so dominated the 1992 Presidential campaign, and surpass health care.
"Clearly, the fact that the public is demanding that something be done on crime and violence is affecting the fact that Washington is paying attention to drugs," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime and Criminal Justice. "When crime becomes an issue, drugs become an issue. They're opposite sides of the same coin."
At the Prince Georges County Correctional Center, Mr. Clinton succinctly linked the two problems. "No nation," he said, "can fight crime and drugs without dealing honestly and forthrightly with the problem of drug addiction."
The President's strategy speaks of attacking the social problems that many believe to be the root causes of drug abuse, and his anti-drug budget sharply increases spending for drug rehabilitation and anti-drug education by $800 million. But, to the disappointment of many drug experts, the Clinton budget continues to allocate the larger portion of the drug budget, 59 percent, to law enforcement, as those of Presidents George Bush and Ronald Reagan did without denting the cocaine and heroin trade.
 
Catching Up With an Issue
 But it was not just the polls that moved the President to action, Mr. Schumer said. It was also a matter of catching up with an issue that had been pushed aside by higher priorities. Since taking office, Mr. Clinton has faced one crisis after another, starting with the upheaval over homosexuals in the military and continuing with his plan to overhaul the nation's health care system.
Mr. Clinton's first drug budget, for example, was almost a carbon copy of Mr. Bush's last budget. It took Mr. Clinton five months to name a director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, Lee P. Brown, a former New York City police commissioner, and the President was nine months late with a mandatory report to Congress on his drug policy. The report was a blueprint of the new strategy, but Mr. Clinton was criticized for not giving any indication of how much money would go for what programs.
"I think he cared about drugs," Mr. Schumer said. "But there were other things with higher priorities. I'm now finding that the White House is getting into the issue of crime and drugs with the same kind of intensity it has been focusing on these other issues."
Administration officials explain the President's silence and lack of focus another way.
"It's been evolutionary," said one Administration official. "The pieces of his program have come together now, and he's ready to move out front with it. You're going to see more of this."
The nation's drug experts are delighted that Mr. Clinton is calling attention to the subject of their concern. They are convinced that it was the "bully pulpit" style of Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush that, to a large extent, brought down the rate of casual drug use from its sky-high levels in the mid-1980's. And they are equally convinced that the silence from the White House since the latter part of the Bush Presidency has significantly contributed to the increase in the use of marijuana among teen-agers that researchers at the University of Michigan reported two weeks ago.
Republicans in Congress seized on the increase in drug use by teen-agers, saying it underscored the feebleness of Mr. Clinton's anti-drug policy.
 
Sending a Strong Signal
 Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal, the president of the Phoenix House, which is based in New York and is the nation's largest residential drug treatment organization, welcomed Mr. Clinton's embrace of the issue. "When the White House is talking about drugs and making them a part of the domestic agenda, it sends a strong signal," he said. "You need a persistent societal message that drug use is not acceptable, that there are real dangers and consequences associated with drug use."
While most drug experts have cheered the proposal to increase spending on treatment and prevention programs -- even though the gap between needs and services will remain Gargantuan -- some former drug officials in the Bush Administration are accusing the Clinton team of misrepresenting its spending on prevention programs. The Clinton Administration acknowledges that about $270 million of the $400 million increase indicated for prevention programs would actually be used to hire more officers for community policing.
"Law enforcement can deter drug use," said John P. Walters, who was deputy director of the office on drug policy under President Bush. "But it is usually programs in schools and workplaces that are counted as prevention. This is an effort to make it look like something else."

HEADLINE: Congress Passes Measure Providing $8.6 Billion for Quake Relief

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Congress gave final approval today to $8.6 billion in relief for the victims of the recent Los Angeles earthquake, coupling the aid with $3.2 billion in spending cuts in a show of concern over the budget deficit.
The House voted 245 to 65 for the measure, staying in session -- despite a day of wintry weather that left the nation's capital blanketed in ice -- to finish work in time to begin a 10-day midwinter recess. Senate approval immediately followed the House vote. 
 In the House, 168 Democrats, 76 Republicans and one independent voted for the measure. Forty-eight Republicans and 17 Democrats voted against.
President Clinton said he hoped to sign the bill on Saturday and indicated that the Government's role in earthquake recovery would continue beyond the relief package. "While short-term disaster relief is absolutely necessary, I want to assure that we'll be there over the long run as well," he said.
Earlier in the day, House and Senate conferees agreed on the package, which includes an additional $2.5 in emergency outlays.
 
Spending for Pentagon
 Besides earthquake relief, the measure provides $1.2 billion for Pentagon operations in Somalia, Bosnia and elsewhere; $685 million in disaster aid for the victims of flooding in the Midwest last summer, and $315 million to rebuild the Cypress Freeway in Oakland, Calif., which was destroyed in the 1989 San Francisco earthquake.
An additional $300 million in assistance for heating the homes of low-income families would go to states hardest hit by the winter weather.
Support in Congress for earthquake relief itself was overwhelming from the start, but the $11 billion bill generated substantial debate over the other spending items as well as the issue of providing spending cuts to offset the costs.
Other disaster aid bills in recent years, including a measure last summer for flood victims, have been financed with deficit spending, and the Democratic leadership in both houses favored that approach for the earthquake measure.
 
Bill Moved Swiftly
 But some lawmakers in both houses pressured for spending reductions, and won $3.25 billion in reductions in the measure. Included was $860 million in transportation programs and $600 million in military construction.
But for all the debate, the bill moved with unusual swiftness through Congress. The earthquake occurred less than a month ago, and it was only last week that the House Appropriations Committee sent the measure on its first steps toward passage.
After two days of debate, the Senate by a vote of 85 to 10 on Thursday night approved $8.6 billion in grants and loans for victims of the Jan. 17 earthquake. The House passed a version of the measure last week.
 
'People Are Needful'
 "The clock is ticking and the people are needful," Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, told senators on Thursday as they inched toward a final vote.
Afterwards, Senator Barbara Boxer, another California Democrat, thanked the Senate for a vote she said would lead the way to reconstruction and "economic recovery" in a state also hard hit by recession.
The earthquake has been blamed for 61 deaths and property damage estimated at $20 billion. It also left tens of thousands of people homeless.
The final legislation would also limit the Government to providing short-term relief to disaster victims who are living illegally in the United States. How that limit would be enforced is not clear. The bill does order the Government to furnish up to 90 days of shelter for victims without regard to their immigrant status.
But the legislation would also make enforcement a matter of discretion, and it would bar officials from discriminating against disaster victims on the basis of race or ethnic origin.
The bill would also extend the deadline for the Government to pursue civil charges against failed savings and loans, including the institution concerned in the Whitewater case that involves the President and his wife, Hillary. The deadline for the institution, Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan, had been Feb. 28 but now stands at Dec. 31, 1995, for it and all other such institutions.

HEADLINE: Wretched Weather Takes Toll on Economy

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The seemingly endless freezing weather and the waves of rain, sleet and snow are hampering output, productivity and sales in businesses from construction to airlines to retail stores.
Economists are saying that if current weather patterns continue, the wealth lost as a result of the severe winter could exceed the economic losses from the California earthquake. 
 "In economic terms, we pretty much always ignore the weather," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting project at Georgia State University in Atlanta. "But this winter has been so harsh in so many parts of the country that we can't ignore it."
Estimates on how much the winter has slowed the economy are just that. But Mr. Ratajczak is projecting that production in the current quarter will be five-tenths of a percentage point lower than it might otherwise have been. At an annual rate, that translates into a drag on gross domestic product of 1.5 to 2 percentage points.
Most economists are assuming that the weather will not stay this bad for much longer and that production lost in the first six weeks of the year will be made up in the rest of the quarter and later in the year. But those expectations are running up against a weather map that offers little relief.
"If this keeps up for another month, it could have a significant negative impact on the first quarter," said Alan Blinder, a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. "I wouldn't be surprised if the economic loss has been worse than the loss from the Los Angeles earthquake. Well over half the nation's population has been affected by this wretched weather."
There are no final estimates for the losses from the California quake. But analysts have estimated that the cost could range from $12 billion to $30 billion.
Hard evidence of the weather's impact on the economy is only beginning to trickle in. The data-gathering task was not made any easier yesterday because bad weather virtually shut down huge areas of the country, from Memphis to Boston.
Even though official Washington was closed yesterday, the Government was open long enough to report that retail sales, a driving force in the economic recovery, fell by five-tenths of a percent last month. It was the first decline in 10 months.
January's freezing temperatures were a big reason for the slide, and most analysts said they still saw underlying strength in consumer confidence.
Some of the lost sales will be made up in coming months. But retailing experts said much of the spending that might have taken place was lost.
"There is no question that retailers have been hard hit by the succession of snowstorms and the very hostile weather," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Consulting Group in New York. "Some of the purchases not made in the last three to five weeks will be made up, but only some. A lot of shopping in January is impulse shopping, and that cannot be made up."
The weather-related problems imposed on retailers have heightened the importance of next weekend's Presidents' Day sales, traditionally the most important retailing event of the winter.
"We won't make this back in a weekend," said Michael Gould, chairman and chief executive of Bloomingdale's. "But hopefully over the balance of the spring season we will."
Retailers and restaurateurs in the New York City area have clearly been hurt by the weather, but analysts said the city's economy had become so dependent on the financial services sector that a sharp rise in interest rates would likely have a more harmful effect than weeks of bad weather.
The weather has also played havoc with the airline industry, which was in financial difficulty even before the bad weather set in.
USAir, an airline with a heavy concentration of routes in the Northeast, estimates that the impact of the weather in January amounted to $10 million to $20 million in terms of revenue lost from canceled flights and higher expenses.
The weather has had a particularly debilitating effect on the economy because it has been so bad in so many different parts of the country, analysts said.
The Federal Express Corporation, the air delivery service, sorts about half its freight in Memphis, where the company is based. Late Wednesday night, an ice storm virtually shut down the city and left hundreds of thousands without power.
"We were in pretty good shape until two days ago," Tom Martin, a Federal Express spokesman said. "But Thursday night was very bad."
The problem has been the frequency of the bad weather, Mr. Martin said. "One day it has been bad in Chicago. The next day it is New York, the next day Boston, and so on," he said. "The cumulative effect of all that has been debilitating."
Major insurance companies are also hoping the bad weather does not persist.
Earlier this month, the State Farm Fire and Casualty Company, the nation's leading home insurer, said it expected to pay more than $81 million in claims for winter storm damage sustained in January in 14 states and Canada. About $70 million of the total represents payments for pipes that froze and broke during the deep freeze of Jan. 15 through Jan. 20, the company said.
Extrapolate State Farm's claims across the insurance industry and "you come up with a number in the hundreds of millions of dollars," said Gerry Parsons, a State Farm spokesman.
"We have had bigger payouts in the past, but this is big," Mr. Parsons said. "It ranks in the top 20."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Federal Express office in Manhattan that closed temporarily is only one illustration of the impact of the relentless storms on businesses. (Carrie Boretz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hosokawa's Report, a la Clinton

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa borrowed a Clinton technique today and took his case to more than 100 students at Georgetown University.
It was a highly unusual performance for a Japanese Prime Minister, far from the carefully scripted appearances his predecessors have made here. But Mr. Hosokawa has proved many times in the last six months that he views his job as being more that of a president proselytizing for change than a prime minister taking a cautious approach. 
 This time he used the opportunity to criticize his country's overregulated economy, complain about his problems with the press, and declare with some passion that his country would never go nuclear.
"There have been reports in the last few days that Japan might change its policy should North Korea arm itself with nuclear weapons," he told the students, reading his speech in English. "I wish the people who write such reports would come to Japan and talk to our people. Then they would realize how deeply we feel about this issue."
Mr. Hosokawa was at his best when he alluded to the frustrations of bringing about what he called Japan's first "inner driven reform," that is, one not dictated by outside powers.
"I am determined to do away with regulations which increase the cost of business, and cost to the consumers." he said. The Japanese, he said, should be able to buy a home at "about two-thirds the present average cost." And he insisted that, despite some evidence to the contrary, "the time has come for Japan to play a much more dynamic role in helping to create the stable, peaceful world which we all desire."
But he steered clear of exactly how Japan would do that -- and whether its people were ready for greater participation in military peacekeeping, an issue that has dogged him for the six months of his premiership.
Recalling that The Washington Post recently called him "poker faced," Mr. Hosokawa conceded that with all his trade problems and the difficulties in keeping his coalition Government together, "perhaps I do look a bit grim these days." He and Mr. Clinton, he said, had "both had our bad days in the media, and we've both had a very tough time trying to get people to agree on policy reforms."
Asked by one student whether Japan was ready to join in sanctions against North Korea if it continues to refuse to allow inspection of its nuclear sites -- an enormously sensitive issue within Japan -- Mr. Hosokawa expressed some exasperation dealing with the Communist Government across the Sea of Japan.
"Only God knows what kind of action North Korea might take as its time expires" to allow the inspections, he said. "But if the U.N. takes sanctions, the Japanese Government will do all it can to the extent that Japanese law allows," he said, stepping around the sticky question of whether it would stop hundreds of millions of dollars that flow each year between Japan and North Korea.

HEADLINE: Exits Pose Danger in Emerging Markets

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
Even Americans who have never left their hometowns are investing in "emerging markets," Wall Street's new name for what used to be called "less developed countries." As these nations' stock markets soared last year, Americans poured more than $9 billion into mutual funds that invest in them.
And in the mutual fund business, every company wants to run a fund that invests in these often quirky little stock markets. According to Lipper Analytical Services, the number of emerging-markets equity funds has grown to 40, from just 22 a year ago. And more are in the offing. 
 The combination of overexcited investors and inexperienced managers is worrying some old-timers in the emerging-markets game. A big concern: fund investors can get out at any time, but the funds themselves can't.
 This year, while some emerging markets have soared -- Brazil has jumped more than 60 percent in the last six weeks -- many of last year's success stories have tumbled, including Hong Kong, which is down 3 percent after doubling last year. Turkey, Thailand and Malaysia have suffered double-digit losses.
 When such markets plummet (and given their volatility, the experts say, it's only a matter of time), American investors may find it hard to bail out of their emerging-markets funds at an acceptable price -- and maybe at all.
"There will come a day when everybody's heading for the exits at the same time, and there won't be an exit," said Mark J. Mobius, one of the founders of emerging-markets investing and a fund manager for the Franklin/Templeton group. He is barnstorming the country right now, preaching about the minimum time horizon he thinks investors must have: five years.
Until recently, impatient investors did not find their way into emerging markets. Most such investing occurred through private partnerships or closed-end mutual funds, which don't let shareholders take their money out (just sell their shares to other investors).
But as some hitherto obscure stock markets heated up in 1993 -- Turkey zoomed over 200 percent, Malaysia, 145 percent and the Philippines, 134 percent -- the mutual-fund business jumped on the bandwagon.
One year ago, the Boston behemoth Fidelity Investments changed the name of a tiny fund to Fidelity Emerging Markets. By the end of the year, the fund had $1.9 billion in its coffers. Despite a sharp selloff in many emerging markets in January, which has put the fund in the red this year, its assets now top $2 billion -- almost as big as Sri Lanka's entire stock market.
"There's a danger when you have a lot of demand chasing a relatively limited amount of supply," said David Warren, executive vice president of Rowe Price Fleming in London, which runs T. Rowe Price's international funds. "An investor starts closing his or her eyes and buying anything, and secondly, it does often attract, one might say, not the right kind of money."
Emerging-market investment gurus remain enthusiastic about the long-term outlook for countries whose economies are growing far faster than America's or Western Europe's. But they concede that they are investing in stock markets, and that markets are vulnerable to all kinds of problems.
 For example, the Hungarian stock market levitated about 80 percent in January as Western investors plunged in. It then lost almost 20 percent of its value in a matter of days, and has now bounced back a bit. According to a report by Bloomberg Business News, the exchange plans to institute some reforms -- such as trading for more than an hour and a half a day -- to cut volatility.
The biggest victim of its own success right now may be India. Managers report that it takes weeks, if not months, to buy or sell a stock, and requires a mountain of paperwork. Sometimes it is just impossible; over the last few years, Indian stock markets have closed for days because of strikes, explosions or scandals.
India may be extreme, but it is not alone. A recent survey of investment managers by the Chicago consulting firm Ennis, Knupp & Associates, found that many managers are so concerned about liquidity that they have held back on investing in South Africa, Indonesia, Taiwan, Chile, India and Turkey. Liquidity -- the ability to buy or sell a stock quickly and easily, without driving prices up or down, and without having to worry about back-office errors or exorbitant fees -- remains a problem in many other markets, too.
"In almost every emerging market, typically the systems are very slow, and there's a lot of paper that can be lost," said Daniel J. Duane, who runs Prudential's global funds. "Inevitably, there's a lot of foot-dragging on settlement, especially when someone has to pay you money."
Even relatively liquid markets, like Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore, experience wild swings as government policies change and as foreign money surges in and out. Which explains why the Fidelity Southeast Asia Fund, which opened its doors last April and soared 65 percent by the end of the year, has since dropped almost 10 percent.
Just as troublesome for short-term investors, some countries, including Chile, India, South Korea and Taiwan, restrict foreign investors' ability to take their money home.
Old hands in the emerging markets have lived through these problems before. They use several methods to cut their risk, including broad diversification, high levels of cash and big holdings of easily sold securities.
And most of the big fund groups have arranged to borrow money from banks (or, in Fidelity's case, from its other funds) so that they will not be forced to dump stocks wholesale, sending markets into free fall. Dick Haberman, Fidelity's head of international equities, notes that his company's fund holds more than 500 stocks in 30 countries, and that his company, which employs 50 analysts outside the United States, has been investing in Asia since 1969.
But a lot of new players have not had that experience, which is why Mr. Duane of Prudential said, "In a way, you have to worry about your competitors." He said that if one emerging-markets fund ran into trouble, it might cause a run on all such funds, as happened in Britain in 1987.
Many companies that do not yet offer an emerging-markets fund plan to add one this year. The chief investment officer of one such firm, Paul Stephens of Robertson, Stephens & Company in San Francisco, said many of the people available to run such funds had only two or three years of experience.
The mania for emerging markets has grown so strong that Barton Biggs, the Morgan Stanley strategist responsible for fueling much of it, last month wrote a satirical report on a man he called Jim the Trigger, who was primed to take advantage of all the "dummies with phony accents and striped shirts with white collars who think Turkey borders Malaysia" but have "portfolios that were up 70 percent last year."
His plan? To create his own country, make it emerge and reap the profits. When it's time to end the scam, he will stage a revolution; investors will be left holding the bag.
Several money managers call the research report the funniest they have ever read. But if Mr. Biggs proves prescient, as he has before, mutual fund investors will not be laughing.

HEADLINE: Manager Says New York Let Hospital Fail

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

 BODY:
The top executive of the company managing the billion-dollar project to rebuild Kings County Hospital said the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation -- and not his company -- was responsible for the project's troubles, and he presented a detailed list of what he called the city's mismanagement and delays.
The complaints came a day after Luis A. Miranda Jr., chairman of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, issued a scathing critique of the decadelong effort to rebuild the city's largest public medical center. 
 On Thursday Mr. Miranda said that the hospital corporation and the construction manager, Turner/Santa Fe Joint Venture, were responsible for fumbling that prevented the construction of a replacement for the obsolete hospital in central Brooklyn.
While Mr. Miranda placed much of the blame on his own agency, he singled out Turner/Santa Fe for criticism, questioning whether it was "up to the job" of replacing New York's largest public hospital.
But yesterday, Desmond Emanuel, the chief executive of Santa Fe Construction Inc., one of the partners in the joint venture, said it was the hospital agency that was not up to the job. Agency officials, he said, constantly altered the design of the new hospital and spent years checking the backgrounds of prospective contractors.
 
Company Won't Be Made Scapegoat
 In an interview, he said he would not allow his company to be made the scapegoat, and said the hospital agency was so inexperienced that it should never have been allowed to handle the project.
"I don't know if H.H.C. is up to the task of building this hospital," said Mr. Emanuel. "I know that we are, because we just want to get this project built. But they have chosen to find a scapegoat and point the finger at us, when we have not delayed this project in any way."
Yesterday, a group of elected officials from central Brooklyn announced that they were forming a committee to monitor the city's progress in rebuilding the hospital, the only health-care provider for the largely impoverished residents of much of the city's most populous borough.
Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. said the group intended to pressure the city to lift the moratorium on the hospital's construction that was imposed last week by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and insisted the building must be completed by the year 2000.
"We don't want to have to fight the city on this, but this project has to move forward," said Mr. Norman, who is also the Brooklyn Democratic leader. "It is too important to the community to be delayed."
Mr. Norman, speaking for a group of City Council members and other elected representatives, said he agreed with Mr. Miranda's assessment that the hospital agency had fumbled the project in the past. But he said the agency must continue to manage the construction in order to avoid further delays.
 
Arrogance and Inexperience
 Turner/Santa Fe, chosen in 1987 to be the construction manager for the huge rebuilding project, is a joint venture between Turner Construction Company, a giant national company based in New York that specializes in institutional work, and Santa Fe, a smaller minority-owned company also based here that has worked on several major projects for the city and state.
Mr. Emanuel said the two companies believed they were prepared for the regulatory and political challenges that usually accompany a huge public building project. But he said they did not expect the "arrogance and complete lack of experience" they faced at the hospital corporation, which had never before tried to build a hospital of this size.
Most of the design and architectural work on the 1,200-bed, 1.4-million-square-foot hospital had been completed by the time the agency selected Turner/Santa Fe to manage the work. But Mr. Emanuel said that shortly after his company began work, several top officials of the agency resigned to enter private industry, including the executive in charge of the Kings County project.
Later, he said, an official of the agency decided to replace the original architects and planners and ordered the entire project redesigned.
The official decided to move various units of the hospital into different buildings, he said, and ordered the deletion of planned bridge between the new hospital and the State University Health Sciences Center across Clarkson Avenue from the hospital in East Flatbush.
"It was like throwing out two or three years of work," said Mr. Emanuel. He estimated that the resulting delay set back the project at least two years.
Agency officials were not at work yesterday because of Lincoln's Birthday and thus could not verify Mr. Emanuel's account of the changes to the project.
 
Contracts Had to Be Redrawn
 As an example of the agency's inexperience, Mr. Emanuel said the hospital planners originally divided the project into only the four basic contracts required by state law: general contracting, plumbing, heating-air-conditioning, and electrical work.
But Turner/Santa Fe quickly realized that there were not enough contractors in the region large enough to qualify for such giant contracts, he said, resulting in a bid process that would not be competitive or economical for the city. In addition, he said, the large contracts meant that no minority firms would be able to participate, despite the insistence of neighborhood leaders that the construction provide an economic boost to the area.
At that point, he said, Turner/Santa Fe and the architects had to redraw the plans and rewrite the paperwork to subdivide the four large contracts into scores of smaller ones. The plumbing contract, he said, was divided to allow individual companies to handle only a few floors.
"That whole process probably added another year to the planning," Mr. Emanuel said.
City officials have cited the unsually large number of contracts for the project as one of the reasons for the moratorium called by the Mayor.
 
Excavation Held Up
 Mr. Emanuel also recounted an almost comical series of events that held up the basic excavation work on the new hospital, necessary before any other construction work on the main building could begin.
In April 1992, he said, the agency awarded the excavation contract to the second-lowest bidder, ruling that the lowest bidder had not properly completed the necessary paperwork. The lowest bidder then sued the city, and was awarded the contract four months later after a court order.
But 10 months later, the lowest bid was thrown out after the agency discovered that it had failed to disclose a previous criminal record. It took another five months for the contract to be awarded to a third company, producing a total delay of 19 months. Even now, Mr. Emanuel said, the agency has still not completed background checks and approved the new company's subcontractors, meaning that no excavation work on the project can begin.
Turner/Santa Fe was criticized two years ago in an independent audit by the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand for experiencing "difficulty in adquately discharging its responsibilities." Mr. Miranda referred to the criticism on Thursday when chastizing the joint venture.
But Mr. Emanuel said his company's difficulties were solely the result of trying to respond to the slipups and constantly changing demands of the hospitals agency. Just two weeks ago, he said, the agency put out new bid specifications on part of the hospital construction and then had to pull them back after the agency's legal department decided it wasn't satisfied with the paperwork.
"It's unprecedented," he said. "I've never seen anything like it. They had no experience at this sort of thing, and they simply didn't rise to the challenge."

HEADLINE: Conservation Agency Chief Is Named

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today nominated J. Langdon Marsh, the second-ranking official in the State Environmental Conservation Department, to replace the department's Commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, who is resigning next month to join a paper company.
The choice of Mr. Marsh was applauded by environmental groups, whose leaders described him as an accessible administrator and able spokesman for the agency and its policies over the last decade. 
 "I can't imagine a more qualified person in the country to run New York's Environmental Conservation Department," said Lee Wasserman, executive director of the Environmental Planning Lobby. "He's willing to talk to anyone and seriously consider their views in a way that I haven't seen in many state officials."
Mr. Marsh's nomination is not expected to encounter opposition in the Republican-controlled State Senate, which approves all commissioners.
Mr. Jorling will step down on March 2 from the position he has held since 1987 to become vice president for environmental affairs for the International Paper Company.
If his appointment is approved, Mr. Marsh, 52, will oversee an agency with 3,900 employees and an annual budget of $281 million that has endured repeated cutbacks amid the tight budgets of recent years.
He will also wield broad regulatory powers over development, state parks, industrial pollution, water quality and transportation -- powers that require balancing the often competing concerns of environmentalists against those of property owners, business and car drivers.
Among the new Commissioner's first responsibilities will be to develop regulations to bring New York into compliance with stricter Federal air pollution standards. Those regulations could have a major effect on an array of everyday matters, ranging from how people commute to work to what kind of lawn mowers they buy.
The new Commissioner will also face major decisions this year involving a state lawsuit to strengthen Federal acid rain regulations, new rules to reduce toxic chemicals in manufacturing and legislation to broaden protections against development in Adirondack State Park.
He will be paid $95,635 a year.
After graduating from Harvard Law School, Mr. Marsh worked for the Peace Corps in Ethiopia, then joined a private law firm in New York City. In 1973 he joined the Environmental Conservation Department as a counsel and rose through the ranks to deputy commissioner. He left the department in 1979 to become director of the Government Law Center for Union University's Albany Law School.
He returned to the department in 1983 as executive deputy commissioner and has held that position ever since.
In a written statement, Mr. Marsh praised Mr. Jorling for being "acutely aware of the crucial linkage between our environmental and economic futures" and vowed to follow a similar path.

HEADLINE: Long Bond Up After Sharp Swings

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Mixed signals on inflation set off sharp price swings in the Treasury market yesterday.
Prices of longer-term Treasury issues ended moderately higher, with the 30-year bond gaining 14/32 point. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.40 percent, from 6.43 percent on Thursday. 
 The market's swings were amplified by light trading volume as a result of the snowstorm in New York City, which led to an early afternoon closing of the Treasury market.
The Labor Department reported yesterday morning that its Producer Price Index, which provides a gauge of inflation pressures before they reach the consumer, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in January.
 
Early Buying on News
 The news initially enticed investors to buy bonds, sending prices sharply higher, because it showed that inflation stayed low and thus lessened the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates soon.
Higher inflation and interest rates can diminish the value of bonds and other fixed-income securities.
But some traders apparently lost enthusiasm and sold bonds after focusing on the so-called core rate of inflation, which excludes the volatile food and energy sectors.
The core rate showed that producer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month. In addition, the rate for capital goods -- including prices for such products as machinery, heavy trucks and computers -- was up six-tenths of 1 percent.
"That's one sector where you really have inflation pressures building," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at the Nikko Securities International Company. "It was a report that wasn't quite the way it seemed."
But prices advanced again later yesterday morning after the University of Michigan reported a drop in consumer confidence in the economy in February.
The Michigan survey index fell to 92.9, from 94.3 in January, according to market participants who saw the report, which is not released publicly.
That seemed to lend credence to the fixed-income camp that says economic growth is not yet strong enough to aggravate inflation.
Still, there are good reasons for the market's skittishness. Last Friday, the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates for the first time in five years, sending Treasury security prices sharply lower across the board.
The market had been awaiting the producer price figures -- and consumer price statistics due out next Thursday -- for clues about when the Fed would act again.
 
Fed Action Expected
 Mr. Brusca said the sharp jump in the prices of capital goods could be one impetus for the central bank to act next month. "Once the Fed has got the bit in its teeth, they're going to run with it," he said.
Prices of short-term Treasuries rose 1/16 point to 3/32 point, and intermediate maturities were 3/16 point to 11/32 point higher.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 2.72, to 1,295.83.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 1031/32 , down 4/32 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 5.53 percent, up from 5.52 percent.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Down Again As Demand Is Seen Easing

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Copper prices fell yesterday for the sixth time in seven days, amid signs that demand will not be as strong as previously expected.
Trading was relatively light in the New York futures markets, which closed several hours early because of the storm in the New York City area. The snow, however, did help lift heating oil prices. 
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, copper for March delivery fell 1.45 cents, to 84.15 cents a pound. The decline followed a surge that took copper to an eight-month high last week on speculation that stronger economic growth in the United States would increase demand.
 
Slower Growth in Demand
 Copper stockpiles have been falling recently in both the Commodity Exchange's warehouse and the London Metal Exchange's warehouse.
But much of the recent decline was caused by restocking by copper consumers. As such, analysts said demand was likely to slow this year to from an annual growth rate of 8 percent in 1993 to a rate of 2 to 3 percent.
"We don't think the market will continue to grow as strongly as it has in the past two years," said Kevin Norrish, research manager at the Commodities Research Unit. "The major part of the restocking is over."
In addition, demand from Europe will probably grow by about only 1.5 percent this year, mainly because Germany's economy is still weak, Mr. Norrish said. And he predicted that demand from Japan would probably not grow.
"Our view is that copper is overvalued at the moment," Mr. Norrish added.
Meanwhile, heating oil prices gained, leading crude oil prices higher, as the snow in the New York City area and forecasts for below-normal temperatures across the East reminded traders that demand would probably remain strong.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, heating oil for March delivery jumped 0.67 cent, to 50.98 cents a gallon, while March crude oil gained 16 cents, to $14.72 a barrel. March unleaded gasoline gained 0.10 cent, to 43.16 cents a gallon.
Heating oil stockpiles have fallen by about 22 percent since January.
"I had a feeling we could see heating oil get one last rise out of this cold weather," a trader with Arb Oil said. But, he warned, "I think this might be the last hurrah before it starts falling again."

HEADLINE: Year's First Price Data Show Little Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The Government today offered its first reading on inflation since the Federal Reserve's move last week to raise interest rates, and the data looked good to many economists.
Prices received by American producers for finished goods rose two-tenths of 1 percent in January, the Labor Department found, as jumps for gasoline, cars and tobacco were mostly offset by declines for food and heating oil. 
 The price data seemed unlikely to upset the Federal Reserve, which raised short-term interest rates last Friday for the first time in five years in an effort to keep prices and expectations about them in check.
Today's price data did, however, show a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent when the erratic food and energy components were excluded, the biggest such rise since January 1993.
Although the period covered by today's reading preceded the Fed's action, and therefore could not be taken as a sign that its higher interest rates were having an effect, many investors were concerned that a big jump in today's figures could have compelled the Fed to raise rates yet again. Analysts, noting that the number of items falling in price about equaled those rising last month, generally expect that the next Fed tightening will be months away.
A separate report from the Commerce Department today said that harsh weather and the California earthquake kept shoppers at home last month, pushing retail sales down five-tenths of 1 percent.
"Inflation remained under control while severe winter weather dampened consumers' shopping habits," Merrill Lynch concluded in a commentary for clients. Despite continuing bad weather, Merrill Lynch predicted the economy would grow at a 3.5 percent pace in the current quarter compared with about 6 percent in the October-December period.
Although economists were surprised by the weakness in retail sales, today's results did little to undermine the conviction of most economists that the economy is on a path of moderate growth -- though throttled back from a very strong finish in 1993 -- while showing only scattered signs of faster inflation.
Once again, the figures posed interpretive challenges because of revisions, new seasonal adjustment factors and downright weird numbers in addition to the disruptions of winter weather. With the Government in Washington essentially closed today because of the weather, private analysts were on their own.
Retail sales, which account for about one-third of economic activity, totaled $180.96 billion last month, 7 percent above the January 1993 level, with no adjustment for inflation.
Although most analysts had expected a modest gain in sales last month, the decline was not large and was generally dismissed as a result of weather and a consumer retrenchment after the holidays.
"Consumers were overextended anyway" as their spending increased faster than their incomes, said Evelina M. Tainer, president of Prime Economic Consulting in Chicago.
 
Earlier Data Revised

 
 But analysts also noted that the department revised upward its tally for sales in both November and December, the latter to a gain of 1.2 percent instead of the eight-tenths of 1 percent originally reported.
Sales of cars and other durable goods -- defined as items lasting at least three years -- slumped 1.6 percent after a string of hefty gains, which, except for a September decline, averaged more than 2 percent for each month since March.
Receipts at automobile dealers fell 1.3 percent last month, a result seemingly at odds with previous reports showing that dealers sold more cars. This puzzle, some suggested, might reflect exceptionally large sales to fleets or that individual customers were buying less expensive models.
Excluding autos, retail sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent in January.
The other main durable-goods categories also tumbled. Merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes posted a 2.4 percent drop while those selling furniture and other equipment for the home took in 1 percent less than in December.
Nondurables, which have lagged as housing and cars powered an economic takeoff since Labor Day, held their own last month, edging up one-tenth of 1 percent.
Gains were 2.1 percent for gasoline service stations, 1.9 percent for drug and proprietary stores and five-tenths of 1 percent for department stores and others selling general merchandise. But these were almost offset by declines of 1.7 percent for clothing stores, 1.2 percent for restaurants and bars and one-tenth of 1 percent for food stores.
 
Puzzling Gasoline Numbers

 
 Analysts also found anomalies in the price data, most prominent of which was a 6.5 percent rebound in the price of gasoline, the biggest jump in more than three years.
Severe weather, they observed, not only reduces driving but also tends to raise demand for heating oil. And since refineries produce both products together -- the ability to adjust the mix of the products is limited -- more production of heating oil means greater supplies of gasoline.
As a result of lower demand and higher supplies, there has been intense price competititon, with gasoline retailing recently at less than 90 cents a gallon in some places, like southeastern Pennsylvania. Economists said today that even if gasoline was priced correctly in January's Producer Price Index it has certainly retreated since.
Whatever uneasiness the price figures inspired involved either the higher "core" rate or the fact that raw materials other than food and energy posted another hefty advance.
Core inflation for finished goods averaged three-tenths of 1 percent in the latest three months. This contrasted with the August-October period when prices fell in two months and barely rose in the third. On the other hand, the core rate for the latest 12 months was just four-tenths of 1 percent, the same as for January, a comforting fact, analysts said.
 
Rises in 2 Sectors

 
 Prices for goods at the intermediate stage of production -- a sack of flour, for example -- climbed two-tenths of 1 percent, reversing a December drop of that size. Durable goods used in manufacturing rose two-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a surge of nine-tenths in December, as hot rolled steel sheet and strip fell 1.1 percent and steel bars rose much less than in January.
Materials for making nondurable goods, like chemicals, eased two-tenths of 1 percent after falling three-tenths of 1 percent in December.
At the crude stage of production, prices rose 1.3 percent over all, to retrace about half of December's decline. Crude materials other than food and energy climbed 1.6 percent after surging 1.8 percent and 2.3 percent in the two preceding months. The main reason for the slowing was a 2.4 percent downturn for iron and steel scrap.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Municipals Beckon, But Beware Rate Rise

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty

 BODY:
FOR bond investors who are at sea over the improving economy, municipals may be an inviting port of call. But, like all who may be affected by rising interest rates, buyers of tax-exempts should consider ways to batten down the hatches.
Last August, the Clinton tax increases made municipals much more lucrative. Last year's low interest rates also produced a record $290 billion in new municipals, making them relatively cheap. Indeed, long-term municipals are now earning 83 percent of what comparable, federally taxable Treasuries earn. 
 At this high ratio, "The tax-free feature is almost gravy," said James Lebenthal, a New York dealer.
This year added another attraction to municipals: the belief that new ones will soon be much rarer. "1993 was a flood; 1994 will be a drought," said Ian A. MacKinnon, the bond chief at Vanguard Group. This January saw only $14.7 billion in new issues, while January 1993 saw $18.4 billion.
If the dearth continues, it will put upward pressure on the price of municipals. This means get-'em-now-while-they're-cheap, of course, but it also means a blunting of today's big bond bugaboo -- rising interest rates.
Should long rates rise half a percentage point this year, "the price of Treasuries will decline 5 percent and municipals by only 3 or 4 percent," said Paul Williams, research director at John Nuveen & Company.
Finally, as tax revenues grow with the economy, dealers are offering many confident buy recommendations. James F. Lynch, editor of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory newsletter ($250, 212 663-5552), likes a $13 million Cambridge, Mass., bond because the city's major industries -- schools and health -- are looking up. He likes a $400 million North Carolina bond, too, since the state "has put its financial house in order."
Mr. MacKinnon of Vanguard likes bonds from New York -- city and state. "Wall Street is on a roll," he explained, "and the state's economy is diversified." Specifically, Mr. Lebenthal recommends the state's Dormitory Authority bonds.
All in all, municipals sound good -- but they are still bonds. How can an investor profit safely if the economy is entering a period of rising rates?
"Buy and hold" is the customary answer. By holding, an investor receives the stated interest during the life of the bond and, at maturity, its face, or par, value. The strategy shields investors from notoriously unpredictable interest rates.
Unfortunately, while mutual funds have many virtues -- expert managers, diversification -- they lack the ability to buy and hold.
"A fund is forever -- it never matures," said Wayne F. Nelson, a broker at Merrill Lynch. Fund managers must buy and sell bonds to put new money to use, to pay redemptions and to plump up yields undercut by management fees. If rates rise, this unavoidable activity will spell trouble.
"You may be the world's best health-stock picker," Mr. Nelson reasoned. "But if the health sector goes down, so does your fund." And fund trades can create taxable capital gains -- something municipal investors presumably want to avoid.
Those who think this defect outweighs funds' virtues should consider individual bonds -- if they have $50,000 to diversify adequately.
Generally traded over the counter in blocks of five $1,000 bonds, municipals are always sold net, "so you don't know the commission," Mr. Nelson said. Thus, he advises comparison-shopping -- asking three brokers for prices on, say, $25,000 of New York City A bonds. Or buy new issues, whose prices are known.
Merrill charges commissions of 0.125 percent to 2 percent on bonds, Mr. Nelson said, though 4 percent fees are not unknown in the industry.
Be mindful of bonds' terms of call, or early redemption. Calls expose investors to the very interest rate risk that the "buy and hold" method neutralizes. But wary investors can avoid the danger. "There are noncallables all over," Mr. Lynch said.
Investors can also "buy and hold" municipals through unit investment trusts, available through bankers and brokers. Like funds, trusts are professionally assembled, diversified portfolios, with modest minimum investments and monthly dividend checks. But, unlike funds, trusts are passive. The bonds are held to maturity.
Nuveen, a big packager of these trusts along with Merrill Lynch and Van Kampen Merritt, has "3,000 outstanding trusts with $20 billion," Mr. Williams said. Nuveen Short Intermediate Insured Trust 27 is typical. It has 14 issues, a five-year average maturity and a $5,000 minimum investment. And a sales fee. A $20,000 purchase carries a 3 percent charge; a $150,000 one, 2.6 percent.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Rising Interest Rates Could Hit Adjustable Mortgages Soon

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo

 BODY:
Among the first consumers to feel the impact of rising interest rates will be homeowners with adjustable-rate mortgages. For them, higher payments are at least six weeks away and probably longer, according to housing economists and interest rate analysts.
Keith T. Gumbinger, an analyst at HSH Associates, an interest rate research firm in Butler, N.J., said the vast majority -- more than 90 percent -- of adjustable mortgages have rates that change annually on their anniversary date. 
 Lenders are required to give 45 days' notice of any rate adjustment. Thus, a homeowner with a loan that has an anniversary date of March 1 had to be notified of the loan's new rate by Jan. 15, which was before the recent rise in rates.
"But if your rate adjustment is coming due in April, you are probably going to see it go up a quarter-point," Mr. Gumbinger said.
On Feb. 4, the Federal Reserve raised a key short-term interest rate to 3.25 percent from 3 percent, a move that has pushed up other short-term rates, like one-year Treasury securities. Many consumers' mortgages use these securities as a benchmark for adjusting rates.
"If they are tied to the one-year Treasury bond, it's possibly going to have an adverse effect on their monthly payment," said Robert Rosenblatt, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
About 27 percent of all home loans have adjustable rates, according to the mortgage group. In addition to loans that adjust annually, the category includes some loans that adjust every six months, two years or three years. A few mortgages even have rates that are fixed for the first five or seven years and that adjust once to a new rate for the balance of the loan.
People who took out adjustable loans last year may not be affected by an increase in rates this year. That's because adjustable-rate mortgages usually cap a rate increase at two percentage points a year and at six percentage points over the life of the loan.
When adjustables come due for the first time, the increase is generally the full two percentage points, because the initial rate was a low "teaser" rate, Mr. Gumbinger said. Consumers presumably have prepared their budgets with this increase in mind and will not have to worry about unexpected increases for another year.
Eventually, the rates on these teaser loans will climb to be more reflective of market rates, which are the one-year Treasury rate and a 2.75 percent markup imposed by the lender.

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Navratilova Exits Early At Chicago of All Places

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Martina Navratilova received an unwanted reminder tonight of why she has declared this year her last in competitive singles play. She was forced to take early retirement from the quarterfinals of the Virginia Slims of Chicago, an event she had captured a record 12 times, by 18-year-old Magdalena Maleeva.
"If this tournament is any indication, I'll be crying after every match I play," said the 37-year-old Navratilova, who was too distraught after her 6-4, 6-3 loss to participate in a bittersweet ceremony to honor her longevity here. 
 Instead, the top-seeded Navratilova retreated to prepare to meet Maleeva yet again tonight, in doubles, and the vanity license plates and city park plaque went temporarily unclaimed.
 
Key Chain Is Filled
 Navratilova, unwilling to turn her final circuit into a circus, had already declined to accept a key to the city. After all, she already had one, thanks to her accomplishment here in 1992, when she not only won the event the 12th time but also broke Chris Evert's record by collecting her 158th career title.
Tonight Navratilova couldn't outhit the fifth-seeded Maleeva from the baseline, nor was she able to outwit her from the net, and she ended up with a defeat that left her panting from the vain effort of chasing balls she couldn't quite catch.
"I really did not quite take it seriously enough in the beginning, and in the second set I was on my heels the whole time," said Navratilova, who lost to Steffi Graf in her 1994 inaugural event a week ago in Tokyo.

 
 
Had Won Two Straight

 
 Maleeva shocked Navratilova in the second round of the United States Open last September, but the veteran had handily ousted the teen-ager in their last two meetings.
A double fault put Navratilova behind by 3-5 in the first set, and although she broke directly back, she again failed to hold serve in the 10th game, in which Maleeva claimed the set with a backhand that traced the sideline. And once Navratilova fell behind by 4-2 in the second set, she "started to get shaky," said Maleeva, who needed three match points to end Navratilova's spectacular singles run here.
Until tonight, Navratilova felt no sense of nostalgia about her visit here, but the instant she wafted a final backhand just beyond the corner she was aiming at, her deflation overtook her. It hurt to lose, particularly for the last time, but Navratilova said her concern about presenting a classy Chicago swan song wasn't the reason she lost.
"That helps to push me, it doesn't make me any worse," she said of her retirement plans. "It's not a detrimental thing."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
N.B.A. Wants the Timberwolves to Stay

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The National Basketball Association wants to keep the Minnesota Timberwolves where they are despite the interest of several United States cities in taking the franchise, Commissioner David Stern said today.
Stern said that while the support of the team's ownership and fans have been firm, the financial problems with the Wolves' arena, the Target Center, will be difficult to resolve. 
 "There's a concern about whether midsize cities can support a team," Stern said at a press conference in conjunction with the All-Star weekend. "There's a terrible economic issue involved. We have to work to have an apparatus to keep teams in cities like this. The N.B.A. wants a team here. We want the Timberwolves to stay here in the present building in the present form."
 
Team's Future to Be Discussed
 Stern said the issue of the future of the franchise will be discussed in N.B.A. Board of Governors meetings this weekend, "but we want to turn down the rhetoric and focus on the issues. I'm more concerned with solving the problem than making headlines."
Stern said among the cities that have expressed an interest in the franchise are New Orleans, Nashville, San Diego, St. Louis and Tampa-St. Petersburg, Fla.
"But our first choice is for teams to stay where they are," Stern said. "It's nice to be wanted, but we're not putting teams up for the highest bidder."
Stern admitted the Target Center "is an economic drain, but the support for the team is fine. I've been impressed with the ownership."
In discussing the state of the N.B.A., Stern said that despite the recent retirements of Michael Jordan, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson, television ratings, attendance and revenues are all up.
"You can't replace Michael, Larry and Magic, but you can't replace Bill Russell, Wilt Chamberlain and Bob Pettit, either," Stern said. "What you do is keep going forward. There's been a tremendous influx of talent that continues to come in."

 
 
A New Look: Dunks and Rookies
 All-Star Saturday has a different look this year. The Legends game is gone, replaced by a mini All-Star game involving rookies only.
The dunk contest will be shorter. Instead of the slow-paced, one-dunk-at-a-time format used in years past, this year's contest will have players doing as many dunks as they can in 90 seconds during the opening round.
The only event that will look the same as it used to is the 3-point shootout. But instead of being held before the dunk contest, it will come at the end of the night.
Competing in the 3-point contest are B. J. Armstrong of Chicago, Dana Barros of Philadelphia, Dell Curry of Charlotte, Dale Ellis of San Antonio, Steve Kerr of Chicago, Eric Murdock of Milwaukee, Mark Price of Cleveland and Mitch Richmond of Sacramento.
The lineup for the dunk contest is down from eight to six players this year. Competing are Antonio Davis of Indiana, Allan Houston of Detroit, Shawn Kemp of Seattle, Robert Pack of Denver, Isaiah Rider of Minnesota and James Robinson of Portland.
The rookie game will have two teams of eight players each, coached by former N.B.A. coaches Doug Collins and K. C. Jones.
On Collins's team are Chris Webber of Golden State, Toni Kukoc of Chicago, Dino Radja of Boston, Rider, Davis, Lindsay Hunter of Detroit, Sam Cassell of Houston and Byron Russell of Utah.
On Jones's team are P. J. Brown of the Nets, Anfernee Hardaway of Orlando, Shawn Bradley of Philadelphia, Jamal Mashburn and Popeye Jones of Dallas, Nick Van Exel of the Los Angeles Lakers, Calbert Cheaney of Washington and Chris Mills of Cleveland.

HEADLINE: Dodging a Trade Battle

 BODY:
In the end, they were two men hemmed in by politics. President Clinton, leader of a Japan-bashing Administration, could not accept Japan's formulaic promises to open its markets. Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, barely holding onto office, could not appear to cave in to American demands to measure American imports.
So they walked away without signing a hollow trade agreement that invited ridicule. In a way, it was refreshing to hear them announce -- not in these words, of course -- that they had gone for a political survival pact rather than a trade agreement. The two leaders reassured the public that the trade rift would not compromise the otherwise strong and friendly relationship between the two allies. The moment, both leaders agreed, called for reflection, not recrimination. 
 At the core of the dispute is a persistent $50 billion trade imbalance that has survived dozens of previous attempts to erase it. Last July the U.S. and Japan entered into a vaguely worded "framework" agreement that committed Japan to reduce its trade surplus and specifically open its market to foreign cars and car parts, insurance and telecommunications equipment and medical equipment. Left unsettled was how to measure whether Japan was living up to its import-creating commitments; that question was supposed to be answered by yesterday's meeting.
Mr. Clinton wants to impose numerical benchmarks that would decisively measure market access; he insists that those benchmarks need not set specific import levels. Mr. Hosokawa rejects numerical benchmarks because, he fears, they will evolve into import targets -- forcing him to dictate purchasing decisions of private industry. That prescription, he said, would reverse the deregulatory thrust of his reform Government.
So where do the two leaders head from here?
For his part, Mr. Clinton can first lower the political flame under the controversy. He misrepresents the cause and exaggerates the importance of the trade deficit. Trade deficits are home-grown, caused not by Japanese bureaucrats but by low U.S. savings: Americans buy more than they produce, and must import the difference. If Japan were to sell less to the U.S., some other country would sell more to willing U.S. buyers. That said, Japan does practice protectionism, though its methods are subtle. Its practices undermine faith in international rules of fair trade and victimize specific U.S. industries. Mr. Clinton is right to demand that the Japanese play straight.
Specifically, he can exhort Japan to do more than previously agreed to cut taxes and otherwise spur its economy; some of the extra spending will spill over into imports. He can continue to demand that practices fully under Mr. Hosokawa's control -- like government procurement methods -- be changed to give foreign companies a fairer shot at contracts. And he can demand an end to discriminatory rules that keep financial service markets closed to foreigners. If Japan refuses to yield on these specific demands, the U.S. would be justified in retaliating under international rules.
But Mr. Clinton treads on shaky ground when he broaches specific market outcomes. One danger is that numerical targets will be driven more by politics than by economics. Besides, there is no basis for determining, for example, how many large cars with steering wheels on the wrong side the Japanese should buy.
For his part, Mr. Hosokawa could produce a list of quantifiable criteria -- such as the number of licensing roadblocks a foreign insurance company or investment firm must hurdle -- that the U.S. could use to measure access. Those criteria need not set a specific numerical target.
If there was any cause for hope yesterday, it was that the two leaders seemed genuinely devoted to finding compromise that met each's legitimate objectives. Perhaps with the deadline of the summit gone, and if politically volatile events in both countries pass, they can find common ground.

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
BEYOND DESPAIR: Three Lectures and a Conversation With Philip Roth, by Aharon Appelfeld. (Fromm, $17.50.) The Israeli novelist argues that literature can and must deal with the Holocaust or give up its pretensions to be a vehicle of spiritual apprehension.
 
THE BINGO PALACE, by Louise Erdrich. (HarperCollins, $23.) Three decent people look for love on a windblown prairie in this novel whose daily life is enriched by supernatural events and the presence of Indian spirits.
 
BITTER WINDS: A Memoir of My Years in China's Gulag, by Harry Wu and Carolyn Wakeman. (Robert L. Bernstein/Wiley, $22.95.) Mr. Wu's memoir of 19 years in labor camps is grimly familiar as to abuse and deprivation but grotesque and surreal in its account of acting out each new political rectification campaign right in the heart of the prison system.
 
BRAZIL, by John Updike. (Knopf, $23.) In the vast, trackless wilds of a Brazil the author freely admits making up out of whole cloth, a tragicomic knight-errant and his dolly, madly in love, break all the rules of class and race.
 
THE CAVEMAN'S VALENTINE, by George Dawes Green. (Warner, $19.95.) Romulus Ledbetter, Mr. Green's protagonist, is a homeless, black, paranoid private eye who can be roused to propriety only by a case as interesting as the one Mr. Green has dreamed up for his first novel.
 
CROSSING THE RIVER, by Caryl Phillips. (Knopf, $22.) A novel, covering two and a half centuries, that presents a brilliantly coherent mythified vision of the irreversible African diaspora.
 
GOING NATIVE, by Stephen Wright. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A road novel that explodes the conventions of the genre as a weird, dangerous shape-shifting protagonist remakes his identity on the way to California.
 
HOW WE DIE: Reflections on Life's Final Chapter, by Sherwin B. Nuland. (Knopf, $24.) The author, a physician, surgeon and teacher for 35 years, offers a wise, humane and cultivated examination of what happens to people when they die, omitting none of the clinical detail.
 
IMAGES: My Life in Film, by Ingmar Bergman. (Arcade, $27.95.) At 75, the great Swedish film maker confronts and reveals himself as artist and man in this evocation of his career, based on a fresh viewing of all his movies.
 
JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES. Volume 2: The Economist as Saviour 1920-1937, by Robert Skidelsky. (Allen Lane/Penguin, $37.50.) How Keynes reshaped the world's economy, made a lot of money and married a ballerina, by an economics professor whose mastery of many subjects seems to match Keynes's own.
 
JOSEPHINE: The Hungry Heart, by Jean-Claude Baker and Chris Chase. (Random House, $27.50.) Prodigious research and outstanding narrative fluency mark this biography of Josephine Baker (1906-75), the irresistible American institution of French revues, cabaret and film.
