HEADLINE: Fine Dining Comes to Vegas

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
Las Vegas has become the latest, and most unlikely, high roller on the national restaurant scene. Just five years ago gastronomic opportunities there were circumscribed by garish institutional hotel fare and modest family-style establishments catering to year-round residents.
But with the arrival of spectacular new resorts like the $1 billion MGM Grand Hotel and Casino, the $475 million Treasure Island Casino and Hotel, and the $375 million Luxor Hotel, leading restaurateurs from around the country have decided that Las Vegas is ready for cutting edge cuisine. 
 Nearly 200 restaurants have opened in the city in the past two years, according to Van Heffner, president of the Nevada Restaurant Association.
"It has really gone wild," Mr. Heffner said. "Our old pace used to be about one restaurant a week. That has easily doubled." One of the biggest success stories is Wolfgang Puck's re-creation of his celebrity chocked Los Angeles grill, Spago, in Caesar's Palace Forum Mall. Spago serves California-style pizzas, grilled fish, game and meat and was designed by Adam Tihany, the architect who has created many restaurant decors.
The all-American steakhouse has found its place in Las Vegas in a big way. Among the most prominent out-of-town establishments to take root in Nevada's sandy soil are Morton's, a Chicago-based chain; Palm, the masculine Manhattan beef emporium, and Ruth's Chris Steakhouse, part of a large New Orleans chain.
The prosperity of those newcomers has prompted other leading American chefs to look toward Las Vegas. The most recent is Coyote Cafe, an offshoot of a Southwestern restaurant by the same name in Santa Fe. Coyote Cafe is in the huge MGM Grand Hotel and Casino. Coyote Cafe caters to all kinds of customers with a formal 90-seat dining room and a 110-seat cafe that serves Mexican and Mediterranean dishes.
The presence of fine dining establishments like Spago and Coyote Cafe has also meant the immigration of sommeliers, nearly an extinct species in the economically pressed East. Impressive wine lists are appearing all over town.
Italian restaurants have been opening at a fast clip, most of them locally based. The biggest and spashiest import is the new Sfuzzi, a stylish and theatrical spot that serves au courant northern Italian fare like individual pizzas, risottos and game.
And as Las Vegas vies to become an all-around family resort rather than just a gambling mecca, chains that cater to children and teen-agers, including every incarnation of fast food, have appeared. A Hard Rock Cafe opened in 1990, with the usual crashing music and colorful T-shirts. First year's sales topped $16 million, a success that has inspired a Hard Rock Hotel and Casino, an $80 million, 325-room property scheduled to open in December. The other teen palace on the way is Planet Hollywood, which has announced plans, but no date, to open downtown.
Why all this activity now? "Las Vegas has a much larger customer base than ever," said Joel Bergman, a leading Las Vegas architect. "We expect 25 million visitors in 1994, and many of those people are coming for a complete vacation that includes leaving the hotels for dinner."
And with its permanent population expected to reach one million by the end of the year, Las Vegas has developed a large, and demanding, core of restaurant-goers. "Many of us travel around the country and dine at places like Spago," Mr. Bergman said. "So it's nice to have these places opening right here."
 BRYAN MILLER

HEADLINE: Co-op Market Drift Continues In Manhattan

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
THE apartment market in New York seems dead to Jeff Mullen, who for the last year has been trying to sell his co-op on the Upper West Side for $118,000. Not even his classified ad promising views of Maui and offering the lucky buyer two round-trip tickets to Hawaii has attracted much interest in his run-of-the-mill one-bedroom unit.
"We did get one person who wanted to know whether you could actually see Hawaii from the apartment," said Mr. Mullen, an advertising copywriter. "They obviously didn't get the joke and thought the building was taller than it is." 
 The market, however, appears vastly different to Virginia M. Henneberry. Last month, she sold her Upper West Side two-bedroom co-op overlooking Central Park. She also received close to her asking price and turned a tidy profit.
"It's a real jewel," said Ms. Henneberry, an investment adviser, who sold the co-op, in a West Side building next door to the famed Dakota, for $475,000. "I would have been surprised if no one had bought it."
The tales of Mr. Mullen and Ms. Henneberry show the vivid variances in the health of the New York residential real estate market. For the relatively small number of wealthy Manhattanites who own large, sought-after co-op or condominium units in financially stable buildings in prime neighborhoods, demand and sale prices are firm, if not strong. But for middle-class owners of the far more numerous dark, cramped studio or one-bedroom apartments, perhaps in a financially precarious building in a marginal area, 1993 was a year of low demand and prices that continued to fall.
"You have a tale of two cities," said Barbara Corcoran, the head of the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan real-estate brokerage that bears her name.
Because most of the apartments in Manhattan fall into the lesser of these two worlds, the median price for all co-ops in the borough fell substantially -- by 9.8 percent -- in 1993, to $77,465 a room, according to figures compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York. Median means that half the apartments sold for more than that figure and half sold for less.
The number of co-ops sold in Manhattan is estimated to have increased slightly in 1993 over 1992, but the volume, as measured by Douglas Elliman, a Manhattan real estate broker, was less than in 1991.
There were, though, some signs of improvement. The overall price decline was not as steep as the double-digit drops of two or three years ago. Moreover, the median sales price among co-ops with three or more bedrooms rose 3.9 percent in 1993 over the previous year. The median sale price of units with one bedroom or less, however, dropped by 12.1 percent.
The happiest sellers may have been those who owned condominiums, which make up 22.7 percent of the market-rate apartments in Manhattan. These units, of which there are 45,000 in Manhattan, soared in value.
According to Yale Robbins Inc., a real estate research and publishing concern, the average sale price of a condominium in Manhattan rose 9.3 percent in 1994, to $335,788, and the number of sales increased by 20.7 percent.
Despite the smattering of positive statistics for the owners of condominiums and large co-ops, these numbers were overshadowed by last year's sharp decline in the overall sales price of co-ops, especially since brokers a year ago predicted that the market would soon start to rise in value.
The slide also marked the fifth straight year that co-op prices have ebbed, evidence that the nation's economic recovery is more rumor than reality for many apartment owners in the region.
For example, Mr. Mullen recently decided to rent his apartment for $1,200 a month and absorb a $300-a-month negative cash flow.
"My sense is that things are bad and getting worse," he said.
Curiously, the continuing decline in co-op prices comes as prices in many other sectors of the residential real estate in the Northeast have begun rebounding, particularly the detached single-family home market in places like Fairfield County, Conn.
ECONOMISTS and real estate analysts have attributed the drop to the rapid price escalation that occurred in the early and mid-80's as well as to the slack demand created by the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs in the city, particularly in the financial-services industry, since the stock market crash in October 1987.
"It's the economy," said Roberto Bezjon, who has been trying to sell his spacious five-room co-op with spectacular East River views for $500,000. The monthly maintenance charge is $1,800, and the minimum down payment is 50 percent.
"Three or four years ago, people would come into my apartment with $750,000 checks saying, 'I want it,' " he said.
"I hope there will be a turnaround," added Mr. Bezjon, a make-up artist who plans to move to the West Coast but keep a smaller apartment in Manhattan.
There is also a huge degree of uncertainty, some brokers believe, among many potential apartment buyers, especially in the middle class, not only about the economy and holding on to their jobs, but also about the lack of liquidity in buying a co-op and the amount of time it may take to realize a profit.
Others note, too, the dwindling number of prosperous, first-home-buying baby boomers moving to Manhattan and perceptions that the quality of life in the city is declining.
One of the most oft-cited fears about buying a co-op, however, involves the restrictive policies that are part of this form of ownership. Co-op boards can require high down payments for buyers in their buildings (50 percent is not unusual in more luxurious neighborhoods).
Further, owners are often barred from subleasing their units (owners are considered tenants) or they are restricted to renting them out for one or two years.
Co-ops, to some degree, have also been stigmatized by buildings that have unsound underlying mortgages, which has led to abnormally large monthly maintenance charges in some cases, particularly in buildings less than 50 percent owner-occupied.
The maintenance on Mr. Mullen's relatively inexpensive co-op, for example, is $1,000 a month. Any buyers, unless they paid all cash, would likely face the prospect of paying more in maintenance than for their mortgage.
"The maintenance is a killer," Mr. Mullen said.
Tracking the ups and downs of the city's apartment market is much more imprecise than measuring the market for suburban single-family detached homes. Not only are there huge disparities between neighborhoods and unit sizes, but co-op sales, unlike sales of condominiums and homes, are not publicly reported. This is because they are, technically, stock rather than real-property transactions.
Besides the Real Estate Board of New York, several Manhattan brokers, most notably Douglas Elliman, the Corcoran Group, and the Halstead Property Company, have their own surveys and indexes, as does the National Cooperative Bank.
But these reports have not been independently verified, their sample sizes are generally small and they tend to give short shrift to, if not outright ignore, the boroughs outside Manhattan and, in some cases, even downtown Manhattan.
Their methodology is also skewed in varying ways and thus they report somewhat different findings. Douglas Elliman's survey of 1,171 apartments, for example, relies mostly on its own sales, which tend to be from largely upscale buildings in uptown locations; according to its survey, average co-op apartment prices fell 3.1 percent in 1993.
The Corcoran Group report, on the other hand, applies an estimate of the variance between listing prices and sales prices, derived from its own offices and those of cooperating brokers, and applies it to a wider sample of listing prices to arrive at its overall sales-price estimates. Its survey, which included condos, stated that average prices fell 1.5 percent last year.
AS for a survey of 925 sales by the National Cooperative Bank -- which is based in Washington and provides an array of financial services, including underlying mortgage financing, to the nation's co-ops -- it showed a 2.4 percent increase in average co-op sale prices for the entire New York area last year.
Though the bank's sample was small, it did scan average prices in the city outside Manhattan, where their sample found that prices fell 8.2 percent in Brooklyn and Queens, and in Westchester County, where they fell 14.9 percent. (The vast majority of the nation's co-op apartments are in the city.)
"Even though the New York City co-op values have yet to reach their 1989 high point of $84,473 per room, the 1993 increase of 2.4 percent is an encouraging sign," said Sheldon Gartenstein, vice president and loan officer at the National Cooperative Bank. "The increase follows two years of steady and significant declines, representing a stabilization of co-op values in the overall market."
In an effort to produce a single comprehensive study of the co-op market in Manhattan, the Real Estate Board of New York began its survey last year and includes sales volume and median prices from various brokers throughout the borough. Even so, its report for 1993 only covered 1,286 transactions, or about 25 percent of approximately 5,000 apartments that the board estimates turn over each year.
There are about 153,000 market-rate co-op apartments in Manhattan.
"The market has bottomed out," said Jonathan Adams, chief economist for the Real Estate Board of New York. "But saying it has turned around may give the impression that there has been an appreciation of value, and it is too early make that conclusion based on our data."
Mr. Adams added that the recovery among larger, more expensive apartments might trickle down and eventually spur demand for smaller, cheaper units. He cautioned, though, that such a scenario is by no means guaranteed. He also predicted that apartments in Manhattan will "see some appreciation" in 1994 as job growth, rents and apartment demand are all thought to be rising this year, while the supply of units remains stagnant because of the dearth of new building.
"I am least confident about the studio and one-bedrooms," he said.
Even among studios and one-bedroom co-op apartments, Mr. Adams said the worst may be over. "At $50,000 a room, it's comparable to renting," he said.
The increasing popularity of condominiums is due, in part, to the declining attractiveness of co-ops over the last five years. Condominiums, though more expensive generally, are easier to buy, sell and rent because there are no restrictive policies. Further, condominiums, unlike co-ops, do not have underlying mortgages and high monthly maintenance fees. In fact, condominium common charges are usually low, though they do not include property taxes, as do co-op maintenance charges.
"I didn't want to the liability of owning a co-op, a piece of the mortgage on the total property," said Nathan Zutty of New Canaan, Conn., who recently paid $332,500 in cash for a 1,400-square-foot, two-bedroom condominium on the Upper East Side. His common charges are $704 a month and his taxes are about $400 a month.
Mr. Zutty, a retired senior manager at Union Carbide in Danbury, Conn., who bought the unit for himself and for his son, Max, a graduate student at Columbia, also believes the New York real estate market is about to be revived. More important, perhaps, he likes New York City. "I was born here, and I always wanted to come back," he said.
BUT not every buyer craves a condominium. Constance Sullivan, for example, said she found it difficult to find a condominium that had the charm -- the moldings, fireplaces and 12-foot ceilings -- of many old co-op buildings. (Pre-war condominiums do exist on Manhattan's Upper East Side, but only a few and the market tends to be dominated by wealthy foreigners.)
"I wanted to be in a prewar building," she said.
Ms. Sullivan, a book packager, said a key factor in her decision to buy a one-bedroom co-op on the Upper East Side for $150,000 was that prices had declined to the point that it made more sense to buy than to continue renting. She had been paying $1,600 a month to rent a similar apartment. For her new apartment, she put 50 percent down and will have a monthly maintenance of $700 a month. "My monthly expenses will be much lower than when I was renting," she said.
Such an endorsement of the co-op market offers little solace to Mr. Mullen, who has offered a trip for two to Hawaii as an inducement to buy. He said his best hopes for selling his apartment probably lie with turning the unit over to a rental tenant in some sort of lease-option arrangement. In the meantime, he'll keep dreaming up novel enticements.
"Maybe we'll offer certificates to Toys-'R'-Us," he said. "It seems to work with gun owners."

HEADLINE: Is There Another Airport in the State's Future?

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER

 BODY:
TRAVELERS using Bradley International Airport at Windsor Locks will be able to fly to more destinations and to choose from more flights under a $364 million plan to expand the airport over the next 20 years.
The plan, developed by the state's Department of Transportation, calls for a new terminal, expansion of an existing terminal and three concourses serving 36 aircraft gates. Ultimately a fourth concourse could be built, raising the number of gates to 54. 
 Improvements like a new Federal inspection service for international flights, a 5,000-space parking garage and a road system serving each terminal with upper and lower roadways are also part of the plan.
The expansion, which must be approved by the Federal Aviation Administration, was drawn up to meet increases expected in cargo and passenger traffic. The number of passengers using the airport each year will more than double by the year 2015, from the current 2.3 million to nearly 5.8 million, according to the Transportation Department. And cargo traffic is anticipated to triple over the next 20 years.
 
New Airport Proposed
 But Bradley may not be the state's only international airport in coming years. A group led by William B. Stanley of Norwich, a former state senator, and Arnold M. Danielsen of East Lyme, a retired Coast Guard rear admiral, have their own vision of Connecticut's airport of the future. They have begun an effort to build support for an international airport and industrial complex in a location that may include parts of Connecticut, Rhode Island and Massachusetts. A precise site cannot be chosen until environmental, economic and engineering studies are made, Mr. Danielsen said.
What they call the Gateway Transportation Center would encompass about 30,000 acres and serve as a transfer point for passengers and cargo. Passengers on flights from Europe and Asia would board connecting flights to destinations in the United States. A two-mile-wide band of parkland surrounding the complex would serve as a buffer zone.
"We're talking about a large airport to handle the airplanes of the future that will carry 550 to 800 passengers and go anywhere in the world nonstop," Mr. Danielsen said.
Even though Gateway is at this point scarcely more than an idea, the mere mention of it strikes fear among environmentalists and others who passionately protect eastern Connecticut's forests and farmlands and promise a relentless fight against a jetport.
State and Federal officials, who also oppose the project, cite the high cost and the many environmental obstacles and maintain there are other airports in the region that can do the job. Local legislators have also spoken out, saying there are more workable solutions to the region's economic problems.
 
'No One Wants It'
 "It's not going anywhere," the ranking Republican on the General Assembly's Commerce Committee, State Senator Catherine Welles Cook, a Republican from Groton, said. "No one wants it. No one supports it."
One center of stiff resistance is in Griswold, in the target area for the Gateway. A Griswold resident, Mary Walton, and the Save Our State Coalition regard Gateway as unwanted, unnecessary and impossible. "It will never be able to provide the jobs it promised, nor will it be able to be built," Mrs. Walton said. The project would result not only in the destruction of valuable natural resources, she said, but also in the upheaval of surrounding communities. "Like people around the casino, people here are trying to preserve their land," Mrs. Walton said. "The whole social life would be affected." An international airport and industrial complex for eastern Connecticut is a concept that Mr. Stanley, now a stockbroker, has kept alive for more than 20 years. While he was a state senator from 1966 to 1970, he became convinced that a Gateway was a means of diversifying the state's defense-dominated economy, since the New York and Boston airports could not continue to expand.
 
Highway, Rail and Air Center
 In 1972, the Connecticut Port Authority Study Commission, headed by Mr. Stanley, recommended a regional transportation center that would include highway, rail and air components. But the General Assembly's transportation committee rejected a bill last year authorizing the state to update the 1972 study.
Nevertheless, Mr. Stanley and Mr. Danielsen said they were committed to the Gateway concept, which they envision will provide eastern Connecticut's depressed economy with industry and jobs, and link businesses in the state with markets around the world. The two have set up the Gateway Transportation Center Corporation and a 26-member board of directors, which includes representatives of labor unions, business and industry, academia, service organizations and the Mashantucket Pequot Indians.
An advertisement by the Gateway Corporation in a local newspaper last June solicited money and volunteer help for everything from clerical work to engineering and management. Thirty to 40 volunteers responded, Mr. Danielsen said, and more than 300 groups and individuals signed up as supporters. Some start-up money will be needed from government or private sources, but all additional costs will be financed with bonds, said Mr. Danielsen, who declined to say how much money the corporation had raised so far.
 
Presenting the Case
 Mr. Stanley, who is proposing that Connecticut, Rhode Island and Massachusetts collaborate on the project, seems undaunted by his critics. "We must present the case so that various legislators will see the wisdom of it," he said. "This will benefit all three states. I'm not going to get out of the way until somebody else comes up with a better idea."
Another Gateway critic, Richard Strauss, Deputy Commissioner of the State Transportation Department, said that the department was trying to attract international flights to Bradley Airport and that a $300 million investment to expand Bradley was minor compared with the cost of a new airport. Bradley's runways are adequate for the types of aircraft expected in the future, and the longest runway can accommodate flights to European destinations. Areas now used for cargo and general aviation will also meet future needs, according to the 20-year plan.
The airport employs 5,000 people, with a total payroll of about $94 million, according to the Transportation Department. The economic benefit to the region is expected to increase from nearly $808 million to about $2.4 billion annually in the next 20 years.
 
'Too Many Airports'
 In addition, a new United Parcel Service cargo installation is scheduled to open at Bradley by the late 1990's, Mr. Strauss said. "What advantage is there in moving traffic from Bradley to a Gateway only 30 miles away?" he asked. "There are too many airports in the area. I don't see the airlines providing service to Boston, Bradley, a Gateway and Providence, and being able to come up with the traffic to fill the planes."
The Federal Aviation Administration has taken the Transportation Department's position. "We try to be consistent with what the state is calling for in its system plan and incorporate it into the Federal plan," the manager of the F.A.A.'s airports division, Vincent Scarano, said. "There's nothing that indicates a need in their system plan for a new airport. Cargo and passenger needs are served by existing airports."
Mr. Danielsen argued that dense populations around most airports prevented their expansion into an airport and industrial complex and that the cost and public inconvenience in expanding Bradley would be high compared with building a new airport in an isolated region.
At Gateway Transportation Center, on the other hand, cargo planes would be provided with loading sites at warehouses in the industrial park. "Our Gateway would be the vehicle," he said, "that would allow businesses to have the 'just-in-time deliveries' that we find so essential in today's very competitive world economy."
The assistant director of public relations for the Mashantucket Pequot Indian Tribal Council, Joseph Carter, is one of two members of the tribe on the Gateway Corporation's board. Mr. Carter said an international jetport in eastern Connecticut would open desirable European markets to the tribe's enterprise, Foxwood High Stakes Bingo and Casino in Ledyard. Bradley Airport is about 60 miles from the casino.
 
Unions Support Plan
 Although the Mashantuckets have not invested any money in Gateway, Mr. Carter said, the tribe is taking a close look at the project's potential. "It would benefit the whole area, not just the casino, by opening a bigger field for businesses and recreation," he said.
Also on the board are John Olsen, president of the Connecticut A.F.L.-C.I.O., which has endorsed the Gateway Transportation Center, and Cameron G. Champlin Jr., business manager of the United Association of Plumbers and Steam Fitters, Local 305. Mr. Champlin said Gateway was the only project he knew of that would put thousands of people who have lost their jobs back to work. About 100 members of the local's rank and file voted recently to donate $2,500 to the Gateway Corporation.
"New England, and especially Connecticut, has a very highly educated work force," Mr. Champlin said. "If we don't do something now, they're going to move to other parts of the country."
But Representative Steven Mikutel, Democrat of Griswold, a critic of Gateway, accused Mr. Stanley and Mr. Danielsen of manipulating hard economic times to sell the project. "It's like starving somebody for a month and then asking if they want to eat," he said. "You don't ask for a decision like this in a poor economic climate. The tendency is to seize any plan."
Fear of a jetport in his backyard nags at Mr. Mikutel, who has been nervously eyeing Mr. Stanley's brainchild for 20 years. "People don't want outsiders like Bill Stanley, who lives in Norwich, saying it's fine to build a jetport in my district,' he said. "There's no compromise. We're going to fight this until they die or we die."
Gateway supporters face another opponent, the Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, Timothy R. E. Keeney, who said the many permits required to build an international jetport on virgin land made a site in eastern Connecticut impractical. A large airport, he added, would make it difficult for Connecticut to comply with the Federal Clean Air Act. "For the increase in air pollution the project would bring, it would have to be offsets elsewhere in the state," he said. "My suggestion is that time might be better spent on another project."
 
Task Force Has Ideas
 Although the state's Department of Economic Development has taken its place in the opposition lineup, the department's spokesman, Joseph M. Cohen, described Mr. Stanley as a man with a vision and political savvy. "Bill Stanley is a visionary who saw something that is likely to happen somewhere, someday," he said. "But whether he can make it happen in this century is a big question mark."
Mrs. Cook, the State Senator from Groton, has come up with an alternative to Gateway. The legislature's export task force, which she heads, is looking for ways to improve export opportunities for small and medium-sized businesses in the state. The task force is examining trade financing problems, changes in the tax code, and infrastructure improvements like more warehouse space at Bradley Airport.
But the Gateway idea will not go away and has, in fact, grown into a volatile issue with powerful players on both sides. Mr. Danielsen is recruiting more people for the corporation's board not only from Connecticut but also from Rhode Island and Massachusetts. "We owe it to ourselves to seize this great opportunity before another, more aggressive and imaginative state grabs the brass ring," he said.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

YUGOSLAV BREAKUP
A forum on the disintegration of the former Yugoslavia will be held at Purchase College Friday at noon, free of charge. Visitors may bring lunch.
The speakers, Evan Kraft, assistant professor of economics at Salisbury State University in Maryland, and Jill Benderly, a journalist and author, have family ties in that beleaguered region. 
 Ms. Benderly participated in establishing an international tribunal to investigate the rape of Bosnian women by enemy forces, and she has been active in the United States and the former Yugoslavia in feminist pursuits. Professor Kraft, a former member of the Purchase College faculty, recently returned from a research visit to Bosnia, adding to his data on the destruction of the economy of the region.
The program will take place in the Social Science Auditorium on the Purchase College campus, 735 Anderson Hill Road. The number to call for more information is 251-6600 or 251-6050.

 
TREE-PRUNING SESSION
Pruning small ornamental trees correctly will be demonstrated on Saturday at Lasdon Park and Arboretum in Somers, organized by the Master Gardeners of Westchester Cooperative Extension of Cornell University.
Carmine Serpe, president of Serpe Tree Service in Scarsdale and member of the American Society of Consulting Arborists and the National Arborists Association, will conduct the session, offering advice based on 45 years of experience.
He will present a one-hour lecture before taking the group outdoors to do some actual pruning, emphasizing the preservation of the tree's inherent structure. Japanese maples, dogwoods, crabapples, flowering cherry and magnolias are frequently topped off, ruining their natural appearance, Mr. Serpe said.
"In winter, when the leaves are off, is the ideal time to observe their natural shape, and in their dormant state, the best time to prune," he said. "Other than removing diseased or broken branches, pruning of older trees should consist of cutting back to the same point each year. Young trees with long shoots should be left alone: the other branches will catch up as the tree matures."
Lasdon Park is off Route 35, and the phone number is 232-3141. Boots and cold-weather gear should be worn. The admission fee will be $7.50; reservations are necessary. More information may be obtained by calling 666-4549.

 
ZYDECO PERFORMANCE
 Roy Carrier and the Nite-Rockers is the latest zydeco band to hit Westchester, performing Saturday night at the Free Synagogue, 500 North Columbus Avenue in the Fleetwood section of Mount Vernon. Free dance lessons will be given from 7:30 to 8:30, and music for listening and dancing begins at 8:30 and continues to midnight. Admission will be $12.50 at the door.
Many aficionados say that Mr. Carrier is one of the few remaining zydeco purists, eschewing amplified instruments and hewing to the original guitars, drums, accordion and rubboard. He has recorded extensively for Lanor Records since 1984, and he jams with other professionals and amateurs every Thursday night at his Offshore Lounge in Lawtell, La.
The barnlike roadhouse accommodating 500 people sits next to Carrier's oversized mobile home and was named for his former vocation -- driller on an offshore oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico during the 1970's. But his musical calling is one of long standing, beginning with the Sears Roebuck catalogue guitar bought for him by his mother when he was a teen-ager.
In recent years he has become a mentor for up-and-coming zydeco musicians, including John Delafose, Beau Jacques and Zydeco Force. His son, Chubby Carrier, still plays with the Nite-Rockers when not occupied with his own band.
For more information, the number to call is 381-0708.

 
VERSATILE BAND
 Shockra, a five-piece band from Boston, plays jazz, funk, rock and rhythm and blues with an energetic edge that inspires its audiences to dance rather than listen sitting down. Its first recording, "Garuda's Groove," was released as a compact disk last May by Apogee Records and has been selling well.
Dave Watts is the drummer and principal songwriter; Dan Coutu is the keyboardist and sound effects man, and Edwin Hurwitz thumps the bass.
Felix Rentschler doubles as guitarist and composer, and Jeff Grove plays saxophone and does vocals, which has contributed to the group's singular sound. The band may be heard at 7 Willow Street in Port Chester on Saturday from 9 P.M. to 4 A.M.
The nightclub, named for its location, is ensconced in a former small opera house. There is no food service, just drinks and music, with a Saturday night cover charge of $10 in advance, $12 at the door. The number to call for reservations is 939-1474.

 
'PETER AND THE WOLF'
 Prokofiev's "Peter and the Wolf" will be performed twice today by the Bronx Arts Ensemble and the Bronx Dance Theater, first at 2 P.M. and again at 3:30 P.M. The fully staged, hour-long production will be presented in the studios of the Dance Theater at 204th Street and Bainbridge Avenue in the Bronx.
Barbara Klein, artistic director of the Dance Theater, was the choreographer, and Yehuda Gilead, conductor of the Colonial Symphony Orchestra in Madison, New Jersey, will conduct musicians of the Bronx Arts Ensemble.
The cast, will be made up of students from the Dance Theater, and a musical introduction to the instruments of the orchestra will be provided by the Bronx Arts Ensemble members.
Tickets are $12 for adults, $10 for children under 12. Call (718) 652-7655 for reservations and directions.

 
PLEIN-AIR PAINTERS
 Just when most people figured plein-air painters had gone the way of the nickel subway ride, up pop five practicing, contemporary Hudson River School artists whose work may be seen at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson in Dutchess County.
The show opens with a reception and free artists' symposium on Thursday at 4:30 P.M. in the college's Procter Art Center, and the pictures will remain on view through March 8. Visiting hours are 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. seven days a week; admission is free.
George Van Hook, one of the exhibitors, has shown his work in galleries and museums across the United States and in France, and he believes that "the work of a plein-air artist is as valid today as it was in former centuries."
He argues that an increasingly alien and often hostile technological environment has had a disorienting effect on many artists, and a return to painting on-site in daylight has provided an escape from the confinement of studios and the numbing impact of high-tech art on the senses.
Other painters represented in the exhibition are James H. Cramer Jr., Robert Hacunda, Robert Schneider and Seth Nadel, all of whom, including Mr. Van Hook, live in the Hudson Valley region.
More information and directions may be obtained by calling the college at 758-6822.

 
CLASSES FOR DISABLED
 An introduction to a program that trains disabled people to qualify for jobs in desk-top publishing or desk-top video production, or to start a similar venture at home, is scheduled Thursday at 11 A.M. at the Choices Center, 125 North Main Street in Port Chester.
Arranged by Westchester Disabled on the Move of Yonkers, the session will include observation of a class in progress and a briefing on the 5-to-11-month courses. They are available to disabled people with average or above-average intelligence who are referred to the center by the State Education Department, which pays the tuition. Classes meet twice a week six hours a day, and 20 hours of homework a week is assigned.
"We assess the referrals in terms of aptitude," said Jean Campbell, the center's director, "not previously acquired computer skills." Classes are formed with an average of five students 18 or older. "Most of our students became disabled through illness or accident," Ms. Campbell said. "We have the adaptive devices to assist them and the latest hard and software on which to learn." There is no charge for Thursday's workshop. The number to call to register or obtain more information is 968-4717. ELEANOR CHARLES

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 13, 1994

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3452 words

HEADLINE: It's a Business. No, It's a Religion

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
THE Texas Medical Center here is the nation's largest health care complex by far, with more acreage than Central Park, more Federal money than the Johnson Space Center and more human traffic than Disneyland. But for two of the nation's foremost heart surgeons, the place isn't big enough for the both of them. In word and deed, these two rivals personify the struggle within the medical establishment over how to deal with outsiders clamoring to control health care costs.
On one side is Michael E. DeBakey, 85 years old and still practicing. Many operations that are now routine first took place under his knife, including the bypass procedure that has kept millions of failing hearts throbbing. 
 But now he is on the defensive, intent on preserving the traditions of American medical research, training and treatment. He says the pressure to contain medical costs endangers not only patients on the operating-room table today but also those who would someday benefit from the expensive research, like his, that has made American medicine arguably the best in the world.
He mocks the growing number of physicians who are accepting prices and practice standards dictated by Government bureaucrats or insurers. When someone from an insurance company -- "some clerk," he says -- called recently to urge him to discharge a 90-year-old stroke victim, he snapped: "You come here and tell the patient's relatives you want her transferred to your care. Otherwise, butt out."
Dr. DeBakey's complaint: "You've got people with no experience in medicine deciding whether a patient should be operated on or how long they should stay in the hospital. All of a sudden they're empowered. You should get some idea how things are going to be under the Clinton plan."
On the other side is Denton A. Cooley, 73, whose achievements include the first use of a man-made heart and leading more open-heart operations -- 60,000 -- than anyone else. He insists that American medicine must change, must become more economical.
Anticipating the triumph of cost-conscious care a decade ago, he swore he could make heart surgery better and cheaper at the same time. Since then, he has signed up 75 insurance plans, including those for Delta Air Lines, Tenneco and Shell, offering them cut-rate, fixed-price heart operations and treatment in return for the patronage of the people they insure. A businessman as well as a physician, he has been called the Sam Walton of heart surgery. He takes it as a compliment.
"Of the many firsts with which I have been involved at the Texas Heart Institute, including the first successful human heart transplant in the United States and the first total artificial heart transplant in the world, the achievement that may have the greatest impact on health care did not occur in the operating room or research laboratory," he wrote recently. "It happened on a piece of paper, 10 years ago, when we created the first-ever packaged pricing plan for cardiovascular surgical procedures."
Although their offices are separated by just a few corridors, Drs. Cooley and DeBakey argue only indirectly. They have refused to talk to each other for 25 years, ever since Dr. DeBakey accused his former protege of stealing his devices to implant the first artificial heart.
"I don't regard him as anyone I need to talk with," Dr. DeBakey said. Dr. Cooley draws no inspiration from his rival either. "He's indicated that health care is the cheapest commodity available," he said. "I have somewhat different opinions. I think it's been overpriced."
The battle between Dr. DeBakey and Dr. Cooley is emblematic of the disputes not just among the 10,000 physicians and Ph.D.'s at the medical center here, but also among the more than 600,000 doctors across the United States. Dr. DeBakey's conviction that doctors alone should decide on how to care for their patients and what it will cost retains great influence. But increasingly, Dr. Cooley's willingness to adapt to a changed marketplace, even take advantage of it, is winning the day. The two surgeons' experiences at Texas Medical Center attest to that.
 
The Battleground
A Medical Fortress Under Siege
 The Texas Medical Center was born more than 50 years ago with an act of Texas populism. The legislature, noting the state's high rates of cancer, decided to provide care and research. With matching donations from a wealthy cotton broker, Monroe D. Anderson, and friends, the center got its start in 1942 on a campus 15 minutes south of downtown Houston.
Today, Fannin Street, known locally as Bedpan Alley, courses through a center with almost 55,000 workers, more than any other Houston employer or any corporation in the state. No other medical complex in the country comes close; the National Institutes of Health, in Bethesda, Md., the second-largest medical center, has 16,490 employees. Texas Medical Center's more than 100,000 daily patients, employees and visitors outnumber Disneyland's daily count by tens of thousands.
The center's combined operating budgets exceed $4 billion a year, with a good deal more than $1 billion from Federal sources, more than goes to operate the Johnson Space Center, according to Texas Medical Center officials.
And it is still growing. The center's institutions have already developed 670 acres, with hundreds more acquired, giving the institutions more land than Central Park's 843 acres.
The center's 14 hospitals and 27 other clinics, schools and research centers serve a clientele as diverse as the surrounding city. At the upper end is Methodist Hospital, the nation's wealthiest with a cash reserve running well into the hundreds of millions of dollars; it is the nation's largest private tax-exempt hospital, with more than 1,500 beds. It offers a skylit palm court, with marble floors and Chippendale furniture, as well as the services of Dr. DeBakey.
Right next door is Dr. Cooley's hospital, St. Luke's Episcopal. It is more the middle-class hospital, with vinyl tile floors and a McDonald's in the basement. Hermann Hospital and a Veterans Administration hospital are also comprehensive, while Texas Children's Hospital and the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center pursue their specialties.
There are also two medical schools, Baylor and the University of Texas, as well as schools of nursing, dentistry and other professions.
Finally, there is Ben Taub, the county's public hospital, whose doctors are so familiar with urban violence that, using a video link, they were able to instruct their counterparts in battlefield treatment during the siege of the Russian Parliament.
The medical center provides whatever coordination, including roads, security and some group purchasing, that the center's many institutions will agree to. But each jealous institution has its own management and budget. And each has had its own way of answering demands for cost controls, from Methodist's refusal to grant discounts for any company or insurer, to St. Luke's eagerness to strike deals for treatment.
Until quite recently, Dr. DeBakey's ardent convictions held greater sway here. If hospitals and doctors nationwide have resisted abandoning their independent ways, Houston's have been especially stubborn.
But in an age when insurers want economy and simplicity, the Texas Medical Center is a superconducting supercollider. The treatment practiced at the medical center remains expensive and specialized at a time when health care buyers in business and government, indeed President Clinton himself, want to increase reliance on medical generalists, community hospitals and clinics that can often treat all but the most serious cases more cheaply.
DECADES ago, most of the medical center's hospitals tried to avoid duplication of services, saving the expense of empty beds or idle staff and machinery. But the center's major hospitals now each have specialists in every field. Not to mention lots of equipment, including 12 million-dollar magnetic resonance imaging machines that Roger Altman, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, recently cited in a speech as an example of waste.
Dr. M. David Low, a neurologist who is president of the University of Texas schools of medicine and related subjects here, said that closer cooperation among rivals can yield great savings. The institutions at Texas Medical Center have so far refused close cooperation, however. For example, they don't think Dr. Low's idea for all 14 hospitals to form a Texas Medical Center Healthcare Plan, then bid on contracts to offer their services as one huge group, could possibly work.
But what the hospitals haven't done themselves, the organizations paying the bills are beginning to do for them. Control of the medical center has been slipping from the long, dexterous fingers of surgeons like Mr. DeBakey into the stubbier hands of people like Ralph T. Smith Jr.
Mr. Smith, director of employee benefits at Mitchell Energy and Development, an oil and gas producer, has shaped an alliance of businesses, also including Compaq and Baker Hughes, that has brought the medical center's hospitals to heel.
The alliance's goal: steer patients to the hospitals with the best records for each treatment. The hospitals with the highest survival rates for, say, heart surgery, and the ability to meet the alliance's prices, would get the business; the others would not, and might see their departments wither away. "Every industry has gone through a shakeout," Mr. Smith said. "Now it is their turn."
Dr. Cooley's approach, which the business alliance applauds, is increasingly guiding the medical center. "His group was the first in the medical center to provide a one-price package of services," Dr. Low said.
In the past few months, every other hospital at the medical center has followed the Cooley example. Even Methodist Hospital, Dr. DeBakey's home, moved into the new era on Jan. 1, through a contract with Mr. Smith's Houston Health Care Purchasing Organization. Faced with the loss of patients from Houston's leading companies, Methodist joined other Texas Medical Center hospitals in negotiating a fee schedule and, reluctantly, allowing the purchasing group to study its treatment records.
The hospitals have changed in other ways too. Last September, Methodist began moving into basic, primary care with the purchase of the humble Diagnostic Center Hospital.
All the hospitals are also finding ways to treat more patients without admitting them. M.D. Anderson has moved into home and outpatient chemotherapy, for example.
With 20 to 30 percent of their beds empty (except at Ben Taub, the county hospital, with less than 10 percent), the hospitals have also been trimming their staffs. St. Luke's has, over the last year, begun ranking doctors on how thrifty they are with drugs, nursing, operating-room time, hospital stays, even bandages.
So much for the notion that real change in medicine awaits the Clinton health plan. "While we were preoccupied with Washington," Dr. Low said, "this managed-care train came and ran over us from behind."
Indeed, the center's managers feel they are under attack in a place where the fences that once protected them from people obsessed with cost have fallen. "Have you read Jurassic Park?" asked Richard E. Wainerdi, the center's president, likening his complex to the island where dinosaurs gained control over humans.
 
On the Defensive
Michael DeBakey: Guard the Faith
 The office suite where he is seated may be a shrine to Michael E. DeBakey, lined with plaques, trophies, honorary degrees and notes from the world's leaders, but it's a shrine to academic medicine as well. Dr. DeBakey remains so obsessed with his trade that he seems to change out of his scrubs only when a president or prime minister wants to hand him another medal.
Just last Sunday, he showed President Clinton the new artificial heart he is developing with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, borrowing the space agency's know-how in miniaturization and pumping. Then he flew to New York to display the heart on CBS.
At 85, he has permitted himself to cut back, but still sweeps into the operating room when friends or patients of long standing insist. One recent evening he did a quadruple bypass complicated by a valve replacement, relying on many of the techniques he had initiated.
The next morning, he was back. For a patient who had nearly lost the use of his legs, he restored circulation by running two new arteries from the aorta, near the heart, down through the groin, using the standard dacron grafts he also developed.
His most grateful and wealthy patients have given him Ferraris, Maseratis, Jaguars, Alfa Romeos. (Too impatient to keep fixing such finicky cars, he instead drives a Volkswagen. "It still has good acceleration, so I can get around people," he said.)
BUT these days, Dr. DeBakey says, many patients who want to see him cannot, forbidden by their health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s. He tells of a woman whose aorta had ballooned like an old innertube, a defect that kills 9 of 10 within six months. A doctor in her family told her to see Dr. DeBakey, who had first developed the repair work for the condition. On learning that her H.M.O. was balking at an operation, especially using a doctor outside its network, he asked, "Do you have a lawyer in the family?" She did. After the lawyer threatened to hold the H.M.O. responsible for her death, Dr. DeBakey operated, and she survived.
He was just as tough when an aide to Donna Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, called recently. He knows that the Clinton health plan would offer some subsidies for teaching and research, and that the Houston business alliance pays teaching hospitals like his an extra percentage point or two on top of fees it pays other hospitals. But it's not enough, he says. Teaching hospitals say their costs are 20 percent higher than other hospitals'.
For Dr. DeBakey, parsimony that leads to cuts in medical training and research is as bad as a botched operation. "My definition of stupidity is an inability to learn from experience," he said. "The English are saying they have a health care crisis. They are closing three of the most important teaching hospitals because they don't have the money." Now we're going the British way, into penny-wise medicine, he charges. "If that's not stupidity, I don't know what is."
Especially when corporate chiefs ask, he questions why they want to foist lower-cost care on their workers. When the top executives themselves need heart surgery, he said, "They come to the best."
Dr. DeBakey looks down at Dr. Cooley as a mass marketer of second-rate medicine. "You have to think in terms of quality," Dr. DeBakey said. "When we do an open-heart procedure, we have two technicians with that pump. They don't. I know that for a fact. We have two people in anesthesiology. We think that makes a difference." (Dr. Cooley, however, says he usually uses two technicians and two anesthesiologists.)
An academic medical center, Dr. DeBakey said, should have higher ambitions than Dr. Cooley's. "He is interested in doing large volumes of surgery at cheap prices. There are many community hospitals doing the same thing and just as cheaply."
Research, training and the best treatment cost more, he said. "Most of our cases are not routine. A lot of theirs are. Sure, you can cut costs. But you get what you pay for."
Dr. DeBakey, a lifelong Democrat who boasts of having made the Nixon enemies list and who recounts how he has welcomed the Government's past efforts to broaden access to medical care, would like to see more spending for health care but less for some doctors. Comfortable on a substantial income that, he says, has never approached $1 million, he gives 75 percent of his fees to Baylor, and insists others on the faculty contribute too. "In the academic world, you don't have time to use all that excess money," he said. "You're interested in providing the best teaching and care. Your leisure time is your work."
 
On the Offensive
Denton Cooley: Hear the Market
 Dr. Cooley's office is not so intimidating as his rival's. It's less like a shrine than a good-old-boy club for Denton Cooley alone. Medical journals and pictures of him with presidents abound, but there too is a disheveled bar, a stack of Playboys and a print commemorating his eagle on an especially tough hole. On the top shelf of the bar sits a plaque. "Poverty sucks," it says, above the double-R Rolls Royce emblem.
From a wealthy Houston family, Dr. Cooley remains much more a part of the city than his rival, whose voice hints of his Louisiana origins but whose only roots seem to be in the territory beyond Type A. He mixes easily with other Houston business leaders, among them his sometimes golfing partner, a certain George Bush. Like them, he is a conservative, favoring rambunctious free enterprise unconstrained by Government. His medical deal-making is no less than could be expected from any executive alert to his market.
He came home to Houston in 1951 to join the Baylor faculty and to work at Methodist with Dr. DeBakey, who had already expanded what doctors could do for heart disease. As Dr. Cooley's own fame grew, he chafed at Dr. DeBakey's rule and moved most of his practice to St. Luke's by 1960.
The complete rupture came in 1969 when Dr. DeBakey heard that Dr. Cooley had implanted the first artificial heart. Dr. DeBakey accused Dr. Cooley of stealing his artificial heart and his research, by secretly contracting with one of Dr. DeBakey's aides. Dr. Cooley says that, with a patient near death, it was urgent to try the new heart.
THE rivalry intensified. Just as Dr. DeBakey has his own research institute at the center, bearing his name, Dr. Cooley has one, the Texas Heart Institute at St. Luke's. He also continues to do research. For patients whose systems are too weak or damaged for heart bypasses, he is experimenting with a laser to drill tiny holes to supply the heart muscles with blood from inside the heart chamber.
By the early 1980's, Dr. Cooley and his surgeons were performing 5,000 open-heart operations a year, mostly bypasses, and his annual medical income passed $9 million. He bought prime Houston real estate. He donated three professorships to the University of Texas at Austin, his college, and $1 million for a gym at Johns Hopkins, his medical school.
Then came the oil, banking and real estate crashes. Dr. Cooley filed for bankruptcy in 1989, listing debts of almost $100 million.
His income has shrunk to about $1.5 million a year, he said. New methods of cleaning out the circulatory system, with medicines and Roto-Rooter-style instruments, have halved the number of open-heart operations under his direction. He also faces new competition from other hospitals, many staffed by doctors he or Dr. DeBakey trained.
The decline would have been much steeper but for his courting of corporations and health maintenance organizations with fixed fees. Now, he offers a bypass for $27,040, well below the national average of $43,370.
He says Dr. DeBakey charges more for treatment that is no better. "He's never cared too much about costs," Dr. Cooley said. The clear plastic tubes that draw blood out of the heart and into a machine during surgery? "A simple plastic tube can cost as much as $75," he said. "We use one that costs less than $10. It has the same qualities that they say makes theirs for $75 foolproof."
He reduces risks, and expense, by minimizing the time that patients are under his knife, ceaselessly modifying and simplifying. "I think people price themselves out of business," he said. "Abercrombie & Fitch has challenges from stores like Wal-Mart."
Watching Dr. Cooley operate, as doctors visiting from Egypt and Italy were one recent morning, is a lesson in economy. No wasted movement, no errant emotion, no extra tools.
The surgery was to replace both a heart valve and the root of the aorta just above in a woman from Michigan, stopping her heart for about 47 minutes, and all circulation for 9.
Let Dr. DeBakey and others gripe about H.M.O.'s and the Clinton plan. Dr. Cooley thinks he can adapt to cost controls, and make a good living at it. "Some of the hospitals that are more expensive than ours are going to suffer for it," he said. "They are going to find some way to contain costs or else they are not going to have patients."
On the one hand, the surgeon who realizes medicine is a business. On the other, one who treats it as a religion. Both have a lot to offer. The challenge for Texas Medical Center, as well as the country, is to combine the best of both of them.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Foreign Investment Roars Into Bombay

BYLINE: By Sanjoy Hazarika

DATELINE: BOMBAY

 BODY:
SINCE November, one of the world's hottest stock markets has been the Bombay Stock Exchange, thanks to an avalanche of foreign investment and the gradual opening of what was once one of the world's most insular economies.
After soaring early last week to 4,162 points on the Bombay Sensitivity Index, the market closed Friday at 3,991 points, a 24 percent rise, in dollar terms, since the first of the year and a rise of almost 50 percent since November. Bombay's is the third best performing market after Brazil and Finland this year. 
 The exchange's last bull run, which drove the index to a record 4,500 in August 1992, was a consequence of fraudulent purchases on credit, which inflated prices. After that boom, laws permitting mutual funds and other foreign institutional investors to invest here were eased in September 1992. But it was not until last summer that substantial funds started arriving.
Their arrival reflected the fact that foreign investors were moving out of markets elsewhere, especially Japan, as well as growing confidence that the stock market scandal of 1992 was over and that the political and social turmoil in India had subsided. Extensive Hindu-Muslim riots in 1992 and 1993 appeared to have abated and Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao had overcome a challenge to his leadership.
Under prior Government rules, overseas investors were barred from playing the Indian markets. Under current regulations, they can put money into Indian companies through foreign institutional investors registered with India's Securities and Exchange Board as overseas investment funds.
One such fund, and the first available to American investors on the New York Stock Exchange, is the closed-end India Growth Fund, which invests primarily in Indian corporate stocks. It closed Friday at $26.625 a share, off from its 52-week high of $30.75 early last month. (Individual foreign investors still cannot directly invest in the market here and foreign institutions can't hold more than 24 percent of stock in a listed company.)
Stock analysts say an estimated $1 billion has surged into the market from overseas buyers in the past few months. In addition, Indian companies have raised more than $1 billion from international markets, all of that through Euro-issues, most of which were heavily oversubscribed. More than 40 Indian corporations are scheduled to float new Euro-issues this year, which may fetch another $4 billion to $5 billion.
A. N. Kolhatkar, the executive director of the Bombay Stock Exchange, said he hoped for an influx of $3 billion into the Indian market through foreign portfolio investors. "The market is buoyant and it is a natural rise although we have too much money chasing too few premium scrips," Mr. Kolhatkar said, referring to individual stocks.
Foreign institutional investors are also tapping the Indian market by raising money here. One example is the Morgan Stanley Growth Fund, the first onshore fund organized by a major foreign investment house. Aiming to raise about $100 million, the company was overwhelmed last month by some 1.4 million Indian investors who put about $300 million into the fund.
From a bare 2.5 million investors in 1980, the Bombay market has galloped to 22.5 million, as more and more Indians turned to it instead of trusting in such traditional investments as gold.
"Foreign investors are coming into India because of the recessions in the United States, Europe and Japan," said Hemendra Kothari, a leading stockbroker whose company, DSP Consultants, helped manage the Morgan Stanley issue. "This is a growing economy, with sophisticated and historic traditions of trading and business, it has a vast consumer class and there is quick appreciation on investments."
Keen to seize the opportunities here, other big foreign investors have also entered the market. They include Alliance Capital, Barclays Zoette Wedd, Fidelity Investments and Lloyd George Management.
As a result of financial measures aimed at liberalizing the economy -- devaluing the rupee, reducing regulations and red tape, opening the doors to foreign investment -- India's Gross National Product is growing at about 4.5 percent a year and inflation has fallen to single-digit levels.
One important hurdle for the market, however, is the lack of adequate custodial services to handle the growing number of transactions. The slow speed of settlement, a paper-intensive market and infrastructural strains are obvious.
Under Securities and Exchange Board rules, only the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank and Citibank qualify to handle custodial services for foreign companies purchasing shares. They have been overwhelmed with the scale of the paperwork, which is largely a consequence of the lack of computerization.
Board officials, concerned about a possible slowing of foreign investment, say it may take several weeks to resolve the problem and that more Indian and foreign banks must share the load. There is talk too of a National Depository, which could pave the way for paperless trading.
Yet major stockbrokers and analysts are bullish about the Indian market over the next few months.
"The index is bound to rise because there is bound to be further liberalization and once the economy opens up, the process is irreversible," said Radheshyam Goenka, one of India's leading stockbrokers.

HEADLINE: At Work;
After the Divorce, the Deluge

SERIES: Second in a series of articles on women and pensions.

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
THERE are so many ways for a woman to end up living in poverty when she is elderly that it seems almost churlish to focus on one particular group as more victimized than any other. Women may, for example, work at jobs in companies unlikely to offer significant retirement coverage and for wages so low that saving is virtually impossible. Or, to increase their income, they may juggle two or three low-paying jobs. Together, the jobs may add up to years of more-than-full-time employment and yield a living wage -- but no benefits and certainly no pension.
Or they may enter and leave the labor force as family duties ebb and flow, interrupting the long march toward qualifying for retirement plans, or lowering the amount they will receive. Or their husbands may die, leaving them with considerably less than the expected amount of retirement income. "Our life patterns are different than the life patterns of men," said Lou Glasse, president of the Washington-based Older Women's League. 
 All women may be at the mercy of their life patterns, but women who divorce in midlife or later are shoved with sudden force into a vulnerable subset of the female experience. It is women who have done what was expected of them and led the most exemplary middle-class lives who may be the least prepared to face the reduced circumstances in which they will very likely find themselves in old age.
A study last year of the economic status of older divorced women by the Brandeis University Policy Center on Aging painted a Lucian Freud-ish picture of the so-called golden years. The study noted that only 5 percent of divorced women living on Social Security and a private pension were poor, but it also revealed that only about a quarter of older women (age 62 and over) receive a pension in addition to Social Security. The median annual income of older divorced women is about $9,000 (in 1990 dollars) and has been growing at a below-inflation rate of 1.5 percent.
Both the study and experts in pensions and divorce say changes in matrimonial law since 1970, when California became the first state to allow "no-fault" divorce -- based on irreconcilable differences instead of designating a guilty party -- have generally not worked to the benefit of women. Where the courts once used alimony and tangible assets to punish and reward, they now focus on distributing property fairly. They have expanded the definition of property to include intangibles like potential earning power and pensions, but in the process women have come to receive alimony less often and for shorter periods of time. The first major study of California's no-fault divorce law, published in 1985, found that men's standard of living went up 42 percent in the first year after divorce and women's went down 73 percent.
The last thing women may be thinking about as they contemplate the sinking trend line of their post-divorce income is a pension that won't come home to roost for several years. "Women, especially if they have children, may have other priorities. They have short-term problems," said Anna Rappaport, a senior actuary in the Chicago office of William M. Mercer Inc., the human resource consultants. "It's easy to say I'm going to solve a 2-year problem at the expense of a 10-year problem."
COMPOUNDING the difficulty is the well-documented reluctance of some women to throw themselves wholeheartedly into financial and retirement planning. "Women don't know enough about the issues," Ms. Rappaport said. "When they make a settlement, they let the husbands keep their pensions without realizing the economic impact."
Women are often not well-served by their lawyers, who themselves may be unfamiliar with the intricacies of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, the Federal law covering private pensions; the Retirement Equity Act of 1984, which broadened the rights of divorced spouses, or the particular pension system relevant to their client. And some lawyers, according to several pension advocates, simply don't think about pensions and benefits, which are not automatically put into play when the marital assets go on the table during a divorce. They may not anticipate changes, like remarriage or the death of the ex-husband, that could nullify the agreement and leave the woman with nothing. Such lapses are not uncommon despite the fact that a traditional defined-benefit pension accrued during a lifetime career at one employer will often be the couple's largest asset, after their home.
WHAT is to be done? First, learn about your family finances and catalogue your potential pension assets. Think long and hard before handling a divorce without a lawyer. When you do engage a lawyer, make sure he or she is knowledgeable about pensions, especially if you fall into a special category, like one of the Federal retirement systems. And if you feel you might be wrecking your karma by raising these topics when you are not contemplating a divorce, or if you can't cope with them when you are, ponder for a moment living alone in old age on the $500 monthly Social Security payment women typically receive.
 
 
 
WHERE TO START LOOKING FOR HELP
THE comprehensive "Your Pension Rights at Divorce: What Women Need to Know," by Anne Moss, is available for $16.50 from the Pension Rights Center, 918 16th Street N.W., Suite 704, Washington, D.C. 20006. The American Association of Retired Persons has published "Women, Pensions and Divorce," a survey of pension issues with a section on proposed reforms. The booklet is available from the American Association of Retired Persons at 601 E Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20049. Also available free from the A.A.R.P. is "A Women's Guide to Pension Rights."
To receive a free packet of information on pensions from the Older Women's League, send a self-addressed, stamped envelope to the league at 666 11th Street N.W. Suite 700, Washington, D.C. 20001. A women-and-pensions edition of the league's newsletter has several short articles and a list of resources. Call 800-825-3695 for the current price.

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
You Decide: Puredrug's Dilemma

 BODY:
To stimulate thinking about global business ethics, the Columbia University Graduate School of Business has prepared case studies. One study, by Joanne B. Ciulla, Karen Marquiss and Hans A. Wolf, is adapted below. If you ran Puredrug -- a fictitious company, with fictitious employees -- what would you do?
YOU are the chief executive of Puredrug, a large, global pharmaceutical company. Your firm has an outstanding reputation for quality as well as a long-term record of growth and profitability. 
 But by October 1993 the company is in trouble. Due to a general economic downturn and product development problems, the firm faces a declining market share and weak profits.
You call an emergency meeting of your top managers. Charles Dunn, head of the export division, reminds you that his department has an opportunity to sign an $8 million sales contract with the Philippine Government. The contract involves Travolene, a new injectable medicine developed by Puredrug for treating serious viral infections, including measles. The drug remains difficult and expensive to manufacture and has been in very short supply since its introduction. The 1993 budget did not include this Philippines sale because there was not enough product available.
Mr. Dunn mentions that Puredrug's inventory contains a large lot of Travolene, produced at a cost of about $2 million. The United States Government rejected the batch for the domestic market on the basis of a new, very sensitive test for endotoxin, a toxic substance. The authorities recently added the new test to the standard safety test, which had been used for many years. The new test revealed a very low level of endotoxin in the Travolene; the old procedure uncovered none.
You ask Ann Doe, the company's chief medical safety officer, whether this rules out shipping the batch to the Philippines. She explains that the Philippines and many other countries still rely exclusively on the old test. "It always takes them a while to adopt more sophisticated practices, and sometimes they never do," she said. "Endotoxin might cause high fever when injected into patients," she added, "but I can't tell you that the level in this batch is high enough to cause trouble. Still, how can we have a double standard, one for our nation and one for third world countries?"
Mr. Dunn disagrees. "It's not our job to overprotect other countries," he said. "The Philippines health authorities know what they are doing. Our officials always take an extreme position. Measles is a serious illness. Last year in the Philippines, half of the children who contracted measles died. It's not only good business but also good ethics to send them the only batch of Travolene we have available." The sale also would put Puredrug into the black for 1993 and help foster a lucrative relationship with the Philippines.
Uneasy, you leave the meeting. You have 72 hours to present a plan to your company board.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Strategies for Rising Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
IF the Federal Reserve thought it was being clear about the future of interest rates when it said on Feb. 4 that it was lifting the Federal funds rate by a quarter-point -- well, the markets bought the idea for a day.
On the Friday the rate rise was announced, stock prices dropped (wouldn't money be hightailing it to grab those higher yields?) and long-term Treasury funds lost a little over half a point (wouldn't they have to, to match the higher yields?). 
 But with the stock market bouncing back last week, the question became: Is the Fed's move really a long-awaited signal that the era of falling interest rates is over? If so, now what?
While the Fed's action was widely perceived as preventive, not a reaction to rising inflation, "If the economy continues to strengthen, this will be the first of many blows to come," said John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, in Chicago.
That's why many investment advisers say now is a good time for income investors to review their strategies.
Most advisers recommend that those in short-term bond funds stay put. "We haven't moved clients out of short- or short-intermediate funds, because we're still operating under the premise that rates won't be rising that quickly," said Steven B. Enright, an investment adviser in Rivervale, N.J.
That doesn't mean investors in short-term bond funds will escape unscathed should rates rise more. "You'll have some price pressure on net asset value, but total return should be positive because there's only so much that you can lose in short-term funds," Mr. Rekenthaler said.
As for long-term bonds, the case is less clear. Some economists say inflation is licked; others say inflation will pick up as the economy recovers. That leaves one thing sure: The uncertainty will produce volatility in the long-term bond markets.
Investors who plan to hold shares 10 years or more and can handle the risk can reap higher yields, Mr. Rekenthaler said. He likes the Vanguard Long-Term Corporate Bond Fund, which yielded an annualized 6.4 percent in January. But most investors would be better off in funds that have shorter maturities and would not be hit as hard by rising rates. Mr. Enright likes the Stein Roe Income Fund and Pimco Total Return.
Many advisers are turning away from United States bonds and looking for income elsewhere. "We don't see domestic investment-grade bonds as a good place to be in 1994," given their extraordinary returns over the last five years, said Craig Litman, an investment adviser in San Francisco.
Instead, he recommends junk bond funds. "We believe the economy will be stable and slow-growing, and inflation won't be a threat over the next year," he said. Even so, "a blip up in rates will have a greater impact on domestic investment-grade bonds." Mr. Litman expects junk bond funds to yield at least 8 percent. His two favorites: Pimco High-Yield Fund and Financial Bond Shares.
Because of their relative insensitivity to interest rates, junk bonds are also the choice of Eric M. Kobren, who edits Fidelity Insight, an independent newsletter for Fidelity funds. He recommends Fidelity Spartan High-Income for investors who can meet the $10,000 minimum investment.
Bob Markham, an Edina, Minn., investment adviser, calls junk bonds "the best bet for income investors." When the Fed announced its rate increase, "stocks, bonds and utilities got trashed, but junk bonds stayed steady," he said. "It's the same scenario I expect to be repeated throughout 1994." Mr. Markham likes Northeast Investors Trust and Federated High-Yield.
The year is also shaping up as a good one for Ginnie Mae funds, Mr. Rekenthaler said, if rates keep rising moderately. He likes the Benham GNMA Income Fund, which yielded an annualized 6 percent in January.
Real estate investment trust funds are another good source of income, Mr. Litman said, with yields of 6 to 8 percent and capital gains potential. "Even assuming no appreciation in the underlying properties," he said, "higher cash flow from rising rents will help earnings and prices." His favorites are the Cohen and Steers REIT Fund and the Fidelity REIT Fund.
On one point the advisers are nearly unanimous: Income investors should diversify their portfolios overseas, where rates have fallen, but remain above domestic rates. But it is important to find funds that can hedge currency risk, and managers who can do so effectively, Mr. Enright said. He recommends Scudder International Bond and T. Rowe Price International Bond.
Because international bonds behave differently from domestic bonds, they lower overall portfolio risk. Nonetheless, he advises capping the foreign fixed-income portion at 10 to 15 percent of the total portfolio.
Mr. Markham would go as high as 20 percent, because "We don't want the entire portfolio subject to what Mr. Greenspan says," he said, referring to Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. Because of the risks of overseas investing, he likes SoGen Overseas, an equity fund with large cash holdings and very cautious management.
Even income investors should own equities as a hedge against inflation. Utility funds may not be a good idea anymore, the advisers say, but try conservative, high-dividend stock funds. Mr. Markham recommends Lindner Dividend and Wellesley Income.
