HEADLINE: PAINKILLER;
The West Moves to Silence the Guns And Change a State of Mind

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TO hear the Pentagon tell it, the threat of NATO air strikes in Bosnia, voiced last week after so much diplomatic huffing and puffing, is neither a carrot nor a stick but an aspirin. It is designed neither "to affect the military outcome nor to propel the parties to settle," said Walter Slocombe, a top official at the Defense Department, but to "reduce the level of violence while the peace process continues." And reduce the level of violence, other senior officers noted, only in a limited area around the besieged city of Sarajevo.
Well, not exactly. The saber-rattling was also designed to break the psychological stalemate that has settled over what used to be Yugoslavia. It was meant to achieve a limited military end with limited military means, yes, but if that is all it does, it will have to be counted a failure. The real goal lies not on the scarred, wooded hillsides above Sarajevo but in the minds of the men and women whose passions keep this conflict alive. 
 NATO's new step is bold only by comparison with the timorousness of past reactions. So then is the decision really a historic departure, as Secretary General Manfred Worner asserted, or is it only an opportunity for President Clinton and the others to be seen, finally, to be taking a tough stance?
Without doubt, the allied warplanes and their pilots have the capacity to knock out some of the artillery pieces that ring Sarajevo; NATO planes enforcing the air-exclusion zone have had ample opportunity to plot targets. There are perils, of course. Allied pilots might be shot down and captured, even tortured, with all the domestic political turmoil that can cause. The Serbs could move some of the guns close to schools or hospitals or other civil installations, to make them harder to hit or to insure civilian casualties if they are hit. There might be retaliation against the United Nations forces stationed in Bosnia; the fear of that is one reason the bombing threat was so hotly debated and long delayed.
But the greatest danger perhaps is more mundane than any of those. Nothing in the decisions made by NATO in Brussels prevents Serbian offensives against other Bosnian towns like Tuzla and Srebrenica; in fact, NATO does not really propose to lift the siege of Sarajevo, just to take the big guns out of the military equation. The Serbs will still control the roads into the city, to say nothing of the power lines and the water mains.
Often in months past, the Serbs have shown that they know how to play the game. Challenged by outsiders, they play possum for a time, and when the attention of the West turns somewhere else, they take the offensive.
Whether the NATO initiative accomplishes anything will depend largely on the much less well-defined diplomatic track upon which the allies have also embarked. The United States has agreed to take a leading role in the efforts to negotiate a settlement, which inevitably means, if Mr. Clinton is serious about it, an effort to nudge, cajole, persuade and ultimately pressure both the Bosnian Government and its Serbian and Croatian rivals to agree on the terms of a partition of Bosnia.
Until now, the Administration has been reluctant to bring any pressure to bear on the Muslims, viewing them as the aggrieved party, entitled to regain lost territory. Even now, State Department officials piously deny any intent to do so; they proclaim their readiness to "work with the Muslims" toward a workable solution.
No one should take that seriously. The Serbs and the Croats will have to be pressured to give more -- not necessarily the 3 or 4 percent more of Bosnia and Herzegovina than the 20 percent originally set aside for the Muslims, although some net addition will surely be required. More important is the location of the territory allotted to the Muslims. It will have to be more compact, more militarily defensible, and it will surely have to include secure access to the sea.
 
Leaning on the Muslims
 Having offered the Serbs, in the initiative that it put on display in European capitals last week, the prospect of a step-by-step easing of economic sanctions in return for good behavior on the battlefield, the United States may have to contemplate the threat of even tougher sanctions to punish bad behavior.
But the Muslims will have to be leaned on as well, especially by the United States. At the moment, they have rejected partition outright, and they are fighting to regain all the lands where Muslims constituted a majority before the war. That represents a formula for continued strife and probably for eventual Muslim defeat, and if there is a peace settlement, they will have to be talked out of that goal, however righteous it may seem to be.
The Muslims have held out when they were alone and almost defenseless. They have little obvious reason to yield now, when they have gained a bit of breathing room, either through a Serbian artillery withdrawal or NATO air strikes that will at least keep the gunners' heads down. Unless the United States talks tough, very little will be achieved. Given the slightest ray of hope, says Sir Fitzroy Maclean, the old Scottish soldier who fought with the Yugoslav partisans during World War II, "these people will fight on forever." Certainly, a few localized air strikes will not deter them; even the Nazi legions never fully brought the Balkans to heel, and the resources they deployed in these parts were indescribably greater.
If the diplomacy fails, as it has before, the United States and its European friends may be drawn in more deeply than they would like. Already, from Lady Thatcher and hard-shell conservatives here, but also from the likes of Senator Richard Lugar, there are appeals for a wider air campaign. Attack bridges behind the battle zone, they say, as well as ammunition dumps and headquarters. Rearm the Bosnians by lifting the United Nations embargo. All that could have dire consequences -- extending the war to Croatia or Kosovo, or driving a wedge between the United States and Russia, whose Slavic soul is already stirring with resentment over the Western alignment against the Slavic Serbs.
If the Administration has planned its next steps, it has kept its plans quiet. But it has surely learned one lesson in the last eight days: inaction is not always the safest or even the wisest course, and the whole political context can be changed by something as unpredictable as a single shell falling in a crowded marketplace in Sarajevo. It happened once. It will likely happen again.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Behind a Dark Mirror: Traditional Victims Give Vent to Racism

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BLACK racism. For some blacks it is a laughable oxymoron. ("How can the victims of racism be racist?") For some whites it is an excuse for doing little to reduce the inequalities that still plague the country. ("See, blacks are just as bad as they say we are.")
The recent diatribe against Catholics, Jews and homosexuals (among others) by Khalid Abdul Muhammad, a member of the hierarchy of the Nation of Islam, has focused attention on the disturbing question of how much racism permeates black America. Indeed, the public fascination with the Nation of Islam -- a fringe group with negligible political and economic power -- is partly explained by white fear that its views are shared by other blacks. Looking at the cleaning women, the bank tellers, partners in their law firm, some whites silently ask, "Do you agree with Louis Farrakhan?" 
 Until recently, the question of how blacks view whites has been largely unexplored territory for scholars and sociologists. Why have sociologists not probed the black psyche to see how much racial animus resides there? Perhaps because they are afraid of what they might find; perhaps because they feel that since whites are the dominant group, their views are more important; perhaps because they feel that blacks have no opinions that whites are bound to respect.
But recent work by pollsters, sociologists and political scientists has uncovered evidence of specific negative attitudes that blacks may harbor toward whites in general and Jews in particular. Seeking responses to a series of assertions (Jews tend to stick together more than other Americans; Jews wield too much power on Wall Street; Jews are more willing than others to use shady practices to get what they want), a 1992 survey by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith found that blacks are more than twice as likely as non-Jewish whites to hold stereotypical views of Jews.
Preliminary findings in a study to be published soon by the National Conference of Christians and Jews found that blacks feel that whites think themselves superior, and that they do not want to share power and wealth with nonwhites. The poll found that black antipathy toward whites is far greater than that of other minorities, such as Latinos and Asian-Americans.
 
'Fill in the Blanks'
 "Of course, there's black racism," said Roger Wilkins, a professor of history at George Mason University, who is black. "I think that any time that you say that a whole group of people is this or that, fill in the blanks, and the blanks are all negative adjectives, and then you go on to prove your conclusions by telling stories that support your use of those adjectives, that's racism."
But, as another black writer, Ellis Cose, points out in his 1993 book, "The Rage of a Privileged Class" (HarperCollins), the harboring of negative views by blacks does not tell the whole story. Surveys of blacks also find that many give American whites, both Jew and gentile, high marks for intelligence and for creating a democratic society. Viewed in this light, the results of the surveys may be less an affirmation of racism than an expression of envy and a plea to share power.
Racism among blacks, whatever its extent, has been like magma bubbling under black nationalism. Like other nationalist movements -- Zionists, the Quebecois in Canada, Serbs seeking a "Greater Serbia" -- those embraced by some blacks have used ethnic solidarity as a political organizing tool.
For some mainstream black politicians, black anger toward whites presents both opportunity and temptation. Just as white politicians often take advantage, some discreetly and others more cynically, of racist attitudes among whites, so black politicians are aware of hostility among their constituents. And when they tap into it, they confront a question of conscience: When do they cross the line into demagoguery?
A call for unity is by implication a call for exclusivity. The desire to maintain that solidarity makes it difficult for many blacks to denounce black racism. But the censure of Mr. Muhammad by people like the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Benjamin Chavis, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and Representative Kweisi Mfume of Maryland, chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, shows that difficult does not mean impossible. Indeed, black officials have shown more willingness to move beyond solidarity than have members of the United States Senate who met with silence the remarks of Senator Ernest F. Hollings when he jokingly implied in December, while commenting on trade talks in Switzerland, that African heads of state are cannibals. A Hollings aide later said the Senator meant no offense.
There are those who argue that even if blacks espouse racist views, it makes little difference since they lack the power to turn those views into action. Such a rationale was articulated by Mr. Farrakhan at his recent press conference: "Really, racism has to be coupled with a sense of real power."
Mr. Farrakhan may have a point. For all the racial bombast by the Nation of Islam and other strident black nationalists, America has had no episodes of large-scale co-ordinated attacks by blacks against whites. But individual acts like the beating of the trucker Reginald O. Denny during the Los Angeles riots demonstrate that black bigotry can maim people and poison the atmosphere.
There is no denying that black bigotry is fed by social and economic conditions. Even discounting, as some whites do, the country's history of slavery, segregation and discrimination, there are trends that insure black resentment of whites will not diminish soon, and that black demagogues will find allies among the disaffected.
Black poverty rates remain stubbornly high. Progress toward closing the income gap between the races stalled in 1975, according to census data, and since then the gap has widened. (For instance, male black college graduates who entered the job market in 1971 earned on average 2 percent more than their white counterparts, but by 1989 the same blacks were earning 25 percent less on average than white men who graduated in 1971.)
Blacks remain the most segregated group, according to the census. Whether it is the result of whites making blacks feel unwelcome, or of declining faith in integration among some blacks, black Americans and white Americans remain huddled in their corners, afraid that any attempt to reach out will tar them with labels: bleeding heart, Uncle Tom. "We don't live next door to each other," said Lani Guinier, the law school professor whose nomination as Assistant Attorney General for civil rights was withdrawn in a controversy over her voting-rights theories. "No one talks to each other. Racial sterotypes fester in isolation."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Change is In the Air in Cuba, but the Paint is Still Peeling

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
THE air of expectation is still heavy wherever one goes in Cuba these days, but it no longer seems to be for the quick, catastrophic fall of the Government following the Soviet Union's collapse.
Rather, one senses a pungent mixture of depression and hope that attends a more gradual passage. As the photos on this page suggest, one world is withering in Cuba. Another of still uncertain shape is being born. The process continues even as the United States, for domestic political reasons, continues to shy from a relaxation of the decades-old trade embargo on Cuba, though it recently lifted the one on Vietnam. 
 The old Cuba still remains everywhere on display, barely creaking by -- in tattered, majestic Havana, in the high-rises without working elevators, in the ration lines snaking around whole city blocks. But more and more, the new Cuba is revealing itself as citizens pursue a quest for betterment made possible by American dollars, whose possession was legalized last year. This is the Cuba of tourist development, of sleek-suited Cuban and foreign businessmen who huddle in well-appointed hotels, and of city skies crowded by satellite dishes. The free-market stirrings coincide with a religious resurgence ushered in by Government liberalizations.
The old and new collide regularly. In the neighborhoods of central Havana, a mother showing her sparsely furnished walk-up is asked why her stove burners were left running with no food cooking. She explains with a smirk: "There's never any gas when I need it. I may as well burn it off when they turn it on." In the same streets on another day, a stranger is greeted by calls of "McDonald's, McDonald's" in a Cuban accent -- a hawker selling hamburgers to all comers with dollars.
If the Government has not yet admitted that the country is heading toward some form of capitalism, the people seem little inclined to await an announcement. State jobs that pay in non-convertible pesos are going unfilled as thousands flock to the informal activities that enable them to earn dollars. Suddenly, because of their access to foreign exchange, hotel waiters and taxi drivers earn more than bureaucrats. Others left to fend for themselves find that they can't, and go wanting.
With Cubans' rush to fit into an expanding private economy, there has come a new candor. "They still say 'Socialism or death' in all their speeches," a sugar-mill worker said of the Communist Party's cadres. "I suppose someone will always have to work for the Government, but if I can help it, it won't be my children."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Workers of the World Reflect -- Two sugar-refinery workers take a cigar break. Many Cubans are forsaking peso-paying Government jobs like theirs to earn dollars in the newly liberalized economy. Still Exercising Socialism -- A group of elderly women limber up in central Havana before medical checkups. Later, they serve food at a nearby hospital -- a reflection of the Government's longstanding exhortation for all to contribute to the common social good. Field of Dreams -- A youth catches a baseball in the ruins of a lot recently cleared to make way for a new tourist complex -- hotels, restaurants, etc. -- that is planned for the center of Havana. In the Shadows -- A homeless man sleeps on the steps of a Havana bank in the early-morning hours. With more Cubans fending for themselves and the social safety net fraying, some go without. Heading for the Light -- Worshipers in Rincon observe the Festival of St. Lazarus. As the Government has become more tolerant in recent years, religious worship has enjoyed a resurgence. (Photographs by ANGEL FRANCO The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Recovery: Manhandle With Care

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
THE good thing about economic recoveries is that they help people. There are more jobs. They pay better. There's more money around. Right?
Curious, then, that the popular economic wisdom holds that the best way to nurture the present recovery is to administer pain. 
 Recovery fans nodded sagely nine days ago when Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, announced that the Fed was pushing short-term interest rates higher. Enthusiasts hailed the move as a "pre-emptive strike" against inflation. Not that there are any signs of inflation.
Higher rates, however, will mean households and companies pay more interest on their loans, in the interest, of course, of prolonging the recovery that they are supposed to be energizing.
To insure discipline, some banks are already starting to raise the rates they charge consumer and corporate borrowers. They tend to do this very quickly, at the slightest hint that rates are inching upward, yet move more slowly when rates head the other way, pocketing the widening difference between what they pay on deposits and what they charge for loans.
Probably a good thing too: The Fed and the commercial banking system are supposed to be guardians of a nation's financial fitness. Start coddling the public and customers and before long you have a $6 trillion economy that resembles a spoiled child -- chubby and out of control.
 
Cruel to Be Kind
 Corporate America has embraced today's eat-your-peas ethos with a vengeance. As any beginning student of economics knows, productivity -- an efficient labor force churning out more and more goods and services -- fuels growth.
With that in mind, American management has taken this approach: fire workers by the thousands and then apply the lash even more firmly to the fortunate few who remain.
In top management circles, the practice is known by the term "re-engineering" -- one of several euphemisms peculiar to this paradoxical, gain-despite-pain recovery.
A Chicago-based employment consulting firm, Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., reported last week that major corporations announced 108,000 layoffs in January, the highest monthly level since it began tracking the figures in 1989.
GTE, Nynex, Scott Paper and Boeing were among the biggest job-cutters, and there is little sign that the pace is easing. Last Thursday, A.T.& T. said it plans to eliminate as many as 15,000 jobs, or 15 percent of the work force in its long-distance business, over the next two years.
"It's such a trend that it's become easier for companies to lay off workers now," says Rick Cobb, a vice president of Challenger, Gray. "There are so many companies doing this, you get lost in the crowd."
The workers who survive these cutbacks are not getting paid more, and fear has undoubtedly played its role in restraining wages. March into the boss's office to demand a raise these days and he may well decide to offer up your job as yet another sacrifice to American economic health.
Meantime, labor costs in the executive suite have not been held in check nearly as well as they have been on the factory floor. Executive salaries have outstripped the inflation rate for years. Every recovery has its anomalies.
The Clinton Administration, in tune with the Zeitgeist, is doing its part.
Its health plan, an ambitious effort to throttle rising medical costs, would add $74 billion to the Federal budget deficit between 1995 and 2000, the Congressional Budget Office estimated last week, taking issue with the Administration's projection of a deficit reduction in that period. Of course, the shortfalls foreseen by the budget office could be offset by "revenue enhancements," or taxes, as they were referred to in less enlightened times.
At worst, we're assured, the high initial cost of the Clinton health plan is just another near-term sacrifice well worth making in the interests of a stronger economy in the long run, as overall health-care spending eventually declines.
John Maynard Keynes, the British economist, had a pithy observation about where we'd all be in the long run: dead. But that's just quibbling, isn't it?

HEADLINE: U.S.O.C. to Let Harding Skate In the Olympics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 12

 BODY:
After a week of legal maneuvering and hours of intensive negotiations today, the United States Olympic Committee cleared Tonya Harding to skate in the Winter Olympics, which opened today in Lillehammer, Norway.
A settlement was reached in a state circuit court in Oregon City, about 20 miles south of here, when the Olympic committee agreed to cancel a hearing next week in which Miss Harding faced administrative charges for her conduct relating to last month's assault on her rival, Nancy Kerrigan. In exchange, Miss Harding agreed to drop a lawsuit filed earlier this week in which she charged the Olympic committee with interfering with her right to compete in the Olympics. She asked for more than $20 million in damages. 
 The settlement brought to an end a sometimes chaotic six-week period in which two overriding questions lingered: Did Miss Harding have anything to do with the assault and would she skate in the Olympics?
One question was answered, although the settlement did not address the possibility of further action against Miss Harding by the Olympic committee at some point. Under its bylaws, the committee could still inititate a disciplinary procedure against the skater if she were found guilty of, or plead guilty to, a crime. That could result in the loss of any medal she might win in Norway.
Nearly all the lawyers left the courthouse without comment today. But one of Miss Harding's lawyers, Dennis Rawlinson, who had notified her of the final details of the agreement, described her as "very, very pleased."
Later, as she climbed into her truck to drive away from her apartment in suburban Portland, Miss Harding said, "I finally get to prove to the world I can win a gold medal."
In Lillehammer, Olympic committee officials said they pursued the agreement with Miss Harding's lawyers to eliminate the distraction the case had become to officials and athletes at the Games. "For the moment the matter is stilled, and we turn all of our energies and resources to our Olympic team," the committee said in a statement.
Miss Harding is scheduled to leave for the Olympics within several days. At the Games, she is scheduled to join a practice group that includes Miss Kerrigan, under an International Skating Union ruling that requires all members of the same country to train together.
 
Skating Is Now the Main Event
 The settlement assures that the women's figure skating competition, which begins Feb. 23, has gained instant spectacle, with the promise of a showdown between two Americans whose lives have intrinsically been linked by an act of violence. Not long after the Jan. 6 attack at the national championships in Detroit, Miss Harding's former husband and three of his associates were charged in the crime.
For her proximity to those four men and her acknowledgement that she delayed telling authorities what she knew about the attack and when she knew it, Miss Harding was thrust into an uncompromising worldwide spotlight, not to mention a local criminal investigation in which any indictments would not have to be made until March 21, well after the Olympics.
But more critically for her Olympic aspirations, she had been summoned by the Olympic committee to explain her behavior in the case even though she has not been charged with any crime. The Olympic committee still felt it had the right to question her sportsmanship and adherence to the sport's code of ethics.

 
 
Discipline Still Possible
 By terms of the settlement, the committee has left any discipline against the 23-year-old skater to the United States Figure Skating Federation, which conducted its own investigation and found last week that grounds existed to call her conduct into question. The federation gave Miss Harding 30 days to prepare a defense and gave the Olympic committee the information it had gathered. The committee claimed jurisdictional rights because of Miss Harding's acknowledgement that she had learned about the involvement of her former husband and the others after she had qualified for the team.
As a result, the Olympic committee scheduled its own procedural review, which was to culminate with a hearing Tuesday in Oslo. At that point, Miss Harding objected, claiming that notice of eight days did not give her enough time to prepare an adequate defense and disrupted her training. To delay the hearing, her lawyers went to court, seeking a restraining order.
On Friday, the Olympic committee agreed to delay the hearing for three days, and Judge Patrick D. Gilroy urged both sides to work through the weekend to resolve their differences.
By early this morning, the lawyers had reconvened in the judge's chambers, where the details of the agreement were eventually set forth.
 
Unrelenting Attention
 The settlement brings to an end one phase of a remarkable saga, reflecting not only a crime against one skater but the hardships of another.
Throughout her ordeal, Miss Harding has made no secret of the stormy relationship she has had with her mother, LaVona Golden, and her former husband, Jeff Gillooly. Mr. Gillooly, a 26-year-old unemployed former warehouse worker, has pleaded guilty to a charge of racketeering for his involvement in the case. In a plea agreement, he received up to two years in jail.
Miss Harding's travails have also been noteworthy for the constancy and intensity of news media attention, with television crews and reporters ever present and living virtually next door to her. ABC News rented the vacant apartment in Clackamas County beside the apartment in which Miss Harding has been living with friends.
That kind of attention played at least an indirect role in the settlement. Miss Harding's fight took on uncommon celebrity, to the exclusion of most other Olympic athletes and developments. That rankled many senior Olympic committee officials, a growing number of whom were said to be willing to forego the hearing as a way of restoring some order to the Olympic routine.
 
Jurisdictional Conflict
 From his remarks during the arguments for the restraining order, Judge Gilroy sounded conflicted by issues in the case, leaving the impression that he would much prefer a settlement rather than having to rule in the case.
Among the major issue that led to his "deep concern" was that of jurisdiction. His questions of both sides during their presentations revealed the sometimes ambiguous relationship between the Olympic committee and individual sports federations -- particularly since the assault occurred before Miss Harding was on the Olympic team, and the conduct for which she could be disciplined -- not telling the authorities right away what she learned about it -- occurred after she made the team.

HEADLINE: JAPAN WARNS U.S. AGAINST IMPOSING TRADE SANCTIONS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa warned the United States today against imposing trade sanctions on Japan after their failed negotiations. His top aides said such action would cause Tokyo to retaliate with sanctions on American products.
"I very much hope the U.S. will refrain from such action," Mr. Hosokawa told reporters before leaving Washington, a day after the eight-month-long trade negotiations between the United States and Japan collapsed. 
 With American officials already vowing to impose some sort of punitive measure on Japan, now that Japan has refused to accept American demands for more open markets, the world's two biggest economies appeared to be poised on the edge of a trade war.
 
Posturing Is Seen
 Then too, there is undoubtedly a lot of posturing going on with the respective warnings, as both sides try to look tough for their domestic audiences, and it is possible that cooler heads will prevail as they approach the brink.
Mr. Hosokawa sounded a polite but firm warning at his morning news conference, which followed a breakfast at the White House with President Clinton. He said that under no conditions would his Government drop its resistance to "numerical targets" for opening Japanese markets, the issue that has been the main stumbling block in the negotiations.
The Americans insist that Japan agree to certain numerical indicators that will prove whether it is opening its markets in autos, telecommunications, insurance and medical equipment. The Japanese refuse to accept such indicators, saying that would constitute "managed trade," and that is why the talks collapsed.
 
'Will Not Modify Position'
 "We will not modify our position in that regard," Mr. Hosokawa bluntly told reporters.
Asked about reports that the United States was considering unilateral trade sanctions on Japan to pry open closed markets, Mr. Hosokawa not only said he hoped that the United States would refrain from such a move, but also pointed out that "that would be a contravention of GATT," the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
He left the clear indication, amplified by some of his aides, that Japan would respond to any attempt by the United States to slap tariffs on Japanese imports by taking the United States to a GATT tribunal, or by imposing its own unilateral sanctions.
Japan has threatened to take the United States to a GATT tribunal for some 20 years each time the United States threatened or took unilateral trade action. But Japan has never followed through out of fear of triggering a broader trade confrontation.
Under GATT rules, a country that believes its exports are being restricted in violation of the agreement's free-trade rules may request that a panel of three experts from countries not involved in the dispute be convened in Geneva. The panel reviews legal arguments by both sides, a process that may take many months, before issuing a ruling. The ruling in favor of the complaining country gives it moral authority to impose trade sanctions.
The United States, however, has not always complied with GATT panel rulings against it, and the Japanese threat does not instill real fear in American negotiators.
Mr. Hosokawa, who presented his visit to Washington as a success from the Japanese point of view, expressed his willingness to return to the bargaining table after "a cooling-off period," but made clear that any concessions on numerical indicators had to come from the American side.
 
Hosokawa Seems Confident
 The Prime Minister seemed quite relaxed and confident. Although American officials described him and his aides as "shocked" by Mr. Clinton's decision to put trade talks on indefinite hold, he and his team evinced the confidence of a younger brother who had finally stood up to an older brother and was now discovering that it really was not that hard after all.
American officials say there is no chance that they will compromise on the issue of numerical indicators. They contend that because the 31 previous trade agreements relied upon Japanese promises instead of quantitative and qualitative measures, the agreements have not made a dent in the Japanese trade surplus with the United States, which now stands at $60 billion.
"We just have to examine what our next step should be," Mr. Clinton said.
One step he is almost certain to take is to issue an executive order reinstating his authority to use the Super 301 trade law, which authorizes the President to identify countries, like Japan, that systematically discriminate against American goods. This designation then starts a clock for imposing sanctions if Japan does not respond by lowering trade barriers.
Another possibility is for the United States to drive up the value of the Japanese yen and therefore make Japanese exports more expensive and American imports to Japan cheaper. After failed summit meeting Friday, the yen closed in New York at 107.13 to the dollar, sharply stronger than the 108.25 yen late Thursday.
Driving up the yen is the preferred weapon of American auto manufacturers. Some 60 percent of Japan's $60 billion trade surplus with the United States is in Japanese auto sales in the United States, and there is a direct correlation between the rise in the yen and the drop in Japanese auto sales in the United States. But pushing the dollar down against the yen raises the cost of living in the United States by making a range of imports more expensive. It also encourages the Japanese to withdraw their funds from the American stock market and Treasury markets.

HEADLINE: CLINTON CONSIDERS TAXING AID TO POOR TO PAY FOR REFORM

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
The Administration is considering a plan to finance President Clinton's proposal to revamp the welfare system by taxing food stamps, welfare benefits and housing assistance and by cutting aid to legal immigrants who are elderly and indigent.
While no decisions have been made, those are among the options being considered by senior officials at the White House, Treasury Department and Department of Health and Human Services, confidential documents and interviews with officials show. The money from the cuts would be used to expand work and job training programs. 
 Critics liken the size of the cuts being considered to those pushed through by President Ronald Reagan. The options illustrate the Administration's difficulty as it simultaneously pursues ambitious welfare and health care proposals while seeking to reduce the deficit.
 
Double-Edged Risks
 One risk is that cuts will hurt the very people the welfare plan seeks to help, the poor and near-poor. That was the fear of the Administration official who disclosed the options, calling them "unconscionable."
A second risk is that the potential reductions, which are already being denounced on Capitol Hill, could alienate some Democrats whose help Mr. Clinton needs to pass his health bill.
Melissa Skolfield, an Administration spokeswoman, declined to discuss any specific options, calling the discussions "very preliminary." But she argued that the pain of any cuts would be more than offset by the benefits to the welfare program, which is intended to help poor women, who are its main recipients, find jobs.
"The plan is going to provide new investments in child care, education and training for poor women, who were simply written off by previous Administrations," she said.
 
Few Options Open
 The cuts being considered are in addition to the $30 billion in proposed reductions in the 1995 budget, which was released this week. One Administration official said the search for money had become "brutally hard" since "painful cuts have already been made."
The choices are being shaped both by law and politics. The 1990 budget law requires the Government to pay for any new spending increases with offsetting taxes or program reductions. And since welfare, mainly the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program, is considered an "entitlement program," the cuts have to come from similar programs whose benefits go automatically to everyone meeting the criteria.
The largest entitlement program is Social Security, but officials consider it too politically risky to try to make cuts there. The growth of the next two largest such programs, Medicare and Medicaid, is being restrained to finance changes in the health care system. That means that most remaining targets are entitlement programs for the poor, mainly welfare, food stamps and disability programs.
"Everything that's left is virtually a mortal wound," the official said.
 
Campaign Promise
 One of Bill Clinton's main promises in the 1992 Presidential campaign was to "end welfare as we know it," and he has vowed to send Congress a bill this spring. He has pledged to expand training programs for people on welfare but then require those still unemployed after two years to join a work program.
A record five million families are receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal welfare program. The number of people who would hit the two-year limit is a matter of sharp dispute, with the Administration's estimates ranging from 500,000 to more than 2.3 million.
The hunt for money is crucial. If the Administration fails to find enough revenue, it could be forced to scale back its plan. Administration officials have said that the welfare plan would cost about $7 billion a year when fully implemented.
The options under consideration have multiplied in recent weeks, as officials prepare to send Mr. Clinton a list by March. Officials are considering cuts in an emergency cash aid program used to prevent evictions and utility cutoffs and to provide shelter for the homeless.
The $300 million program is growing rapidly, and Federal officials suspect that states are using it to finance services they once provided themselves.
Administration officials are also considering a plan that would make it harder for drug addicts and alcoholics to receive disability payments through the Supplemental Security Income program by claiming their addiction as a disability.
 
Aiming at Obscure Program
 As another way of raising money, the Treasury Department is scouring a $16 billion annual tax credit program for low-income families, looking for signs of fraud or abuse. The issue is considered politically sensitive since the program is one of Mr. Clinton's favorites and the Administration gave it a large increase last year.
The search for viable options is difficult enough that officials at the Department of Health and Human Services proposed cutting $1.2 billion a year from an obscure provision of Social Security, which provides increased payments to retired fathers who have young children.
They were overruled by senior officials, including Donna E. Shalala, the department's Secretary, who feared that the move would antagonize the powerful lobby for retired people.
Ms. Skolfield, the Administration spokeswoman, emphasized that "no decisions have been made." But reports of the financing options are already drawing fire from Administration allies on Capitol Hill.
They argue that the cuts could increase the number of poor Americans, since the money gained would be used largely to pay for the administrative costs of the welfare plan, like the overhead in the work and training programs.
"You're taking money away from poor people to hire social workers," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who is a senior member of the Ways and Means Committee. "It's foolish for them to even consider these alternatives. It's just damn stupid."
"I've already heard some liberal members say they will not support health care reform," if the financing plan for welfare change is considered too severe, he said.
But the potential cuts got a warmer reception from Senator Hank Brown of Colorado, a co-sponsor of a Republican welfare plan. "I'm encouraged that they're looking for ways to pay for it," he said.
 
A Crucial Meeting
 The financing debate began in earnest at a late January meeting in the White House that included Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff; Leon E. Panetta, the budget director; Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury Secretary; Robert E. Rubin, the President's economic policy adviser, and Carol H. Rasco, the White House domestic policy adviser.
Officials from the Department of Health and Human Services, led by David T. Ellwood, an assistant secretary, presented the meeting with a list of six options, estimated to save $6.5 billion to $9.3 billion a year.
Mr. Panetta and Mr. Bentsen were dissatisfied with some choices, officials familiar with the meeting said, and each has asked his staff to suggest alternatives. Mr. Panetta, who displays an award in his office for promoting nutrition, was particularly skeptical of the plan to tax welfare and food stamp benefits.
Among the proposals presented by Mr. Ellwood that seem likely to remain on the final Administration list are the cuts in benefits to immigrants. But the proposal is likely to arouse bitter opposition from the House Hispanic caucus, which unsuccessfully fought an earlier round of reductions last year.
The debate focuses on the Supplemental Security Income program, which provides cash payments of $434 a month to elderly or disabled people who are indigent. It also provides them with Medicaid. Currently, most immigrants must wait five years before they can apply for the benefits. The Administration proposal would save $1.8 billion a year by barring immigrants from the program until they become citizens.
The issue only involves legal immigrants; illegal immigrants are already barred from applying.
 
Looking at Immigrants
 Some Congressional Republicans are seeking to finance their own welfare reform proposals with even more restrictive rules on payments to immigrants.
Those who favor the reductions argue that some immigrants are cheating the system by inviting their elderly parents to immigrate and then signing them up for aid rather than supporting them. But opponents, including Mr. Matsui, argue that it is unfair to single out immigrants for cuts.
The proposal to tax such payments, as well as welfare, food stamps and housing assistance may face a tougher fight, both inside the Administration and on Capitol Hill. The human services department's paper estimated the taxes, described as "recapture" provisions, could save the Government $1.5 billion to $4 billion a year.
Some officials argue that taxing the benefits would make the system fairer by treating all incomes alike. Consider two families, each making $15,000 a year and one receiving food stamps. The family with the food stamps clearly has more income, but its tax burden is the same.
Arguments against the taxes are also strong. They increase the economic burden of many low-income working families, who are precisely the people Mr. Clinton has tried to help by expanding tax credit programs and vowing "to make work pay."
The suggested cuts have caught some outside analysts by surprise, in part because they were proposed by Mr. Ellwood and Wendell E. Primus, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services.
Both men have reputations as zealous advocates for low-wage workers, and their proposal seems to underscore the severity of the budget constraints.
Mr. Ellwood is a former Harvard professor who coined the phrase "make work pay." Mr. Primus, a former aide on the Ways and Means Committee, spent more than a decade fighting off Republican plans to cut programs for the poor.
Both have said the Clinton plan intends to increase the incomes of the needy, but neither could be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: The Big Train Wreck

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
From the time Japan's first postwar Prime Minister took office, the job has come with a single mandate: whatever you do, keep the Americans happy.
So whenever a trade crisis erupted -- first over textiles, then autos, computer chips, beef and citrus, cellular phones, baseball bats and construction -- there was always a last-minute sucking-in of breath from Tokyo and a deal. Some worked, some failed, some markets opened and many had an odd way of remaining sealed, but open confrontation was avoided. 
 Now, Morihiro Hosokawa, arguably Japan's most innovative and interesting leader in decades, is trying a very different approach. On Friday, he became the first Japanese Prime Minister to say no to the Americans, and he said it at a summit meeting with the American President.
Mr. Hosokawa has once again taken a tremendous political gamble. He is betting that the applause he will receive for standing up to the Americans will drown out whatever condemnation comes his way -- particularly from the powerful Japanese business community and the ousted Liberal Democratic Party -- for putting at risk the one international relationship that keeps Japan afloat.
His defiance will likely appeal to a growing soft nationalism in Japan, a sense that nearly 50 years after the end of World War II the country can stand up and speak out a bit more directly. But if the relationship sours in the coming months, it could contribute to Mr. Hosokawa's political problems at home, and it could be used to speed the end of his coalition Government.
 
Seeking High Moral Ground
 Mr. Hosokawa has been careful to cast his action in moral terms, arguing that what the United States wanted him to do -- set numerical "targets" or "indicators" for the sales of American goods in the Japanese market -- was a gross interference in free markets. It was managed trade, he said, adding more regulation to an economy that he has sworn to deregulate.
Without question, the argument will play back home in Japan, where Mr. Clinton's mounting pressure is being characterized as the latest whining of a country that is making Japan a scapegoat for its competitive failings.
"It's a high-wire act," one of Mr. Hosokawa's aides acknowledged. "But we are convinced that his popularity will go even higher."
Mr. Hosokawa is certainly not acting like a man scared that his broader relations with Washington are imperiled. He seemed relaxed when he met with a small group of reporters traveling with him late Friday. And this morning at a news conference he said again that he did not think the breakdown of talks would "undermine Japan-U.S. bilateral relations as a whole." He talked of a "cooling-off period," and said he fully intended to go ahead with other market openings on his own -- not because they were good for America, but because they were good for Japanese.
 
First Summit Failure
 Behind Mr. Hosokawa's willingness to make this the first Japanese-American summit meeting that ever failed to reach a trade accord lies a generational change in Japanese politics -- a change whose full dimensions the Clinton Administration may not have fully understood when they welcomed Mr. Hosokawa seven months ago as the urbane reformer who would finally remake the country.
Because Mr. Hosokawa is of a new generation -- Mr. Clinton's generation -- White House officials have said for many months that the two men would work together as a team, battling a $50 billion trade surplus that will not let up.
What Japanese officials say the White House was not listening to were Mr. Hosokawa's repeated vows to bring those changes about from within, letting market forces work on their own instead of relying on outside pressure. He acknowledged in a speech at Georgetown University late Friday that such an approach can be enormously frustrating to Japan's trading partners because it happens so slowly.
"The problem is the pace of change in Japan," he said. But he said he told Mr. Clinton that "my administration is promoting deregulation," and that dictating targets "runs right in the face of our basic tenet."
 
A Long Way From MacArthur
 Even the Japanese were a bit surprised by Mr. Hosokawa's casualness during his news conference with President Clinton on Friday, which he followed -- so that he did not leave town with too many bad feelings -- with a largely social breakfast at the White House this morning.
"We could not have imagined something like this happening even a year ago," one of Japan's top trade negotiators said Friday night. Mr. Hosokawa's predecessor, Kiichi Miyazawa, who was forced from office in July, came of age as a politician in the days of the American occupation of Japan. That was when Gen. Douglas MacArthur ruled the Japanese economy, or what was left of it after the war, by fiat.
Among members of Mr. Miyazawa's generation, that sense of the relationship remains. But Mr. Hosokawa, in one of the striking moments of his exchange with President Clinton at the White House, said that disagreements are to be expected "in a relationship between grown-ups, as we two are." He continued that theme this morning. "In the past we settled for ambiguous agreements that created misunderstandings," he said. The United States, he added, often "took advantage of the process to get more concessions."
Mr. Hosokawa, as one Government official who has known him for some time said, "does not have an inferiority complex toward the U.S. or Europe, or a superiority complex about Asia; this is what makes him different."
 
Haunted by a Family Memory
 Yet Mr. Hosokawa is also haunted by one particular memory when he deals with America: the image of his grandfather, Fumimaro Konoe, one of the last civilian Prime Ministers before World War II.
As Prime Minister, Mr. Konoe temporized while military leaders manipulated him. He was frustrated in his efforts to communicate to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, and some believe that only worsened the tensions that led to the war.
Last year, writing in a leading intellectual magazine, Bungei Shunju, Mr. Hosokawa argued that the lesson of his grandfather's premiership was simple. "If you raise your voice," he said, "you must raise it clearly."
Mr. Hosokawa did just that. But one of the mysteries of what one senior Japanese official called "our first big train wreck" is whether Mr. Hosokawa was leading the bureaucrats who stiff-armed the Clinton Administration, or whether, like his grandfather, he was led by them.
 
Alliances With the Enemy
 Few of those around Mr. Hosokawa doubt that he is sincere when he says that his dispute with the Clinton Administration is a matter of principle.
Mr. Hosokawa often seems to agree with those in the Clinton Administration who say Japan will not change until it humbles the powerful bureaucracy that sets policy in Tokyo and commands the economy to a degree that is unmatched in the West.
The Prime Minister has said repeatedly that if the balance of power is to shift back to consumers in Japan, rather than producers, political leaders must regain control.
Weakened by battles within his eight-party coalition Government, it is doubtful that he has the power to do it. Mr. Hosokawa's own staff is considered ineffective and inexperienced. To pass critical legislation at home -- particularly a tax and economic stimulus plan -- he had to create alliances with the same bureaucrats he has vowed to fight.
 
A Secret Emissary
 His uncertainty about how to deal with the bureaucracy was evident even before he left Tokyo. While he was still immersed in political struggles at home, Mr. Hosokawa clearly had a premonition of the conflict awaiting him in Washington. So he reached out to an old friend of the family, Akitane Kiuchi, a former Japanese Ambassador to France and to Thailand. Mr. Kiuchi was sent as a secret emissary to Mr. Clinton to plead for time.
The Japanese trade negotiators, who were already at work in Washington, did not have an inkling of the visit, and they were outraged when they learned what had happened. But Mr. Kiuchi came only with a plea, not a plan. He had no authority, or experience, to negotiate in the Prime Minister's behalf. The mission failed.
Some Japanese saw it as a technique drawn from the feudal lords who populate Mr. Hosokawa's family tree. Messengers were often sent to the shogun, seeking alliances that would maintain the balance of power.
"Perhaps we should have expected it," one Japanese Foreign Ministry official said. "This is how his family survived for 450 years."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 30; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1352 words

HEADLINE: As Nations Trim Costs, Embassies Feel Pinch

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Before the global marketplace, before the recession, before the decline of greed and the rise of austerity, there was the diplomatic party. There were dozens of them. Every night.
Any enterprising youth with a decent suit or little black dress could ditch budget meals at home to graze on hors d'oeuvres at some embassy function here. 
 No longer.
 
From Receptions to Lunches
 As governments around the world tighten their belts, the squeeze has been felt in many of the 164 embassies here. Even those social functions that remain are increasingly an extension of work or a showcase for a country's cultural exports. The result: less lavish parties and tighter, more focused functions, including breakfasts and lunches.
"In the past, we would have big receptions," said Lionel Majeste-Larrouy, press counselor of the French Embassy. "Now we tend to have a working session lunch or a dinner around a good table. We still use the crystal and champagne, but it is more targeted."
Gone is the splendor of social functions like those given by Ardeshir Zahedi, the Iranian Ambassador in pre-Ayatollah days. Mr. Zahedi's parties featured bands, fresh orchids, 24-karat game prizes, caviar and champagne with guests like Henry A. Kissinger, Andy Warhol and Elizabeth Taylor schmoozing in the embassy's blue-tiled Persian Room.
Gone, too, the yearlong series of parties and receptions that built up to the visit of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, in 1982. That kind of opulent overkill is frowned on today.
"We can certainly say that things are not as lavish or extravagant as they were during the Marcos days," said Jose Ebro, a press officer at the Philippine Embassy. "Our social entertaining is focused on business and investment initiatives."
Didi Cutler, who worked for the New York City Commission for the United Nations and the United Nations Consular Corps, said, "Today it's a question of what is appropriate."
 
Some Big Events Remain
 Appropriate does not necessarily mean fewer guests. In 1993, the British Ambassador entertained 11,500 people at various functions, from small breakfasts to huge receptions.
Still, ambassadorial functions are much more likely to be about drumming up business for the home countries than about celebrating the arrival of a political figure or an eligible movie star. Few diplomats can complain these days, as did Bernard Vernier-Palliez, the French Ambassador to the United States in early 1980's, that he had to attend "futile parties."
Today, tradesmanship is as much in demand as statesmanship.
"Your country's priorities inform your entertaining, and India's priorities are economic growth and investment," said Nirupama Rao, minister for press and information at the Embassy of India.
Because the United States is India's largest foreign investor, Ms. Rao said it was natural that one of the latest social events given by Ambassador Siddhartha Shankar Ray was a 40-person dinner for officials from a group of American companies like General Electric, International Business Machines, American Telephone and Telegraph, General Motors and others interested in doing business in India.
 
Seeing the Nation
 The expansion of the global market also means that many ambassadors no longer restrict their entertainment to Washington.
Ambassador Jukka Valtasaari of Finland recalled that on his first diplomatic visit here in 1977, only 50 Finnish companies had businesses in the United States, most of them in New York. Today, 350 Finnish companies are doing business in the United States.
"That dictates changes in your operational and entertaining methods," said Mr. Valtasaari, who travels outside Washington 50 days of the year.
But Mr. Valtasaari said the size of the United States and its many centers of influence outside the capital did not diminish the need to entertain here.
"You need to work for your access," he said. "Unlike some other countries where you deal more with institutions, Washington is a person-to-person city."
 
More, but More Focused
 Still, the emphasis is a narrower palate.
"We're doing more but in smaller and more focused groups," said Ruth Yaron, press counselor of the Israeli Embassy. "It's easier to meet people, to talk and have a benefit out of a dinner party."
There has also been a shift from reliance on the dinner as the only meal for diplomatic entertainment.
Ambassador Paulo Tarso Flecha de Lima of Brazil, who recently played host to the Princess of Wales during a in low-key visit said that diplomatic entertainment in Washington tended toward "stag functions at luncheons, whereas in London there was more entertaining around dinner."
Certain diplomatic social functions, however, remain de rigueur, like national day or independence day celebrations when the entire diplomatic corps is traditionally invited.
"We are talking about thousands of people," said Ms. Yaron of Israel's independence day celebrations in May, "and building a tent outside in the yard for the overflow."
Nabil Osman, minister and counselor of press information at the Egyptian Embassy, said leaner, more focused entertaining was "a worldwide phenomenon."
 
'Taxpayers Expect Results'
 Terry Colli, director of public affairs at the Canadian Embassy, said: "All over the industrial world, governments have deficits and taxpayers expect to see results for the dollars spent. Doing a diplomatic dinner just to entertain another diplomat, or anyone else for that matter, when there is no immediate issue of business is rare.
"We are out here to achieve an objective," Mr. Colli said. "We have to think: What are we achieving for Canada when we do this function?"
Increasingly, embassies also use social functions to promote their culture and art.
Especially active are the French, Mexican and Japanese Embassies.
The Embassy of Japan, for example, recently offered two evenings devoted to lectures exploring the relations between black Americans and Japanese.
"We think that it is extremely important to contribute to the community in Washington, because mutual understanding between the two countries begins with people-to-people communication, not Washington-to-Tokyo diplomatic negotiations," said Kenji Nakano, a press officer at the embassy. Last year, the embassy gave 24 such events.
 
The Top Entertainers
 Japan and Britain, perhaps because of their imperial and monarchial backgrounds, still maintain some of the most elegant social functions. They also entertain in big numbers.
"Such entertaining still continues because it's an important aspect of doing the job," said Peter Bean, press secretary at the British Embassy. One of the embassy's largest functions, Mr. Bean said, was a reception last fall for 300 people, followed by a dinner for 100 for Nelson Mandela, the South African leader of the African National Congress.
"In some instances, entertainment will be small," Mr. Bean said, "for example, the breakfast meeting with Prime Minister John Major, there were only six guests."
When those limousine- and long-dress occasions do occur, they are most likely to be because an embassy has made its building available for a charitable event.
Mr. Colli of the Canadian Embassy said, "We receive well over 300 requests a year to use the embassy for charitable events and that is over and above Canadian requests."
Sometimes, especially among the new embassies created in the wake of the demise of the Soviet Union, there is truncated entertainment -- even on national days.
"We simply cannot afford the big bash," said Jonas Paslauskas, an official at the Lithuania Embassy. "Usually we have one big reception on our national day, Feb. 16, and we try to invite mainly European countries and countries with which we have diplomatic relations instead of the entire diplomatic corps."
And for some embassies, there is no entertainment at all.
"We consider it important," said Lublin Dilja, Ambassador of Albania. "But because Albania is in a period of transition and there are economic problems, we haven't had any parties."

HEADLINE: Japan Sees Hosokawa Leveling Ties With U.S.

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's refusal to accede to American trade demands on Friday is being seen here as the beginning of a new relationship with the United States, one in which Japan has an equal voice and cannot be bullied into making concessions just for the sake of preserving peace with its main ally.
"The United States must learn that it can't simply make very unreasonable demands by using external pressure," said Kuniko Inoguchi, a professor of political science at Sophia University in Tokyo. "Such a traditional style of negotiating won't work anymore. This reflects a change in political culture." 
 But if Mr. Hosokawa's stand is being greeted favorably and even with a little self-satisfaction here, there is also a sense of dread about the chill in trade relations that may lie ahead and a sense of uncertainty about what Japan should do now.
 
'We Couldn't Do Otherwise'
 "We are not too happy about the result, but we couldn't do otherwise," said Kazuo Nukazawa, a managing director of Keidanren, the most powerful business lobbying group in Japan.
Trade negotiations under the framework signed by the two nations in July broke down on Friday without reaching agreements to open Japan's markets for automobiles and auto parts, insurance, and telecommunications and medical equipment.
The stumbling block was Washington's demand for "objective criteria" to measure progress, which Japan insisted were numerical targets that would contravene free trade.
It is always unclear how much any single agreement can do to reduce the trade gap. While some of the imbalance is the result of informal barriers in the Japanese market, much of it also has to do with getting Japanese consumers to spend instead of save and getting American companies to invest more heavily in everything from distributorships to factories in Japan.
American negotiators seemed convinced that Japan would concede at the last minute, as it has in past negotiations. This time, it did not happen.
"We maintained our principle," said one mid-level official at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, who stayed in his office Friday night and watched the live broadcast of the news conference by President Clinton and Prime Minister Hosokawa at 4:30 A.M. But he became more sober when he thought of the consequences of standing on principle. "Another storm will come, and it will be severe," he said.
Indeed, Washington is already thinking of reviving a trade law that allows it to declare countries unfair traders and apply sanctions. But the first blows to Japan are likely to come from a rise of the yen, which will squeeze Japan's export-oriented automobile and electronics companies. The vise already began to tighten on Friday, with the dollar falling to about 107 yen in New York trading, down more than one yen from the day before.
Some politicians and business leaders have long argued that Japan should be more assertive in its relationship with the United States. That point of view found its voice in "The Japan That Can Say No," a book written a few years ago by Shintaro Ishihara, a politician, and Akio Morita, the chairman of the Sony Corporation.
Mr. Hosokawa appears to be better positioned than his predecessors to move the two nations toward what he called "a relationship between grown-ups," because he is part of a younger generation of politicians who feel less beholden to the United States for its help in resurrecting Japan's economy after World War II.
Another factor is that with the ending of the cold war, the United States and Japan feel less compelled to sweep their economic differences under the rug to present a united front on security issues.
 
Political Fallout Minimal
 Maintaining smooth relations with Japan's senior ally and biggest trading partner has been one of the most important jobs of the Prime Minister. But political analysts here say that unlike what would have happened in the past, Mr. Hosokawa will not suffer much, either in political power or popularity, from the breakdown of talks in Washington.
Mr. Hosokawa presides over a fragile coalition that has almost torn itself apart over electoral and tax reform. In both of those cases, the Prime Minister suffered damaging setbacks, only to save himself with watered-down compromises.
But on the issue of numerical targets for the purchase of American goods, there has been relative unanimity among politicians. Even Yohei Kono, the president of the opposition Liberal Democratic Party, while chiding the governing coalition for failure to reach an agreement with the United States, said today that he agreed with the Prime Minister's position against numerical targets.
Businesses, while wanting to keep good relations with the United States, are in less of a mood for bargaining now because of the severe recession here. Auto makers, for instance, are having enough trouble keeping their traditional suppliers afloat without worrying about buying more American components.
Nor has the public shown much interest. Many people here seem concerned not with bilateral relations, but with nine inches of snow, the worst snowstorm in 25 years, which paralyzed Tokyo today. Of course, those interested in trade found it somewhat symbolic of a new chill in relations that both Tokyo and Washington should be hit with rare snowstorms just as their leaders were meeting.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Kazakh Chief Each Filling a Need

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE WASHINGTON, Feb. 12, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
Kazakhstan's President, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, is to arrive here on Sunday for an official visit during which the Clinton Administration plans to shower him with increased aid as it tries to make him a model for other leaders of the former Soviet Union.
In return, President Nazarbayev will give President Clinton what he wants most from the Kazakh leader: the signed document in which Kazakhstan formally joins the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and a pledge to become a nonnuclear state. 
 For Washington, that is a crucial step toward cementing relations with a leader whose nation, the largest in area in the former Soviet Union after Russia, used to have 104 long-range SS-18 missiles, each with 10 warheads.
The Administration is showing its appreciation to Mr. Nazarbayev by announcing plans to more than triple aid to Kazakhstan, from $91 million this year to $311 million next year. Some of it will be used to dismantle warheads. The Administration will sign more than half a dozen cooperation agreements with the Kazakh leader on economic, military and space matters.
Mr. Nazarbayev, the former steelworker turned Communist Party leader turned capitalist head of a new country, will receive the attention he desires: a meeting and lunch with President Clinton on Monday, capped by a dinner with Vice President Al Gore as host at the State Department.
When Secretary of State Warren Christopher visited Kazakhstan in October, he pressed Mr. Nazarbayev to provide the papers for the nonproliferation treaty then and there. But the Kazakh leader, with a sense of theater and political moment, signaled that he would do it only at a White House ceremony with Mr. Clinton. Two years ago in Lisbon, Kazakhstan tentatively agreed to sign the treaty.
Administration officials want to use Mr. Nazarbayev's visit partly to show that they are paying more attention to the former Soviet republics other than Russia. As part of this strategy, the Administration is doubling its economic aid to Ukraine to more than $300 million and plans to promote that country's transition to capitalism.
One official said Mr. Nazarbayev was being rewarded not only because Kazakhstan is joining the treaty, but also because "his country has done more on economic reform than all of the other newly independent states.
"It's in a region where we want to see more reform," the official said, "and we want to show we are good to countries that want to reform."
Kazakhstan has moved rapidly to privatize large and small businesses and has opened itself to more Western investment than any other newly independent state. With one of the biggest oil fields outside the Persian Gulf, Kazakhstan has signed an agreement with the Chevron Corporation in which the San Francisco-based company plans to put up four-fifths of the $20 billion to develop the field.
Kazakhstan, the ninth largest country, borders Russia, China, the Caspian Sea and three other former Soviet republics: Kyrgyzstan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. It is abundant in gold, silver, chrome, zinc and iron ore and is an exporter of wheat and coal.
Attracted by those resources and by Kazakhstan's embrace of economic reform, executives from more than 50 companies, including A.T.& T., Amoco, Du Pont and Procter & Gamble, will meet on Monday with Mr. Nazarbayev at a conference organized by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which helps American companies pursue foreign business opportunities. Mr. Nazarbayev is eager for a flood of Western investment that brings jobs, technology and better living standards to his nation of 17 million.
Among the agreements Mr. Nazarbayev is expected to sign is a memorandum of understanding with the Pentagon to establish regular contacts between senior military officials. There are three agreements with the investment corporation, including one to support a gold processing plant to be operated by the Minproc Corporation of Englewood, Colo. There will also be an agreement under which a Russian rocket will use the Baykonur space center in Kazakhstan to launch an American communications satellite.

HEADLINE: Easy as Pie? Not in New Mexico Town

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PIE TOWN, N.M.

 BODY:
In New Mexico as in other places, naming towns is a quirky business. Some names honor people, like the Duke of Albuquerque. Others are linked to Catholicism, including Santa Fe and Las Cruces. And one, Truth or Consequences, pays homage to a quiz show. But only this one owes its name to a dessert.
Conjuring up aromatic images of home and truck stop, Pie Town, a mile west of the Continental Divide, has always drawn people. In New Mexico's territorial days, some say, weary cowboys came here for sweet sustenance. Spotting it on a map in 1940, Russell Lee, a Farm Security Administration photographer, drove from Amarillo, Tex., and captured the indomitability and interdependence of its people, primarily homesteaders from Texas fleeing the Dust Bowl and the Depression. 
 Curious tourists still forgo the more streamlined Interstate 40 for Route 60 to check out Pie Town. And every September, a thousand or more people come here for the Pie Festival, complete with pie-eating and pie-baking contests.
The "Welcome to Pie Town" sign at the city limits depicts a Boston cream pie and two others of uncertain lineage. But the sad truth is that a recent visitor could not buy a single slice of pie in Pie Town. Finding people was almost as hard. The piquant smell of burning pinon wood, a ubiquitous sign of life in New Mexico winters, is faint here. The pie-shaped telescope on the edge of town, run by the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, probably picks up more activity in galaxies light years away.
 
A Crucial Crossroads
 The Pie Town to which Mr. Lee brought his Speed Graphic was poor but populated, and vital. It was a place without telephones or running water, but with all-night dances, community sing-alongs and a "literary society," a place in which women in aprons fixed each other's hair, and men in overalls built each other's dugout homes. There was even a main drag, with newly minted signs for Dr. Pepper and Beech-Nut chewing tobacco hammered into its storefronts.
Pie Town, about 100 miles southwest of Albuquerque, still has some communal trappings, including a volunteer fire department, two churches and a Town Council. But almost from the day Mr. Lee left, it has been dying. First came World War II, which lured many to munitions plants elsewhere. Then came drought, which left the land too dry to produce pinto beans. Mr. Lee placed the 1940 population at 250 families; Rand McNally found 85 people last year.
Even its alluring name cannot protect Pie Town from the kind of creeping oblivion that is facing hamlets everywhere. Its hardiest commercial creatures were gas stations. Now there are only carcasses -- a Shell, a Mobil, a Phillips 66, condemned by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency for leaky storage tanks. The nearest working gas stations are 22 miles away, in either Datil or Quemado. That's also where Pie Town's 13 children learn their three R's now that all the area's one-room schools are gone.
The Pie Town Post Office is open only four hours day. Just about the only other going concern is H. & R. Block. "You can't get anything in this town, but they still expect you to pay your taxes," said Crystal Leyba, 29, who drives the local school bus.
 
Economic Extremes
 Many of the rough-hewn structures of logs and mud that housed the homesteaders have been abandoned. So has the former beanery, where farmers brought whatever they had extracted from the begrudging ground.
"You have to do some pretty hard work to make a living in this country," said Roy McKee, 83, a Texan who came to Pie Town in 1937, and whose brother can be seen dancing a jig in one of Mr. Lee's most famous photographs.
Pie Towners tend to fall on the extremes of the economic spectrum. Many are on welfare. Others are wealthy ranchers, including a few original families who strung together their 640-acre sections into valuable pieces of property.
"The ones that stayed are wealthy now if they would admit it," said James Hogg, an 89-year-old former teacher and rancher who arrived in 1931. "You never ask a cowman how many cattle he has, because he won't tell you. He'll tell his banker if he needs to borrow money, and he's supposed to tell the tax people. Supposed to."
 
What's in a Name?
 Down the road from the old general store, whose Coca-Cola signs are too faded to make worth stealing, is what was once Harmon Craig's store. From its ovens came Pie Town's first pies -- or so some say. For just as the spelling of Pie Town is debatable -- some road signs say Pie Town, others Pietown -- so, too, is the etymology.
In one story, a family carrying a wagonload of dried fruit and flour to California lost a mule here. Rather than push westward, they stayed. And rather than let the fruit rot, the wife made pies. Another story has a drunken cowboy looking at the dessert selections on an early menu and declaring, "This must be Pie Town!"
In her history of the area, Mr. McKee's daughter, Kathryn McKee-Roberts of Bosque Farms, N.M., determined that Pie Town's first pie man was Clyde L. Norman, who sold dried apple pies at his gas station in the 1920's. Shortly after, he placed a Pie Town sign on his roof. He soon sold out to Mr. Craig, who put the town on the postal map.
"The postal inspector came to appraise the situation and said a more suitable name must be found, as 'Pie Town' was ridiculous and 'beneath the dignity of the department,' but Mr. Craig said either that or nothing!" Ms. McKee-Roberts wrote.
 
Passing the Rolling Pin
 For a time, Mr. Craig's wife and daughters made the pies. From the Craigs the rolling pin was passed to a Mrs. White, then to Edd Jones and Jody Carver and Lester and Emily Jackson. But the Jacksons divorced, and until a retired couple, Arthur and Cleo Candalaria, arrived a few years ago from Grants, 70 miles north, Pie Town was pieless.
Truth be told, the Candalarias, who live behind their store, have been importing pies from Albuquerque, 15 or 20 of them a week. They are closed for the winter, however, and, ready for another challenge, have their store on the block. Like Pie Town, its prospects are uncertain.
"The world has changed so much," said Mr. Candalaria, breaking into tears. "It's all damned cities -- dog-eat-dog, drugs, murder and rape. People can no longer live on the land, be neighborly. It's all gone."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Russell Lee, a Farm Security Administration photographer, left Pie Town in 1940 after capturing the interdependence of its people in pictures that brought notoriety to the New Mexico town. But since then, it has been dying, as evidenced by an abandoned gas station photographed late last year. (David Margolick/The New York Times); Pie Town in 1940 was poor but populated and vital.
