HEADLINE: Is Albany's Bureaucracy Half Full or Half Empty?

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo kept his pledge, made as the recession darkened three years ago, to cut 1 in 10 state jobs. Now he says the pain is over. This year, he is calling for almost no layoffs, as his re-election campaign nears and the economy tiptoes into a recovery.
But even after the elimination of 20,000 positions, the questions remain. Is the state work force, connected in the minds of voters to the taxes they pay, at optimal size? Or should Mr. Cuomo seek deeper cuts from the Legislature? The questions are likely to stalk him as he runs for a fourth term as head of a state administration still slightly bigger than when he took office in 1983. 
 "To have a year when the Governor says, 'It's over, it's done and I have no suggestions to make to reap productivity savings,' that's disappointing," said Cynthia Green of the Citizens' Budget Commission, a watchdog agency. "We're not out of the woods. We're not at a point where these things are not important."
Even Mr. Cuomo's harshest critics give him credit for the cuts over the last three years, which resulted in 7,000 layoffs, 4,000 early retirements and vast numbers of jobs vacated but never filled. He says he is not finished: this year's budget calls for another 170 layoffs, 2,100 jobs lost through attrition, various cuts for efficiency and the empanelment of a bipartisan commission to reorganize and reduce government.
But as New York City and New Jersey prepare to lay off public workers, it is clear the big cuts in the state are over for now, in a work force of 238,131 in 1992, the latest year for which complete data are available. Though many experts say services have not declined significantly, Andrew J. Zambelli, Mr. Cuomo's chief of staff, said the pause was necessary to review the effect of the cuts on the work force and delivery of services.
"Literally two months ago we finished this reduction," Mr. Zambelli said. "We're reviewing what it all means, absorbing it, understanding it."
But some business groups and governmental experts, as well as at least two potential Republican challengers, have marshaled numbers and anecdotes to suggest that the Governor has not gone nearly far enough, either in direct cuts or other efforts to streamline government.
For example, the combination of state and local workers per 10,000 population in New York ranks fourth in the country and is the highest among the 11 most populous states, according to Federal census data from 1991, the last year available.
When looking at state employees alone, the only ones over whom Mr. Cuomo has direct control, New York State ranks only 36th in workers per capita. But some argue that the state delegates much authority to local governments, for instance education and social services, and thus bears responsibility for keeping all costs in check. They argue that the overall work force, of which the state remains a major part, determines the tax burden and to varying degrees a corporate climate in New York that business groups say is costly and inhospitable.
 
Problems on Local Level
 "A big part of the problem is on the local level," said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute in Albany, a research organization financed by the state.
But Mr. Gold added: "Governor Cuomo has emphasized that we are in a very competitive time. New York has to continue to slim down its work force. Because if it doesn't, the state is going to continue to have stratospheric taxes and that is going to strangle the economy."
In 1983, the year Mr. Cuomo took office, the work force was reduced from 234,201, to 229,176, but it then rose to a high of 255,817 in 1989. These figures include the state university system, the judiciary and the Legislature, areas over which the Governor's office contends it has less than full control.
 
More Prisons
 Claudia Hutton, a spokeswoman for the State Division of the Budget, argues that the increase was necessary: the state has opened 27 prisons since 1982, doubling inmate population, and by 1989 had 28,500 corrections workers, up from 16,000. The number of state police officers, judges and parole officers increased, and the state opened a teaching hospital in Stony Brook and two veterans' hospitals. There were other financial burdens, like an explosion of Medicaid costs.
But by late 1990, the recession was choking off tax revenues and the Governor faced a $6.5 billion budget gap. So Mr. Cuomo pledged a 10 percent cut in workers financed by the general fund, the part of the budget derived from taxes and fees. According to state budget numbers, this was cut 12.7 percent between November 1990 and November 1993, from 185,718 to 162,117. The percentage cut in the same period has been just under 10 percent for all state jobs controlled by the executive branch, including those paid by fees and by Federal money.
"That didn't mean we had too many people to start with," Ms. Hutton said. "It means we recognized what we had to do. In the end we did what we had to in order to keep the budget balanced."
 
Services Broadened
 Nearly every other state in the nation also broadened its services through the 1980's, mostly in corrections and education. With the exception of New York and a few other large states, most states and localities continued to expand their payrolls throughout the recession, according to a recent study by the Rockefeller Institute.
In New York, there is a consensus, even among some unions, that the cuts, while deep and painful for many individuals, did not devastate the overall quality of state services, which have been traditionally much broader in New York than in other states. A large majority of the cuts, more than 12,000 positions, came from the Offices of Mental Health and the Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities, in a budget-driven acceleration of deinstitutionalization in favor of small, private, community programs.
 
Room for More Cuts?
 Some critics say the apparent ease with which the state slimmed down by 10 percent is proof more could go.
"A bloated government has lost some of the excess fat but still is completely out of shape," said State Senator George E. Pataki, Republican of Peekskill, who is seeking the Republican nomination for Governor. Herbert London, who is also seeking the nomination, has made similar criticisms.
Senator Pataki and groups like Change New York, the conservative political action group, advocate more layoffs as well as changes such as abolishing the state energy office, issuing health vouchers for poor people and reducing staffing at prisons.
But Ms. Hutton of the budget office said hacking into the work force is not so simple and not always desirable.
"Politically the popular thing to say is we have too many employees," Ms. Hutton said. "Then you take that general statement and say where are we going to cut? But if you cut the Department of Motor Vehicles and it results in longer lines, they say, 'Why did you do that?' I think employees are often used as battering rams in the political process and that's not fair to them."
In arguing against further cuts, Ross D. Hanna, the director of contract services with the Civil Service Employees Association, and other union leaders say the work force has been reduced enough. He said the effects of the layoffs since 1991 were real but felt more within the ranks. For example, the Department of State, which inspects buildings, lost all 13 of its inspectors but still had to do the job with other workers.
"The individual taxpayer might not notice these things," he said. "If you have less people working in a social services office or office of the state, things take longer to get done. And it is a significant problem. We have people who are truly overburdened."
Union leaders argue, though not stridently, that the state should selectively rehire some state workers as the economy improves. But they and other experts seem more concerned with intelligent planning for future changes or layoffs.
 
More With Less
 Among other experts, Frank J. Thompson, dean of the School of Public Affairs at the State University at Albany, said Mr. Cuomo had not done enough to streamline government, combine overlapping functions and reform the Civil Service system. The Governor's office has some successes of doing more with less, like the revamping of the Department of Motor Vehicles, which has tried to reduce frustration by relying more on the telephone and mail, and has various initiatives to do more. But many experts say the state has lagged and results have been minimal.
"If you look at what the State of New York systems require, it is probably not overstaffed," Mr. Thompson said. "It probably needs more people to make these systems work."
"The real question is -- and it's very hard to do in New York -- a lot of the functions of the state need to be streamlined," he said. "Then we could focus more on the front-line services positions that you and I care about as taxpayers."

HEADLINE: U.S. and East European Weapons Dealers Clash

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GLIWICE, Poland

 BODY:
Three years ago, the tank factory here, reeling from the loss of its reliable Warsaw Pact customers, was greatly relieved when Syria signed a contract for 300 tanks. Then disaster struck. Washington did not like the idea, and Poland responded by canceling the tank deal.
"It's a miracle we survived," Marek Jurkiewicz, spokesman for the Bumar Labedy factory, said recently. 
 And the survival has been tenuous at that: more than half the plant's workers have been laid off. The future would be a little brighter in this polluted industrial pocket of southern Poland if the company could wrap up two other sales -- to Iran and Pakistan.
But Washington's objections have hindered these deals and are preventing another Polish factory from shipping Kalashnikov rifles to Myanmar, and another from selling helicopter parts.
 
Someone Always 'Telling Us'
 "Before, the Soviet Union was telling us what to do," Mr. Jurkiewicz said. "Now the United States is telling us what not to do. It amounts to the same thing."
Eastern European leaders say they want to stay on Washington's good side, particularly as they try to enter NATO. But these countries, facing the transition to capitalism and rising unemployment, are desperate for business, and many of their best customers are on Washington's list of undesirables.
The Eastern Europeans are also frustrated that Washington has not come up with millions of dollars to convert the arms plants to peaceful uses, an idea much discussed at the end of the cold war. In the meantime, the United States remains the world's largest arms factory.
"They are preaching that we drink water while they drink wine," said Vladimir Dlouhy, the Czech Minister of Industry and Trade, who was angry after Washington's intervention scuttled the sale of Czech-made radar and of civilian nuclear power plant engines to Iran. "I consider it hypocritical."
 
Concern About Ethnic War
 Washington's fear is that Eastern European arms will fuel ethnic conflicts and strengthen repressive governments. Shoppers in the Eastern European arms bazaars come largely from the third world, attracted by lower prices and by a willingness to sell to them where the West is often reluctant.
Eastern European arms makers generally abide by United Nations embargoes, but the embargoes now cover only Iraq, Libya and Yugoslavia. They waver when the list expands to countries suffering from civil strife and those Washington accuses of state-sponsored terrorism, like Syria and Iran, or of human rights abuses.
Washington's objections to the Polish tank sale to Iran are raised "in almost every meeting," said Jerzy Pomianowski, a senior official in the Polish Foreign Ministry. Poland argues that since Iran already has 3,000 tanks, selling it 100 more, as the Bumar Labedy plant wants to do, will not contribute to regional instability.
A poor human rights record is the reason the United States cites for opposing the sale of helicopter spare parts by a Polish company to Myanmar, formerly Burma. This rankles Poles, who note that there are American-made Bell helicopters there. These were sold as civilian helicopters, but American officials say they were quickly adapted for military use.
Another Polish company would like to sell Kalashnikov rifles to Myanmar.
 
Burma Is 'Promising'
 "I have been in Burma," said Raymond Szwonder, an executive at Luzcnik Metal Works in Radom, 60 miles south of Warsaw. "It looks very promising to us as a market."
Mr. Szwonder was arrested in Germany two years ago on charges by the United States that he was part of a conspiracy to sell arms to Iraq. He was never extradited, and four other defendants were acquitted. Today he is a member of the Polish Senate and chairman of its defense committee.
"The Bulgarians don't give a damn about any lists" Mr. Szwonder said in an interview. "The Czechs aren't saints either."
The Czech Republic personifies the turnabout on arms sales.
In the 1980's, Czechoslovakia was the seventh-largest arms exporter in the world, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute.
 
Czech Business Growing
 After the fall of Communism, the Government of Vaclav Havel banned or restricted arms sales to more than 50 countries at one point. Today, the conservative Government of Vaclav Klaus has no such list, and the business is growing.
Miroslav Duda, president of Ceska Zbrojovka, which manufactures pistols, submachine guns and rifles, said the company could have converted to tractor hydraulics and airplane gearboxes, but his studies showed that the arms business was more profitable. So today only weapons come off the computerized assembly lines at the sprawling factory in Uhersky Brod, 120 miles east of Prague. Production has increased 15 to 20 percent each year since 1990, Mr. Duda said.
 
Policing Is Difficult
 Czech officials said the Government respects United Nations military sanctions and prohibits arms sales to countries where there is civil strife. Last year the Government blocked shipments of arms to Bolivia and Panama when it suspected that the weapons were destined for other places, probably the former Yugoslavia. But the Government cannot police all sales.
Recently, a Czech company, Tesla Pardubice, wanted to sell Iran an advanced radar system, called the Tamara, and Mr. Dlouhy, the Minister of Trade, saw no reason why it should not, arguing that it is a "non-aggressive defense system."
But after Washington complained, the Czech Government stopped the sale. Other Middle Eastern countries are now negotiating to buy the system, according to Czech officials; Chile has also expressed an interest.
Iran also came close to buying components for a nuclear power station from another Czech company, Skoda Plzen, in a deal that Mr. Dlouhy endorsed because it was a civilian project. Again, however, Washington objected, and the Czech Foreign Ministry vetoed the sale.
But Skoda, which was one of the largest arms manufacturers in Europe during the cold war, is not discouraged. Recently, it formed a consortium -- the RDP Group -- with other arms makers.
 
Modernizing the T-72 Tank
 One of the consortium's first projects will be modernizing the T-72 battle tank, once the mainstay of the Soviet Army. There are tens of thousands of T-72's in the former Soviet Union, in the Middle East and throughout the third world.
As Skoda gets back into the tank business, it will be competing against companies that were once part of the national family, but which are now on their own across the border in newly independent Slovakia.
During the cold war, the tanks, armored personnel carriers, and artillery that rolled off the assembly lines from ZTS factories formed the spine of the Slovakian economy. Now the Slovakian arms manufacturers are putting together their own consortium, said Rudolf Cyprian, a spokesman for ZTS.
The principal customers will be in the Middle East, Asia and Africa, said Lubomir Gazak, a senior official in the Slovak Ministry of Economy. He said the Government had a list of countries to which arms sales were forbidden. He would not identify them, but he said Syria and Pakistan were not on the list.
 
Bulgaria Sells to Syria
 Another country that has no qualms about dealing with Syria, is Bulgaria. In the last two years, Bulgarian companies have sold Kalashnikovs and other weapons to Syria, according to Mladen Mutafchiiski, president of Teraton, a state-owned company that arranged the sales.
Last fall, when the Georgian Government went shopping for arms for its civil war, it bought at least 1,000 Kalashnikovs from Bulgaria, he said.
Algeria, Albania and Yemen have also received Bulgarian weapons in the last year, arms traders say. But officials will not discuss the matter.
Though no Eastern European government is as secretive as Bulgaria, neither does any country have such strict public disclosure laws as the United States. As the arms business in former Warsaw Pact countries takes on new life, it will become more difficult to determine who the new customers are.

HEADLINE: U.N. Speeds Arms-Monitoring Effort in Iraq

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 12, Special to The New York Times 

 BODY:
The United Nations is speeding up its monitoring of Iraq's military industries in an effort to determine whether Baghdad has complied with Security Council disarmament terms, a move that would bolster the position of Iraqi officials who have cooperated with the inspection effort.
The supporters of cooperation -- chief among them is Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz -- appear to be facing political difficulties in Baghdad, officials here say. 
 Once the Security Council agrees that Iraq is complying with the disarmament order, it has the power to lift the embargo on Iraqi oil sales imposed under Resolution 687, which ordered the elimination of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction after the defeat of its armed forces in the Gulf war.
In a statement issued on Friday, Rolf Ekeus, head of the special commission overseeing Iraq's disarmament, and Mr. Aziz said they planned to "expedite" the inspections to insure that Iraq is not producing banned weapons. The statement said the Security Council would be informed of the results "at the earliest feasible time."
The joint statement was negotiated in Baghdad on Feb. 5 after Mr. Aziz asked Mr. Ekeus to fly there on short notice to provide political support from the United Nations in his efforts to persuade his Government to continue cooperating with the Security Council's disarmament plan, officials here said.
The statement said that the talks in Baghdad consolidated "the breakthrough" achieved last summer. They were referring to Iraq's decision to cooperate with the disarmament order after being convinced by the Special Commission that compliance will give the country access to billions of dollars in oil revenues again.
Recently, however, the Clinton Administration has hinted that it may impose additional conditions for easing the embargo, including Iraq's recognition of Kuwait's frontiers and an end toattacks on dissident Kurds and Shiites.
Mr. Ekeus has warned that setting up a long-term monitoring system to prevent production of nuclear, chemical or biological arms is taking longer than expected and that it may not be ready until near the end of this year.
The United States has said it will want to test the monitoring system for at least six months before it even considers lifting the oil embargo.
Iraq had hoped the Council would agree to ease sanctions in January. It did not, prompting bitter complaints in Iraq's Government-controlled press and leading to an even higher inflation rate, which is a result of the trade embargo. Last summer the dollar was worth about 50 Iraqi dinars on Baghdad's free market. The dinar has now fallen to around 270 to the dollar.
Writing on Jan. 20, just after the sanctions review, in Babil, a daily paper owned by President Saddam Hussein's son Udai, Nuri Najm al-Marsumi, first Under Secretary in the Ministry of Culture and Information, said "beware of the patient man's rage."
He warned that "Iraqis will not remain silent at the continuation of the blockade" and seemed to threaten a new confrontation with the United Nations, saying, "We are capable of bringing the game back to the beginning ."
Opponents of the policy of cooperating with the United Nations argue that it is not worth pursuing because the United States will not agree to the lifting of sanctions as long as Mr. Hussein remains in power.

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans Deep Cuts in Malaria Vaccine Program

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is planning deep cuts in a program to develop a malaria vaccine just as tests of a promising experimental vaccine get under way in Africa, Government officials say.
The Administration is seeking to trim the budget for health programs at the Agency for International Development because of demands for more money to bolster the Commonwealth of Independent States and the peace efforts in the Middle East, Joseph J. Byrne, a spokesman for the agency, said on Friday. 
 Vaccine researchers in the United States and at the United Nations Development Program said they were alarmed at the prospect of cuts in funds for malaria research.
Officials of A.I.D. said "substantial cuts" would be made in funds the agency provides for tropical disease research and other health programs, with some programs losing as much as 40 percent of the money they got in 1993.
 
$2.5 Million for Research
 The agency has sent about $2.5 million annually to the Tropical Disease Research Global Program of the World Health Organization.
"We are not going to zero this program," Mr. Byrne said of research on a malaria vaccine. "But it will probably be cut substantially."
He said the agency was trying to preserve programs that serve people in need, and so research programs may take larger cuts than programs such as those for rehydration therapy to prevent diarrheal disease, the leading killer of children in Africa.
"Malaria is only the No. 3 killer," Mr. Byrne said. "So we don't want to move money from things like rehydration therapy. We are also trying to cut programs that have disproportionately high administrative expenses."
The malaria vaccine being tested in Africa was created in Colombia by Dr. Manuel Patarroyo and his colleagues. In tests in Colombia it was found to reduce the number of malaria attacks in children by more than 70 percent, and in adults by 20 percent.
Though the vaccine is only partly protective, it is the first to prevent parasitic disease at even this level, said Dr. D. A. Henderson, Assistant Secretary of Health at the Department of Health and Human Services.
The experiments in Africa began last year. Next Friday in the medical journal Vaccine, scientists will report that in the first injections in Africa, no serious side effects were seen and those injected showed strong stimulation of their immune defenses.
The next step, already begun, is to immunize 600 children in Tanzania to see how much malarial attacks can be reduced. Results are expected next year.
Dr. Henderson, a leading expert in public health, said in a telephone interview that cuts in research programs in tropical health could be catastrophic. "Some people are oriented to stick with programs out in the field, thinking they can drop the research and pick it up later," he said. "It's not true. Once you kill the research it is dead, because it takes five to ten years to build a research program back up once you dismantle it."
Dr. Tore Godal, director of the tropical disease research program, said in an interview that the United States had contributed greatly to the development of the malaria vaccine, and that other countries looked to the United States for substantial contributions.
He said other countries may be inclined to cut their support if they see the United States doing so. The program's budget is about $30 million. He said about $5 million of that money is spent on research in labs in the United States.
If the United States reduces its contributions, Dr. Godal said other donors will press him to cut the amount of money spent in the United States. "We may have to cut the support we give to American researchers," he said, "which would be very unfortunate, because they are very efficient and competitive."
Mr. Byrne said substantial cuts would be made in many programs in the A.I.D. health budget, which last year was $114 million.

HEADLINE: WINTER OLYMPICS;
Kerrigan Glides Through Compulsory Interview

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LILLEHAMMER, Norway, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Six police officers, dressed in severe black uniforms and with even more severe faces, provided escort for Nancy Kerrigan's interview with the world's sporting media today. Fittingly, it was high noon. The long-anticipated figure-skating shootout between Kerrigan and Tonya Harding is less than two weeks away.
Photographers formed a human gridlock in the auditorium, standing shoulder to shoulder on a railing, elbowing for position, awaiting Kerrigan's arrival amid a media throng that numbered in the hundreds. Mike Moran, spokesman for the United States Olympic Committee, admonished reporters to ask their questions with a microphone. "Don't injure yourselves," he said, in case this interview turned into a journalistic roller derby. 
 He needn't have bothered. This was less a news conference than a taping of "Oprah," with the media serving as a live studio audience. Olympic and skating officials say that Kerrigan has healed, physically and mentally, from the clubbing attack on her right knee, but they insist on treating her like an emotional cripple.
 
Stronger Now
 Attempting to shelter her from a storm of tough questions, Moran and Kristin Matta of the United States Figure Skating Association, sat on the podium and chatted with Kerrigan, eliciting such insightful responses from her as, "My family has been there since I was born."
Finally, when the floor was opened for questions, Kerrigan handled herself quite well, thank you. In sheltering and protecting Kerrigan, Olympic and skating officials have missed one critical point. The attack, however chilling, appears to have made her stronger and more confident. Where she was vulnerable five weeks ago, crying "Why, why, why?," Kerrigan is self-assured now. There is no need to protect her. She can protect herself.
When one foreign journalist suggested today that the judges would feel sorry for her and give her artificially high scores, Kerrigan replied, "I don't think it's true. I don't think people have a reason to feel sorry for me. I'm capable of performing everything I've worked for all year, for 18 years."
Since she couldn't drive to a convenience store in Massachusetts without news-at-11 shadows trailing her, Kerrigan said, she stayed inside and watched the Harding saga unfold on television. To her, it seems like the mysteries she loves to read.
"It's kind of like reading a book," Kerrigan said. "You can't wait to get to the end to see what happens."
 
Thrown Together
 The end finally came today, when the U.S.O.C. announced it would allow Harding to compete without first appearing at a disciplinary hearing scheduled for this week in Oslo.
Now that Harding will compete, she and Kerrigan will apparently practice at the same time, in the same rink. They will live in the same building, on different floors, but they are bound to bump into each other. In the dressing room. In the cafeteria. Somewhere. Harding, who has maintained her innocence in planning the attack despite a guilty plea by her former husband implicating her, has said that she would like to hug Kerrigan if given the chance.
"I don't know how I'm going to feel when I see her," Kerrigan said. "I don't know what's going to happen. It is personal, between the two of us, not you guys."
 
Other Stories, Too
 Again, she bemoaned her lack of privacy, though, in truth, Kerrigan has sought the spotlight as much as she has run from it. And she appeared slightly disingenuous when she said she hadn't considered the economic windfall from her attack; her agent, after all, has entertained more than 35 offers for a television movie. Still, she said all the right things about diverting attention from other Olympians.
"There are a lot of great athletes and stories and I don't want to take anything away from the other athletes," Kerrigan said. "I hope the other athletes get the recognition they deserve. They worked hard to get here."
Kerrigan has worked as hard as anyone. After a disastrous performance at the 1993 world championships in Prague, she has mended her cracked porcelain confidence.
"She was afraid to do a perfect program in practice," Evy Scotvold, her coach, said. "She was afraid she couldn't do it. She didn't want to find out that she couldn't. I had never seen her do a perfect program until October. There has been a great maturing in her life this year."
And if she wins a gold medal, there will be another news conference. This one would be bigger than Katarina Witt's loopy, beer-induced, coronation gigglefest at Calgary in 1988. Bigger than the Dream Team's Meet the Press gathering in 1992. Bigger than anything the Olympics has ever seen.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Olympic and skating officials say that Nancy Kerrigan has healed, physically and mentally. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: WINTER OLYMPICS;
Class Against Dash In Battle of Styles

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAMAR, Norway, Feb. 12

 BODY:
When pairs figure skating begins on Sunday, and Russian gold medalists from the previous two Olympics take the ice, nine judges will have a decision to make. Not a decision about talent, but about style.
What do they prefer: the husband-and-wife artistry and harmony of Yekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov, the 1988 champions? Or the muscular invention and flexible contortions of Natalya Mishkutienok and Artur Dmitriev, the 1992 champions? 
 "I think we skate better, but it is the judges' problem, not my problem," Dmitriev said.
So far, the judges have voted for the elegance and line and unison of Gordeyeva and Grinkov. At the recent Russian championships. At the recent European championships. And at every other competition before these. Gordeyeva and Grinkov conjure something about the essence of figure skating, about grace and control and tandem flow that is unrivaled in the sport.
 
Setting the Standard
 "Gordeyeva and Grinkov are the clear favorites," said John Nicks, who coaches the American champions, Jenni Meno and Todd Sand. "When you have a 170-pound man on the ice and you don't hear a sound, that's an indication of wonderful control. She's a much better jumper than before. The others may be better in terms of originality and flexibility. They may be more pleasing to the public. But, in terms of the skating fraternity, Gordeyeva and Grinkov are the example for everyone in pairs skating today."
Gordeyeva was only 16 at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary, an effervescent sprite weighing but 90 pounds who was tossed so effortlessly and spectacularly by Grinkov, her partner. With the Soviet Union beginning to crumble, they turned professional in 1990, leaving Mishkutienok and Dmitriev as their Olympic successors. In 1991, Gordeyeva and Grinkov married. A year later, a change in the rules, allowing professionals to regain amateur status, opened the door for their Olympic return. But it wasn't an easy decision. Gordeyeva was six months pregnant at the time. Could she regain her fitness to skate the demanding jumps and spins? Did she want to?
 
Gave Birth in New Jersey
 "We watched a lot of tapes of the last Olympic Games," Gordeyeva said. "In the end, the decision was more emotional than calculated."
Wary of the uncertain medical care in the former Soviet Union, Gordeyeva came to the United States, delivering her baby -- a daughter named Daria -- in Morristown, N.J., on Sept. 11, 1992. Gordeyeva had gained only 18 pounds during her pregnacy, so there wasn't much extra weight to lose. A month after she gave birth, she began skating again. She is six years older than 1988, which, along with motherhood, has given Gordeyeva a maturity she lacked at the Calgary Olympics.
"Before, we were not like machines, but we did not feel everything," Gordeyeva said. "Now, we are together, and we feel our skating."
If Gordeyeva and Grinkov, who is 27, are defined by their balletic grace, then Mishkutienok and Dmitriev, their friends and chief rivals, are to be remembered for their daring, gymnastic elasticity.
Figure skating was inelegant and unartful at the 1992 Winter Olympics in Albertville, France, marred by repeated falls and unfulfilled performances. Except for Mishkutienok and Dmitriev. Their strenth and originality was mesmerizing; at one point Mishkutienok draped herself around Dmitriev like a feather boa, then inverted herself, head at his feet, for what has come to be known as the Natalya Death Spin.
"It's up to the judges to decide which style they like," said their coach, Tamara Moskvina. "Classical, easy-looking, but something that doesn't catch your soul. Or something that expresses a lot of emotion and celebrates the movements themselves."
 
Subpar in Copenhagen
 It has not been an entirely satisfying season for the defending champions. Over the summer, one of their training rinks in St. Petersburg was closed to skaters so that it could be used to store bananas. Later, the rink reopened. At the recent European championships in Copenhagen, Mishkutienok and Dmitriev finished third after a Czech judge inadvertently gave them marks of 4.4 and 4.7 instead of 5.4 and 5.7 in the technical program. The judge realized her mistake, but the referee did not allow a change. Moskvina didn't complain.
"They didn't skate well," she said. "But in the last few practices, I have my hopes back."
Two new spirals and an innovative combination spin have been added to their Olympic program, which includes a side-by-side triple-toe-loop jump. For the moment, there are no concerns about Mishkutienok's weight, about which Moskvina is forever worried. Before the 1992 Olympics, Dmitriev hurt his back when Mishkutienok fell on him during a routine. In Albertville, Moskvina said that Mishkutienok, who is 23, skated like a cloud, but a "heavy cloud."
"She is not a feather, but she looks nice," Moskvina said of her skater's 1994 Olympic form.
Dmitriev, who is 25 and married, has fathered a son named Artur Jr. since the Albertville Olympics. Money from a professional tour has allowed him to purchase a car; he know longer has to take a series of buses to practice in St. Petersburg, as he did in 1992.
Another gold medal would mean more money on tour, a chance to keep up with Russia's skyrocketing inflation. He and his partner have the expressiveness and creativity to win. The question is, do they have the preferred style? Only nine judges know the answer.

HEADLINE: Desperately Seeking Someone?

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
MELISSA LEVINE says she went on 17 blind dates last month, and that's not even counting the guy she met by the bee pollen.
"I was in the health food store, and I saw this man looking at the products," said Ms. Levine, a 33-year-old financial planner who lives in Manhattan. "I went up to him and said, 'What are you buying?' and when he told me bee pollen, I said, 'Oh, get it, you'll have a lot of energy.' " He gave her his card on the way out, and they had a date soon after. 
 When she isn't being set up, Ms. Levine meets men all over New York, often just because they're there. (Ask her about the time she ended up going out with the guy who answered the reservation line for the Hampton Jitney.)
"I think it's easy to get a date," she said. "What's hard is getting a second one."
Ms. Levine's travails may seem a bit extreme, but the search for love in New York is clearly not for the weak of stomach. There are about 3.4 million single people in New York City, and what an awful lot of them seem to have in common is the belief that finding a mate in New York is like waiting for the E train on Sunday night: you assume one must be out there, but it isn't arriving any time soon.
"I hated being single," said Valerie Frankel, a magazine editor from Brooklyn and co-author of "The Heartbreak Handbook," a memoir of dating in New York. "I used to meet a lot of guys at bars. I would end up thinking, 'Why am I going home with a guy I met in the East Village?' But I did it because I was hopeful."
Sometimes it even works out. Yet the angst of it all drives many single New Yorkers into the arms of a thriving industry with a simple credo: there must be a better way.
Computer dating services, personal ads, special singles nights and weekends, singles groups with niches and special interests as diverse as New York (singles lawn bowling in Central Park?) -- the dating industry is not exactly new. Still, at least according to some experts in the laws of the dating jungle, these frantic times especially seem to demand some kind of order.
"I saw a lot of nostalgia during the 80's for the old structured system where rules were clear," said Beth Bailey, director of American studies at Barnard College and the author of "From Front Porch to Back Seat: Courtship in 20th-Century America." "In freeing ourselves from rules, we now know less how to behave."
Not surprisingly, this nostalgia seems to increase in direct proportion to age.
"When you are between the ages of 20 and 30, you're not single, you're unattached," said Michael Brandon, editor of Singles Almanac, a journal for singles in the New York area. "At around 30 you become actively single, and that's when you start attending parties, taking singles trips, weekends and things like that."
Perhaps this doesn't sound very romantic. Perhaps you really believe that you'll find your perfect match on that Sunday night E train. Perhaps you will. But it can't hurt to consider the alternatives.
 
THE CRUELEST MATH?
 Even the Census Bureau would probably agree that it's hard finding love in New York. Consider the numbers:
While it isn't exactly true that there are no single men out there, there are an awful lot more single women. Of those 3.4 million single New Yorkers, roughly 2 million are women, while only 1.4 million are men.
And, yes, New York, male and female, is significantly more single than the nation as a whole. Across America, 57 percent of men and 52 percent of women are married; in New York, only 47 percent of men and 39 percent of women are.
And while there are no accurate statistics for gay New Yorkers, their predicament is much the same.
"There is a myth that dating here is easier for gays, but it just isn't true," said Donald Suggs, a spokesman for the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. "Whether you're a gay man, lesbian or straight, we are all equally dysfunctional. Dating in New York is simply incredibly difficult for everyone."
All of which, among other things, keeps roughly a dozen dating services in business in the city.
Actually, the boom time for dating services was the 80's, when about 30 operated in New York City alone. But many were driven out of business by the recession. Others either closed or moved to northern New Jersey in the early 90's, after the State Attorney General's office began cracking down on unscrupulous services by enforcing some of the most stringent regulations in the country.
Under these rules, dating services are not allowed to charge more than $500 for a 6- to 12-month membership. In addition, the contract must stipulate the minimum number of dates the service will provide. If the service does not keep its promise, the customer is entitled to a refund.
The Attorney General's office says it gets few complaints these days, and Mr. Brandon, the editor of the singles magazine, agrees that the survivors are generally reputable.
"A good service is one with a strong backlog of people," Mr. Brandon said. "It is run by people who are sincere, people who bend the rules, give an extra couple dates when the membership has run out."
How, then, do these dating services go about finding you the love of your life? At Together, a national company with three franchise offices in New York City, clients spend up to three hours with a "personal introduction counselor" who talks them through their dating needs, and gives them a questionnaire that rivals the S.A.T. in length and requires analytical thinking.
"New Yorkers are very busy," said Sherri Gilman, the spokeswoman for Together, which claims 1,500 clients here. "They are more interested in a real relationship and as a result want more of a screening process."
On the "attitude profile" section of the questionnaire, for example, respondents are asked to examine certain statements and check off their responses, from "strongly disagree" to "strongly agree."
A few sample statements: "I find cultural arts boring." "Early hotel checkout times are annoying." "It's highly probable we will have to pay for our sins after life on earth."
The answers are computer coded, and matches are made according to compatibility in responses. "It's very scientific," Ms. Gilman said.
Many of the dating services tend to pepper their spiels with promises about all of the "quality people" they offer. And what, exactly, are quality people?
The services' rosters all seem to be filled with the attractive and the well employed. (About 60 percent are women, a figure that generally holds for the industry as a whole.) Most of these people, many of the services acknowledge, are white and middle class.
Many dating service owners say they take only "professionals"; they talk obsessively about all the doctors and lawyers the women manage to meet.
"People," said Ruth Roses, founder of Catholic Singles Matching Club, "are yearning to meet someone who meets their standards."
 
LADIES (AND MEN) WHO LUNCH

For those who can't stomach the idea of an entire evening with a stranger, there's a dating service with a reassuring name, It's Just Lunch. Started in Chicago and new to New York this year, this service sets up people for weekday lunch dates. As one of the founders, Andrea McGinty, points out, "Not much can go wrong in an hour. Lunch is nonthreatening, and you don't have to worry about the good-night kiss."
Ms. McGinty and her partner, Margaret Kunkler, interview potential lunch dates, capture them in Polaroid, then get down to the business of matchmaking.
Sitting on the floor of their midtown offices, the women plow through the piles of applications. "Here's David," said Ms. McGinty, running her hands over a new application. "He doesn't mind kids, but no New York accent. He's a little old fashioned."
Ms. Kunkler holds up a woman's application. "Oh, she could probably do that. She loves to sail." Ms. McGinty is thrilled. "This guy has a sailboat!"
Comments made in the margins during interviews with the clients guide them, too.
"No losers," reads the scrawl on the back of one.
"I feel on edge with her. She seems desperate."
"Episcopal: Easter only."
"No smoke (might tolerate a pipe)."
Once they think they discern a match, they call both parties (never giving out the other person's last name or phone number) and, if both agree, tell them the time and place to show up for lunch.
Because It's Just Lunch has relationships with several Manhattan restaurants, the maitres d'hotel are well practiced in their role of discreetly showing dates to their tables. Clients are instructed to call with feedback within 48 hours, the better to plan future dates, should they be needed.
After eight months in New York, It's Just Lunch boasts 750 clients, as well as one marriage and two engagements.
Jack Isenberg recently suspended his membership with It's Just Lunch, which was given to him as a birthday gift and still had time on the meter, after six dates led him to his new girlfriend.
"I am lazy and this seemed like a very 90's thing to have them do it for me," said Mr. Isenberg, who is 50 and divorced and owns a manufacturing company. "It's also good because it doesn't matter if it doesn't work out. You meet someone new, they're sweet, they're charming and thank you very much goodbye."
 
THE DATING DELI

Dan Fields has a utilitarian approach to matchmaking. At Fields Exclusive Service, which has been brokering marriages in New York since 1920, there is no handholding, no exploring past pains, no soft talk about emotional dysfunction. If an appointment with your average dating service is somewhat akin to a day of therapy, an hour with Dan Fields is more of a stop at the salad bar.
"You tell me what you like and I give it," said Mr. Fields, a "middle 60"-year-old who inherited the business from his father, who inherited it from his. "I have millionaires, I have working class, I got all religions and race. You tell me the height, you tell me the weight, you tell me the religion and that's what I'll give you." (With a side of cole slaw?)
"In the old country they came to grandfather's house," said Mr. Fields, the old country being Russia. "They said, 'I am looking for a certain type of lady,' and he matched them. Today I find a partner for future and happiness."
Mr. Fields claims a roster of 90,000 current clients and says he is responsible for thousands of marriages. But he is vague as to just how he matches people up. He says his 30 years of experience have molded him into a perceptive Cupid, but one might think the key actually rests in his surplus of supplies.
"I give some people 100 names, and others just one or two," he said, relying once again on his rather nebulous points of reference. "I have one gentleman who I gave 275 names, but he married the first one I gave him."
Mr. Fields doesn't so much arrange matches as help his clients make them. They must write him or stop by and tell him the vital statistics being sought in a mate. He will respond in a letter with a list of names, their vital statistics and phone numbers.
"I don't call nobody," he said, with the defiance of an insulted grandfather who is waiting for you to make amends. "If you need more numbers, I will send you more. And more and more and more and more."
 
MIX AND MATCH

Maybe all this matchmaking makes you nervous. Maybe you'd rather look around on your own, or at least what could pass for on your own. New York is flush with organizations devoted to the sponsorship of all sorts of events for all sorts of singles.
These professional party-givers say their events are a giant step up the evolutionary ladder from the traditional singles-bar jungle, because the atmosphere is preconditioned. The guests come from a list, not from the front door, and everyone knows that everyone else is looking.
"In a bar, you never know what to expect," said Jesse Itzler, a musician and entrepreneur. "A place could be packed, but there might only be five girls there. A party is a festive atmosphere, with an open bar and dancing. Everyone is there for the same thing. It works out great."
One such group is Singles of Distinction, which sponsors parties, weekend getaways and longer trips for singles "of all ages." The other night, the event was country dancing at Denim and Diamonds, a midtown singles bar.
The guests, who paid $25, were mostly 38-something folks from all over the city with varying degrees of dancing ability and Western fashion sense. One woman, decked out in black cutoffs, fishnet stockings and a black cowboy hat, danced front and center, two-stepping with a near-vengeance and intimidating those around her onto the sidelines.
There sat mostly women, sipping beers or primary-colored drinks, their eyes darting around the room. Holly Ellison, a 36-year-old market researcher, said she felt comfortable going to a singles event at Denim and Diamonds, because she already knew the place and liked the crowd.
"This is better than the personals," she said.
Hardy Blasberg, a 44-year-old engineer, said he usually met people by accident. When it was pointed out to him that this was a planned singles party, he appeared confused. "Oh, really? This is a singles night?" he said. "I didn't know, I thought I had just come out to have a good time."
Mr. Itzler has created his own slightly subversive singles fantasy for people in their 20's. He rounds up a large group of men and women (most too young to take the imminent prospect of marriage terribly seriously), charges them $50 and presides over a mock wedding reception. But first, there is the ceremony.
Guests' names go into two hats, one for men, one for women, and a bride and groom and an entire wedding party are drawn. The rest of the night is spent celebrating the union of two people who just met.
Call it a Generation X mixer. "Everyone likes to go to weddings," said Mr. Itzler. "People in the city are always looking for something new and creative to do."
 
PERFECT MATE SEEKS SAME

In the spirit of enterprise, mystery and creativity, there is always the old singles standard: the personal ad. Dr. Bonnie Eaker Weil, a Manhattan psychologist who specializes in relationship counseling, works with her patients on writing them.
She should know: she met her husband seven years ago through answering an ad in New York magazine that read, "Be my Guinevere. A truly romantic handsome dentist seeks a caring relationship with an attractive professional woman."
Dr. Eaker Weil started hitting the personal ads after a series of really bad dating-service dates. After three dates, one guy told her he wanted her to meet his mother. They ended up going to a mausoleum.
"There are a lot of desperate people out there," she said. "I tell my clients if they want to get married, they have to take it as seriously as if they were trying to get a master's degree. They have to work at it."
Here is how she tells her patients to write and screen the personals:
Looking to get married? Use the word commitment in your four-line text. Wary of "commitment phobic" men? Skip the ads that ask for beautiful women, or mention high heels and skirt lengths. Keep in mind that people lie about their age and looks.
"When people say that they are attractive, they usually aren't," she said. "If they say they are handsome or beautiful, it usually means they are attractive. When you read these things, you have to go down a notch."
 
A HAPPY ENDING

In the end, there is always the hope of happenstance romance.
Will Hermes, a 33-year-old editor, met his wife, Anne Galperin, on a hot summer afternoon waiting for the E train.
"The train was put out of service and everyone had to get out so we started chatting on the platform," he explained. Another train finally came, and he noticed that she got off at Forest Hills. The next night, he got off there, hoping she would show up, and sure enough, she did.
"I tried to act like I just happened to be there, which of course, she didn't buy," he said. "I mean, why would I just happen to be hanging out against a steel girder?" He bought her an ice cream and soon they were boarding the train together each morning.
Now that's a New York love story.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RICHMOND HILL;
Coming Back Soon: Engine Company 294

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Mayor Guiliani is losing little time in delivering on a campaign pledge he made to the people of Richmond Hill.
Last year he stood in front of the firehouse on Jamaica Avenue and promised, if elected, to restore its Engine Company 294. Local leaders had assailed the fire company's elimination by the Dinkins administration in a 1990 economy move -- especially after two brothers died in a nearby fire a few days later. 
 Mr. Giuliani rolled up a big electoral margin in Richmond Hill. Although his maiden budget proposal -- which focuses primarly on the fiscal year that begins July 1 but also updates the current budget -- called for severe cutbacks at most city agencies, the Fire Department was spared, and Engine Company 294 was restored. The date for the opening has not been announced, but it could come by the end of this month.
"We're going to have a welcome-back party, and I'm going to pop the champagne," said Dario L. Centorcelli, president of the Coalition to Save Engine Company 294 and a past president of the Richmond Hill Block Association. The coalition organized rallies, candlelight vigils and other protests to garner support for the engine company's return.
The price tag for firehouse renovations and staffing for the engine company, as set forth in the Mayor's budget proposal, would be $432,000 through the end of June. The annual cost after that would be about $1 million. Sheldon S. Leffler, chairman of the City Council's Public Safety Committee, predicted that the council would support the fire company's restoration.
The fire company's backers have said that its closing had caused deadly delays in the response of firefighters to alarms. But Fire Department officials denied those charges, saying its crews arrived quickly from other firehouses. A state judge in 1991 upheld the elimination of the engine company, saying that the move had been based on "sound fire protection principles."
Richmond Hill's fire station has continued to have a ladder company, whose role is to enter a burning building, find the fire, rescue anyone inside and vent the structure. An engine company's role is to bring and deploy the hose, connecting it to a hydrant and directing the stream of water.
"We rank third highest in fire fatalities among the 14 community districts in Queens," said Mary Ann Carey, the district manager for Community Board 9, "so we're very excited about getting 294 back. It's been a long time coming."
 B.L.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;
A Restoration Revived for Prayer And Posterity

BYLINE: By NINA REYES

 BODY:
For years, the roof did little to keep rain from sluicing down into the sanctuary of the Eldridge Street Synagogue, and in the 1950's congregants had to move into the basement. Upstairs, in the richly detailed sanctuary, illuminated by dozens of stained-glass windows, pigeons alone occupied the pews.
Today, the leaks have been repaired and the birds are gone, but gaping, blackened holes in the soaring ceiling, caused by water damage, still need to be patched and replastered. And only a tiny Orthodox congregation of 25 to 30 still worships at the Lower East Side temple, though it lies in what was once the largest Jewish community in the world. 
 Reincarnation of the synagogue, one of the city's oldest, has been slow. Structural restoration began with considerable fanfare almost a decade ago, but with the recession and other causes tugging at donors' pocketbooks, lack of funds has stalled work. Now, the Eldridge Street Project, the nonprofit group coordinating the renovation, has hired a consulting company, Pierpont & Wilkerson, to advise on fund-raising strategies as organizers prepare to start the second phase of restoration. The total needed to complete the renovation is estimated at $6.7 million.
The first phase, a $2 million effort that concentrated on stabilizing the building's structure, was completed in 1991. The work being planned now includes replacing plumbing, heating and electrical systems. The third and final phase involves restoring the sanctuary's trompe l'oeil works, its stained-glass windows, the enormous central chandelier and the congregation's sacred treasures.
At the heart of the restoration is the hope that the temple, which first opened for services in 1887, can be preserved not just as a place of worship but also as a monument to the early immigrant community.
"We're basically developing the foundations of a national institution," said Roberta Brandes Gratz, the project president. "So many people -- blacks, Asians, Hispanics -- have never thought of Jews as having a parallel history to theirs." As they walk through the temple and hear about its past, she said, "you can see them make the connection."
Ms. Gratz says she believes the century-old synagogue can offer new immigrants in the neighborhood, now engulfed by Chinatown, an opportunity to view their experience as part of the area's cultural heritage.
Each year nearly 10,000 people visit the temple, which lies between Division and Canal Streets, and children from nearby Public School 124 visit monthly as part of their social studies program.
"When we started people didn't even realize there was a Lower East Side left," Ms. Gratz said. "Now do you know how many tour groups go through the Lower East Side? We hadn't begun to appreciate our American Jewish history roots."
 NINA REYES

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Eldridge Street Synagogue is starting a campaign to raise about $6.7 million for restoration work. (Eldridge Street Project)

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Luring Two Pigeons With One Bean

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
WHY did General Motors have such a hard time when it started marketing its Chevrolet Nova in Latin America? Quite simple. "No va" means "no go" in Spanish.
How do you kill two birds with one stone in German? You hit two flies with one swat. In Italian, you lure two pigeons with one bean. In Korean, you catch two fish with one rod. 
 It was to perform such linguistic and cultural pirouettes that TransImage International Communications was created nearly five years ago. From its headquarters in an old printing factory in TriBeCa, the company offers communication and marketing services to American corporations doing business anywhere in the world, everything from developing ads in foreign languages to refocusing brochures to vetting television commercials.
When Time-Warner decided to offer its first annual report in six languages, it turned to TransImage. When a major communications company wanted to make sure there were no cultural bloopers in its commercials, it had them checked by TransImage (which did notice that one ad, set in Hong Kong, had a brothel in the background). And when the state of Oregon wanted to market itself as an international tourist destination, it contracted with TransImage to produce a Pop Art-style video for Japanese and German audiences.
Indeed, TransImage is finding itself at the leading edge -- along with dozens of other highly specialized, internationally oriented service companies that now thrive in Manhattan -- as New York carves out a position as perhaps the world's most important center for global business.
"New York's roots in the international marketplace are especially significant today," wrote Hugh O'Neill and Mitchell M. Moss in "Reinventing New York: Competing in the Next Century's Global Economy," an influential 1991 economic study for the Urban Research Center at New York University. New York's prosperity, they concluded, will flow "primarily from its role as the leading -- although by no means unchallenged -- urban center in an increasingly integrated world economy."
For Magda Sole, 35, a co-owner of TransImage, American business is just beginning to learn a lesson already well established in most other countries. "If you are just buying, you can do that in any language," she says. "But if you are trying to sell someone something, the key is to communicate in your customer's language."
She knows what she is talking about. Ms. Sole, who speaks seven languages, was born in Barcelona and educated in Switzerland. She worked in Italy before coming to New York 10 years ago. Her partner, David Halvorsen, a 41-year-old American, spent several years studying and working in Sweden.
TransImage's staff reflects New York in all its cultural diversity. Maha See, its director of operations, is from Myanmar and has lived in Singapore. He speaks Burmese, Chinese and several other languages. One project manager, Frederic Autran, is French. Another, Naoko Okabe, came to New York from Tokyo as a student. (The staff of 16 does include a few native New Yorkers.)
Ms. Sole and Mr. Halvorsen, longtime friends, founded TransImage in 1990 after deciding they were dissatisfied with their jobs -- she with a translation company, he as a computer and communications manager for Merrill Lynch. They also felt the time was right for a company that could do more than provide standard translations.
TransImage opened its doors just as the regional economic downturn was turning its full fury on New York City. Nonetheless, the company has grown rapidly, recently moving from its old scruffy office on Franklin Street to a larger, custom-designed space in a Hudson Street building. Last year, TransImage billed more than $2.5 million to about 300 clients.
The way the company is run accounts, in part, for its ability to adapt to a changing world marketplace: TransImage is an exemplar of an emerging business trend that experts call the virtual company. In place of the standard organizational structure, in which everyone works out of the same office or is part of a more far-flung but fixed management system, TransImage operates flexibly with its small staff core. Via fax, E-mail and even old-fashioned telephone, that core coordinates the activities of nearly 350 freelance translators, editors, writers and designers around the world.
THERE is little place for traditional corporate culture at TransImage. Everyone works in a big open space divided into three areas -- for design, production and marketing. The few separate offices are shared as needed. It is difficult to tell where one job ends and another begins.
The company can draw on expertise in 80 different languages, as well as knowledge of a panoply of cultures.
In advising American companies on marketing in France, Mr. Autran, for example, discusses how to avoid offending French sensibilities.
"The French are enamored by American products, yet threatened by American cultural imperialism," he said. "We tell them how to avoid a faux pas that might cost them sales." Mr. Autran points to Eurodisney, just outside Paris, as one company that underestimated that problem.
Similarly, TransImage helped a United States auto parts company enter the Japanese market by developing a brochure modeled on advertising popular in that country. Rather than using glitzy American techniques, the brochure included long interviews with Japanese executives discussing the future of the industry. Only at the very end did the company even mention its own name.
Colors and images also mean different things in different cultures. Some carry particular messages. Green, the color of Mohammad's flag, must be used with care in Islamic countries, as must blue in nations with a Greek Orthodox population. Orange is sensitive in Buddhism. Yellow, which in America connotes cowardice (a yellow streak) or faithfulness (a yellow ribbon), carries religious and mystical overtones in India. In China, yellow represents both the Emperor and pornography.
Design features that may work in the United States, like bold elements with bright, trendy colors, could come on too strong in Japan, where black, white and pastel dominate.
Many American companies, with their assumption that English has become a universal language and American standards predominate, suffer when they fail to take such differences into account.
But cultural misunderstanding works in reverse, too. Mr. See remembers a trip to Japan at Christmas time. In a cafe, there was a sign: "Happy Birthday, Jesus Christ Superstar."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Foreign Investment Roars Into Bombay

BYLINE: By Sanjoy Hazarika

DATELINE: BOMBAY

 BODY:
SINCE November, one of the world's hottest stock markets has been the Bombay Stock Exchange, thanks to an avalanche of foreign investment and the gradual opening of what was once one of the world's most insular economies.
After soaring early last week to 4,162 points on the Bombay Sensitivity Index, the market closed Friday at 3,991 points, a 24 percent rise, in dollar terms, since the first of the year and a rise of almost 50 percent since November. Bombay's is the third best performing market after Brazil and Finland this year. 
 The exchange's last bull run, which drove the index to a record 4,500 in August 1992, was a consequence of fraudulent purchases on credit, which inflated prices. After that boom, laws permitting mutual funds and other foreign institutional investors to invest here were eased in September 1992. But it was not until last summer that substantial funds started arriving.
Their arrival reflected the fact that foreign investors were moving out of markets elsewhere, especially Japan, as well as growing confidence that the stock market scandal of 1992 was over and that the political and social turmoil in India had subsided. Extensive Hindu-Muslim riots in 1992 and 1993 appeared to have abated and Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao had overcome a challenge to his leadership.
Under prior Government rules, overseas investors were barred from playing the Indian markets. Under current regulations, they can put money into Indian companies through foreign institutional investors registered with India's Securities and Exchange Board as overseas investment funds.
One such fund, and the first available to American investors on the New York Stock Exchange, is the closed-end India Growth Fund, which invests primarily in Indian corporate stocks. It closed Friday at $26.625 a share, off from its 52-week high of $30.75 early last month. (Individual foreign investors still cannot directly invest in the market here and foreign institutions can't hold more than 24 percent of stock in a listed company.)
Stock analysts say an estimated $1 billion has surged into the market from overseas buyers in the past few months. In addition, Indian companies have raised more than $1 billion from international markets, all of that through Euro-issues, most of which were heavily oversubscribed. More than 40 Indian corporations are scheduled to float new Euro-issues this year, which may fetch another $4 billion to $5 billion.
A. N. Kolhatkar, the executive director of the Bombay Stock Exchange, said he hoped for an influx of $3 billion into the Indian market through foreign portfolio investors. "The market is buoyant and it is a natural rise although we have too much money chasing too few premium scrips," Mr. Kolhatkar said, referring to individual stocks.
Foreign institutional investors are also tapping the Indian market by raising money here. One example is the Morgan Stanley Growth Fund, the first onshore fund organized by a major foreign investment house. Aiming to raise about $100 million, the company was overwhelmed last month by some 1.4 million Indian investors who put about $300 million into the fund.
From a bare 2.5 million investors in 1980, the Bombay market has galloped to 22.5 million, as more and more Indians turned to it instead of trusting in such traditional investments as gold.
"Foreign investors are coming into India because of the recessions in the United States, Europe and Japan," said Hemendra Kothari, a leading stockbroker whose company, DSP Consultants, helped manage the Morgan Stanley issue. "This is a growing economy, with sophisticated and historic traditions of trading and business, it has a vast consumer class and there is quick appreciation on investments."
Keen to seize the opportunities here, other big foreign investors have also entered the market. They include Alliance Capital, Barclays Zoette Wedd, Fidelity Investments and Lloyd George Management.
As a result of financial measures aimed at liberalizing the economy -- devaluing the rupee, reducing regulations and red tape, opening the doors to foreign investment -- India's Gross National Product is growing at about 4.5 percent a year and inflation has fallen to single-digit levels.
One important hurdle for the market, however, is the lack of adequate custodial services to handle the growing number of transactions. The slow speed of settlement, a paper-intensive market and infrastructural strains are obvious.
Under Securities and Exchange Board rules, only the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank and Citibank qualify to handle custodial services for foreign companies purchasing shares. They have been overwhelmed with the scale of the paperwork, which is largely a consequence of the lack of computerization.
Board officials, concerned about a possible slowing of foreign investment, say it may take several weeks to resolve the problem and that more Indian and foreign banks must share the load. There is talk too of a National Depository, which could pave the way for paperless trading.
Yet major stockbrokers and analysts are bullish about the Indian market over the next few months.
"The index is bound to rise because there is bound to be further liberalization and once the economy opens up, the process is irreversible," said Radheshyam Goenka, one of India's leading stockbrokers.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 20, 1994, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The World Markets column last Sunday about the Bombay Stock Exchange misstated the rules for banks' providing custodial services for foreign investment institutions. The United States Securities and Exchange Commission requires that any bank providing such services for investment firms and mutual funds have at least $200 million in capital. Under that guideline, several banks qualify, including Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank, Citibank and Standard Chartered Bank.

HEADLINE: At Work;
After the Divorce, the Deluge

SERIES: Second in a series of articles on women and pensions.

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
THERE are so many ways for a woman to end up living in poverty when she is elderly that it seems almost churlish to focus on one particular group as more victimized than any other. Women may, for example, work at jobs in companies unlikely to offer significant retirement coverage and for wages so low that saving is virtually impossible. Or, to increase their income, they may juggle two or three low-paying jobs. Together, the jobs may add up to years of more-than-full-time employment and yield a living wage -- but no benefits and certainly no pension.
Or they may enter and leave the labor force as family duties ebb and flow, interrupting the long march toward qualifying for retirement plans, or lowering the amount they will receive. Or their husbands may die, leaving them with considerably less than the expected amount of retirement income. "Our life patterns are different than the life patterns of men," said Lou Glasse, president of the Washington-based Older Women's League. 
 All women may be at the mercy of their life patterns, but women who divorce in midlife or later are shoved with sudden force into a vulnerable subset of the female experience. It is women who have done what was expected of them and led the most exemplary middle-class lives who may be the least prepared to face the reduced circumstances in which they will very likely find themselves in old age.
A study last year of the economic status of older divorced women by the Brandeis University Policy Center on Aging painted a Lucian Freud-ish picture of the so-called golden years. The study noted that only 5 percent of divorced women living on Social Security and a private pension were poor, but it also revealed that only about a quarter of older women (age 62 and over) receive a pension in addition to Social Security. The median annual income of older divorced women is about $9,000 (in 1990 dollars) and has been growing at a below-inflation rate of 1.5 percent.
Both the study and experts in pensions and divorce say changes in matrimonial law since 1970, when California became the first state to allow "no-fault" divorce -- based on irreconcilable differences instead of designating a guilty party -- have generally not worked to the benefit of women. Where the courts once used alimony and tangible assets to punish and reward, they now focus on distributing property fairly. They have expanded the definition of property to include intangibles like potential earning power and pensions, but in the process women have come to receive alimony less often and for shorter periods of time. The first major study of California's no-fault divorce law, published in 1985, found that men's standard of living went up 42 percent in the first year after divorce and women's went down 73 percent.
The last thing women may be thinking about as they contemplate the sinking trend line of their post-divorce income is a pension that won't come home to roost for several years. "Women, especially if they have children, may have other priorities. They have short-term problems," said Anna Rappaport, a senior actuary in the Chicago office of William M. Mercer Inc., the human resource consultants. "It's easy to say I'm going to solve a 2-year problem at the expense of a 10-year problem."
COMPOUNDING the difficulty is the well-documented reluctance of some women to throw themselves wholeheartedly into financial and retirement planning. "Women don't know enough about the issues," Ms. Rappaport said. "When they make a settlement, they let the husbands keep their pensions without realizing the economic impact."
Women are often not well-served by their lawyers, who themselves may be unfamiliar with the intricacies of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, the Federal law covering private pensions; the Retirement Equity Act of 1984, which broadened the rights of divorced spouses, or the particular pension system relevant to their client. And some lawyers, according to several pension advocates, simply don't think about pensions and benefits, which are not automatically put into play when the marital assets go on the table during a divorce. They may not anticipate changes, like remarriage or the death of the ex-husband, that could nullify the agreement and leave the woman with nothing. Such lapses are not uncommon despite the fact that a traditional defined-benefit pension accrued during a lifetime career at one employer will often be the couple's largest asset, after their home.
WHAT is to be done? First, learn about your family finances and catalogue your potential pension assets. Think long and hard before handling a divorce without a lawyer. When you do engage a lawyer, make sure he or she is knowledgeable about pensions, especially if you fall into a special category, like one of the Federal retirement systems. And if you feel you might be wrecking your karma by raising these topics when you are not contemplating a divorce, or if you can't cope with them when you are, ponder for a moment living alone in old age on the $500 monthly Social Security payment women typically receive.
 
 
 
WHERE TO START LOOKING FOR HELP
THE comprehensive "Your Pension Rights at Divorce: What Women Need to Know," by Anne Moss, is available for $16.50 from the Pension Rights Center, 918 16th Street N.W., Suite 704, Washington, D.C. 20006. The American Association of Retired Persons has published "Women, Pensions and Divorce," a survey of pension issues with a section on proposed reforms. The booklet is available from the American Association of Retired Persons at 601 E Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20049. Also available free from the A.A.R.P. is "A Women's Guide to Pension Rights."
To receive a free packet of information on pensions from the Older Women's League, send a self-addressed, stamped envelope to the league at 666 11th Street N.W. Suite 700, Washington, D.C. 20001. A women-and-pensions edition of the league's newsletter has several short articles and a list of resources. Call 800-825-3695 for the current price.

A chart with the At Work column last Sunday, about how women can evaluate their pension and retirement income, misstated the telephone number for the Social Security Administration. It is (800) 772-1213.
