HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Strategies for Rising Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
IF the Federal Reserve thought it was being clear about the future of interest rates when it said on Feb. 4 that it was lifting the Federal funds rate by a quarter-point -- well, the markets bought the idea for a day.
On the Friday the rate rise was announced, stock prices dropped (wouldn't money be hightailing it to grab those higher yields?) and long-term Treasury funds lost a little over half a point (wouldn't they have to, to match the higher yields?). 
 But with the stock market bouncing back last week, the question became: Is the Fed's move really a long-awaited signal that the era of falling interest rates is over? If so, now what?
While the Fed's action was widely perceived as preventive, not a reaction to rising inflation, "If the economy continues to strengthen, this will be the first of many blows to come," said John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, in Chicago.
That's why many investment advisers say now is a good time for income investors to review their strategies.
Most advisers recommend that those in short-term bond funds stay put. "We haven't moved clients out of short- or short-intermediate funds, because we're still operating under the premise that rates won't be rising that quickly," said Steven B. Enright, an investment adviser in Rivervale, N.J.
That doesn't mean investors in short-term bond funds will escape unscathed should rates rise more. "You'll have some price pressure on net asset value, but total return should be positive because there's only so much that you can lose in short-term funds," Mr. Rekenthaler said.
As for long-term bonds, the case is less clear. Some economists say inflation is licked; others say inflation will pick up as the economy recovers. That leaves one thing sure: The uncertainty will produce volatility in the long-term bond markets.
Investors who plan to hold shares 10 years or more and can handle the risk can reap higher yields, Mr. Rekenthaler said. He likes the Vanguard Long-Term Corporate Bond Fund, which yielded an annualized 6.4 percent in January. But most investors would be better off in funds that have shorter maturities and would not be hit as hard by rising rates. Mr. Enright likes the Stein Roe Income Fund and Pimco Total Return.
Many advisers are turning away from United States bonds and looking for income elsewhere. "We don't see domestic investment-grade bonds as a good place to be in 1994," given their extraordinary returns over the last five years, said Craig Litman, an investment adviser in San Francisco.
Instead, he recommends junk bond funds. "We believe the economy will be stable and slow-growing, and inflation won't be a threat over the next year," he said. Even so, "a blip up in rates will have a greater impact on domestic investment-grade bonds." Mr. Litman expects junk bond funds to yield at least 8 percent. His two favorites: Pimco High-Yield Fund and Financial Bond Shares.
Because of their relative insensitivity to interest rates, junk bonds are also the choice of Eric M. Kobren, who edits Fidelity Insight, an independent newsletter for Fidelity funds. He recommends Fidelity Spartan High-Income for investors who can meet the $10,000 minimum investment.
Bob Markham, an Edina, Minn., investment adviser, calls junk bonds "the best bet for income investors." When the Fed announced its rate increase, "stocks, bonds and utilities got trashed, but junk bonds stayed steady," he said. "It's the same scenario I expect to be repeated throughout 1994." Mr. Markham likes Northeast Investors Trust and Federated High-Yield.
The year is also shaping up as a good one for Ginnie Mae funds, Mr. Rekenthaler said, if rates keep rising moderately. He likes the Benham GNMA Income Fund, which yielded an annualized 6 percent in January.
Real estate investment trust funds are another good source of income, Mr. Litman said, with yields of 6 to 8 percent and capital gains potential. "Even assuming no appreciation in the underlying properties," he said, "higher cash flow from rising rents will help earnings and prices." His favorites are the Cohen and Steers REIT Fund and the Fidelity REIT Fund.
On one point the advisers are nearly unanimous: Income investors should diversify their portfolios overseas, where rates have fallen, but remain above domestic rates. But it is important to find funds that can hedge currency risk, and managers who can do so effectively, Mr. Enright said. He recommends Scudder International Bond and T. Rowe Price International Bond.
Because international bonds behave differently from domestic bonds, they lower overall portfolio risk. Nonetheless, he advises capping the foreign fixed-income portion at 10 to 15 percent of the total portfolio.
Mr. Markham would go as high as 20 percent, because "We don't want the entire portfolio subject to what Mr. Greenspan says," he said, referring to Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. Because of the risks of overseas investing, he likes SoGen Overseas, an equity fund with large cash holdings and very cautious management.
Even income investors should own equities as a hedge against inflation. Utility funds may not be a good idea anymore, the advisers say, but try conservative, high-dividend stock funds. Mr. Markham recommends Lindner Dividend and Wellesley Income.

HEADLINE: THE MYTH OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT

 BODY:
Although single-shot efforts at housing or education or health care can make important contributions to a better life, they cannot alone be effective in transforming the dreadful conditions at the bottom of our society. What is required is literal transformation of these dysfunctional neighborhoods into fit places to live and raise families.
 To this end, the Enterprise Foundation is working with residents of the Sandtown neighborhood of Baltimore (10,300 people, in 72 square blocks -- 44 percent jobless, the center of violent crime), in an effort to transform these conditions -- and all at the same time. The project is being watched across the country as a potential model. 
JAMES W. ROUSE Founder-Chairman
F. BARTON HARVEY Chairman, The Enterprise Foundation Columbia, Md.

LENGTH: 1510 words

HEADLINE: Efforts to Stem Violence in the Workplace

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

 BODY:
A Disgruntled employee at a Westchester-based manufacturing company began warning his supervisor that he would come to work one day with his semiautomatic weapon and go on a shooting spree. The man, who appeared increasingly unkempt and whose behavior had become progressively more threatening, assured his co-workers that his aim was good because he had served in the Vietnam War.
A manager at a different corporation in the county was being stalked by one of her employees. The harassment began with a call to the manager's home, but the campaign soon escalated. The employee became more menacing -- showing up at the manager's house, following her around town and tracking her down on vacation.
 HB>Incident in Mount Vernon
 Both of these incidents were defused by corporate employee-assistance programs before they could explode into violence. The two companies involved would discuss the cases only on condition of anonymity. Several weeks ago in Mount Vernon, however, a workplace dispute ended in tragedy. 
 William Santiago, 22, of Yonkers, was dismissed in late January from his job at Steve's Market, a grocery chain with stores in Yonkers and Mount Vernon. Two days later, he attempted to kill his former boss by spraying him with gasoline and setting him on fire. Landers Chambers, 51, owner of the market, was severely burned but survived the attack. Mr. Santiago, the former employee, was fatally burned in the incident. Police said it was unclear whether his death was accidental or a suicide.
All three incidents illustrate what is increasingly recognized as a serious cause for concern -- violence in the workplace. Last year, a study called "Fear and Violence in the Workplace," conducted by the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company of Minneapolis, reported that from July 1992 to July 1993, more than 2 million Americans were victims of physical attack on the job. An additional 6 million workers were threatened and 16 million were harassed, the report said.
"Violence is spilling into the workplace," said Peggy Lawless, research project director for Northwestern. "It is pervasive. Our figures showed that chances are one in four that a worker may be attacked, threatened or harassed on the job next year."
The National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, based in Cincinnati, released a study calling workplace homicide a "serious public health problem." During the 1980's, the institute documented 7,603 homicides in American workplaces. The Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that in 1992, there were 138 murders in the workplace in the New York City area.
 
Figures Are Misleading
 Those figures do not distinguish between murders committed in the course of other criminal activities, like robberies and rapes of employees, and outbreaks of violence that occur between co-workers on the job. In other words, they include the taxi driver who is robbed and murdered on the job as well as the laid-off employee who exacts revenge on his supervisor. Experts say that the vast majority of violence on the job is still related to crime from the outside, particularly robbery. But they warn that employee-to-employee violence is on the rise.
At a recent symposium on workplace violence sponsored by the United States Postal Service in Washington, Dr. Dennis L. Johnson, president of a management consulting firm in Stuart, Fla., who is considered an expert on the subject, said that violence within the workplace -- in which an attacker has a known relationship with co-workers, supervisors or customers -- was one of the fastest-growing crimes in the country.
While employers in Westchester have long examined ways to keep workers safe on the job by reducing crime from the outside -- by hiring security guards, using employee identification cards, installing closed-circuit television, maintaining well-lighted parking lots, and the like -- they are now being forced to pay closer attention to the type of violence that may be induced in the workplace itself.
"We are getting called into more and more in-house situations where there is the potential for a violent outcome," said Lise Mayers, who is based in Purchase as area manager for Personal Performance Consultants, an employee-assistance company that provides counseling services for more than a dozen corporate clients. It was Personal Performance that was called in to handle the situations involving the employee making threats to co-workers and the employee stalking his manager.
 
A More Violent Society
 The county government is also starting to look at the problem.
"Obviously people are concerned about the trends in violence at work and recognizing that this is something you have to be aware of and knowledgeable about -- even if it hasn't happened to you directly," said Pat Doyle, director of alcohol and drug abuse services for the County Department of Community Mental Heath. "You look at it from the preventive perspective as well as if it happens, what is your protocol about it?"
Violence at work is pervasive enough that trade journals for employee-assistance professionals run articles like "When Employees Make Good on Bad Intentions" and "After the Incident . . . Intervention," with tips on treating post-traumatic stress disorders. One advertisement offered employers a three-hour videotape on workplace violence, which covered "traits in the violent offender, assessment procedures, hostage considerations" and other subjects.
Experts who study workplace violence attribute its increasing prevalence to a number of factors. First, they say it is a reflection of a more violent society, particularly the availability of guns. According to Niosh, 75 percent of workplace homicides are committed with firearms.
Second, the pervasiveness of drugs and alcohol contribute to the instability of the work force. In some instances, domestic violence migrates into the office. An abusive husband, for example, can track down his wife at work.. But most recently, it is the stress and potential violence triggered by the wave of corporate layoffs that has become the focus of employers.
"With downsizing throughout corporate America, there is this overwhelming sense of insecurity and fear," said Dr. Estherann Grayzel, corporate medical director for Nynex, which has corporate offices in Manhattan and White Plains. "When someone feels out of control, that he no longer controls his destiny -- and there's no support system in place -- there is the potential for trouble. It's the loners who are most likely to explode."
 
Layoffs a Major Contributor
 Ms. Lawless, who conducted the study for Northwestern, said that her research revealed that layoffs were a "major contributor" to violence in the workplace. In Westchester, as elsewhere, an entire corporate culture has developed over making layoffs as least traumatic as possible. One caveat is never to dismiss anyone on a Friday because they will then be alone over the weekend while trying to absorb the blow. ("Frequently, it's not at the point when someone is fired that you have the outburst -- it has to percolate a little," Ms. Mayers said. "Someone is apt to explode a few days later.")
Dr. Grayzel said Nynex makes every effort to be sensitive to employees during terminations with in-house discussion groups to teach skills for coping and preparing for change. At International Business Machines, with corporate headquarters in Armonk, every manager receives training on how to handle layoffs as well as how to handle an employee who is having professional or personal difficulties. Both I.B.M. and Nynex make extensive use of their employee-assistance programs, which can counsel employees on how to handle stress, drug- and alcohol-abuse problems and other mental health issues. Termination benefits often include extended access to those services.
So ingrained are layoffs in the corporate culture now that counseling is offered at both companies to "survivors," those who have avoided the most recent wave of cutbacks. Scott Brooks, manager of human resources issues at I.B.M., said that such employees often experience "survivor's guilt" because they still have a job and former co-workers do not and that they also suffer from anxiety over being the next to go.
 
Threat-Assessment Teams
 Of course, the vast majority of people who are laid off do not respond with threats or violence. But when such a situation arises, it is taken seriously. I.B.M., which declined to identify any specific incidents, acknowledged that it has developed threat-assessment teams to cope with potential violence.
If a threat is made, staff members from the human resources, security, medical and legal departments convene to evaluate the problem and make a judgment on how to intervene appropriately and when to call in law enforcement agencies.
"Instead of playing ostrich, companies have to deal with this," Ms. Mayers of Personal Performance Consultants said. "In Westchester, especially with the economy, we haven't seen all the fallout yet."

HEADLINE: Some Districts Planning to Hire New Teachers

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
FACED with increased student enrollments and growing numbers of teachers eligible for retirement, many school districts are planning to hire teachers in the new school year.
For the first time in three years districts are beginning to rehire or replace teachers who were laid off as a result of losses of state aid and budget cuts. 
 Some districts have also offered incentives to encourage teachers to retire early and, in some cases, are trying to save money by hiring younger, less experienced teachers.
The Island has 127 districts, with 56 in Nassau County and 71 in Suffolk. Not all districts plan to hire teachers next year. The districts planning to hire are mostly those with retirement incentives for teachers and those that have had significant increases in enrollment, particularly in the elementary grades and largely from students from overseas.
Over the last three years Long Island lost 5,000 jobs in education, said Dr. Bruce Brodsky, president of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association. The cuts included teachers, administrators, support workers like guidance counselors and psychologists, custodians and lunchroom aides, Dr. Brodsky said, adding:
"Most school districts are now in the midst of developing their budgets for next year. They are looking at projected enrollment, staffing and the questions of what class size does the board of ed want to maintain? What courses will be offered next year? What has been mandated by the state for us to do? What services did we cut that we can possibly restore? And, finally, how many personnel are needed to achieve those goals?"
Dr. Brodsky added that for many districts two priorities would be rehiring staff members like psychologists, social workers and guidance counselors, as well as multilingual teachers to work with growing populations of students who do not speak English.
 
The Decline 'Is Over'
 For teaching candidates seeking positions on the Island, job prospects are beginning to brighten, the Superintendent in Hewlett-Woodmere, Dr. Bert Nelson, said. "The long period of enrollment decline that followed the postwar years is over," he said. "Most Long Island school districts are experiencing increasing enrollment, beginning first on the elementary level, and this will result in increasing teaching positions.
"Parallel to that is a maturing staff eligible for retirement. As a cost-saving measure a number of districts have begun to offer various local retirement incentives, to get people to think about retiring early. This creates more opportunities for people seeking teaching positions."
Teachers are eligible to retire with benefits at 55. Some districts and some states have added incentives to encourage teachers to retire, according to Dr. Edward Broderick, president of the Suffolk County Council of Superintendents and Superintendent of the Westhampton Beach Schools.
"In Florida, for example," Dr. Broderick said, "retirement incentives have saved the state billions of dollars. While several other states have followed Florida's example, New York has not offered any statewide plan, and it is up to local districts to decide whether or not to offer retirement incentives. If the state does come out with a policy it will negate the plans of individual school districts."
Westhampton Beach has a $25,000 incentive for teachers 55 and older. At the end of the school year 15 teachers out of a staff of 120 will leave.
"Next year 23 teachers will be eligible for retirement," Dr. Broderick said. "Many will take advantage of the incentive and will bale out. With 50 percent of our teachers on the maximum pay steps receiving the top salary, their retirement will be a great cost savings to the district."
 
Advantages of Younger Teachers
 Districts are obligated by contractual seniority and recall rights to rehire teachers who were laid off at their old salaries. To fill many remaining positions districts are looking to hire teachers at the lowest pay steps.
Education officials see financial advantages in hiring younger, less experienced teachers, said Dr. James Ruck, Superintendent of the Sachem Schools. "When an experienced employee making a salary of $70,000 retires and you can replace him with someone on step one making $30,000, it's a big financial help," Dr. Ruck said.
The Herricks district in New Hyde Park has had a 30 percent turnover over the last five years, mostly from retired teachers, said an assistant to the superintendent, Michael Klopfer. The district has a $25,000 retirement incentive and starting salaries of $32,900 for a teacher with a bachelor's degree and $38,000 with a master's.
"For next year we're looking to hire between 10 and 15 new teachers out of a staff of about 300," he said. "The trend in this district, as in many others, is to recruit quality teachers on lower steps."
 
Starting at $30,000
 "In Westhampton Beach," Dr. Broderick added, "for years we went for experienced teachers so we didn't have to break them in. Under our contract we could hire up to step 10. But in the last three years every new teacher has been hired at step 1.
"Many applicants with four years' experience are willing to come in at step 1 so as to get the job. With so many teachers who have been excessed, many are willing to accept a lower salary. It's a buyer's market. Our starting salary with a bachelor's degree is about $30,000. If we can't fill the positions then we go higher."
Administrators say every available position attracts hundreds of applicants. In Herricks, Mr. Klopfer said, 300 to 500 people apply for each elementary-school position.
In Rockville Centre 400 to 600 applications are received for each elementary position, said Superintendent William Johnson, who is also president of the Nassau County Council of Superintendents. Salary negotiations are dictated by the levels of education and years of experience, Dr. Johnson said, adding:
"Level of education is not negotiable. We are bound by contract. A candidate with a master's degree can't agree to accept a salary based on a bachelor's degree. But years of experience credited to salaries are negotiable. Applicants with five years of experience, for example, can accept a starting salary of step 2."
Among the many candidates, the pools are smaller in specific areas, Dr. Johnson added. Opportunities are greater in the fields of advanced science and mathematics, technology, home and career skills, library science and speech therapy.
Some districts have developed programs to help new teachers. This year Herricks started a mentoring program to help train 15 new teachers. Mr. Klopfer said the program offered informal support by experienced teachers. The average time spent with the new teachers, before and after school and on their lunch hours, has been 30 hours. The program has cost $6,000.
Herricks has also introduced "collegial circles," groups to discuss topics like curriculums and other academic programs. "They are a cost-effective way to address teacher isolation and allow teachers to provide support for one another," Mr. Klopfer explained.
In Hempstead assistants have been hired to work with teachers in the classrooms. Superintendent Eddy Bayardelle said: "These paraprofessionals are trained in the school district and encouraged to get their teaching degrees. More and more we are hiring them as our new teachers. It's an economic way to hire new teachers at the entry level who know the expectations of the district, thereby guaranteeing the quality we're looking for."
State-mandated programs will also affect many districts. One new requirement is to provide transition services for special-education students between 18 and 22 who graduate from high school, said Dr. Johnson. That may increase the need for special-education teachers, he said.
"On the Federal level," Dr. Brodsky added, "the big word in special education is 'inclusion.' As we bring more handicapped kids into the classroom we'll need more special-ed teachers and additional support staff. Although New York has not yet mandated full inclusion we're moving in that direction."
 
Districts With Few Openings
 Not all districts are looking for new teachers. For districts without retirement incentives, the turnover is minimal, said Superintendent Carole Hankin in Syosset. She added that her district would have few openings next year.
In Rockville Centre, another district without a retirement-incentive package, there will be no new teaching positions. But the staff will be redistributed to fill whatever gaps arise, said Dr. Johnson.
"School districts tend to go in cycles," Dr. Ruck said. "When other districts were facing declining enrollment and cutting back their teaching staff Sachem was still growing. Now, while many districts are hiring new teachers, we're on the other side of the cycle, facing a slight decline in population and not hiring. In a few years, as enrollment across Long Island continues to climb, more teacher hiring is expected."
The key word for most districts is balance, Dr. Nelson said. "We're all struggling with our budgets," he added, "trying to maintain and improve our services in an economy that hasn't turned around fully. In the face of increasing enrollment, that's a challenge and a half."

HEADLINE: Statistics Offer No Solace To Those in Jobless Line

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
FOR Yvonne Harris, a former office manager and bookkeeper who was waiting in line with several hundred other unemployed workers at a State Department of Labor office here last week, it was little consolation that many of the country's economic indicators were signaling an end to the recession.
"All I know is my story," said Ms. Harris, who lives in White Plains, "and I've gone from being a Cinderella to a Raggedy Ann: I've worked my whole life, and now this." 
 In the nation's capital, the latest figures showed that the Consumer Confidence Index surged for the third time in a row in January to 83.2 percent and factory orders rose 1.2 percent in December, the fifth increase in a row. President Clinton and economic forecasters greeted the news as more evidence that the country was pulling itself out of a long, hard slump.
But Juan Carlos, an unemployed chef from Port Chester, viewed matters from a different perspective. "We don't care what they are saying in Washington because you can see with your own eyes what's happening here," said Mr. Carlos, who was waiting for his benefits as the long line at the Labor Department office snaked through a hallway and down a flight of stairs. "This line just keeps growing, and people are losing heart."
 
Benefits for Only 26 Weeks
 Although jobless figures for Westchester in December, the most recent available, showed that unemployment in the county had dropped to 4.7 percent from 5.6 percent for the same month in 1992, Margaret Herrera, manager of the office on Prospect Street here, said that statistics notwithstanding, she was busier than ever processing claims.
Also, the Federal Government last week ended its extended unemployment insurance program, making matters more difficult for those out of work for long periods. Workers once again are limited to collecting benefits for 26 weeks only.
"What we're seeing is more frustration among the unemployed, especially those who were in white-collar jobs," Ms. Herrera said. "Companies continue to downsize, and there's not a lot of rehiring going on."
 
Better Prospects Elsewhere
 James Mason, a former sales and marketing employee for a large Westchester firm who was also at the unemployment office, said he had been sending out a steady stream of resumes since he lost his job two months ago. "Still no work," said Mr. Mason, who lives in Stamford. "It's taking its toll on me."
Others waiting in line were hopeful that the national trends might soon trickle down to the local economy, although one unemployed man, a former white-collar worker who agreed to be interviewed only on the condition that his name not be used, said, "I'm getting ready to pack up my bags and move to another state."
Indeed, job prospects are better in most parts of the country than in the Northeast, and it may be months before the region pulls out of its slump, economic analysts said.
"Nationally, we are starting to see the leading indicators -- factory orders and the work week -- improve," said Joseph J. Kozlowski, a regional economist for the State Department of Labor. "But locally, we haven't seen gains in employment, and that's the way we measure the local economy."
While the State Department of Labor reported a drop in the jobless rate, it also released figures showing that from December 1992 to the same month last year, the county lost 7,200 jobs.
 
'Not the True Story'
 "The low unemployment rate is terribly misleading," said Thomas J. Spitznas, an economist in Mount Vernon who specializes in trends and forecasts. "What we are really seeing in Westchester is a dropout in the labor force: discouraged workers.
"If you have 20 people and 2 are unemployed, you have a 10 percent unemployment rate. But if the next month, one of those workers gives up and stops looking for a job, you officially have only one person out of 19 not working, and the jobless rate drops to 5.2 percent," he said. "So the headlines read, 'Major Improvement in Labor Market,' but that's not the true story."
Mr. Spitznas said Westchester's problems were not only the result of continued downsizing in the corporate sector. He blamed, in part, "the cost of doing business downstate."
"When a company's income is not growing, things like workmen's compensation in the state, the cost of living and local property taxes become very painful," he said.
Noreen L. Preston, an economist with the County Office of Economic Development, said new job growth in New York City may relieve some of the unemployment problems locally.
"Once New York City gets going, Westchester generally follows suit," she said. "But the big companies' layoffs here are still hurting us. It's hard to counteract the major headliners like Nynex."
Nynex, which has its corporate center in White Plains, announced last month that it would cut up to 12,000 jobs, or about 25 percent of its work force in New York State, by the end of 1996. The large telecommunications company said that about 1,100 workers in Westchester, about one-fifth of its work force here, could be affected by staff reductions.
Another major employer of local workers, I.B.M., has seen its work force in the county drop from more than 14,000 in 1986 to about 7,500 last year, said Scott Brooks, a company spokesman.
Cutbacks at I.B.M. and other Fortune 500 companies in the county are also reflected in the high office vacancy rates being reported -- 35 percent in the main business district of White Plains at the end of 1993, Ms. Preston said.
Meanwhile, figures from the State Department of Labor confirmed what people waiting in line for their unemployment checks already knew. The statistics showed that the manufacturing sector of the county's economy lost 2,700 jobs in a one-year period from December 1992 to the same month last year. The service-producing sector -- which includes wholesale and retail trade, transportation and public utilities and finance and real estate -- lost 3,600 jobs for the period. There were another 800 jobs lost in construction and mining.
 
A Longer Work Week
 By contrast, general merchandise stores in the county -- department stores like Bradlees, for example -- saw an increase of 700 jobs, and health services recorded 400 new jobs for the period.
The work week in Westchester, however, grew longer over the year, with manufacturing reporting that it had gone to 41.9 hours last December -- the longest work week on record -- from 40.5 the year before, said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist with the State Department of Labor. Workers in the transportation industry, for example, recorded seven hours overtime during a sample work week.
But while employers have been adding hours, they have also been cautious about rehiring -- perhaps reflecting a lack of confidence about the long-range outlook for the economy, Mr. Surdey said.
One fallout from the layoffs is that many workers are toiling longer and harder to hold on to the jobs they have, especially as they witness fellow workers join the ranks of the unemployed. The work load that was shared by many has fallen on the shoulders of the relatively few left after downsizings.
 
Smaller Staffs Under Pressure
 Herbert Levitt, 56, an art director from Larchmont who works for a Manhattan advertising agency, lost his job last year but recently found full-time employment. Grateful to be working again, he said he was putting in more hours and taking work home on weekends.
"I've watched mergers and firings in this industry and have seen people around me lose their jobs," Mr. Levitt said. "And you can't say anymore, 'I'll see you Monday,' because that attitude doesn't hold in a tight job market."
Mr. Surdey cautioned that the smaller staffs responsible for keeping up the output "can't go on doing that forever, because they are going to get burned out."
Looking ahead, the economists said that the outlook is not promising for unemployed workers trying to retrain for new fields, especially if they expect to re-enter the work force at their former salaries.
"When displaced workers retrain or go into business for themselves, statistics show they don't get back on the same income track," Mr. Spitznas said. "There is always the occasional success story, like when someone invents something, but that doesn't happen too often."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A line of jobless workers at the New York State Department of Labor office in White Plains spills out the door into the lobby. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Supplies Of Blood Decline

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
While many parts of the country are reporting that blood supplies have dropped to the lowest level since World War II, blood bank officials in Westchester and the greater New York region say they have been able to maintain a two-to-three-day supply.
"The blood supply is a little soft," said Vivien Epstein, an associate administrator for Hudson Valley Blood Services in Elmsford. "We should have a five-day supply, but we are O.K." The organization supplies blood and blood products to about 50 hospitals in the Bronx, Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess, Rockland, Orange, Ulster and Sullivan Counties. 
 Ms. Epstein added: "Sometime in November, we had a five-day supply, but after that it dropped off, as it traditionally does over the holidays. December is usually the most difficult time for us."
Even though the shortage was not being called an emergency, the organization was nevertheless "concerned," Ms. Epstein said.
 
Layoffs Have Affected Supply
 In January, the normal after-holiday rebound in the number of blood donations did not occur, most likely because of severe weather and flu outbreaks, officials said.
Blood supplies have also been affected by the weak economy and job layoffs. "We have been hard hit by the downsizing," Ms. Epstein said. "Traditionally we depend very heavily on the business community. It's had a domino effect, because people's priorities change. If you are looking for a job, or worried about the one you have, giving blood is not the first thing on your mind."
Also, with a leaner work force, there have been fewer donors in the companies where Hudson Valley Blood Services holds its regular drives.
Donations from people 17 and older in the Hudson Valley fell to 5,000 units of blood, about 1,000 short of the goal last month. Ms. Epstein said that from April 1993 to this March, Hudson Valley Blood Services would need 73,125 units.
 
Million Units a Year
 At the New York Blood Center in Manhattan, the parent organization for Hudson Valley Blood Services, Andrea Smith, a spokeswoman, said that in the region there was a two-and-a-half-day supply of blood, or about 4,500 units.
"We are a little bit short of Type O," she said. "Hospitals like to keep that on hand." The center also has a low inventory of Type B.
The New York Blood Center, which supplies parts of New Jersey, all of Long Island and the Hudson Valley region, is the largest blood center in the country, distributing about a million units of blood each year to 260 hospitals. The American Red Cross, which collects and processes about 50 percent of the blood transfused in the United States, does not serve this area.
The chronically ill -- those with cancer, heart conditions and terminal illnesses -- are the primary recipients of blood transfusions, Ms. Smith said. Chemotherapy patients, especially, need blood platelets, which aid clotting following treatment.
 
Bone Marrow Processing
 Blood plasma, the liquid portion of blood, contains mostly water but also hasproteins and other nutrients needed by burn victims and hemophiliacs.
Red cells, the third component of blood, are often needed during surgery and for accident victims.
While most donors give whole blood, some are apheresisdonors. During an apheresis process, platelets or plasma are processed out for transfusions, and the remaining components of the blood are returned to the body.
In addition to whole blood and apheresis donations, Hudson Valley Blood Services also performs bone marrow processing and storage, tissue typing for the National Marrow Donor Program and rare blood typing.
Ms. Epstein said that fear of contracting diseases like AIDS has deterred some potential donors. But she explained that all materials used to draw and collect blood are sterile and are used only once before they are discarded.
 
Quick Replenishing
 It is estimated that 95 percent of the population will require a blood transfusion or blood product at least once, and 1 out of every 10 people admitted to hospitals require blood, according to Hudson Valley Blood Services. Yet fewer than 4 percent of the population donate, while 40 percent in the region are considered qualified to do so.
After a donation, the body replenishes the liquid portion of the blood within 72 hours, and the red cells within 2 to 4 weeks. A donor can give whole blood every 56 days, while apheresis donations can be made as often as every 72 hours.
Anyone in good health between the ages of 17 and 76 who weighs at least 110 pounds can give blood. Those over 76 can give with the written consent of a doctor.
Those interested in giving blood should call (800) 843-2566 for information on times and places. Donors are asked to bring picture identification with them.

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Black or White? Labels Don't Always Fit

BYLINE: By Michael Eric Dyson; Michael Eric Dyson is the author of "Reflecting Black: African-American Cultural Criticism."

 BODY:
AT ITS BEST, POP MUSIC PRESSES an anxious ear to American society, amplifying our deepest desires and fears. At times, too, pop invites us to listen to ourselves in ways forbidden by cultural debates where complexity is sacrificed for certainty. In this vein, the reascent to the top of the charts of Mariah Carey's newest album, "Music Box," signals more than her musical dominance.
Part of Ms. Carey's significance -- and undoubtedly the sharpest controversy around her -- has nothing to do with the singer's musical gifts. Instead it derives from the confusion and discomfort that her multiracial identity provokes in an American culture obsessed with race. Though she has made no secret that she is biracial (her mother is Irish-American, her father is a black Venezuelan), Ms. Carey's candor evokes clashing responses from fans and critics. Some see her statement of mixed heritage as a refusal to bow to public pressure to choose whether she is black or white. But in light of the "one drop" rule -- where a person is considered black by virtue of having one drop of black blood, a holdover from America's racist past -- many conclude that the issue of racial identity, for Ms. Carey and other interracial people, is settled. 
 To make matters more complex, Ms. Carey's vocal style is firmly rooted in black culture. It features a soaring soprano and an alternately ethereal and growling melisma that pirouettes around gospel-tight harmonies. So if she's not clearly black yet sings in a black style, is she singing black music? And what difference does it make? Without even trying, Ms. Carey's music sparks reflections about how race continues to shape what we see and hear.
Partly what's at stake is the messy, sometimes arbitrary, politics of definition and categorization. What makes music "black music," and who can be said to legitimately perform it? Consider the fiery fusion of rock, soul and blues performed by Lenny Kravitz (like Ms. Carey, the child of an interracial marriage) and Terence Trent D'Arby, or the socially conscious hard rock of the group Living Color. Is theirs black music? Though the answer is often negative, the roots of their music can be traced to black cultural influences, from Howlin' Wolf to Jimi Hendrix. The difficulty of fixing labels to what Mr. Kravitz, Mr. D'Arby and Living Color do highlights the racial contradictions at the center of contemporary pop music.
Behind this painful, often protracted struggle to get at the "original article" is what can only be termed the anxiety of authenticity. Such quests are more than academic for black folk because of the history of appropriation and abuse of black musical styles by white performers and producers. While black artists like King Oliver and Chuck Berry initiated musical innovations from jazz to blues-based rock, the public recognition and economic benefits due them evaporated, while derivative white artists like Benny Goodman and Elvis Presley reaped huge artistic and financial rewards.
Curiously enough, the debate over authenticity lies at the heart of hip-hop, though irreverence and transgression are staples of rap culture. But authenticity, even in a genre as closely identified with black culture as rap, does not strictly follow the rules of race. For instance, while the white rapper Vanilla Ice was greeted within hip-hop with derision because he came off as a white boy trying to sound black, white rap groups like Third Bass and House of Pain have been enthusiastically embraced because of their "legitimate" sounds and themes. Conversely, black rap artists like Hammer and Fresh Prince have been widely viewed as sellouts because of their music's pop propensities.
An even thornier issue is the belief in many black communities that some artists obscure their racial roots in a natural but lamentable response to a racist environment. As a result, they benefit from being black (given the extraordinary popularity of black music) but do not identify with the black people who support them before they discover a crossover market. In the extreme, this circumstance leads to the ideal of the pan-ethnic, omni-racial artist, an exotic fantasy whose energy derives from an implicit denial of the inherent value of simply being black.
Still, as the saying goes, the finger pointed at artists implies several others pointed back at ourselves. American culture is redefining itself through bitter debates about "identity politics," "multiculturalism" and "universalism." Music cannot be naively expected to triumph over social differences. Because of the schmaltz that often passes for conscience in pop, the quest for transcendence -- whether of race or, for that matter, sex and class -- is often hindered by sappy appeals to brotherhood and oneness. What such impulses reflect is a desire to fix what has gone wrong in a culture intolerant of difference.
THE ANXIETY of authenticity about what and who is really black in pop music is proportional to just how increasingly difficult it is to know the answer. As multiracial unions of sex and sound proliferate, the "one drop" rule may lose its power. And, as cultural theorists are now proud to announce, race is not merely a matter of biology but an artifice of cultural convention. Such a construction is meant to establish and reinforce the power of one group over another. This view does not mean that black music is solely the product of perception. Nor does it mean that black music's power must be diluted to a generic form. What it does suggest, however, is that the meaning of race, like the art it molds, is always changing.
In the end, what Ms. Carey's career may teach us is that paranoia about purity is the real enemy of black cultural expression, which at its best has been characterized by the amalgamation of radically different elements. It is precisely in stitching together various fabrics of human and artistic experience that black musical artists have expressed their genius and grit.

HEADLINE: SUITS CHALLENGING REDRAWN DISTRICTS THAT HELP BLACKS

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 13

 BODY:
A year after Congressional redistricting sent a record number of minority lawmakers to Capitol Hill, newly created black Congressional districts face a rising tide of court challenges that may threaten those electoral gains.
At stake are not just the future of the districts and the representatives being challenged. At issue is a tangle of politics and race that has the potential to affect the nature of districts, from city councils to Congress, and the makeup of Congress at a time when President Clinton is trying to maintain the fragile margin of support in the House that provided him with legislative victories in his first year in office. 
 The challenges stem from a United States Supreme Court ruling last June in Shaw v. Reno, a case that challenged a predominantly black district that snakes across 160 miles of North Carolina. The state, defending the district's shape, said that the 12th Congressional District had an urban identity that went beyond race and that it had complied with Federal dictates to enhance black representation in a state that, before 1992, had not had a black member of Congress for nearly a century.
 
'Racial Gerrymandering'
 But the Supreme Court ordered a district court to review the contention by the plaintiffs, who are white voters in the 12th District, that the district, which stretches from Durham to Charlotte, is a form of "racial gerrymandering" that isolates black voters in an artificial entity whose only justification is race.
Seven months later, the ruling is being used by some disgruntled white voters and politicians to challenge electoral districts from North Carolina to California, from hospital boards to Congressional seats.
"Everybody is raising this Shaw v. Reno argument from the smallest town you can think of, right on up to Congress," said Laughlin McDonald, a lawyer at the American Civil Liberties Union in Georgia who specializes in voting rights. "It's really a movement now."
But the main focus of the suits has been on Congressional districts.
 
Other Challenges
 Last December, a Federal District Court in Louisiana rejected Louisiana's Fourth Congressional District, which zigzags across that state, picking up black voters. In January, white voters and politicians filed a suit challenging Georgia's 260-mile-long 11th Congressional District, which covers a swath of central Georgia from Atlanta to Savannah. And next month, a Federal District Court in North Carolina will hear the state's defense of the 160-mile-long 12th Congressional District, which runs along Interstate 85.
Suits have also been filed challenging new Congressional districts in Florida and Texas. All are elongated or oddly shaped and represented by first-term black legislators. They are among the 50 or so districts, mostly in the South, created after the 1990 census to make minority representation in Congress more closely resemble minority presence in the population; these districts were also intended to comply with the Voting Rights Act, which was passed in 1965 and amended in 1982. The 1982 amendment stipulated that the law was meant to apply not just to discriminatory practices but to serve as a vehicle for voting practices that would increase minority representation.
It is not clear what standards the courts will eventually adopt and how many of the challenges will prove substantial. But blacks in the House, who saw their numbers grow to 39, from 26, after the 1992 redistricting process, are angry over what they regard as an effort to overturn black electoral gains.
"This is an epidemic now," said Representative Cynthia McKinney, the first-term Democrat from Georgia's sprawling 11th District. "The agenda is to turn back the hands of the clock and to put minorities back in the back of the bus."
 
Question Once Thought Closed
 But the challenges do raise vexing questions about whether the law guarantees opportunity or outcome -- the right to have a fair electoral system or the right to have adequate minority representation -- that until last year were thought to have been settled but that are now wide open. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, writing the Supreme Court's opinion last year, summed up the concerns when she said that the North Carolina district "bears an uncomfortable resemblance to political apartheid."
Alan Slobodin of the Washington Legal Foundation, a conservative legal organization, agreed with the concerns voiced by Justice O'Connor. "We think the pendulum has swung too far toward a kind of racial Balkanization that's intolerable from a constitutional standpoint," he said.
Under prodding from the Justice Department during the Bush Administration, redistricting based on the 1990 census produced a historic increase in minority representation in Congress. But to achieve that, state legislators fashioned some of the most unusual-looking districts that Congress has seen.
 
'Sherman's March'
 North Carolina's 12th District, represented by Melvin Watt, a black lawyer serving his first term as a Democratic Congressman, has been described as one in which a politician could drive on I-85 with the car doors open and hit every voter in the district. Louisiana's Fourth District, represented by Cleo Fields, a black former state senator in his first term as a Democratic Congressman, has been compared to the mark of Zorro. Georgia's 11th District, represented by Ms. McKinney, is known by some as "Sherman's March," recalling the path of the Civil War general's drive from Atlanta to the Atlantic.
The Supreme Court ruling on June 26 did not throw out North Carolina's districting plan; it sent it back to the district court for review. But in December, a three-judge Federal panel in Shreveport used the Court's language in the North Carolina case to justify rejecting the shaping of Louisiana's Fourth District. Citing Justice O'Connor's words, the Louisiana panel said the district was a product of "racial gerrymandering" and was not "narrowly tailored to further any compelling governmental interest." Louisiana officials are appealing, but if the decision is upheld, the state will be forced to redraw its map, changing not just the Fourth but other districts as well. The representatives who hold those seats, however, would not be summarily removed from office; rather, they would have to seek re-election from revised districts.
"There's an element out there that has no interest in seeing minorities have any representation that will always be there, unless there's a legal standard that makes them understand they can't win," Mr. Watt said. "The Supreme Court ruling was almost an invitation to attack these districts."
 
'Political Apartheid'
 But critics say the districts make a mockery of traditional geographic boundaries and create artificial districts predicated almost entirely on race. "It's basically political apartheid," said Larry Chesin, a lawyer for the Georgia plaintiffs, who included one of the white candidates who lost to Ms. McKinney.
Race has inflamed the issue, but the districts have as much to do with partisan politics as race. Some Democrats complain that George Bush's Justice Department was the guiding force behind the districts, intending to segregate black voters into a few black districts that would be Democratic while creating a lot of white districts that would be Republican.
Others say the biggest factor in the districts' odd shapes was the need of white Democratic incumbents to retain as many black voters from their districts as existed before 1992.
David Bositis, a senior researcher at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington research organization specializing in issues affecting blacks, said North Carolina's 12th District, often cited as the most bizarre-looking of all, reflected the needs not of blacks but of white Democrats in districts like North Carolina's Second District. There, Tim Valentine, a Democrat, won with 55 percent of the vote in a district where blacks are 20 percent of the electorate.
 
To Whose Benefit?
 "The idea that the two black districts were drawn to rope in black voters is total baloney," Mr. Bositis said. "They were drawn to protect the six white incumbents."
He also said the idea that Mr. Watts's district ghettoizes black voters was equally wrongheaded. With an electorate that is 53 percent black, the district has racial balance close enough to offer the potential of being represented by a white, he said. And critics of the Supreme Court ruling say that focusing on what the Court called the district's "bizarre" shape sets a maddeningly subjective standard that ignores the widespread practice of creating odd-looking districts for other purposes.
But in other districts, like Louisiana's Fourth, which is 64 percent black, it is hard to argue that the district is not anything other than a designated black seat. And skeptics say there is something dangerous about an electoral system in which blacks and whites are increasingly segregated into districts in which whites represent whites and blacks represent blacks.
"If you have a kind of racial segregation built into the electoral districts, that has to increase racial polarization in the society," said Merle Black, a professor of politics and government at Emory University in Atlanta.
Carol M. Swain, a political science professor at Princeton University and author of "Black Faces, Black Interests: The Representation of African-Americans in Congress (Harvard University Press, 1993) said the real losers could be black politicians. By pushing for largely black districts, they may insure easy victories in Congress, but they will also fail to generate broader support that can carry them to higher office.
The effort to give minorities the political representation that their numbers warrant without skewing the political process solely along racial lines has proved to be politically explosive. For example, the nomination of Lani Guinier, President Clinton's original choice to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, fell apart when some of her solutions -- significantly different from the ones now under court challenge -- were used to cast her as a radical.
Even proponents of the districts under attack say they are imperfect solutions to the reality that blacks often face extreme hurdles to winning in districts that do not have a black majority. The result, they say, has been a success in terms of providing better choices to black voters, but, they continue, it has also been a social experiment inflamed by emotional issues of race.
"This was the first time in the history of this country that the reapportionment process was subject to some form of fairness guarantee beyond the one person, one vote standard," said Dayna Cunningham, a lawyer with the Voting Rights Project of the N.A.A.C.P Legal Defense Fund. "It's like you put your foot in the water and the water's cold, you feel shocked, and you pull it out."

HEADLINE: Beyond Pigs and Quilts in Cooperative Extension;
In New York City, Growing Trout in the Bronx and Teaching About AIDS and Drugs

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
Philson Warner showed off the catfish and striped bass that he was rearing in dozens of gurgling tanks and plastic garbage bins in a makeshift laboratory in the South Bronx, remembering with some antipathy the time the central oxygen pump expired for a day and hundreds of fish simultaneously moved heavenward. He didn't care to talk much about the occasional floods.
He nodded at his vegetables and spices -- celery, spinach, basil -- being grown hydroponically in nutrient-rich solution. That is how you do things when you are a high-rise farmer. He's working on a device that will hang from the ceiling. "Won't take up as much space, great for the city," he said. "Listen, I'm always dreaming." 
 People squeezed for money trickle into the lab and are presented food, exchanging only thanks. The fish eventually become dinner at shelters. And children are recruited from the surrounding moldering neighborhood to work in the lab in the hope that they will choose to learn about science rather than deviance.
 
Starting Fish Farms
 "We want to show the kids that this isn't so bad," Mr. Warner said. "Science can be a neat can of worms. We've had people start fish farms."
Mr. Warner is one of about five dozen people working for the Cornell Cooperative Extension's New York City operation, what at first blush seems an indisputable oxymoron. Cooperative Extension programs, spawned by the Federal Government in 1914, were intended to funnel practical knowledge to a rural America. Their inappropriateness for a city famously low in corn production and pathetic in the number of hogs bred for market was so obvious that no one even bothered to try an extension program in New York for decades.
"I grew up in New York and thought extension was all agriculture and home economics -- pigs and quilts -- and that is the stereotype that it still has," said Ruth Allen, who is now the director of Cornell Cooperative Extension's New York City operation. "But extension has so much application to the city of New York."
Sure, it's dicey trying to raise cows on West End Avenue, but trout grow fine in the Bronx. Certainly, sewing doesn't do a lot for hyperactive New York children, but they like working in soup kitchens. The extension started a "Confabulator Program," where parents visit their children's schools to tell family stories. It has a "Master Angler" program that trains adult fishermen to teach children to fish off the piers as a way to make them ecologically aware.
And, of course, the gardens. The Cornell Extension operation oversees 13,000 community and home gardens, many in formerly blighted lots, that generate about $1 million a year in crops. One important piece of distinctly urban advice dispensed by the gardening experts is to pick the crops as soon as they ripen or else they will be stolen, a snippet less pertinent for the five acres cultivated on well-guarded Rikers Island.
Moreover, the New York operation has bent the mandate somewhat to be relevant. It has a program dealing with rehabilitating decaying apartment buildings. It sings the virtues of monitoring water quality. There is a literacy program. It teaches about AIDS and resisting drugs. In fact, as the peculiar ills of the cities have crept into rural and suburban areas, many rural extension programs have expanded their scope, too, in effect mimicking the New York operation.
 
First, Food Prices and Grades
 Two laws created Cooperative Extension. The Morrill Act of 1862 set up a land-grant university in each state aimed at making education available to the children of the working class. Then the Smith-Lever Act of 1914 dictated that all land-grant colleges initiate programs to disperse practical information into the community. Given the times, the principal information to be shared related to agriculture and home economics. The program fell under the auspices of the United States Department of Agriculture.
In the wake of the laws, Cornell, the state's land-grant school, began an extension program in each of the state's 57 counties -- except for New York City. Not until 1948 did Cornell give the city a whirl, confining itself to a service that furnished information about food prices and grades. Two people staffed it. Not until the mid-1960's did the city operation branch into programs in broader consumer education and later a service to train tenants about caring for their housing.
The New York Extension program now employs 20 full-time staff members and 42 paraprofessionals, who operate under a $4.6 million budget supplied by the Federal Government, the state and private grants. The program has chosen to go where it feels most needed -- the direst broken-down neighborhoods.
 
Still Unsung Soldiers
 Dozens of programs hum along, and Ms. Allen wants the operation to increasingly focus more on broader issues. "We still want to help low- income families increase their consumption of vegetables," she said. "But these families have lots of problems. We want to help them manage their money and deliver parenting education. We're talking in Far Rockaway about helping that community create an infrastructure to deal with water quality.
"Con Edison funds us to try to reduce energy expenditures in targeted communities, and so we show people how to caulk windows and tell them about energy-efficient light bulbs. We are now looking at helping communities influence public policy."
The extension people would not mind being noticed a bit more. In rural expanses of New York State, just about everyone knows the extension people and a healthy proportion solicit their wisdom. The city extension agents remain unsung soldiers.
Shielding her face from the brittle wind, impassive to her own anonymity, Raquel Rios trudged along West 174th Street in Washington Heights and settled on a building. "This area is not so bad," she said. "There aren't too many drug dealers."
She is a nutrition educator for Cornell Cooperative. Harlem and Washington Heights are her milieu. By knocking cold on doors, her goal is to uncover families that can profit from better nutritional and food safety information. In recent years, she has also diversified into waste and money-management tips.
When she finds a willing party, she leaves some literature and takes the name. She then arranges to visit the candidate periodically and school them in depth.
 
Helping With Nutrition
 A quizzical woman cradling a toddler answered the door at 551 West 174th Street. Ms. Rios identified herself and gave a quick pitch. "I don't have time now," the woman said. "I can give you five minutes." She beckoned Ms. Rios in. Her name was Maria Baez.
Could she use some help with her nutrition? Ms. Rios asked.
"Yes, my son is a picky eater," she said. "Yams, beans. I'd like to get him to eat more things. Some days he doesn't want to eat anything. He doesn't want to drink milk anymore."
Ms. Rios took her number and left some basic material, including sample recipes for peanut butter roll-ups, orange smoothie and chili-bean dip.
A cornerstone of extension programs are 4-H clubs (the head, heart, hands and health operations). New York City and 4-H don't seem to mix. How can a youth living on West 54th Street raise a plump chicken that he can enter in a county fair?
It's not encouraged. But the New York Extension program began sponsoring 4-H clubs in the mid-1980's and has 30 now. They study photography, clean up parks, read and sing to the elderly and learn about that quintessential New York animal, the pigeon.
On East 34th Street, the subject was Maria. She has it hard. She has three children, one a teen-ager seemingly glued to the phone. She is divorced from her husband and is paid less than $20,000 a year as a nurse's aide. Her debts are in anarchy. Her dream is to own a washer and dryer.
Maria was under scrutiny in conference room A at the East 34th Street headquarters of the New York Extension operation, as the embodiment of one of the newest programs: teaching low-income women to manage their finances.
Assembled around tables were 24 people from social-service agencies in the Bronx. They were being trained to help their needy clients. Maria was a composite character patched together by Hada Lugo de Slosser, a Cornell consumer-education program leader, who teaches the workshop.
This day, Maria was planning a family celebration. She had 16 people coming and probably needed $75 to pay for it. But the class skipped down the list and determined that Maria's sister could bring the pumpkin and apple pies. They shaved the soda bill. Eventually, they wrung a good $20 or so out of the cost through intelligent shopping. Maria could have her celebration, Ms. Lugo de Slosser said.
"Next time," she went on, "we will help Maria start saving. Then she can think about that washer and dryer. Won't that be nice?"
