SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 3118 words

HEADLINE: Court-Appointed Defense Offers the Poor a Lawyer, But the Cost May Be High

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANNISTON, Ala.

 BODY:
For Jimmy Davis, a 23-year-old accused of murdering a sales clerk in a robbery attempt, the justice system moved with frightening speed: After a five-day trial in December, it took 90 minutes for a jury to find him guilty of murder and two hours for it to recommend that he be put to death in the electric chair.
As Calhoun County sheriff's deputies led the lanky defendant with protruding, frightened eyes from the courtroom, he softly muttered under his breath: "This ain't right. This is wrong." 
 But lawyers who specialize in capital-case appeals say Mr. Davis's experience was unsurprising, given the weakness of his defense.
Assigned to the case in March, when the slaying occurred, Mr. Davis's defense lawyers say they began investigating the case in earnest "a few weeks before" the trial started on Dec. 6.
During the trial the prosecution put forth 28 witnesses and the defense just one. Though an intelligence test showed Mr. Davis to have an I.Q. placing him between the mentally retarded and the low average, no experts were put forward to address his mental competence or to discuss the effects of his harsh childhood.
 
Short Shrift for a Life
 Little effort was made to present Mr. Davis as a three-dimensional person. No motion was made for a change of venue, even though the case had caused a furor about street crime in Anniston, a city of 30,000 people in northeastern Alabama about halfway between Atlanta and Birmingham. Prospective jurors were not questioned about racial attitudes, even though Mr. Davis is black and the clerk he was convicted of murdering was white.
Nothing the defense did was blatantly negligent, say death penalty experts who were asked to examine this case. In fact, in an interview after the trial, the prosecutor gave the defense lawyers credit for shrewdly getting the judge to allow the jury to consider a lesser murder charge.
But the death penalty experts said the defense of Jimmy Davis fell into the vast gray area of lackluster or routine efforts given most indigent suspects in capital cases. And that, they say, is the problem: Regardless of Mr. Davis's guilt or innocence, no one's life should be disposed of so casually.
"The cases that involve the highest stakes and the most difficult constitutional issues are given very short shrift," said Stephen B. Bright, director of the Southern Center for Human Rights and a professor at Yale Law School. "I find it immensely troubling when the life of a person is dispensed of in three or four days when we spend months on civil litigation involving say the licensing of Cabbage Patch dolls or the secret behind Coca-Cola's syrup."
When Judge Malcolm Street Jr. sentences Jimmy Davis on Feb. 14 he has two choices: life without parole, or death. If the judge follows the jury's recommendation, Mr. Davis, a high school dropout who has lived all his life in this city, will join 125 other Alabama inmates on death row.
 
Defense for $20 an Hour
 If this case follows the typical course, a sentence of death will be just the start of a tortuous journey through state and Federal appellate courts that could last years and cost tens of thousands of dollars in public money. Increasingly, what consumes the courts as death sentences are appealed is the extent and adequacy of the defense at the trial stage.
Often, that defense is inexperienced and ill-paid. Mr. Davis was represented by two relatively experienced court-appointed lawyers, Jonathan Adams, who had worked on four previous capital cases, and Steve Giddens, who had worked on two; in all cases their clients were convicted.
While fees for lawyers in private cases usually start at $125 an hour, court-appointed lawyers in Alabama capital cases are paid $20 an hour for out-of-court work. The state assumes a lawyer needs no more than 100 hours to prepare for each phase of the trial and pays a maximum of $1,000 for a trial. Because the penalty part of the trial after a decision is reached on guilt is considered, lawyers are entitled to another $1,000 for that. The lawyers are paid $40 an hour for work in the courtroom.
These kinds of fees are common in court-appointed systems around the country. Most lawyers, including those for Mr. Davis's case, insist that money is not a consideration in their work.
But critics of the Alabama system of indigent representation say that many lawyers put in only the amount of work that is commensurate with the fee and that 100 hours is not enough to research a capital case. The fee system, said Bryan A. Stevenson, head of the Alabama Capital Resource Center, amounts to "a built-in disincentive for thorough representation."
Another problem with systems like Alabama's, these critics say, is the dependence of the lawyers on judges for appointment to cases. Often, particularly in small towns, a deference or coziness among judge, lawyer and prosecutor can arise, discouraging aggressive advocacy for the accused.
Mr. Bright said he had found that "getting the death penalty was not so much the result of how bad the crime was or how bad the defendant was, but how bad the lawyer was."
 
The Crime
Instead of Money, A Man's Death
 Around dusk on March 17, 1993, while Anniston was digging out from a freak snowstorm, two men with bandanas and sweatshirt hoods hiding their faces walked toward the Direct Oil gas station near downtown. Johnny Hazle, a 50-year-old clerk at the combination self-service station and convenience store for seven years, was talking with his friend Dewey Waites, a 65-year-old retiree.
According to accounts by the police, the lead man pulled out a .25-caliber semi-automatic pistol, pointed it at Mr. Hazle and shouted at him to give him the money. When Mr. Hazle, either ruefully or nervously, laughed and looked toward Mr. Waites, the gunman fired at least two shots, hitting Mr. Hazle in his chest and lower back. Mr. Waites, who was behind Mr. Hazle and never saw either intruder, ducked to the floor, and the men fled without any money.
The next day, acting on a tip, the Anniston police arrested Jimmy Davis, Alphonso Phillips, then 17 years old, and his cousin, Terrance Phillips, then 16. They later found the handgun used in the robbery hidden under bushes and old awnings in the backyard of the house belonging to the Phillipses' grandmother.
The police would later say that the plan to rob the station was hatched as the three walked there from the Carver Community Center that evening and that it was Mr. Davis who had led the group and fired the fatal shot. The police said Alphonso Phillips was supposed to get the money and Terrance Phillips had been designated the lookout but had gotten scared and left before the shooting.
 
The Pretrial Phase
Few Seeds Planted For an Appeal
 Jimmy Davis's court dossier in the Calhoun County Circuit Court clerk's office is a thin one for a case involving a capital offense. Its lack of heft reflects the fact that his lawyers did not pepper the court with pretrial motions, which outside lawyers said could have served a variety of purposes in effectively advocating for Mr. Davis.
Motions for actions like a change of the trial's location, the suppression of some evidence crucial to the prosecution case, or the use of questions that should be raised to explore jurors' attitudes could have clearly signaled the prosecution that it faced more than token opposition. Such motions might also have made the prosecutor more willing to consider a plea bargain for Mr. Davis that would have spared him the death penalty.
Even if no motions succeed, by raising them and then objecting to their denial, defense lawyers preserve them for reargument on appeal. Under state law, the failure to raise issues like prejudicial publicity or racial bias at the trial level precludes their being raised at all on appeal in the state courts.
Experienced death penalty defense lawyers said in interviews that it should not be uncommon to file 50 to 100 pretrial motions in such cases.
"Sometimes the most important race is the race to the courthouse to see who gets there first to make a deal with the prosecutor," Mr. Bright said. "And pretrial motions can put your client in a better position to make a deal."
Between last March, when their client was arrested, and Dec. 6 when jury selection began, Mr. Adams and Mr. Giddens filed six, mostly routine, motions. A potentially significant motion, requesting psychological screening of Mr. Davis, was filed just a week before the trial.
"I don't believe in filing a lot of frivolous motions," said Mr. Giddens when asked about his actions before the trial. "I'm not in the habit of filing motions that I can't argue. There was never any offer of a plea bargain from the district attorney. I explored that possibility but there was no offer. There were no statements made by my client that should have been suppressed, and so I don't know what else we could have filed."
 
The Investigation
Building a Case In Several Weeks
 Mr. Giddens said that he and Mr. Adams started investigating Mr. Davis's case in earnest "a few weeks before" the start of trial. At another point Mr. Adams put the start at two weeks before.
Outside experts in capital cases say that in trials involving charges against more than one person it is essential for a lawyer to keep track of the others and their legal maneuvers because they might make a deal with prosecutors and turn against his client.
It was in early October that Terrance Phillips, who was accused of agreeing to be the lookout and was charged with capital murder, made an agreement to plead guilty to robbery and accepted a 10-year sentence with the hope of probation in exchange for testifying against Mr. Davis.
Mr. Giddens, who with Mr. Adams practices primarily in neighboring Talladega County, said he did not learn about the plea until early November, almost a month after it was entered.
He and Mr. Adams talked very briefly with Terrance once by accident about two weeks before the trial. They had gone to his grandmother's house to question his relatives about the discovery of the gun.
"They didn't know who I was at first, but then they asked me a few questions before I left," said Terrance Phillips in an interview. "My lawyer had told me how far to go in answering questions, but they didn't ask me that many."
Mr. Adams said Alphonso Phillips had refused to be interviewed, but he added that he and Mr. Giddens spoke with several other prosecution witnesses. The investigation also included several visits and talks with Mr. Davis.
Another important part of the two lawyers' investigation included a visit to Lillie Bell Davis, Mr. Davis's mother. She said she first saw her son's lawyer, Mr. Adams, when he knocked on her door unannounced late at night a week before trial. A timid woman who did not finish high school, Mrs. Davis said she was wary of him.
"He said that I had to get Jimmy's sisters to come to the trial and cry and beg for his life," Mrs. Davis said. But she said she was scared of him and did not trust him.
On Dec. 7, just as the lawyers were preparing for opening statements, the prosecutor, Joseph Hubbard, announced that Alphonso Phillips had entered a plea agreement. He would testify against Mr. Davis, naming him as the one who shot the clerk, and in exchange, Mr. Hubbard would lower his charge to robbery and recommend 20 years' imprisonment.
 
The Trial
Issues Are Left Unexplored
 Jury selection in a case involving a black defendant and a white victim that failed to take pains to qualify black jurors would be almost automatic grounds for appeal and reversal under the United States Supreme Court's 1986 ruling in Batson v. Kentucky, which prohibits "systematic discrimination" on the basis of race.
In this case, the trial court came up with a racially diverse jury, starting with 16 blacks in a pool of 127 people and seating a jury of eight whites and four blacks -- 33 percent black, exceeding the county proportion of 18 percent.
But the makeup of the jury was somewhat misleading. The panel included four jurors in occupations generally viewed as fostering sympathy for law-enforcement officials. The jurors were a black former military policeman, a black former Anniston police officer, a female postal worker and a female nursing technician in the emergency room at the local hospital.
In selecting the jury, Mr. Giddens and Mr. Adams probed the candidates' feelings about the extent of crime in the community but avoided any questions to white jurors about their racial attitudes, including whether they lived in all-white neighborhoods or sent their children to segregated schools. Such questions, they said, would do more to awaken racial prejudice and "we wanted to stay as far away from that as possible," Mr. Giddens said.
Other defense lawyers like Mr. Bright and Mr. Stevenson insist that queries about racial attitudes of jurors in cases where the victim is white and the accused is black are often essential to provide adequate and aggressive representation. Lack of such questioning can be used as part of an appeal, they said.
Just before the trial, Mr. Adams said that no matter what he and Mr. Giddens did they would end up being second-guessed by lawyers who would handle his appeals in the event of a guilty verdict. Noting that such appeals in Alabama are handled by Mr. Stevenson's Alabama Capital Resource Center, he said that expertise could be better used at the trial level to prevent possible errors.
With Mr. Davis's decision not to take the stand, the core of the defense strategy seemed to be to shatter the credibility of the three main prosecution witnesses, Alphonso and Terrance Phillips and Willie Smith, a 21-year-old friend of the defendant. Mr. Smith, who was in jail on separate robbery charges at the time of trial, corroborated the Phillipses' testimony that Mr. Davis had talked about shooting Mr. Hazle.
During cross-examination, the lawyers confronted the witnesses with inconsistencies between their testimony and earlier statements to the police. The three witnesses invariably responded that they had been trying to evade punishment earlier but were now resigned to telling the truth.
The jury was told of the Phillipses' plea bargains, but the defense did not emphasize any motive the brothers might have to implicate Mr. Davis. Only once did a defense lawyer, Mr. Adams, suggest that perhaps it was Alphonso Phillips who actually pulled the trigger or that perhaps Willie Smith was at the scene rather than Jimmy Davis. But the suggestion was made almost in passing in closing arguments, and there was no evidence brought forward to support this.
The prosecutor, Mr. Hubbard, gave the defense lawyers credit for using testimony that Mr. Davis had said he would shoot the clerk in the leg if necessary to persuade the judge to give the jury an option of considering the lesser charge of felony murder, which carries a maximum sentence of life in prison. Mr. Hubbard said murder convictions had been overturned when the jury was not given that option.
 
Mitigating Evidence
Giving Accused A Human Face
 While a 1984 Supreme Court decision, Strickland v. Washington, found that the Sixth Amendment right to counsel did not necessarily mean a right to have a "meaningful attorney-client relationship," many lawyers who handle death penalty cases say that effective representation almost requires such a relationship to present the client as a human being.
"The evidence presented should weave a fabric of the defendant's life -- triumphs and successes as well as failures and obstacles," wrote Welsh S. White, a professor at the University of Pittsburgh law school in a recent article in the University of Illinois Law Review. "Vivid details are important. In presenting this evidence, one of the goals is to make the sentencer see the defendant as an individual who is connected to other lives."
However, Jimmy Davis sat alone as the jury heard evidence about his role in the crime. Mrs. Davis said she could not get time off from her job as a maid at the Holiday Inn. Throughout this phase the main picture of Jimmy Davis was sketched by the prosecution. It showed him as a rootless, purposeless young man who had dropped out of school, been put out of his mother's house and spent his days wandering the streets aimless and unemployed.
Only after the guilty verdict, during the sentencing phase, did Mr. Giddens and Mr. Adams seek to present their client in a different light and suggest mitigating factors that they hoped argued against a recommendation of the death penalty. And even then, those efforts fell short of standards highlighted by other lawyers familiar with such cases.
For the first time they called as a witness Mrs. Davis, who testified after her workday. She described her son's history of disciplinary problems and his growing up without a father after she and her husband separated when the boy was barely a year old. She asked the jury to show mercy.
Annie M. Story, a specialist in intelligence tests with the Calhoun County Mental Health Department, told of sitting with Mr. Davis for an hour and 15 minutes on Dec. 4, the Friday before the trial, and administering two tests. The results showed Mr. Davis to have an I.Q. of 77, placing him on the "borderline" in functioning, "somewhere between mentally retarded and low average," Ms. Story said.
Though the defense lawyers could have asked the court to finance further intelligence tests, they did not examine more thoroughly the possibility of mental retardation or brain damage.
An effort by defense lawyers to interview Mrs. Davis more extensively and to get access to medical records might have fleshed out other possibilities of brain damage and neurological problems.
When she was pregnant with Jimmy, Mrs. Davis told a reporter, her husband was abusing her and she did not care for herself properly. It affected the fetus, she said, and after a difficult birth, Jimmy was kept in the hospital for three weeks.
Later in his life, as she tried to guide him and discipline him in the only ways she knew, she said, she may have gone overboard. When Jimmy was 9 years old, a teacher at his school observed welts on his thighs and buttocks and reported it to social welfare agencies. Mrs. Davis said social workers visited her and warned her about possible child abuse charges.
"He was just 9, but he knew what they had told me," Mrs. Davis said ruefully. "That's when I slacked up with the whippings. I told him that if he didn't want to obey me, he must want the white man to come and raise him. Now here I am, running after him in this courthouse."

HEADLINE: Yen Soars and Stocks Fall on Collapse of Trade Talks

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 14

 BODY:
In the first sign of business's deep disappointment over the collapse of trade talks between Japan and the United States, the yen soared and share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply today.
The dollar settled at 105.90 yen in late trading here, down from 107.20 yen in New York late Friday. 
 The Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell 531.45 points, or 2.7 percent, to close at 19,459.25. Volume was very thin as most investors watched nervously from the sidelines. The exchange was closed on Friday because of a national holiday.
The failure of President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa to break the impasse over trade in Washington on Friday has led to speculation that the United States may impose sanctions against Japan.
In coming weeks, the Clinton Administration is expected to encourage a strong yen against the dollar as just one step to force Japan to come to terms on trade, analysts said.
 Ever since the Administration took office, it has tended to encourage a stronger yen as one means of shrinking Japan's yawning trade surpluses. A strong yen makes imports less expensive for the Japanese and tends to reduce exports by making Japanese goods more expensive for foreigners.
 The expectation that the United States would seek a strong yen prompted today's rise in the value of the yen.
"There were no signs of central bank involvement, but the feeling toward the dollar is overwhelmingly bearish," said Laurent Depus, a foreign exchange trader at Chase Manhattan Bank in Tokyo. "A stronger yen is considered almost part of the sanctions the U.S. will take."
A strong yen, however, is the last thing that the Japanese economy needs. It is still reeling from a two-year-old recession, and one of the key reasons the economy failed to recover last year was the rising value of the yen, which hit exporters and other manufacturers hard. That sent corporate profits plummeting and reduced industrial investment.
Worried about another round of corporate belt-tightening, investors sold off shares this morning. But the market has risen considerably over the last two months, and today's decline only reduced, rather than wiped out, those large gains.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

Companies
A tiny American Indian bank in Montana is challenging the insurance industry's hold on the lucrative annuity business. The move will have ramifications far beyond the reservation because insurance companies have been fighting to keep banks from encroaching into this area of their operations. [Page D1.] 
 The race for F.D.A. approval of artificial blood heats up. Among the benefits of a blood substitute are that it does not have types that must be matched and that it harbors no pathogens. [D1.]
QVC will not raise its bid for Paramount Communications, Barry Diller, QVC's chairman, said. Coming less than 48 hours ahead of the expiration of both QVC and Viacom's competing tender offers in the battle for control of Paramount -- and with Viacom still perceived to be the leader -- the statement was viewed by some traders and executives as tantamount to a concession. [D1.]
The U.S. Postal Service has collected more than $500,000 in fines over the last three years from companies that sent "nonurgent" mail by private couriers like Federal Express and DHL. Now private couriers and their customers are fighting back. Legislation has been introduced in Congress that stops the Postal Service from being able to investigate and intimidate companies into using the Postal Service instead of private couriers. [D2.]
 
The Economy
The toy industry is recycling old stars to extend their lives, reviving old hits that fell on hard times and sometimes even bringing back a flop to try once more. [D1.]
The overall operations of most large corporations were not greatly affected by the big winter storm on Friday. [D1.]
Increases in home heating oil prices are expected for customers in metropolitan New York because of increased fuel use and because many wholesalers are raising prices. [B2.]
 
International
Clinton Administration officials are considering a number of responses to Japan's rebuff of American trade demands. [D5.] The yen soared against the dollar and Japanese stocks fell on disappointment over the collapse of the trade talks. [D5.]
A nationwide strike in Germany's vital metalworking industry appeared nearly unavoidable after contract negotiations between labor and management broke down without resolving the crucial issues of wages, working hours and job security. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Redirecting Technology to Travelers From Troops

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
A steel net used on aircraft carriers to stop jet fighters from plunging into the sea is being tested at Illinois railroad crossings to stop cars from driving into the path of oncoming trains. Materials involved in the production of Stealth bombers are being used in the construction of a San Diego bridge, and a technology developed to simulate tank battles is being tested for the study of automobile traffic in urban areas.
The beating of swords into plowshares is booming in the world of transportation, where military technology is being applied to an array of new projects. Technology was the big winner in President Clinton's budget, and the Transportation Department proposed $692 million for research and development, a 14 percent increase over current spending. Of this amount, $425 million was for projects designed to enhance commercial applications of defense-related technology. 
 "We think transportation technologies are the most ripe for defense conversion," Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena said in a recent interview.
 
Replacement for Radar
 Transportation researchers are developing civilian uses for the Global Positioning System, a $10 billion network of 24 satellites that provides navigation information to American troops. The researchers hope to make this technology available to aircraft pilots, motorists, transit systems and ships.
The researchers also hope to use satellites to track civilian aircraft all over the world, replacing radar. They are steadily improving their ability to amass weather and flight information instantaneously, and give air traffic controllers a better sense of when and where to reroute aircraft.
"We're constantly refining the system and improving the quality of information," said Richard Wright, chief of automation applications at the Transporation Department's premier technology research center, the Volpe National Transportation Systems Center, in Cambridge, Mass.
Military technology involving sensors and computer information systems is also being used in the development of so-called "smart cars," whose sensors and computers exchange information with similarly equipped highways, enabling motorists to avoid traffic jams by using alternate routes. The new budget earmarks $289 million for this project.
Transportation researchers also hope to use lightweight, high strength material developed by the military to develop the first generation of "clean cars" with high gas mileage and low emissions, high-tech safety devices and super sophisticated air traffic controls. They are conducting studies on alternative fuels, lightweight buses and magnetic levitation trains.
But Mr. Pena stressed that the Administration was also committed to deployment and commercialization. He noted that many technologies developed in the United States were later commercialized abroad, including railroad technologies like magnetic levitation and the tilt trains.
"We're now trying to buy them from the Swedes and the Spaniards," Mr. Pena said of the two train technologies. "Let's not make that mistake again."
The Secretary noted that the Federal Government had a history of financing transportation programs, including the transcontinental railroad, the highway system and aerospace programs. "Investment in technology and in transportation systems has been critical to developing the vast continental economy of the United States ever since Colonial times," he said.
In addition to the Transportation Department's research programs, civilian transportation projects make up half the $475 million awarded last year for Technology Reinvestment Project programs overseen by the Pentagon's Advanced Research Projects Agency. These programs are matched by private sponsors on a 50-50 basis.
"Industry has to perceive that there is a market," said Noah Rifkin, the Transportation Department's director of technology deployment. "It helps us validate the importance of the technology, and therefore represents true defense conversion and dual-use capability."
The Technology Reinvestment Project received 2,800 applications last year requesting a total of more than $9 billion in grants. Last October, the President announced the first round of selections, 41 projects involving 272 industrial sponsors.
Transportation projects also get a large share of the research money awarded the National Institute of Science and Technology, whose budget will rise from $200 million this year to $750 million in 1997.
 
'Technology Secretary'
 In the broadest sense, the Federal Government this year budgeted $2.7 billion for transportation research and development, including projects in the Departments of Defense, Energy and Transportation, as well as National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Of this amount, $1.9 billion involved aviation, $585 million was for motor vehicles, $80 million was for railroad projects and $55 million for waterways.
The Volpe Center, the heart of the Transportation Department's technology programs, conducts and oversees $225 million in research projects annually. Twenty percent of this money is spent at the center, whose 550 researchers hold 250 advanced degrees including 65 Ph.D.'s. The remaining 80 percent of the money is awarded to consulting firms.
Dr. Richard R. John, the center's director, said that in recent years, "Transportation has not been a major constituent of the research and development community," adding, "It's been primarily a regulatory and grant-making agency."
But all that has changed, Dr. John said, because "Pena wants to be the 'technology secretary.' "
The center has no budget of its own. Each project is financed by a Federal agency, and the center's researchers speak of meeting their sponsors' goals. Dr. John said the center's mission was to "anticipate and create awareness of national, state, local and international transportation issues."
Mr. Pena noted that transportation accounted for 21 percent of the nation's economy, 50 percent of its petroleum consumption and 51 percent of ambient air pollution.
"We can't simply buy, build or invest our way out of these problems," Mr. Pena said. "We must turn to technology for solutions."

HEADLINE: U.S. Weighs Trade Actions on Japan

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
After Japan's rebuff of American trade demands, Clinton Administration officials said today that they had agreed that a swift response was needed but were struggling to find one unlikely to start a trade war.
"There is a unanimous understanding on the American side that there is a range of actions and that we will undoubtedly be choosing one or more of them," a senior official said. 
 The options under consideration range from very moderate ones, like ordering a study showing how Japan excludes imports in certain sectors, to instituting powerful sanctions, like reinstating the President's authority to use a potent trade law authorizing him to punish countries that systematically discriminate against American goods.
According to several officials, the Clinton Administration might take action against Japan as soon as Tuesday, when a deadline expires for Japan to announce plans to open up its cellular telephone market to foreign products.
 Several officials said the President's top economic advisers would meet Monday or Tuesday to discuss and perhaps decide what the response should be to the breakdown of trade talks on Friday during a visit by Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa.
Criticizing the Administration for trying to foist "managed trade" upon Japan, Mr. Hosokawa rejected demands that Japan agree to numerical indicators that would show whether it was opening markets.
 
 
Fear of a Trade War
 Scared of starting a trade war and of being accused of fomenting trade frictions, the Clinton Administration seems to be leaning toward what might be called "managed trade retaliation."
"You would find some sentiment in the Administration to react with a scalpel, and not with a blunt instrument," one senior policy maker said.
Whatever action is eventually decided, one official said, may be more of a veiled threat than formal retaliation. One possibility under consideration is for the Clinton Administration to announce some numerical criteria that it believes Japan should meet in terms of increasing imports in one or more industries.
After his breakfast with President Clinton on Saturday, Prime Minister Hosokawa warned the United States not to order sanctions against Japan. His aides asserted that Japan would retaliate with its own sanctions.
 Mr. Hosokawa said Japan would never drop its opposition to what he described as the Clinton Administration's call for "numerical targets" for increasing access in autos, insurance, medical equipment and telecommunications.
The Tuesday deadline on cellular telephones could give the Administration a convenient hook to hang a retaliation order. Some officials, however, said retaliation might have been ordered in this longstanding dispute even if Mr. Hosokawa and Mr. Clinton had reached an overall trade agreement last week.
In 1989, under pressure from Washington, Japan agreed to give Motorola Inc. roughly one-third to one-half of the cellular phone market in the Tokyo region. Motorola now complains that Japanese companies have worked behind the scenes to sabotage the accord and that as a result it has less than 4 percent of the market.
"That deadline certainly hits at an interesting time," a senior official said.
Administration officials said they felt caught between Congressional forces that want to hit Japan hard and fears of a trade war, especially since many officials feel sympathy for Mr. Hosokawa. Administration officials often say in private that they like the Prime Minister for his pledges to deregulate the Japanese economy.
 The Administration feels pressure from another source: its oratory on Japanese trade has been so strong that officials fear they will look weak if they do not respond firmly.
"On one hand, our response will be resolute, and on the other hand it will be quite prudent," one official said. "It has to be managed, quite measured, to help keep things in bounds."
The Administration's options include deploying its heavy trade artillery, namely a trade law known as Super 301. Under the law, the President can identify a country that systematically discriminates against American goods. That law requires the President to take action if that country does not remove trade barriers within a certain time.
Officials say one option is for the President to sign an executive order that re-establishes his power to use Super 301, without identifying Japan. But if the President wants to get tough quickly, he can single out Japan in that new executive order.
The advantage of the latter action, officials say, is that it would impose a deadline that would create immense pressure on Japan to make some concessions. The disadvantage is this strategy could lead to a cycle of retaliation.

HEADLINE: Public Advocate, Private Battle

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
On a recent morning in a midtown Manhattan hotel, Mark J. Green, New York City's new Public Advocate, stood before about 200 business and civic leaders and offered a treatise on turning some functions of city government over to private companies -- an issue that was a cornerstone of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign last year.
Indeed, in the six weeks since his inauguration, Mr. Green has seized the issue of reinventing government with a passion. He has prepared position papers, met with a national expert on the topic, and traveled to Washington to share his ideas with Vice President Al Gore. 
 Mr. Green, a 48-year-old disciple of the consumer advocate Ralph Nader, said that embracing the issue was only natural, and that he had long been a champion of making government leaner and more efficient. But others suggest that it is one of many ways Mr. Green has chosen to make a mark in the city's second-highest post, a job that is ill-defined and widely perceived as just short of ceremonial.
 
'The Bureaucracy Beat'
 During the long campaign last year for the position once known as City Council President, Mr. Green promised to be "a quality-of-life cop patrolling the bureaucracy beat," to bring government closer to the people. Now he is grappling with how to make good on that pledge. In many ways it has not been easy.
For decades, the position came with a full vote on the powerful Board of Estimate, assuring the holder influence in important city matters. But after the board was abolished five years ago and the City Council was enlarged and given more power, many officials, including former Mayor David N. Dinkins, advocated abolishing the position.
Instead, the job was watered down, and now its only major duties are presiding over the City Council and serving as the city's ombudsman. While the former City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, commanded a staff of 65, Mr. Green can employ just 45 workers. The office's annual budget under Mr. Stein was $3.7 million, while Mr. Green's is $2.7 million.
Even the setting has changed. Instead of using the complex of offices in the east wing of City Hall, where Mr. Stein and his predecessors worked in close proximity to the Mayor and City Council, Mr. Green and his staff occupy a set of somewhat dingy rooms on the 13th floor of the Municipal Building, across the street.
But a larger problem for Mr. Green is making the powers within government -- and the public -- take his position more seriously. Mr. Stein, who was often accused of spending much of his last years in office preparing to run against Mr. Dinkins, was hounded by the perception that every report he released, and every investigation of a municipal operation he conducted, was motivated by politics. Moreover, under its new name, the job and its functions are not well understood by many New Yorkers, opinion polls have found.
 
Green's Ambitions
 Mr. Green, who is often mentioned as a potential mayoral candidate for 1997, is clearly struggling to be recognized for his work in his current job, rather than as a potential candidate for higher office. "No one, not my wife, staff, politician, or anyone, has ever heard me seriously discuss aspiring to run for mayor," he said.
"I have worked to counter this," he added. "It disadvantaged, if not disabled, predecessors of mine."
In an effort to give a nebulous post some muscle, he has chosen to focus on some contentious issues, most notably overhauling government. In his first two weeks on the job, Mr. Green issued a report on the economics of garbage collection, and suggested that the Sanitation Department compete with private companies, a move he said could save $250 million. He also created a 14-member commission to study 10 topics and agencies, from civil service and procurement to providing information on city government to citizens electronically.
Staff members say that in trying to identify himself with privatization, Mr. Green, a Democrat, has embarked on a strategy to give his position weight while not appearing to be the Mayor's No. 1 critic -- as was often the case with Mr. Stein.
"We've always gotten along well," he said of Mr. Giuliani, a Republican. "But the charter intended natural institutional checks and balances, and it's the Mayor's government that I'm supposed to be a watchdog of. But I'm trying to be a watchdog, not a scolder of the Mayor."
 
More Than Spending Cuts
 Mr. Green has also suggested that cutting government spending alone will not stimulate the city's government, and has recommended improving job-training efforts, lowering some taxes, developing industrial parks and reforming development-incentive programs.
To spread his message, he has met with business groups and traveled frequently throughout the city, speaking to everyone from the New York Leadership Conference and small-business organizations to churches in Harlem.
Under the City Charter, the Public Advocate -- like the City Council President before -- presides over Council meetings, although few of Mr. Green's predecessors did so. Mr. Green, by contrast, has presided over all the Council meetings since his inauguration. He plans to introduce a number of bills, and indeed has already introduced a bill seeking to establish competition in the city's waste-hauling industry.
"I count Council members as the public who can inform me and help me do my job well," he said. "Few if any people know a Council area better than the Council member elected there."
Mr. Green, who served as Consumer Affairs Commissioner under Mr. Dinkins, spent most of his career in consumer advocacy and as an author of books on government and policy. Apart from two unsuccessful attempts at elective office -- for the House of Representatives and the Senate -- he has not spent much time immersed in local-government issues. That leads to the question: is this former congressional hopeful satisfied with the limited duties of his current post?
Some officials within city government and Mr. Green's own staff members maintain that his ambitions for the office are far higher than those of most of his predecessors. "He is bursting with a million things he wants to do to make government more effective," said a staff member, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "But I think he is frustrated because there are some severe limits on staff, on money and on the attention he craves."
 
Criticism of Giuliani
 Mr. Green has so far been selective in his criticism of Mr. Giuliani. He disagreed with the Mayor on abolishing the Consumer Affairs Department and on weakening the city's program to encourage city contracts with businesses owned by women and members of minority groups. On the other hand, he agreed with several of Mr. Giuliani's budget-reduction proposals.
Many in city government say it is too soon to tell how effective Mr. Green will be. "The fact that he hasn't fired off a cannon every week means he is serious about fighting the perception that he views this job only as a stepping stone," said John D. Sabini, a City Councilman from Queens. "Everyone acknowledges that he's a serious student of the process and that there are a wide range of things he can do. But his approach to the job is still a work in progress."
No matter how many studies he undertakes or reports he produces, converting his ideas into policy will be difficult.
"How do I implement anything?" Mr. Green asked. "Through the power of persuasion. The strength of my office is that it's exhortatory. The weakness of my office is that it's exhortatory. You mobilize public and political support around a good idea. And hope you can have some impact."

HEADLINE: Special Elections Will Fill Nine Seats in the State Legislature

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Nine empty spots in the state Legislature -- seven seats in the Assembly and two in the Senate -- will be filled in special elections on Tuesday.
The elections will not change the balance of party power in the Democratic-led Assembly or the Republican-led Senate. 
 But they could have a marginal effect on the drive in the Legislature to override Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's annual veto of death penalty legislation. The Senate could pick up two more supporters of the death penalty, which would provide the 41-vote minimum for overriding a veto in that house.
But an override must pass both houses, and the Assembly will remain several votes shy of the 100 votes needed for an override no matter who is elected on Tuesday.
Here is a rundown of the races:
In the 21st Senate District in Brooklyn, Carl Kruger, 44, a Democrat and former Assembly aide, is running against Irwin Plascoff, who works at an industrial metal company, on the Republican and Conservative tickets.
The seat, in an overwhelmingly Democratic district, was vacated in October by Donald M. Halperin, who is now the state Division of Housing and Urban Renewal commissioner.
In the Senate race to succeed Anthony M. Masiello, who took office last month as the Mayor of Buffalo, Anthony R. Nanula, a real-estate developer and Democrat, is running against Dianna D. Henderson, a social worker and a Republican. The 57th Senate District is almost 70 percent Democrat, and about one-third of its residents are black.
Ms. Henderson, 37, until recently a teacher and counselor at the Clarkson Center for Human Services, is black. Mr. Nanula, 28, the son of the co-founder of the Tops supermarket chain, is white. Both are candidates for public office for the first time.
In the Assembly races, Philip M. Boyle, a Republican lawyer and former Congressional aide, is running in the Republican-dominated Eighth Assembly District on Long Island against Randall Hinrichs, a Democrat on leave from his job as a prosecutor in the Suffolk County District Attorney's Office.
Mr. Boyle, 32, was once an aide to John C. Cochrane, who left the Assembly last year after being elected Suffolk County treasurer. Mr. Hinrichs, 37, has been involved in Democratic fund-raising.
Also on Long Island, Marc Herbst, a Republican with ties to the Assemblyman who vacated the seat in the 14th Assembly District, is challenging Kevin C. Gorman, a former banker.
 
Backing for Queens Seat
 Mr. Herbst, 30, is a deputy receiver of taxes in Oyster Bay. Mr. Gorman, 42, is the owner of Dackland Pub in Levittown. They are fighting for the seat vacated last year by Frederick E. Parola, a Republican elected as the Nassau County Comptroller.
Two powerful Democrats, Alan G. Hevesi and United States Representative Thomas J. Manton, are squabbling over who will fill the 28th Assembly seat left open in Queens after Mr. Hevesi left the legislature to become New York City Comptroller. Mr. Hevesi is supporting Melinda Katz, a young lawyer who worked on his campaign last year. She is running on the Liberal ticket in the solidly Democratic district.
But Mr. Manton is behind Michael Cohen, the local Democratic district leader. John F. Haggerty Jr., on leave as an aide to Assemblyman Clarence D. Rappleyea, the minority leader, is running on the Republican ticket.
In the 46th Assembly District in Brooklyn, Jules Polonetsky, 28, a Democrat and an aide to United States Representative Charles E. Schumer, is facing Michelle Heitzner on the Republican and Liberal tickets. The district, controlled by Democrats, was represented by Howard Lasher, now a City Councilman.
The South Bronx seat vacated by David Rosado, who was also elected to the City Council, is being sought by Carmen E. Arroyo, a local school board member long active in Democratic politics, and Juan Nunez, a Republican. Democrats outnumber Republicans in the district, the 74th, four to one. Also running is Agustin Alamo for the Conservative Party, Federico Perez on the Liberal and Popular tickets and Melvina R. Smith on the Renegade ticket.
In the Riverdale section of the Bronx, Jeffrey Dinowitz, a Democrat, is going against Mark Friedlander, a Liberal who is president of the city Tax Appeals Tribunal. The seat, the 81st Assembly District, was vacated by G. Oliver Koppell, now the state Attorney General.
Mr. Dinowitz, 39, is the local Democratic district leader and an administrative law judge for New York State. No Republicans entered the race. Herbert McCay is running on the Conservative ticket.
In the 129th Assembly District in Ontario, Yates and Livingston Counties, Craig J. Doran, a Republican lawyer, is running against William J. Eddinger Jr., a high school teacher and Democrat.

HEADLINE: Neediest Cases: When Layoffs Replace Dreams

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
John O. remembers the exact moment he and his wife, Monique, decided to move from London to the United States.
It was during a vacation in 1985, when they flew into Houston and rented a car to drive west to San Antonio through the rolling Texas hill country. 
 "We stopped on the roadside that morning for breakfast at a small place," he said in a quiet voice with a distinctively clipped accent. "And they served us -- oh, my -- a plate of very thinly sliced beef with a sauce on it that I cannot describe. It was simply incredible."
On returning to London, the couple sought out the delicacy, barbecued brisket, at Harrods department store, but were sorely disappointed. "We found some but it was much more expensive and certainly not as good," he said.
In 1987, after several more visits, the couple moved to the United States, settling in Manhattan. Mr. O. found a good job with a real-estate company and the couple rented a roomy $1,500-a-month studio apartment on West 52d Street.
Then their new life collapsed. The real-estate company declared bankruptcy; Mr. O. lost his job, and he and his wife had to move to a cheaper apartment in Astoria, Queens. He found another job as an export manager for a smaller company, but that company, too, went bankrupt in 1992. "It seemed like all of America was going out of business at that time," he said.
Throughout 1993, he bounced from one part-time job to another, trying to make enough to keep his apartment and also to pay the mounting medical bills for his wife, who was told that she had colon cancer shortly after the couple moved to New York.
For a time, he walked door to door selling clocks. He took another door-to-door job in the winter selling heating oil, but fell ill with pneumonia. His taxable income in 1993 was $1,710, according to statements from his employers. This year, he has not had a paycheck to speak of.
At his lowest point, in early January, thousands of dollars behind in rent, he turned to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, a beneficiary of the UJA-Federation of New York, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The fund, which is conducting its 82d annual appeal for donations, helps tens of thousands of New York's unfortunate -- the unemployed, the homeless, former addicts and children whose parents are suffering from AIDS.
Because The Times pays the campaign's overhead, every dollar goes to the charities to assist the poor. But the fund's ability to help is in danger, as contributions continue to lag. The appeal continues through Feb. 28, so there is still time to give.
As for Mr. O., who paused at the Jewish Board's offices the other day on his way to yet another job interview, he still holds out hope that America will become the place he dreamed of. "Everything so far, I must laugh off," he said, "or I would probably go crazy."

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Population Update

 BODY:
The population in New York City is holding steady while other northeastern cities, especially in New England and New Jersey, continue to shrink, according to new estimates by the Census Bureau that cover 1990 to 1992. The fixed boundaries of older northeastern cities and the lack of space for new housing inhibit their growthand prompt a population shift to the farther reaches of these metropolitan areas, census analysts say. While immigration has helped keep New York City's population relatively stable, the recession took its toll on cities like Hartford, Boston and Bridgeport. Suburban counties in the New York region continue to grow and the New York metropolitan area, by far the nation's largest, added about 120,000 people.

HEADLINE: A Demeaning Travel Ban to Cuba

 BODY:
It is hard to deny the value of a free trade in ideas and information across international frontiers. Yet for five years, successive Administrations have resisted lifting restrictions on travel by writers and artists during trade embargoes against countries like North Korea, Vietnam and Cuba.
Now the Clinton Administration appears to be playing the same game. It promised to review existing bans in order to fend off a liberalizing amendment put forward by Representative Howard Berman, a California Democrat who is chairman of the subcommittee on international operations. But after the review, Cuba was still excluded from any relaxation of travel bans. 
 This year both House and Senate have adopted amendments by Mr. Berman and Senator John Kerry urging the President not to restrict travel whose purpose is informational, educational, religious or humanitarian. Yet these exhortations may not be enough to overcome Cuban-American hard-liners, who lavish campaign contributions on key lawmakers and who oppose any relaxation on travel bans to Cuba.
Under existing embargo laws, Americans, with few exceptions, need prior official permission to travel to Cuba. The exceptions are U.S. officials, journalists, U.S. citizens with close relatives in Cuba, professional researchers and expenses-paid guests of the Castro regime.
Though Fidel Castro's near-bankrupt island has ceased to be a security threat, this demeaning cold war restriction persists. And Secretary of State Warren Christopher, in seeking to deflect any legislation, faces both ways simultaneously.
The Secretary has assured Mr. Berman that "dissemination of information and ideas is a significant element in the promotion of democracy" and a "central tenet of our foreign policy." But he nevertheless insists the Administration needs the authority to control information flow, lest it be used as a "pretext for evasion of the larger financial purposes of economic embargoes." It would be hard to improve on the elastic nullity of those phrases.
The other day, the Administration completed its review of travel bans and decided that some liberalization was in order -- but not for Cuba. This frustrated hopes for an executive order that would extend the list of those who need no advance permits for Cuba. Such an order would have left in place the ban on U.S. tourism, as mandated by Congress, but would have lowered the barrier to teachers, writers, artists, physicians, human rights advocates and church leaders.
The time seems overdue for this small step to freer travel. If the Clinton Administration cannot effect this modest change by executive order, then why not make the Berman amendment binding?

HEADLINE: Who Pays Physicians

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Fond Memory: The Family Doctor Is Rarely In" (The Week in Review, Feb. 6): I agree that doctors seem greedy and arrogant, and that they "don't care about people as much as they used to." 
 The primary difference between the turn-of-the-century physician in your photo and myself is that he was paid by his patients. Patients are resentful because they do not have adequate quality control. They cannot fire their physician and hire anyone else they please.
Almost all my fees come from employer-paid insurance companies or the Government. America can return to a respected but less greedy and arrogant physician once physicians are again paid directly by patients and patient-bought insurance.
This would take a simple act of Congress equalizing tax deductions on medical care. Patients pay for their own care with after-tax dollars, while employers deduct the benefit of medical care as a business expense. Physician and patient behavior would change with this change in tax law. And the medical-care percentage of the gross national product would drop.
 
BERT A. LOFTMAN, M.D.
Atlanta, Feb. 7, 1994

HEADLINE: Shock Therapy for the Pentagon

BYLINE: By Lawrence J. Korb; Lawrence J. Korb, a national security specialist, is a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Only shock therapy can change the mind set that developed in the Department of Defense during the cold war. Since the tearing down of the Berlin Wall in 1989, the Pentagon has experienced a great deal of attempted therapy and next to no shock.
When the Bush Administration was treating it benignly, one of the Pentagon's severest critics was Les Aspin, then chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. 
 He criticized the proposed downsizing of the Pentagon to adjust to the "new world order" as simply defense by subtraction, and a response to the Pentagon's organizational needs rather than to threats to U.S. interests. He suggested that a radical -- "bottom-up" -- review was needed if America was to get the peace dividend it earned from spending $7 trillion to outlast the Soviet empire.
Candidate Bill Clinton endorsed the Aspin approach and President-elect Clinton selected Mr. Aspin to be Secretary of Defense to revolutionize the Pentagon. After slightly more than a year of the Clinton Administration, it is clear that there will be little real change.
Mr. Aspin is gone, and Mr. Clinton, after offering the job to such traditionalists as Adm. Bobby Ray Inman and Senator Sam Nunn, said in his State of the Union Message, "We must not cut defense further."
True, Mr. Aspin and his deputy and successor, William Perry, did carry out the bottom-up review, but it was bottom-up in name only. It resulted in a barely changed military force and a budget about 85 percent of the average cold war level.
The Navy will maintain the 12 carrier battle groups that it "needed" during most of the cold war. The Air Force gave up some 200 tactical fighters but gained an equal number of strategic bombers for tactical use. And while the Army lost two active ground divisions, the Marines gained one and the Army National Guard and Army Reserve were maintained at cold war levels.
Relics of the cold war like the SSN-21 Seawolf submarine, Trident II missiles, F-22 fighter and Milstar communications system survived the review even though the Soviet threat that brought about their development has gone away.
Bill Clinton will spend more on defense than Richard Nixon did two decades ago ($260 billion as against $230 billion in inflation-adjusted dollars), and the United States will spend more for national security than the rest of the world combined. Moreover, two years from now the military budget will begin to increase again.
How did this happen? First, instead of reinventing the Pentagon, the Pentagon reinvented the threat and downplayed the contributions of our allies. The service chiefs convinced Mr. Aspin and Mr. Perry that the regional threats from countries like Iraq and North Korea (whose military spending is $20 billion a year between them) are almost equal to that posed by the Soviet Union, which spent about $300 billion a year before its collapse.
They ignored the potential military roles of European countries in another regional war -- say, a second Persian Gulf war -- and minimized the South Korean military's contribution to its country's defense.
Second, Mr. Aspin and Mr. Perry did not tackle the 1948 agreement among the Joint Chiefs of Staff that allows the four armed services to duplicate one another's efforts in many combat and support functions.
Third, the revamping of our strategic nuclear forces was postponed for a year.
The Pentagon budget could easily be reduced to $200 billion a year from its present $260 billion. A budget this size would still insure the pre-eminence of our armed forces and their ability to handle any military threats to our national security. It would provide for 15 ground divisions, 20 tactical air wings and 9 carrier battle groups backed by an arsenal of 1,000 strategic nuclear weapons.
Bill Clinton was elected as the candidate of change. He endlessly exhorts the nation not to fear change. Why can't he take his own advice?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Riders in the Storm;
Blasts of Winter Weather Drive Commuters to the Trains

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
In fair weather, mass transit officials plead and beg for riders; they advertise, they offer discount packages for sporting events, they even jot down license plate numbers of cars at highway toll plazas and write to the owners, offering them free weekly tickets.
But in the snow and ice, people flock to the trains. Sales of one-way tickets for peak-hour trains were up 11.5 percent on Metro-North and 8 percent on the Long Island Rail Road in January of this year compared with January 1993. Ridership was up on New Jersey Transit and on Amtrak, too, officials there report, although neither one has January figures yet. The Transit Authority said it would not know for a few weeks whether token sales for city subways were up in January. 
 "The weather was a sales promotion," said Daniel M. Brucker, a spokesman for Metro-North. "But instead of being handled by our marketing department, it's handled by God, which is good, too."
Just how many foul-weather friends the railroads made last month is impossible to determine because it is not clear how many individuals bought one-way tickets, which serve to represent trips made by people who would not ordinarily take the train. Presumably most of those travelers bought at least two, and some may have bought far more. Sales figures indicate that Metro-North sold 82,000 extra tickets last month, showing an increase not only in one-way tickets but also in ten-trip tickets, which sell at a discount, too. The L.I.R.R. sold an extra 33,000 one-way tickets, while its sales of 10-trip tickets were flat.
If the L.I.R.R. made converts in January, it may have lost some of them last Friday, when snowdrifts covered the electrified third rail and shut down most of the railroad's operations.
But Susan McGowan, a spokeswoman, sought to minimize the impact of Friday's problems. "For the most part we're willing to stand on our record," she said. "We got through 11 storms. This was the 12th."
 
To Bus or Not to Bus
 The Port Authority, which operates the bus terminal in Manhattan, and bus operators said they did not yet have ridership figures for January. Bad weather induces some people to ride the bus, but other bus riders stay away because buses travel the same snowy highways as cars, and because they do not like waiting for the bus on snowy roadsides.
But the Port Authority said the number of cars and trucks crossing the Hudson and the Staten Island bridges was down 13.6 percent in January from the same month last year, falling to 7.5 million vehicles from 8.6 million.
National Weather Service records show that Central Park had precipitation on 15 days in January, and most days it was snow. The 5.59 inches of moisture last month created 19 inches of snow, which is about two-thirds of what falls in an entire winter in an average year. (The total for the winter, as of yesterday, was 41.3 inches.)
At Metro-North, which serves customers in Connecticut as well as New York, Daniel M. Brucker, a spokesman, said: "We made a million dollars more than usual in January. Of course, we probably spent a million in overtime."
But the importance of increased ridership, he said, is in getting new people on the trains. "This means more to us than helping people out in the snowstorm," he said. "We actually count every one of them as potential long-term customers."
Metro-North and the L.I.R.R., both divisions of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, have joint radio, television and print advertising campaigns. Both intermittently advertise package deals on train tickets and admission to shows at Radio City Music Hall, exhibitions at the Javits Convention Center and similar events.
Last year the L.I.R.R. used records from the Department of Motor Vehicles to trace the ownership of cars coming across toll approaches to the East River and mailed out offers of free tickets. The railroad gave away 1,700 weekly tickets, with an average value of about $44, a promotion that cost $75,000, not counting administration costs.
The January weather appears to have exposed several times as many riders to the system for a marketing cost of zero. (The number could be around 15,000, supposing that each rider bought two one-way tickets.)
Last month the L.I.R.R. announced it had hired a marketing specialist and assigned five managers to work with her in drumming up new business, especially among commuters to New York City, people traveling from one destination on Long Island to another, reverse commuters traveling from city homes to suburban jobs and leisure travelers.
Both the L.I.R.R. and Metro-North report that ridership has been generally growing for the last six months, which is a reflection of economic activity rather than the weather. Metro-North, the only railroad that made detailed statistics available, recorded declines in travel in January in only one category: one-way tickets sold at a discount to elderly people and the handicapped.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Mass Transit: Avoiding the Snow" shows ticket revenue on the Metro-North Railroad Jan. 1992 and Jan. 1993. (Source: Metro-North Railraod)

HEADLINE: Woman Who Lost a Right-to-Die Case in Canada Commits Suicide

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Sue Rodriguez, who fought unsuccessfully all the way to the Supreme Court of Canada for the right of the terminally ill to end their own lives, died Saturday in what the police are calling a doctor-assisted suicide.
Assisted suicides are illegal in Canada, as they are in the United States. Mrs. Rodriguez's death at her home in Victoria, British Columbia, has revived the debate over whether such activity should be criminal in Canada. 
 Her lawyer, Chris Considine, released a statement from his client in which Mrs. Rodriguez again pleaded with the federal Government to legalize assisted suicides for people suffering painful terminal illnesses. "I hope that my efforts will not have been in vain," she said.
Mrs. Rodriguez, 43, was an employee in a real estate office in Victoria in 1991 when she learned that she had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, an incurable and fatal nerve condition that slowly shuts down the body's muscular functions.
She went to court in British Columbia and finally to the Supreme Court, arguing that the ban on assisted suicide denied her constititonal right to life, liberty and security of the person.
Her death came four and a half months after the Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 ruling, upheld lower court decisions that the criminal code sanctions did not abridge her rights. The majority said the state's interest in protecting life's sanctity took precedence over the right to a dignified death.
Television cameras, which followed Mrs. Rodriguez's court struggle while graphically showing her physical deterioration, made her into a national symbol for the cause of euthanasia.
The issue is not going away, said Marilynne Seguin, executive director of Dying With Dignity, a group lobbying for euthanasia for more than a decade. A Gallup poll last year placed the Canadian public's approval of assisted deaths at 77 percent.
The Federal Justice Minister, Allan Rock, said he favored a free vote in Parliament. Last year members voted overwhelmingly against a motion that would have required Parliament to consider euthanasia legislation, but Mrs. Rodriguez's high-profile struggle, and now her death, may have altered the political landscape.
Still, it is unlikely that Parliament will deal with the issue soon. Mr. Rock said the matter needed further study, and Solicitor General Herb Gray said economic issues were the Government's priority.
 
Parallels With United States
 The right-to-die movement here has parallels with the one in the United States, where Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who has helped 20 people commit suicide, is campaigning for a state constitutional amendment to legalize doctor-assisted suicide in Michigan. Washington and California rejected laws permitting assisted suicide in state referendums.
At the scene of Mrs. Rodriguez's apparent suicide was a member of Parliament, Svend Robinson, a New Democrat from Vancouver who, the police said, is under investigation, along with an unidentified doctor.
The Premier of British Columbia, Mike Harcourt, said Sunday that prosecutors would rely on new provincial euthanasia guidelines in deciding whether anyone should be charged.
According to the guidelines, it is illegal "to advise, encourage or assist another person to perform an act that intentionally brings about his or her death." But the guidelines also give authorities discretion over the laying of charges in individual cases.
Mr. Robinson told a news conference on Monday that he had held Mrs. Rodriguez in his arms on Saturday and "she peacefully lapsed into unconsciousness and stopped breathing approximately two hours later." He said she had died "with incredible courage and dignity." He declined to identify the doctor and did not go into detail on the procedure used to bring about her death. He did say he had no reason to believe he had committed any crime.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

International
The Clinton Administration has decided to initiate sanctions against Japan for failing to live up to a 1989 agreement to allow Motorola to enter the lucrative Tokyo cellular phone market. The Administration, which did not rule out the possibility of a trade war with Japan, will reportedly announce the steps today. [Page A1.] Motorola has long favored sanctions. [D7.] 
 Huge trade gaps with Japan are not popular with Americans. But few economists say the chronic trade imbalance is much of a problem. Nor do economists believe that trade policy can ever balance the account. Peter Passell: Economic Watch. [A1.]

Companies
Viacom won the bidding war for Paramount Communications, executives close to the negotiations said. They said Viacom received more than the majority of Paramount shares needed. [A1.]
Ford Motor's plan to acquire control of Hertz by buying back a stake from a German bank will be investigated by the European Union's executive commission. [D3.]
Federal regulators asked a bank on a Blackfoot Indian reservation to delay plans to offer a certificate of deposit that qualifies, the bank says, for the tax advantages of an annuity. [D3.]
Oracle plans to announce a software system for interactive television, which analysts say could challenge Microsoft. [D4.]
Aoki of Japan agreed to sell 70 Westin hotels for $708 million to a Mexican conglomerate. [D4.]
Chrysler recalled about 110,000 sedans to adjust electrical wires. The recall was the auto maker's fifth since December. [A16.]
Nike named a top marketing executive as president. [D4.]
 
Markets
The dollar plunged to a six-month low against the yen after trade tensions between Washington and Tokyo intensified. [D1.]
 Blue-chip stocks ended higher after stumbling on concerns over trade tensions between the United States and Japan. [D8.]
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell. [D16.]
Heating oil prices fell sharply as warmer weather spread from the East Coast to the Midwest. [D18.]
 
The Economy
Telephone companies are cutting jobs by the tens of thousands, and although the telecommunications industry is growing, many of those laid off will have trouble finding work. This seeming contradiction is a result of the industry's drive to cut costs and adopt automated network technology. [D1.]
Clinton Administration economists called for limited intervention in the economy in the annual Economic Report to Congress. The economists said the Government should spend money on research in manufacturing, fight monopolies and force companies to pay for pollution. [D1.]
California is set to begin spraying insecticide in a controversial effort to save the state's $18-billion-a-year agriculture industry from the Mediterranean fruit fly. [D1.]
Stockpiles of unsold goods showed no change in December and sales rose, suggesting that businesses were able to clear their shelves and warehouses of goods during the holidays. [D2.]
 A national survey of employers showed that their medical spending had slowed but was still rising much faster than the 3 percent general inflation rate. [D3.]
An H.M.O. trade group proposed uniform Federal standards for the operation and financing of health plans. [A17.]

Autos, a cyclical business, appear to be nearing a peak, based on past performances. But analysts say a recent wave of selling in auto stocks may have been premature. Market Place. [D8.]
 Basketball stars are the reigning champions in the competition for commercial endorsements. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Sharply Vs. the Yen

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Accelerating a descent that began about 10 days ago as trade tensions between the United States and Japan intensified, the dollar plunged yesterday to a six-month low against the Japanese yen.
The dollar's 4.7 percent decline against the yen in New York trading to 102.25, from 107.20 late Friday, was particularly steep. In the last 10 days, the dollar has fallen and the yen has risen by about 10 percent. 
 "That is a meteoric rise for a major currency," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International.
The rise in the yen is the currency market's response to a long-simmering bilateral dispute that may yet boil over into some sort of trade war. In addition, traders and investors are pushing the value of the dollar lower and the yen higher because Washington does not appear ready to step in to stem the dollar's fall. Yesterday, for example, there was no apparent intervention by the Federal Reserve to support the dollar.
Yesterday's New York close was the lowest the dollar has been against the yen since Aug. 18, when the dollar hit 101.65 yen. A day earlier, the dollar hit its record low against the yen, closing at 101.11.
 
 
Further Decline in Tokyo
 In Japanese trading today, the dollar fell a bit further from its New York close. In late trading in Tokyo, the dollar was quoted at 102.05 yen.
On Friday, President Clinton said that top-level trade talks with Japan had ended without agreement, setting the stage for possible American retaliation against Japan.
Yesterday, while initiating sanctions against Japan for failing to allow Motorola Inc. access to the Tokyo cellular phone market, the President refused to rule out a broader trade war. But he said he would take "some days" to ponder options he might take before imposing sanctions.
"The market is saying that since other devices for reducing Japan's trade surplus with the United States are not working, Washington is therefore in favor of a higher yen as a way of cutting that surplus, and will do nothing to stop it from appreciating," Mr. Hormats said.
A stronger yen and a weaker dollar could reduce Japan's trade surplus with the United States by making Japanese exports to the United States more expensive for Americans to buy. American officials have made clear that they are willing to resort to this blunt technique as a way to force Japan to consider opening its markets to more American products as an alternative way to cut the Japanese trade surplus.
In recent days, that perception has been reinforced by the lack of comments or actions by officials or monetary authorities in Washington or Tokyo that might brake the yen's rise.
Unless and until that happens, currency traders and analysts said yesterday, the market would continue to take the yen higher against the dollar.
"As long as the Clinton Administration leaves the perception in the market that it wants the dollar lower against the yen, it will go lower," Scott Pardee, chairman of Yamaichi International America Inc., said. "The moment they clear the air in a meaningful way, it will rise again to some more tradeable level."
A senior Treasury official said late yesterday that the Administration's exchange rate policy remains unchanged. "We do not believe in artificially manipulating exchange rates," the official said.
 
An Unclear Level
 At this juncture, it is unclear what that level might be.
About a year ago, C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, startled some when he suggested that the dollar needed to fall to 100 yen before meaningful improvement in America's $60 billion trade deficit would be seen.
But with Japan still mired in recession, Mr. Bergsten amended that view yesterday. "When I did the calculation it was based on the assumption that Japan would resume a 3 percent to 3.5 percent growth rate in the foreseeable future," he said.
Under current conditions, the dollar might have to fall to "90 to 95" yen, Mr. Bergsten said.
The dollar also fell against the German mark yesterday, finishing at 1.7240 marks in New York trading, down from 1.7535 on Friday.
Prices for gold, which is seen as a safe haven in times of economic turbulence, also jumped yesterday in reaction to the turmoil in currency markets. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery rose $3.90 to $385.60 an ounce. March silver gained 9.5 cents to $5.35 an ounce.
But Mr. Bergsten and others were quick to note that despite the decline against the world's strongest currencies, the dollar is far from weak. Economic recovery at home and continued recession or sluggish conditions in Europe and elsewhere in the industrialized world have been the leading forces behind the dollar's rise against other leading currencies.
As long as the yen continues to rise against the dollar, pressure from Japan's private sector on Tokyo to do something about the trade surplus will probably intensify. And that, the analysts said, is almost certainly what Washington wants.
"The high yen is a source of enormous pressure on Japanese industry, whose profits are already being squeezed by recession at home," Mr. Hormats said.
