HEADLINE: U.S. IS SUPPORTING NEW HAITIAN PLAN

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration expressed its support today for a new plan to end the crisis and military dictatorship in Haiti, but it criticized the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's exiled President, for not endorsing the plan.
Parliament members agreed on Friday in Washington to call on Father Aristide to name a new prime minister and form a broad-based Government that would pass legislation paving the way for restoring democracy and getting the military to step down. 
 Unable to hide the Administration's frustration with Father Aristide, a senior official faulted him today for refusing even to meet with the members of Parliament who drafted the plan.
It borrows many elements from an accord that Haiti's military and Father Aristide signed in July that called for restoring democracy in October. But when the deadline arrived, the military refused to cede power, leading to the resumption of a fuel and arms embargo on Haiti.
A senior Administration official said the new plan was important because the embargo alone would not force the military to relinquish power until the economy had totally crumbled.
"We feel if you only use sanctions, you destroy the country, and you don't build a lasting political solution," the official said.
Advisers to Father Aristide criticized the plan for not specifying when he would return to power and when the military would step down.
Michael Barnes, a former Maryland Congressman who is the Haitian leader's top American adviser, said the plan ignored the dangers a new government faced. "President Aristide would be reluctant to name a government under these circumstances because there is a good chance government officials would be killed, just as the Justice Minister was killed last year," he said.
Under the plan the new government would work with Parliament to pass a law that separated the military from the police and granted amnesty to those who carried out the 1991 coup that ousted President Aristide.
Then, the leader of the military, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, would be expected to retire, and Michel Francois, the police chief of Port-au-Prince and a coup leader, would be transferred to another position. Those moves would open the door to Father Aristide's return.
 
Why Aristide Is Balking
 Father Aristide's advisers said he was balking at the plan because he saw no reason why it would cause the military leaders to step down.
But Administration officials said right-wing members of Parliament who helped draft the plan indicated they were confident that the embargo was biting so hard that the military would be ready to step down if the plan was carried out.
Some officials involved in the Haiti talks speculated that Father Aristide feared that any new government would be more conservative than he is and might shunt him aside.
Two of the Haitian Parliament members who were instrumental in drafting the plan are considered possible candidates for prime minister. One is Victor Benoit, President Aristide's Education Minister and head of the left-of-center Konakom party. The other is Julio Larosiliere, a conservative Senator with close ties to the business sector.
In interviews today, several of Father Aristide's advisers faulted the Clinton Administration for not moving faster to urge the United Nations to tighten the trade embargo. "That is precisely the wrong message to send to the thugs who continue to kill people every day in Haiti," Mr. Barnes said.
American officials said the United States, France, Canada and Venezuela had agreed on the text of a resolution that would make the embargo mandatory around the world and essentially ban all but food and medicine from entering Haiti.

HEADLINE: Leader of House Arms Panel to Visit North Korea

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
As a deadline in the Administration's standoff with North Korea looms, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee is to travel there this week on a secretly arranged trip at the invitation of the Government of Kim Il Sung.
In a brief telephone conversation today, the chairman, Representative Ronald V. Dellums, declined to comment on the trip. But Administration officials said Mr. Dellums hoped to help defuse the dispute over North Korea's nuclear weapon programs. 
 Mr. Dellums sought and received White House approval for the visit, which comes just before the International Atomic Energy Agency's board of governors meets in Vienna on Feb. 21. Unless North Korea allows a thorough inspection of its nuclear sites by then, the agency is expected to refer the issue to the United Nations Security Council for the imposition of sanctions.
It was unclear if Mr. Dellums, a liberal California Democrat who assumed control of the committee from Les Aspin last year, would carry a written message from President Clinton to Kim Il Sung. But the 12-term lawmaker received an extensive briefing from an array of Government experts on North Korea last Saturday.
"Dellums is not an emissary from the Administration, but he obviously knows our views," a senior Administration official said.
Mr. Dellums becomes the latest of a short list of American lawmakers who have visited North Korea.
Stephen J. Solarz, a former New York Congressman who headed the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia and Pacific affairs, visited in 1980 and 1991 to discuss reducing tensions on the Korean peninsula and urge North Korean compliance with nuclear treaties.
Senator Robert C. Smith, Republican of New Hampshire, visited North Korea in 1991 and 1992 to discuss an accounting of Americans still listed as missing from the Korean War.
Representative Gary Ackerman, a New York Democrat who succeeded Mr. Solarz as head of the House Foreign Affairs panel, visited last October, the last American lawmaker to do so.
Mr. Dellums received his invitation from Pyongyang in late December or early January, and told Administration officials he would like to accept it during the Congressional recess this week, said one senior Administration official.
But Mr. Dellums told White House officials that he would only go if they had no objections, and that his visit remained unpublicized. "He didn't want to be a cowboy on this," a Defense Department official said.
No Government agency objected and the Administration quietly arranged the briefing with diplomatic, military and intelligence experts. Only a small number of Administration and Congressional officials were told of Mr. Dellums's plan, these officials said today.
North Korea's invitation to Mr. Dellums is intriguing. While well versed on an array of national security issues from his long tenure on the Armed Services Committee, Mr. Dellums has said very little publicly on the Korean nuclear dispute in the past year.
Indeed, Mr. Dellums has kept a relatively low-profile in his first year as committee chairman, focusing on running the panel and working with his Senate counterparts to produce a military budget. Aides say that Mr. Dellums intends to stake out more public positions on foreign affairs and the Administration's long-range war-fighting strategy and budget that Mr. Aspin unveiled last year.
"Peace is my passion," is one of Mr. Dellums's favorite adages, and some Administration officials said today that North Korea may consider Mr. Dellums more receptive or understanding of its nuclear position than the Administration.
An Administration official said Mr. Dellums plans to leave as early as Tuesday, fly commercially to Seoul and travel by land to the demilitarized zone between the North and South.
In Pyongyang, Mr. Dellums is expected to meet with the North Korean leader and his top advisers. A Foreign Service officer familiar with North Korea is expected to accompany Mr. Dellums, who will return to Washington this weekend or early next week.

HEADLINE: Housing Chief Wields A Wrecking-Ball Plan

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Vincent Lane is the chairman of the Chicago Housing Authority, a post that is a lot like being the engineer of a train wreck. Every time he turns around something is going wrong, someone is angry with him, another car is flying off the track.
But after nearly six years as chairman, Mr. Lane has become one of the brightest stars in the nation's galaxy of public housing officials. He is a pragmatist, a businessman, a black role model, a registered Democrat with the soul of a Republican, a man who says he is willing to try almost anything to turn his dreary and dangerous patch of urban America into a safe and shining home where the poor can rear their children instead of burying them. 
 As he sees it, he is locked in a battle between peril and promise, and peril has a 30-year head start. The outcome could shape the future of public housing across the nation, and that worries his critics, who believe that his vision of progress disguises a prospect of more hardship and displacement for the poor.
 
Goal Is to Shrink
 Mr. Lane, 51, says he believes he can save public housing by shrinking it -- both the bureaucracy and the buildings -- beginning with the authority's vertical slums at the Cabrini Green development on the near North Side.
Backed by the local, state and Federal governments, he plans to demolish three buildings at Cabrini and maybe two other tattered projects closest to expanding neighborhoods of wealth. The plan calls for the cleared land to be leased by private developers to build groups of low-rise buildings whose residents would be 75 percent middle class and 25 percent poor. Cabrini's remaining buildings would be renovated and integrated with working-class families. So far, $50 million in Federal money has been set aside for the project, which is expected to cost $350 million in government and private money.
Since not all of Cabrini's 7,000 tenants could be accommodated, some would be moved elsewhere in the city and the suburbs. No one, Mr. Lane stressed, would leave until replacement housing was built or purchased.
At least that is the plan. Community advocates, tenants and others are more cynical.
"Obviously, the ultimate goal is to depopulate the area of African-American people and repopulate it with middle-class whites," said Robert Starks, associate professor of political science and inner-city studies at Northeastern Illinois University. "It's basically a land grab issue."
But Douglas S. Massey, a professor of sociology at the University of Chicago and a co-author of "American Apartheid" (Harvard University Press, 1993), said: "I think it's good for everybody. It should be a model for the elimination of this subsidized ghetto that has been frozen in concrete for 30 years. The conditions in these high-rise projects are ghastly."
 
Trouble Delivering Basics
 Developers have long lusted after the land, especially the 70 acres that is Cabrini Green, perhaps the country's most infamous housing project but not even Chicago's most troubled. It receives so much attention because it is just a few blocks from the glitter of the Magnificent Mile shopping district.
For Mr. Lane, the land is the only bargaining chip his poor tenants have.
"You can't rely on charity and altruism," he said. "They're here today and gone tomorrow. But self-interest is here forever. It will make people do a lot of things."
Whatever the future holds for Chicago public housing, first Mr. Lane and his 150,000 mostly black and desperately poor tenants will have to survive the present.
With more trouble than money, Mr. Lane says, his agency cannot always deliver the basics. The city has sued Mr. Lane's agency five times this wicked winter for not providing adequate heat to some project buildings.
The American Civil Liberties Union has also sued Mr. Lane, essentially saying he used the Constitution as a floor mat in the name of order when he sent in the police without warrants to search hundreds of apartments for weapons.
He has been called Uncle Tom and worse. But many of his colleagues call him a role model. Robert L. Armstrong, president of the National Association of Housing Redevelopment Officials, which represents 3,300 housing authorities, said Mr. Lane had brought fresh ideas to public housing.
"I believe," Mr. Armstrong said, "that he will have some long-term impact on the housing industry in general and in Chicago in particular. But the problems were so bad when he took it over that it will be quite some time before you see the real effect of what he's doing."
 
'This Is a Revolution'
 When he took the job in 1988, Mr. Lane inherited a haunted house of prejudice and failed policy.
Chicago's was perhaps one of the worst housing authorities in the country, he said, a sprawling system built largely in the 1950's and 60's to keep the poor tenants as far as possible from the centers of power and wealth yet close enough to find on Election Day -- an example of what Professor Massey calls American apartheid.
"The conditions I found were like third world," Mr. Lane said. "I'm trying to change the physical and spiritual environment of public housing forever. This is a revolution."
But even revolutionaries need a break.
Frank Sinatra was on the juke box late last month at Rico's, a trendy restaurant on the city's near West Side and an outpost for an expanding settlement of young professionals and powerful institutions hungry for land. It was the end of a long day for Mr. Lane, who sat sipping red wine and listening to "My Way," a metaphor for his life as chairman. Ten minutes earlier, he had been describing his vision of the future to 200 residents at the ABLA Homes, a public housing project, shrouded in snow and poverty, a few blocks away.
The meeting had gone well. No one had called Mr. Lane any names, even after telling the tenants that demolishing their apartments to make room for private development was their best shot at a "normal American life."
If they did not begin to plan and bargain now, he warned, market forces and land-hungry developers would surely roll over them, leaving them in the cold with nothing but bad memories.
The tenants, who already have plenty of bad memories, did not look happy about what they were hearing. The chairman had just used the dreaded D-word -- demolition -- but it could also stand for displacement and discrimination.
"Mr. Lane," a woman said, rising slowly to her feet, "we're all a little frightened."
He replied: "I know. But we can't keep patching these raggedy buildings together forever."
The next night, he made his case again at Henry Horner Homes, a weary project on the West Side.
He uses any edge he can get in his campaign. His race, he acknowledges, can be a shield and a sword. "The tenants would be ticked off if a white man said some of the things I say," Mr. Lane said with a sad laugh and another sip of wine. "Like when I say that sometimes we are our own worst enemies."
On the stump, "choice" and "privatization" are his mantra. Controversy is his fate. "I can't seem to let things settle down," he said.
Just this month he awarded a contract to a private security company owned by a senior member of the Nation of Islam to help protect, manage and heal one of the city's toughest housing projects, the Rockwell Gardens, on the West Side. The negotiations began long before the recent uproar over the anti-Semitic remarks made by a high-ranking Nation of Islam aide, Khalid Abdul Muhammad, who was dismissed this month by Louis Farrakhan, the group's leader. But Mr. Lane forged ahead.
"A lot of my friends are Jewish," he said. "But I know one thing: I was out at the Joliet Correctional Center and I saw Muslims working with the hard-core criminals and doing miracles. I want to see if they can do that for me at Rockwell. I'd rather deal with some people being offended by them being here than deal with these burials we have to deal with every other day."
Mr. Lane, who is divorced and has three grown children, was an infant when his family moved from Mississippi to Chicago, and he was reared on a block of working-class families right across the street from a housing development on the South Side. The housing project was as neat as the rest of the neighborhood.
So he can remember a time when public housing was not the prison of despair and decay it has become.
And it is that memory that keeps him getting back on the train.

HEADLINE: A Call for Economic Intervention by Government

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
President Clinton's economists want the Government to do more to tweak the economy, addressing areas like health care and technological research where they think the free market has failed.
They put forward their most comprehensive version of this view today, releasing their first annual Economic Report to Congress, a book-length document mandated by Congress since 1946. 
 While recent reports by Republican administrations have broadly criticized the Government, contending it played too great a role in the economy, today's document calls for a lower threshold for Government intervention. Instead of the typical Republican chapter bemoaning the price of Government regulation, the Democratic economists have a chapter entitled "Microeconomic initiatives to promote efficiency and productivity." They would have the Administration spend money on manufacturing research, to fight monopolies and to force companies to pay for their pollution.
"I think there is something different about the whole tone of this," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers and the report's main author. "There is a lot here implicitly about the role for the Government to do something that would be beneficial to the future performers of the economy, not harmful."
 
Republicans Disappointed
 Some Republicans say they are disappointed. "That was my special baby -- we had a special section on regulatory," said Murray L. Weidenbaum, who was President Reagan's first chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers and is now an economics professor at Washington University in St. Louis.
Republican versions of the annual report called for two tests to be met before governmental action could be justified: first, markets have failed to produce optimal results -- as, for example, when only sick people buy health insurance -- and second, Government action must be demonstrably better than private sector action.
Today's report tends to include the first test but says less about the second. The report is optimistic that intervention can work once market failures are identified.
For example, both last year's economic report, released a week before President George Bush left office, and this year's identify a problem in health care insurance: sick people tend to buy the most comprehensive health plans, while healthy people tend to buy more modest plans or forgo insurance. This problem of adverse selection means that comprehensive insurance may be difficult to obtain, because insurance companies are afraid it will be used heavily.
The last Bush Administration report called for modest steps to tackle this issue. The Clinton report is stronger in calling for Government intervention, saying: "By compelling all insurers to cover pre-existing conditions and by eliminating limitations on lifetime payments, the Government could reduce the adverse selection problem in private insurance markets and thereby improve how they function."
But this year's report, while different in many ways from the Republican versions, is also much more cautious than some liberal Democratic prescriptions for broader Government involvement in the economy. Republican critics contend that the Administration has already adopted these liberal solutions, saying the Administration's plans for extra research spending amount to an industrial policy. Even some officials, like Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary, have suggested this was the case.
This report studiously avoids any such stand. "I think industrial policy has a particular meaning, which I don't think is very characteristic of what we are doing," Ms. Tyson said.
 
Some Free Markets Cheered
 And there are many places where the report shows an enthusiasm for free markets that work well. For example, the report includes a scathing criticism of laws aimed at stopping dumping, a practice in which foreign companies sell goods here for less than they are sold at home or for less than they cost to produce. The antidumping laws allow American companies to seek steep tariffs on low-priced foreign goods that cause them financial injury.
"Both in the United States and elsewhere, antidumping laws go beyond preventing anticompetitive practices -- which should be their rationale -- and often have the effect of protecting domestic industries from foreign competition," the report says. "For example, a recent study found that, during the Reagan Administration, nontariff barriers including antidumping actions probably reduced U.S. manufactured imports by around a fifth -- largely by discouraging foreign producers from entering the U.S. market or by discouraging those that do export here from lowering their prices."
The early draft of the report had even stronger language, which was watered down after a strong interagency protest from the Office of the United States Trade Representative, a Federal official who requested anonymity said.
 
Kantor Defends Laws
 Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, has been a defender of these laws as a way to combat collusive foreign practices that are hard to address with American antitrust laws.
Ms. Tyson personally wrote much of the trade chapter, while her two colleagues on the council, Joseph E. Stiglitz and Alan S. Blinder, helped write other chapters.
One of the biggest internal debates each year concerns the color of the annual report's cover. The reason, said Michael Boskin, who ran the council for President Bush, is that the council's economists and secretaries, "get sweatshirts and T-shirts and coffee mugs, and they sort of like it to be a color that hasn't been around for a year or two." The staff members pay for these color-coordinated accessories themselves. This year's cover is a fashionable teal blue.

HEADLINE: Along Digital Path, Dead-End Jobs

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
When Richard Baldomar of Flatbush, Brooklyn, was laid off in July 1991 after 14 years offering help over the phone as an A.T.& T. customer service representative, he -- like many of his peers -- assumed his experience at one of the world's leading telecommunications companies would open a lot of doors.
To enhance his chances for work in the rapidly changing communications industry, Mr. Baldomar finished his bachelor's degree in media studies at St. Francis College in Brooklyn. But now, after several months seeking customer-service jobs from communications companies as diverse as Time Warner, MCI and Metromedia, and even branching into other fields by approaching Hertz, Chemical Bank and Wells Fargo, Mr. Baldomar has concluded that his $28,000-a-year A.T.& T. job may not be convertible currency.
 
85,100 Lost Jobs
 "It did help me with initial contacts and put me in the first level of applicants," said Mr. Baldomar, 54. "But after that, nothing." He is now studying video production at the New School for Social Research in Manhattan. 
 Mr. Baldomar's case is far from unique. In the last 16 months, the nation's telephone companies have announced plans to shed 85,100 jobs, and experts say that many of those laid off will have trouble finding work, even though the telecommunications industry is rapidly growing.
This seeming contradiction stems from the fact that the telephone industry, feeling competitive pressure from cable television companies and other new rivals, is cutting costs by shedding layers of management and continuing to adopt automated, computerized network technology.
That means fewer maintenance people and telephone operators and fewer middle managers to keep track of them. And as the nation's communications system heads toward a future in which television programs, phone calls and computer services all mingle as digital bits of data pulsing through a single pipeline into American households, the workers whose skills are specific to running a plain old phone network may have trouble hitching a ride on the vaunted "information superhighway."

 
 
Not Very Portable

 
 "The jobs are not nearly as transferable as they thought they would be," said Laura Unger, president of Local 1150 of the Communications Workers of America in Manhattan. The local chapter, which represents workers at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, had shrunk from 2,600 members to fewer than 1,000 in the last three years -- even before A.T.& T. announced Thursday that it would shed 15,000 additional jobs over the next two years. About a third of the new layoffs will come at or around the company's headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J.
Ms. Unger said that in past layoffs, clerical workers who earned about $25,000 a year and technicians who earned more than $40,000 were among those who had the most trouble finding jobs.
With all of the large phone companies announcing big job cuts in recent months, including A.T.& T.'s announcement last week, there are few cloistered workplaces left among the biggest companies in this once-stable industry. Since September, U S West said it would cut 9,000 positions, Pacific Telesis announced it would eliminate 10,000 jobs, GTE said it would cut 17,000 positions, and Nynex said it would shed 16,800 jobs in New York and New England.
Clerical, blue-collar and white-collar jobs are all being eliminated, creating markedly different challenges in finding work, even at lower pay. But all of the displaced workers share the dread that a telephone industry career may have prepared them for little else.
In particular, the thousands of managers whose positions are being eliminated from the phone companies will find stiff competition for jobs, whether inside or outside the telecommunications business. There are simply too many managers chasing too few jobs. A survey of 870 companies by the American Management Association last year found that for the first time the companies that cut jobs shed more salaried workers than hourly employees. Indeed, more than half of the cuts announced by A.T.& T. last week will be white-collar jobs.
And even as the telephone people swell the ranks of the job seekers, their situation may portend an uneasy employment future in other once-stable industries, where regulated monopolies may give way to competitive markets.
"You're going to see exactly the same situation in the electric power business," predicted Robert M. Tomasko, author of "Rethinking the Corporation" and a consultant with Arthur D. Little Inc. "You're seeing the beginnings of the consolidation of a lot more power companies." Mr. Tomasko also predicts a similar job shakeout in the health care industry.
Still, in many ways, the employees who are laid off from the largest phone companies have several advantages over workers dismissed from other industries. A.T.& T., for example, has an outplacement service that provides career counseling and training in interviewing skills and that prints professional-looking resumes at no cost to employees. A.T.& T. employees can also continue working at the company for many months, drawing down their severance pay while they look for jobs within the company or at other concerns.
"On paper, it looks very good," said Ms. Unger of the Communications Workers union.
 
 
New Opportunities
 Moreover, new opportunities for some types of work may open up. The largest phone companies are expected to invest as much as $50 billion in the next five years to build advanced networks that carry new voice and video services. Pacific Telesis in San Francisco, for example, has announced plans to spend $16 billion over seven years on a video network to serve many California markets.
Although the phone companies spend considerable sums each year to upgrade their equipment, laying the groundwork for the new technology will require them to spend more than they have historically. The Pacific Telesis plan, for example, calls for the company to spend $400 million a year over current levels.
Many analysts say the telephone job cuts were overdue, a delay made possible by the fact that the cash-rich phone companies were able to wait until they finally felt compelled to take action. The timing should mean, at the least, that many telephone workers will be hunting for work in an economy that is growing rather than shrinking or stagnant.
"If there is a time you've got to pick for losing a job, this is a good year," said Mr. Tomasko, the author and consultant.
 
 
MFS Is Hiring
 Many people who are losing their jobs at the established phone companies are looking for work at concerns like the MFS Communications Company, a telecommunications services company in Omaha. MFS provides local and long-distance phone service to corporate customers in competition with the traditional phone companies.
Some telephone people are indeed finding jobs as MFS expands. The company hired 500 people last year -- roughly 80 percent coming from the telephone industry -- and it expects to hire 500 to 1,000 people a year for the next three years. But James Q. Crowe, MFS's chairman, noted that despite the rapid growth of his company and other advanced technology start-ups, there would be a lag before enough jobs opened up to accommodate many of the displaced phone workers.
"Even if it doubles every 18 months, it will be some period of time before we will see large numbers of jobs created," he said.
And not all displaced phone workers are seen as equally valuable. Many telephone company workers seeking new work, for example, will be hamstrung by the cradle-to-grave mentality that long pervaded the phone industry. That culture is not nearly as ingrained as it was before the Bell System was broken up a decade ago, but it has not disappeared altogether. Some A.T.& T. clerical workers laid off in early rounds of job cuts, for example, have had trouble finding new work because they are skilled at using computer systems found only at A.T.& T.
"If they can't think outside of what they've been doing for all these years," said John J. Parkington, a consultant at the Wyatt Company in San Francisco, who has done consulting work for several telecommunications companies, "the transition to new employment will be very difficult."

HEADLINE: Clinton Faces Pressure to Remove Health Plan's Provision on Early Retirees

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
The sudden need to carve savings out of its health care plan is putting pressure on the Clinton Administration to drop or scale back its proposal that the Government assume companies' costs of health care coverage for early retirees.
Eliminating that provision could save more than half of the increase in the deficit that the Congressional Budget Office foresaw from President Clinton's plan. 
 The budget office analysis made public last week concluded that instead of reducing the deficit by $58 billion in five years, as the Administration predicted, the plan would increase the deficit by $134 billion over 10 years before it began saving the Government money.
That has prompted a search for economies both within the Administration and among its supporters on Capitol Hill. One of the biggest savings would be eliminating the coverage for early retirees already covered by their former employers. It was inserted into the plan in an effort to win the support of major companies, especially auto, steel and aircraft manufacturers with big health care liabilities for former workers aged 55 to 65. At 65, the workers become eligible for Medicare.
Many Administration supporters on Capitol Hill and elsewhere have contended that big manufacturers have been ungrateful and have not supported the plan as much as this boon to them would seem to demand. That impression was heightened this month as three major business groups -- the Business Roundtable, the National Association of Manufacturers and the United States Chamber of Commerce -- spurned the Clinton plan.
But most supporters are reluctant to call for dropping the retirees provision because those companies' unions also have a strong stake in that proposal, and the unions have been solidly behind Mr. Clinton.
A Congressional Budget Office official said in an interview last week that the retirees provision would save business $85 billion through the year 2004, and cost the Government the same amount. He declined to disclose year-by-year projections that could be compared with the Administration's estimate that the plan would cost $14.8 billion through the year 2000.
The budget office report itself said this provision would cost $15 billion a year in 2004. The costs of the program, which would begin in 1996, increase gradually. In the first three years, under the Clinton plan, employers would have to continue paying part of their contractual payments.
The savings are inviting. Such a loyal Clinton supporter as Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, said, "I think we ought to look at it."
Stronger comments came from two other leading Congressional figures on health care whom the Administration counts on having with it eventually, Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California.
Senator Chafee, who led the Senate Republican health care task force that produced a bill calling for universal coverage by requiring individuals, not employers, to buy coverage, said these cost estimates showed the provision was "even worse than I originally thought it was."
 
'Generous Beyond Belief'
 He said he had never seen why "some drill press operator in Providence, Rhode Island, who is working quite near the minimum wage should have to pay taxes to relieve General Motors of the obligation it freely entered into."
Mr. Stark, chairman of the House Ways and Means subcommittee on health, said the budget office's numbers showed that this provision was "generous beyond belief." Unlike Mr. Chafee, he did not call for killing the proposal outright, but said, "It is very unlikely that this provision, in its very generous form, will survive."
The health subcommittee may be the first to vote on any form of the Clinton bill. Mr. Stark said he might support a greatly reduced version of the subsidy to companies that are now obliged by contract to provide health insurance to early retirees.
At the White House, the spokeswoman for health care, Lorrie McHugh, defended the provision. She said workers who retire at 55 worry that they may not retain health insurance, even if their former employers now insure them. She called the provision "insurance against insurance company discrimination."
"There is no denying that this is a benefit for those corporations that have gone an extra mile in guaranteeing coverage for their employees," Ms. McHugh said. "But the real beneficiaries are those Americans who have worked hard all their lives and are now finding it difficult to obtain coverage that is affordable."
 
In Trouble From the Start
 But she argued that about 60 percent of the nine million early retirees were not insured by their former employers, and that it was important for the Government to assume coverage of people 55 and over who were not part of a working household. Under the Clinton plan, the Government would pay 80 percent of the insurance costs for those people. In working households, employers pay that 80 percent.
Insurance for early retirees has seemed to be in trouble from the start, even though Hillary Rodham Clinton, the Administration's chief health care advocate, had strongly defended it in hearings.
For example, Mrs. Clinton told Senator Chafee at the Finance Committee on Sept. 30 that the provision was important for two reasons. First, she said, many companies were abrogating or reducing their promised benefits to early retirees. Second, she said, "those companies that are continuing to provide retiree benefits are doing so at an extraordinary cost that we think should be more broadly shared by the general public."
Even so, Administration officials acknowledge that they will have to go along with some cost reductions in the program so that the Congressional Budget Office will consider it neutral or favorable in its impact on the deficit.
As Mr. Daschle told reporters on Tuesday, "It sure would be easy to trim the budget with that."

HEADLINE: California Loads Sprayers, Fearing Return of the Medfly

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CORONA, Calif., Feb. 14

 BODY:
At 9 P.M. Tuesday, a squadron of helicopters is to begin spraying the neighborhoods, parks, schools and farms of this Riverside County community 45 miles east of Los Angeles, with the insecticide malathion in a much-disputed effort to save California's $18 billion-a-year agriculture industry from the Mediterranean fruit fly.
If the spraying is successful -- preventing the insect's return in this area -- it will represent a small victory in the state's 20-year war to eradicate the Medfly, which lays eggs in fruit and vegetables, causing them to rot and become unfit for sale. 
 But state officials said that even if they never win the war, they must win this battle against the latest outbreak of the Medfly here in some of the state's richest farmland or risk a devastating quarantine of all California produce from states and nations that have not been infested.
Japan and other countries have threatened to impose an embargo if the state does not eliminate the pest, which has reappeared after a four-year absence.
The pestilence has been persistent and relatively long-term. Medflies have been caught in one of every three cities in Los Angeles County since 1975, and their range has extended from San Jose more than 400 miles south to Orange County and east to San Bernardino.
Environmentalists and local officials have tried to stop the spraying because of what they see as a potential health threat from the pesticide. William P. Workman, assistant city manager of Corona, said today that it had filed a petition with the California Supreme Court this morning seeking an immediate halt to the spraying.
Mr. Workman said California officials had not shown the city any documentation that the Japanese would impose a quarantine. "It's very frustrating to be at the end of this dog wagging a malathion tail," he said.
Carl DeWing, a spokesman for the California Department of Agriculture, said, "We are under pressure from our trading partners to stop the spread of the Medfly, and just like the earthquake, floods, and hurricanes, we are in a state of economic emergency to resolve this thing."
State officials and economists said that a quarantine on California fruit and vegetables would deliver a potentially lethal blow to the state's fragile economy, which has been depressed by big layoffs in the aerospace and weapons industries and a sharp decline in real estate prices, and hurt further by natural disasters including the recent Los Angeles earthquake.
Phillip Romero, chief economist for Gov. Pete Wilson of California, said that an embargo on the state's produce could potentially cost $6.2 billion a year in exports, $1.6 billion from foreign markets and the rest from other states.
At greatest risk is the $300 million a year that comes from exports to Japan. A senior official of the United States Department of Agriculture in Tokyo warned last month in a letter to the deputy administrator of the plant protection and quarantine division that the Japanese were "becoming very uncomfortable" over the discovery in December of a pregnant Medfly in Corona. As before, there have been sightings of other flies elsewhere in the state.
 
Differing Anxiety Levels
 The official, Ralph R. Iwamoto, director of the Tokyo office of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, expressed belief that the detection of a Medfly in a commercial production area would cause the Japanese "to change their quarantine regulations and put a ban on imports of Medfly host commodities from the whole state of California."
"This will trigger similar actions by other Asian countries at a great loss to the producers and exporters in California," Mr. Iwamoto said in the letter, which was provided to The New York Times by California agriculture officials.
The Japanese, he said, believed that "aerial spraying is imperative to stop the spread of Medfly and cause a turn of events to prevent the quarantine ban on California."
A lower-key response came today from a Japanese official in Los Angeles. Akihiko Nishiyama, an Agriculture Ministry representative at the Japanese Consulate there, said that while Japan was concerned about Medfly infestation in California, it would not, as a matter of policy, make any demands that a particular means of eradication be used.
Asked if his Government had threatened to embargo California fruit if the Medfly were not eradicated, Mr. Nishiyama replied, "As far as I know, Japan has not said such a threatening thing."
 
Connected Reprisals
 But Jerry Siebert, agricultural resource economist at the University of California at Berkeley, said today that "the Japanese play hardball when it comes to trade, and the Medfly provides them with a good reason to close down produce markets."
Referring to reports from Washington that the Clinton Administration had decided to authorize certain telecommunications sanctions against Japan, he added, "Given the current state of trade relations between the two countries, I believe the Japanese will jump at the chance to quarantine."
Mr. Romero, the economist in Governor Wilson's office, estimates that the loss of the Japanese market would cost the state 6,100 jobs and the loss of all foreign markets would eliminate 35,300 jobs. About half of those would be in agriculture and the other half in related fields.
"If California produce is not available, foreign buyers will find it somewhere else," Mr. Romero said, "and it could take years for us to regain lost markets if we are quarantined."
Among countries or territories that might follow Japan in quarantining California produce, according to growers in this area, are South Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Australia. China, which recently began importing apples from Washington, has already quarantined California produce because of the Medfly.
 
Plenty of Housing
 There are more than 200 agricultural products that can serve as host for the Medfly, including oranges, grapefruit, avocados, strawberries, peaches, plums, nectarines, table and wine grapes and dates.
In battling the fly, state and Federal agriculture agencies spent more than $200 million from 1975 through 1993, using a variety of methods from quarantines to releasing sterile fruit flies. The Federal and state governments have split the cost equally.
Aerial spraying of malathion has been successful in eradicating the Medfly in Florida, but spraying in California has proved far less effective. The fly continues to spread into orange and grapefruit groves in some of the region's richest farmland, like in Riverside County.
State officials and growers said they think main reason the Medfly continues to thrive in California is the arrival of infected fruit and vegetables, typically in travelers' luggage. Agriculture officials regularly confiscate fruit from passengers arriving at Los Angeles International Airport.
William K. Quarles, president of the California-Arizona Citrus League, said his group was pressing for stricter Federal regulations preventing people from bringing in fruit. "Certainly, no one wants to encourage the use of any of these pesticide materials," he said, "but somehow, some way, this fly must be eradicated."
 
All for One Fertile Fly?
 Opponents of aerial spraying here in Corona say that the discovery of one fly in December does not justify the spraying of 18 miles of city blocks. Although no long-term health studies have been conducted on malathion, residents are concerned about the long-term effects of the pesticide and have organized protests. The City Council has taken the state to court to block the aerial spraying.
The last aerial spraying of malathion in Southern California was done for 100 nights four years ago over 500 square miles of Los Angeles, Orange, and San Diego counties. Hundreds of people complained of respiratory problems and rashes, but the state said that tests conducted after spraying showed that malathion could not be blamed for most of the complaints.
State officials advise people with conditions like asthma or allergies to remain indoors during the spraying.

HEADLINE: Motorola, Long a Backer of Sanctions

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
It is not a surprise to see Motorola Inc. emerging as the first testing ground in the developing trade dispute between the United States and Japan. Motorola has long been a leading proponent in corporate America of the necessity of using sanctions to pry open Japanese markets and protect domestic ones from unfair import competition.
"We cannot allow our competition to have a sanctuary," Robert Galvin, then Motorola's chairman, said in a 1989 interview with Business Week that summed up more than a decade of battling in Tokyo and Washington to level the trade playing field. 
 Motorola, a microchip and telecommunications company based in Schaumberg, Ill., is the market leader in cellular telephones in the United States, and along with L. M. Ericsson of Sweden is also a leader in the European market.
In Japan the company's analog cellular service has picked up 49 percent of the Osaka region market. The fact that the same service has picked up just 10,000 subscribers in the far larger Tokyo-Nagoya corridor, compared with nearly one million for the Japanese systems market by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Japan's state-owned telecommunications company, and Nippon Ido Taushin, has been cited by Motorola as evidence that Japan is preventing free competition.
The dispute traces to the Japanese Government's decision to assign the license to develop Motorola's technology to Nippon Ido, which was already committed to using a Japanese system and has been slow to invest in the infrastructure necessary to make the Motorola technology appealing.
Motorola's most visible success in Japan has been in pagers, and it came after a long battle to win acceptance. After years of resistance from Nippon Telegraph, Motorola has become Nippon's biggest supplier of the devices. It has sold more than one million of them.
 
Tariff Protections Won
 Motorola's most significant assist from Washington in combating Japanese trade practices came in the early 1980's, when it convinced the Commerce Department that Japanese manufacturers were illegally dumping pagers and cellular telephones in the United States. It won tariff protections of up to 106 percent.
Although the Japansese cellular phone market is one of the most important foreign cellular markets, the revenues involved in this dispute are not enough to play a major factor in the investment outlook for the company, some analysts said. But James L. Barlage, who follows Motorola for Smith Barney Shearson, does fret that investors might irrationally sell Motorola stock if they begin to fear that it will be at the heart of a trade war.
Over all, however, Japan plays a significant role in the company's earnings, accounting for about $930 million of the $13.3 billion in revenues in 1992, the last year for which regional sales statistics are available.
More importantly, by committing itself to match or top Japanese manufacturing quality, Motorola emerged during the 1980's as one of the nation's most highly respected manufacturers and the first winner of the Federal Government's Malcolm Baldrige Quality Award.
Motorola's combative attitude is based on profound respect. Motorola executives repeatedly toured Japan in the 1980's seeking partners for various ventures and studying Japanese manufacturing techniques. Mr. Galvin developed friendships with several Japanese businessmen, most notably Akio Morita, the man who built Sony into a multinational electronics equipment powerhouse.
Motorola helped Japanese industry get back on its feet in the 1950's after World War II, responding to President Dwight D. Eisenhower's urgings that American companies buy more Japanese products. But the resurgent Japanese companies played a major role in driving Motorola out of the television business -- it sold its Quasar line to Matsushita -- and even the car radio business that had given the company its name and first major product during the 1930's. During the 1980's, the company decided to fight back rather than give in when the Japanese attacked.
Trade battles have not prevented Motorola from forming alliances with Japanese companies. It has a joint manufacturing operation with Toshiba Inc. that markets Motorola semiconductors in Japan and provides Motorola with memory chips and chip technology. That agreement helped lift Motorola's semiconductor sales in Japan from 1 percent of Motorola's chip business in 1975 to more than 11 percent in 1992, or $522 million, according to Dataquest Inc, a market research firm.

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Big Trade Deficit With Japan: Some Think It's No Problem

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
"America's trade deficit with Japan is not very popular with the American people or the American Government," President Clinton allowed at the news conference with Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan in which the two agreed to disagree over trade. "It's hard to explain it, year in year out, always getting bigger," he added.
Most economists would undoubtedly agree with Mr. Clinton that mega-deficits are not popular, nor easy to explain to the great majority of Americans who prefer their economics lessons in easy-to-swallow gel caps. But it is equally safe to say that few economists think the chronic trade deficit with Japan is a problem in itself worth much of a fuss -- or, for that matter, an economic problem at all.
 
 
Individual Complaints
 This does not necessarily mean that individual American exporters don't have a legitimate gripe with the Japanese: Motorola may encounter a lot of static when it tries to sell mobile phones in Tokyo, and Chrysler may hit a brick wall when the company tries to sign up dealers for its nifty little Neon runabout. But there is no reason to believe that free trade nirvana -- an entirely open world trading system -- would balance the Japanese-American account or even change it measurably. 
 "The Japanese may be giving American exporters a hard time, but the bilateral deficit is not evidence of it," said Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
By the same token, economists generally reject the idea that America's chronic trade deficit with the world (or Japan's chronic surplus) is linked to anyone's trade policy. "America runs a deficit because Americans spend more than they produce at home," said Gary Saxonhouse, a University of Michigan specialist in the Japanese economy. "We make up the difference in imports" -- or at least we do as long as foreigners are willing to finance the transactions.
The day may even come, Mr. Saxonhouse suggested, when America will regret demands that the Japanese spend more on themselves and lend less abroad to accommodate capital-scarce economies. "It would be better to build bridges in Tadjikistan that are badly needed than more back home in overbuilt Tohoku Province," he argued.
Start with the relatively easy part, the logic behind mainstream economists' near indifference to country-to-country deficits. "I have a chronic deficit with my barber, who doesn't buy a darned thing from me," said Mr. Solow, who still manages to get by selling his expertise to a university -- which sells him nothing in return. The economist is satisfied as long as he earns enough to pay his bills and save for a rainy day; to try to balance his accounts one by one with the butcher, baker and laptop computer maker would be nothing short of absurd.
Mr. Saxonhouse notes that Japan has virtually no energy or other natural resources of its own; much of its economy is devoted to manufacturing. Hence if, by accident or design, Japan were to buy exactly as much abroad as it sold each year, the island would almost certainly run surpluses with most countries (including America) that were not in the business of exporting oil.
Of course, Japan does not balance its trade with the rest of the world. It exports roughly a third more than it imports, making up the difference with loans to foreigners or direct foreign investment in factories, office buildings and the like. Wouldn't the trade surplus of Japan with America, along with its political problems, be smaller if Tokyo did what was necessary to pare its surplus with the world?
The answer is almost certainly yes. In 1989 and 1990, strong years for Japan's economy and weak ones for America's, the surplus of Japan with America fell roughly in proportion to the decline in its overall surplus.
That is why James Tobin, an economist at Yale University and another Nobel laureate in economics, argues that "the best thing Japan could do for us is to stimulate their economy," thereby sucking in more imports and giving Japan's traditionally export-minded manufacturers incentives to redirect their efforts toward the now-moribund home market.
 
A Diplomatic Deception
 This point has not been lost on the White House. Indeed, the sophisticated economists working for President Clinton quietly insist that they are engaged in a form of diplomatic sleight of hand, blustering about unfair Japanese trade practices so that Tokyo will be frightened into doing what many Japanese after all would want them to do anyway: spend more at home.
There's an immediate problem with this ostensible strategy, however: It has not worked. Japan's credit and monetary policy is already so loose that further loosening is apparently nearly pointless. What is more, the Ministry of Finance is deeply opposed to using deficit spending to increase domestic demand, and it has powerful political allies whose allegiances cut across the current reigning coalition and the out-of-office Liberal Democratic Party.
Thus when Prime Minister Hosokawa proposed a big three-year tax cut on the eve of his trip to Washington, he was forced to settle for a one-year reduction unlikely to bring Japan out of recession or bring down the trade deficit very much.
Badgering Tokyo to get its economy cooking may still work when the Japanese stop cheering Mr. Hosokawa for standing up to Uncle Sam and start remembering that fiscal stimulus is as much in Japan's interests as America's. But those who think that a reduction in America's deficit with Japan will make a significant difference in America's overall deficit with the world are probably mistaken, Mr. Tobin said.
 
Effect on U.S. Deficit Slight
 America's external deficit, remember, is the difference between what America produces and what it spends. Thus while a boom in Japanese demand may increase American exports, the change would be reflected in America's total deficit only if American output went up more than American domestic spending -- a possible but not especially likely occurrence.
There is another reason why keeping up the pressure on the Japanese to spend more like Americans could prove problematic, Mr. Solow said. It is one thing to encourage Japan to avoid recessions; it is quite another to accelerate the maturing economy's drift toward higher consumption and lower savings. For if Japan does not produce the flood of goods and good credit terms needed to finance the development of poor countries along with the renaissance of the former Soviet bloc, who will? Apparently not America, which itself has been feeding at Japan's credit trough.
In the final reckoning, Mr. Solow said, Japan's external deficit "is nobody else's business."
"All we can legitimately ask," he said, "is that they play fair on trade."
